<blockquote class="calibre_21" id="filepos31385" aid="7K4G1"><blockquote class="calibre8" aid="7K4G2"><blockquote class="calibre_22" aid="7K4G3"><span class="calibre1" aid="7K4G4"><span class="italic" aid="7K4G5"><span class="bold" aid="7K4G6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="7K4G7">Part One</span></span></span></span></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote class="calibre_23" aid="7K4G8"><blockquote class="calibre8" aid="7K4G9"><blockquote class="calibre_22" aid="7K4GA"><span class="calibre1" aid="7K4GB"><span class="bold" aid="7K4GC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="7K4GD">GAR OG NADRAK</span></span></span></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><br class="calibre3"/><p class="calibre_" aid="7K4GE"><img class="calibre_24" src="kindle:embed:0008?mime=image/jpeg"/>
</p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_8" aid="7K4GF"></div>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
  <link href="kindle:flow:0001?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
<link href="kindle:flow:0002?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
</head>
  <body class="calibre" aid="8IL20">
</body>
</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos31902" aid="8IL21"><span class="calibre5" aid="8IL22"><span class="italic" aid="8IL23"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL24">Chapter One</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="8IL25"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL26">There was, Garion decided, something definitely mournful about the sound of mule bells. The mule was not a particularly loveable animal to begin with, and there was a subtle difference to his gait that imparted a lugubrious note to a bell hung about his neck. The mules were the property of a Drasnian merchant named Mulger, a lanky, hard-eyed man in a green doublet, who – for a price – had allowed Garion, Silk, and Belgarath to accompany him on his trek into Gar og Nadrak. Mulger’s mules were laden with trade goods, and Mulger himself seemed to carry a burden of preconceptions and prejudices almost as heavy as a fully loaded mule pack. Silk and the worthy merchant had disliked each other at first sight, and Silk amused himself by baiting his countryman as they rode eastward across the rolling moors toward the jagged peaks that marked the boundary between Drasnia and the land of the Nadraks. Their discussions, hovering just on the verge of wrangling, grated on Garion’s nerves almost as much as the tiresome clanging of the bells on Mulger’s mules.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL27"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL28">Garion’s edginess at this particular time came from a very specific source. He was afraid. There was no point in trying to conceal that fact from himself. The cryptic words of the Mrin Codex had been explained to him in precise detail. He was riding toward a meeting that had been ordained since the beginning of time, and there was absolutely no way he could avoid it. The meeting was the end result of not one, but </span><span class="italic" aid="8IL29"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2A">two</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2B"> distinct Prophecies, and even if he could persuade one of them that there had been a mistake someplace, the other would drive him to the confrontation without mercy or the slightest consideration for his personal feelings.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL2C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2D">‘I think you’re missing the point, Ambar,’ Mulger was saying to Silk with that kind of acid precision some men use when talking to someone they truly despise. ‘My patriotism or lack of it has nothing to do with the matter. The well-being of Drasnia depends on trade, and if you people in the Foreign Service keep hiding your activities by posing as merchants, it won’t be long before an </span><span class="italic" aid="8IL2E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2F">honest</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2G"> Drasnian isn’t welcome anywhere.’ Mulger, with that instinct that seemed inborn in all Drasnians, had instantly recognized the fact that Silk was not what he pretended to be.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL2H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2I">‘Oh, come now, Mulger,’ Silk replied with an airy condescension, ‘don’t be so naïve. Every kingdom in the world conceals its intelligence activities in exactly the same way. The Tolnedrans do it; the Murgos do it; even the Thulls do it. What do you want me to do – walk around with a sign on my chest reading “spy”?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL2J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2K">‘Frankly, Ambar, I don’t care what you do,’ Mulger retorted, his lean face hardening. ‘All I can say is that I’m getting very tired of being watched everyplace I go, just because you people can’t be trusted.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL2L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2M">Silk shrugged with an impudent grin. ‘It’s the way the world is, Mulger. You might as well get used to it, because it’s not going to change.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL2N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2O">Mulger glared at the rat-faced little man helplessly, then turned abruptly and rode back to keep company with his mules.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL2P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2Q">‘Aren’t you pushing it a little?’ Belgarath suggested, lifting his head from the apparent doze in which he usually rode. ‘If you irritate him enough, he’ll denounce you to the border guards, and we’ll never get into Gar og Nadrak.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL2R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2S">‘Mulger’s not going to say a word, old friend,’ Silk assured him. ‘If he does, he’ll be held for investigation, too, and there’s not a merchant alive who doesn’t have a few things concealed in his packs that aren’t supposed to be there.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL2T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL2U">‘Why don’t you just leave him alone?’ Belgarath asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL2V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL30">‘It gives me something to do,’ Silk replied with a shrug. ‘Otherwise I’d have to look at the scenery, and eastern Drasnia bores me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL31"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL32">Belgarath grunted sourly, pulled his gray hood up over his head, and settled back into his nap.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL33"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL34">Garion returned to his melancholy thoughts. The gorse bushes which covered the rolling moors had a depressing gray-green color to them, and the North Caravan Route wound like a dusty white scar across them. The sky had been overcast for nearly two weeks, though there was no hint of moisture in the clouds. They plodded along through a dreary, shadowless world toward the stark mountains looming on the horizon ahead.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL35"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL36">It was the unfairness of it all that upset Garion the most. He had never asked for any of this. He did not </span><span class="italic" aid="8IL37"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL38">want</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL39"> to be a sorcerer. He did not </span><span class="italic" aid="8IL3A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3B">want</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3C"> to be the Rivan King. He was not even sure that he really </span><span class="italic" aid="8IL3D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3E">wanted</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3F"> to marry Princess Ce’Nedra – although he was of two minds about that. The little Imperial Princess could be – usually when she wanted something – absolutely adorable. Most of the time, however, she did not want anything, and her true nature emerged. If he had consciously sought any of this, he could have accepted the duty which lay on him with a certain amount of resignation. He had been given no choice in the matter, though, and he found himself wanting to demand of the uncaring sky, ‘Why me?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL3G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3H">He rode on beside his dozing grandfather with only the murmuring song of the Orb of Aldur for company, and even that was a source of irritation. The Orb, which stood on the pommel of the great sword strapped to his back, sang to him endlessly with a kind of silly enthusiasm. It might be all very well for the Orb to exult about the impending meeting with Torak, but it was Garion who was going to have to face the Dragon-God of Angarak, and it was Garion who was going to have to do all the bleeding. He felt that the unrelieved cheerfulness of the Orb was – all things considered – in very poor taste, to say the least.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL3I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3J">The border between Drasnia and Gar og Nadrak straddled the North Caravan Route in a narrow, rocky gap where two garrisons, one Drasnian and one Nadrak, faced each other across a simple gate that consisted of a single, horizontal pole. By itself, the pole was an insubstantial barrier. Symbolically, however, it was more intimidating than the gates of Vo Mimbre or Tol Honeth. On one side of the gate stood the West; on the other, the East. With a single step, one could move from one world into a totally different one, and Garion wished with all his being that he did not have to take that step.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL3K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3L">As Silk had predicted, Mulger said nothing about his suspicions to either the Drasnian pikemen or the leather-clad Nadrak soldiers at the border, and they passed without incident into the mountains of Gar og Nadrak. Once it passed the border, the caravan route climbed steeply up a narrow gorge beside a swiftly tumbling mountain stream. The rock walls of the gorge were sheer, black, and oppressive. The sky overhead narrowed to a dirty gray ribbon, and the clanging mule bells echoed back from the rocks to accompany the rush and pounding gurgle of the stream.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL3M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3N">Belgarath awoke and looked around, his eyes alert. He gave Silk a quick, sidelong glance that cautioned the little man to keep his mouth shut, then cleared his throat. ‘We want to thank you, worthy Mulger, and to wish you good luck in your dealings here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL3O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3P">Mulger looked at the old sorcerer sharply, his eyes questioning.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL3Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3R">‘We’ll be leaving you at the head of this gorge,’ Belgarath continued smoothly, his face bland. ‘Our business is off that way.’ He gestured rather vaguely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL3S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3T">Mulger grunted. ‘I don’t want to know anything about it,’ he declared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL3U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL3V">‘You don’t, really,’ Belgarath assured him. ‘And please don’t take Ambar’s remarks too seriously. He has a comic turn of mind and he says things he doesn’t always mean, because he enjoys irritating people. Once you get to know him, he’s not quite so bad.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL40"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL41">Mulger gave Silk a long, hard look and let it pass without comment. ‘Good luck in whatever it is you’re doing,’ he said grudgingly, forced to say it more out of courtesy than out of any genuine good feeling. ‘You and the young man weren’t bad traveling companions.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL42"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL43">‘We are in your debt, worthy Mulger,’ Silk added with mocking extravagance. ‘Your hospitality has been exquisite.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL44"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL45">Mulger looked directly at Silk again. ‘I don’t really like you, Ambar,’ he said bluntly. ‘Why don’t we just let it go at that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL46"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL47">‘I’m crushed,’ Silk grinned at him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL48"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL49">‘Let it lie,’ Belgarath growled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL4A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL4B">‘I made every effort to win him over,’ Silk protested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL4C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL4D">Belgarath turned his back on him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL4E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL4F">‘I really did.’ Silk appealed to Garion, his eyes brimming with mock sincerity.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL4G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL4H">‘I don’t believe you either,’ Garion told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL4I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL4J">Silk sighed. ‘Nobody understands me,’ he complained. Then he laughed and rode on up the forge, whistling happily to himself.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL4K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL4L">At the head of the gorge, they left Mulger and struck off to the left of the caravan route through a jumble of rock and stunted trees. At the crest of a stony ridge, they stopped to watch the slow progress of the mules until they were out of sight.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL4M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL4N">‘Where are we headed?’ Silk asked, squinting up at the clouds scudding past overhead. ‘I thought we were going to Yar Gurak.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL4O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL4P">‘We are,’ Belgarath replied, scratching at his beard, ‘but we’ll circle around and come at the town from the other side. Mulger’s opinions make traveling with him just a bit chancy. He might let something slip at the wrong time. Besides, Garion and I have something to take care of before we get there.’ The old man looked around. ‘Over there ought to do,’ he said, pointing at a shallow green dale, concealed on the far side of the ridge. He led them down into the dale and dismounted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL4Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL4R">Silk, leading their single packhorse, pulled up beside a small pool of spring water and tied the horses to a dead snag standing at its edge.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL4S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL4T">‘What is it that we have to do, Grandfather?’ Garion asked, sliding out of his saddle.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL4U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL4V">‘That sword of yours is a trifle obvious,’ the old man told him. ‘Unless we want to spend the whole trip answering questions, we’re going to have to do something about it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL50"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL51">‘Are you going to make it invisible?’ Silk asked hopefully.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL52"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL53">‘In a manner of speaking,’ Belgarath answered. ‘Open your mind to the Orb, Garion. Just let it talk to you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL54"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL55">Garion frowned. ‘I don’t understand.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL56"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL57">‘Just relax. The Orb will do the rest. It’s very excited about you, so don’t pay too much attention to it if it starts making suggestions. It has a severely limited understanding of the real world. Just relax and let your mind sort of drift. I’ve got to talk to it, and I can only do that through you. It won’t listen to anybody else.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL58"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL59">Garion leaned back against a tree; in a moment he found his mind filled with all manner of peculiar images. The world he perceived in that imagining was tinged over with a faint blue haze, and everything seemed angular, as if constructed out of the flat planes and sharp edges of a crystal. He caught a vivid picture of himself, flaming sword in hand, riding at great speed with whole hordes of faceless men fleeing out of his path. Belgarath’s voice sounded sharply in his mind then. ‘Stop that.’ The words, he realized, were not directed at him, but instead at the Orb itself. Then the old man’s voice dropped to a murmur, instructing, explaining something. The responses of that other, crystalline awareness seemed a trifle petulant; but eventually there seemed to be an agreement of some kind, and then Garion’s mind cleared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL5A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL5B">Belgarath was shaking his head with a rueful expression. ‘It’s almost like talking to a child sometimes,’ he said. ‘It has no conception of numbers, and it can’t even begin to comprehend the meaning of the word danger.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL5C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL5D">‘It’s still there,’ Silk noted, sounding a bit disappointed. ‘I can still see the sword.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL5E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL5F">‘That’s because you know it’s there,’ Belgarath told him. ‘Other people will overlook it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL5G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL5H">‘How can you overlook something that big?’ Silk objected.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL5I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL5J">‘It’s very complicated,’ Belgarath replied. ‘The Orb is simply going to encourage people not to see it – or the sword. If they look very closely, they might realize that Garion’s carrying </span><span class="italic" aid="8IL5K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL5L">something</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL5M"> on his back, but they won’t be curious enough about it to try to find out what it is. As a matter of fact, quite a few people won’t even notice Garion himself.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL5N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL5O">‘Are you trying to say that Garion’s invisible?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL5P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL5Q">‘No. He’s just sort of unremarkable for the time being. Let’s move on. Night comes on quickly up in these mountains.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL5R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL5S">Yar Gurak was perhaps the ugliest town Garion had ever seen. It was strung out on either side of a roiling yellow creek, and muddy, unpaved streets ran up the steep slopes of the cut the stream had gouged out of the hills. The sides of the cut beyond the town had been stripped of all vegetation. There were shafts running back into the hillsides, and great, rooted-out excavations. There were springs among the diggings, and they trickled muddy water down the slopes to pollute the creek. The town had a slapdash quality about it, and all the buildings seemed somewhat temporary. Construction was, for the most part, log and uncut rock, and several of the houses had been finished off with canvas.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL5T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL5U">The streets teemed with lanky, dark-faced Nadraks, many of whom were obviously drunk. A nasty brawl erupted out of a tavern door as they entered the town, and they were forced to stop while perhaps two dozen Nadraks rolled about in the mud, trying with a fair amount of success to incapacitate or even maim each other.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL5V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL60">The sun was going down as they found an inn at the end of a muddy street. It was a large, square building with the main floor constructed of stone, a second storey built of logs, and stables attached to the rear. They put up their horses, took a room for the night, and then entered the barnlike common room in search of supper. The benches in the common room were a bit unsteady, and the tabletops were grease-smeared and littered with crumbs and spilled food. Oil lamps hung smoking on chains, and the smell of cooking cabbage was overpowering. A fair number of merchants from various parts of the world sat at their evening meal in the room – wary-eyed men in tight little groups, with walls of suspicion drawn around them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL61"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL62">Belgarath, Silk, and Garion sat down at an unoccupied table and ate the stew brought to them in wooden bowls by a tipsy servingman in a greasy apron. When they had finished, Silk glanced at the open doorway leading into the noisy taproom and then looked inquiringly at Belgarath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL63"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL64">The old man shook his head. ‘Better not,’ he said. ‘Nadraks are a high-strung people, and relations with the West are a little tense just now. There’s no point in asking for trouble.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL65"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL66">Silk nodded his glum agreement and led the way up the stairs at the back of the inn to the room they had taken for the night. Garion held up their guttering candle and looked dubiously at the log-frame bunks standing against the walls of the room. The bunks had rope springs and mattresses stuffed with straw; they looked lumpy and not very clean. The noise from the taproom below was loud and raucous.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL67"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL68">‘I don’t think we’re going to get much sleep tonight,’ he observed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL69"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL6A">‘Mining towns aren’t like farm villages,’ Silk pointed out. ‘Farmers feel the need for decorum – even when they’re drunk. Miners tend on the whole to be somewhat rowdier.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL6B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL6C">Belgarath shrugged. ‘They’ll quiet down in a bit. Most of them will be unconscious long before midnight.’ He turned to Silk. ‘As soon as the shops open up in the morning, I want you to get us some different clothing – used, preferably. If we look like gold hunters, nobody’s going to pay very much attention to us. Get a pick handle and a couple of rock hammers. We’ll tie them to the outside of the pack on our spare horse for show.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL6D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL6E">‘I get the feeling you’ve done this before.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL6F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL6G">‘From time to time. It’s a useful disguise. Gold hunters are crazy to begin with, so people aren’t surprised if they show up in strange places.’ The old man laughed shortly. ‘I even found gold once – a vein as thick as your arm.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL6H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL6I">Silk’s face grew immediately intent. ‘Where?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL6J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL6K">Belgarath shrugged. ‘Off that way somewhere,’ he replied with a vague gesture. ‘I forget exactly.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL6L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL6M">‘Belgarath,’ Silk objected with a note of anguish in his voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL6N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL6O">‘Don’t get sidetracked,’ Belgarath told him. ‘Let’s get some sleep. I want to be out of here as early as possible tomorrow morning.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL6P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL6Q">The overcast which had lingered for weeks cleared off during the night; when Garion awoke, the new-risen sun streamed golden through the dirty window. Belgarath was seated at the rough table on the far side of the room, studying a parchment map, and Silk had already left.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL6R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL6S">‘I thought for a while that you were going to sleep past noon,’ the old man said as Garion sat up and stretched.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL6T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL6U">‘I had trouble getting to sleep last night,’ Garion replied. ‘It was a little noisy downstairs.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL6V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL70">‘Nadraks are like that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL71"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL72">A sudden thought occurred to Garion. ‘What do you think Aunt Pol is doing just now?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL73"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL74">‘Sleeping, probably.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL75"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL76">‘Not </span><span class="italic" aid="8IL77"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL78">this</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL79"> late.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL7A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL7B">‘It’s much earlier where she is.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL7C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL7D">‘I don’t follow that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL7E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL7F">‘Riva’s fifteen hundred leagues west of here,’ Belgarath explained. ‘The sun won’t get that far for several hours yet.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL7G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL7H">Garion blinked. ‘I hadn’t thought of that,’ he admitted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL7I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL7J">‘I didn’t think you had.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL7K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL7L">The door opened, and Silk came in, carrying several bundles and wearing an outraged expression. He threw his bundles down and stamped to the window, muttering curses under his breath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL7M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL7N">‘What’s got you so worked up?’ Belgarath asked mildly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL7O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL7P">‘Would you look at this?’ Silk waved a piece of parchment at the old man.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL7Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL7R">‘What’s the problem?’ Belgarath took the parchment and read it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL7S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL7T">‘That whole business was settled years ago,’ Silk declared in an irritated voice. ‘What are these things doing, still being circulated?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL7U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL7V">‘The description </span><span class="italic" aid="8IL80"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL81">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL82"> colorful,’ Belgarath noted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL83"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL84">‘Did you see that?’ Silk sounded mortally offended. He turned to Garion. ‘Do I look like a weasel to you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL85"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL86">‘—an ill-favored, weasel-faced man,’ Belgarath read, ‘shifty-eyed and with a long, pointed nose. A notorious cheat at dice.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL87"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL88">‘Do you </span><span class="italic" aid="8IL89"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8A">mind</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8B">?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL8C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8D">‘What’s this all about?’ Garion asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL8E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8F">‘I had a slight misunderstanding with the authorities some years ago,’ Silk explained deprecatingly. ‘Nothing all that serious, actually – but they’re </span><span class="italic" aid="8IL8G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8H">still</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8I"> circulating that thing.’ He gestured angrily at the parchment Belgarath was still reading with an amused expression. ‘They’ve even gone so far as to offer a </span><span class="italic" aid="8IL8J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8K">reward</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8L">.’ He considered for a moment. ‘I’ll have to admit that the sum is flattering, though,’ he added.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL8M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8N">‘Did you get the things I sent you after?’ Belgarath asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL8O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8P">‘Of course.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL8Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8R">‘Let’s change clothes, then, and leave before your unexpected celebrity attracts a crowd.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL8S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8T">The worn Nadrak clothing was made mostly of leather – snug black trousers, tight-fitting vests, and short-sleeved linen tunics.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL8U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL8V">‘I didn’t bother with the boots,’ Silk said. ‘Nadrak boots are pretty uncomfortable – probably since it hasn’t occurred to them yet that there’s a difference between the right foot and the left.’ He settled a pointed felt cap at a jaunty angle. ‘What do you think?’ he asked, striking a pose.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL90"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL91">‘Doesn’t look at all like a weasel, does he?’ Belgarath asked Garion.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL92"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL93">Silk gave him a disgusted look, but said nothing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL94"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL95">They went downstairs, led their horses out of the stables attached to the inn, and mounted. Silk’s expression remained sour as they rode out of Yar Gurak. When they reached the top of a hill to the north of town, he slid off his horse, picked up a rock, and threw it rather savagely at the buildings clustered below.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL96"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL97">‘Make you feel better?’ Belgarath asked curiously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="8IL98"><span class="calibre_1" aid="8IL99">Silk remounted with a disdainful sniff and led the way down the other side of the hill.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_9" aid="8IL9A"></div>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
  <link href="kindle:flow:0001?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
<link href="kindle:flow:0002?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
</head>
  <body class="calibre" aid="9H5K0">
</body>
</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos60187" aid="9H5K1"><span class="calibre5" aid="9H5K2"><span class="italic" aid="9H5K3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5K4">Chapter Two</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="9H5K5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5K6">They rode for the next few days through a wilderness of stone and stunted trees. The sun grew warmer each day, and the sky overhead was intensely blue as they pressed deeper and deeper into the snowcapped mountains. There were trails of sorts up here, winding, vagrant tracks meandering between the dazzling white peaks and across the high, pale green meadows where wildflowers nodded in the mountain breeze. The air was spiced with the resinous odor of evergreens, and now and then they saw deer grazing or stopping to watch them with large, startled eyes as they passed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5K7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5K8">Belgarath moved confidently in a generally eastward course and he appeared to be alert and watchful. There were no signs of the half-doze in which he customarily rode on more clearly defined roads, and he seemed somehow younger up here in the mountains.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5K9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5KA">They encountered other travelers – leather-clad Nadraks for the most part – although they did see a party of Drasnians laboring up a steep slope and, once, a long way off, what appeared to be a Tolnedran. Their exchanges with these others were brief and wary. The mountains of Gar og Nadrak were at best sketchily policed, and it was necessary for every man who entered them to provide for his own security.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5KB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5KC">The sole exception to this suspicious taciturnity was a garrulous old gold hunter mounted on a donkey, who appeared out of the blue-tinged shadows under the trees one morning. His tangled hair was white, and his clothing was mismatched, appearing to consist mostly of castoffs he had found beside this trail or that. His tanned, wrinkled face was weathered like a well-cured old hide, and his blue eyes twinkled merrily. He joined them without any greeting or hint of uncertainty as to his welcome and began talking immediately as if taking up a conversation again that had only recently been interrupted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5KD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5KE">There was a sort of comic turn to his voice and manner that Garion found immediately engaging.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5KF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5KG">‘Must be ten years or more since I’ve followed this path,’ he began, jouncing along on his donkey as he fell in beside Garion. ‘I don’t come down into this part of the mountains very much any more. The streambeds down here have all been worked over a hundred times at least. Which way are you bound?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5KH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5KI">‘I’m not really sure,’ Garion replied cautiously. ‘I’ve never been up here before, so I’m just following along.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5KJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5KK">‘You’d find better gravel if you struck out to the north,’ the man on the donkey advised, ‘up near Morindland. Of course, you’ve got to be careful up there, but, like they say, no risk, no profit.’ He squinted curiously at Garion. ‘You’re not a Nadrak, are you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5KL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5KM">‘Sendar,’ Garion responded shortly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5KN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5KO">‘Never been to Sendaria,’ the old gold hunter mused. ‘Never been anyplace really – except up here.’ He looked around at the white-topped peaks and deep green forests with a sort of abiding love. ‘Never really wanted to go anyplace else. I’ve picked these mountains over from end to end for seventy years now and never made much at it – except for the pleasure of being here. Found a river bar one time, though, that had so much red gold in it that it looked like it was bleeding. Winter caught me up there, and I almost froze to death trying to come out.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5KP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5KQ">‘Did you go back the next spring?’ Garion couldn’t help asking.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5KR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5KS">‘Meant to, but I did a lot of drinking that winter – I had gold enough. Anyway, the drink sort of addled my brains. When I set out the following year, I took along a few kegs for company. That’s always a mistake. The drink takes you harder when you get up into the mountains, and you don’t always pay attention to things the way you should.’ He leaned back in his donkey saddle, scratching reflectively at his stomach. ‘I went out onto the plains north of the mountains – up in Morindland. Seems that I thought at the time that the going might be easier out on flat ground. Well, to make it short, I ran across a band of Morindim and they took me prisoner. I’d been up to my ears in an ale keg for a day or so, and I was far gone when they took me. Lucky, I guess. Morindim are superstitious, and they thought I was possessed. That’s probably all that saved my life. They kept me for five or six years, trying to puzzle out the meaning behind my ravings – once I got sober and saw the situation, I took quite a bit of care to do a lot of raving. Eventually they got tired of it and weren’t so careful about watching me, so I escaped. By then I’d sort of forgotten exactly where that river was. I look for it now and then when I’m up that way.’ His speech seemed rambling, but his old blue eyes were very penetrating. ‘That’s a big sword you’re carrying, boy. Who do you plan to kill with it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5KT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5KU">The question came so fast that Garion did not even have time to be startled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5KV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5L0">‘Funny thing about that sword of yours,’ the shabby old man added shrewdly. ‘It seems to be going out of its way to make itself inconspicuous.’ Then he turned to Belgarath, who was looking at him with a level gaze. ‘You haven’t hardly changed at all,’ he noted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5L1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5L2">‘And you still talk too much,’ Belgarath replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5L3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5L4">‘I get hungry for talk every few years,’ the old man on the donkey admitted. ‘Is your daughter well?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5L5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5L6">Belgarath nodded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5L7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5L8">‘Fine-looking woman, your daughter – bad-tempered, though.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5L9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LA">‘That hasn’t changed noticeably.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5LB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LC">‘Didn’t imagine it had.’ The old gold hunter chuckled, then hesitated for a moment. ‘If you don’t mind some advice, be careful in case you plan to go down into the low country,’ he said seriously. ‘It looks like things might be coming to a boil down there. A lot of strangers in red tunics are roaming about, and there’s been smoke coming up from old altars that haven’t been used for years. The Grolims are out again, and their knives are all new-sharpened. The Nadraks who come up here keep looking back over their shoulders.’ He paused, looking directly at Belgarath. ‘There’ve been some other signs, too,’ he added. ‘The animals are all jumpy – like just before a big storm – and sometimes at night, if you listen close, there’s something like thunder way off in the distance – like maybe from as far off as Mallorea. The whole world seems to be uneasy. I’ve got a hunch that something pretty big’s about to happen – maybe the sort of thing </span><span class="italic" aid="9H5LD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LE">you’d</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LF"> be involved in. The point is that </span><span class="italic" aid="9H5LG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LH">they</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LI"> know you’re out here. I wouldn’t count too much on being able to slip through without somebody noticing you.’ He shrugged then, as if washing his hands of the matter. ‘I just thought you’d like to know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5LJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LK">‘Thank you,’ Belgarath replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5LL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LM">‘Didn’t cost me anything to say it.’ The old man shrugged again. ‘I think I’ll go that way.’ He pointed off to the north. ‘Too many strangers coming into the mountains in the last few months. It’s starting to get crowded. I’ve about talked myself out now, so I think I’ll go look myself up a bit of privacy.’ He turned his donkey and trotted off. ‘Good luck,’ he threw back over his shoulder by way of farewell and then he disappeared into the blue shadows under the trees.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5LN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LO">‘You’re acquainted with him, I take it,’ Silk observed to Belgarath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5LP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LQ">The old sorcerer nodded. ‘I met him about thirty years ago. Polgara had come to Gar og Nadrak to find out a few things. After she’d gathered all the information she wanted, she sent word to me, and I came here and bought her from the man who owned her. We started home, but an early snowstorm caught us up here in the mountains. He found us floundering along, and he took us to the cave where he holes up when the snow gets too deep. Quite a comfortable cave really – except that he insists on bringing his donkey inside. He and Pol argued about that all winter, as I recall.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5LR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LS">‘What’s his name?’ Silk asked curiously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5LT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5LU">Belgarath shrugged. ‘He never said, and it’s not polite to ask.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5LV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5M0">Garion, however, had choked on the word ‘bought.’ A kind of helpless outrage welled up in him. ‘Somebody </span><span class="italic" aid="9H5M1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5M2">owned</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5M3"> Aunt Pol?’ he demanded incredulously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5M4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5M5">‘It’s a Nadrak custom,’ Silk explained. ‘In their society, women are considered property. It’s not seemly for a woman to go about without an owner.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5M6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5M7">‘She was a </span><span class="italic" aid="9H5M8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5M9">slave</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5MA">?’ Garion’s knuckles grew white as he clenched his fists.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5MB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5MC">‘Of course she wasn’t a slave,’ Belgarath told him. ‘Can you even remotely imagine your Aunt submitting to that sort of thing?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5MD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5ME">‘But you said—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5MF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5MG">‘I said I bought her from the man who owned her. Their relationship was a formality – nothing more. She needed an owner in order to function here, and he gained a great deal of respect from other men as a result of his ownership of so remarkable a woman.’ Belgarath made a sour face. ‘It cost me a fortune to buy her back from him. I sometimes wonder if she was really worth it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5MH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5MI">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="9H5MJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5MK">Grandfather!</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5ML">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5MM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5MN">‘I’m sure she’d be fascinated by that last observation, old friend,’ Silk said slyly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5MO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5MP">‘I don’t know that it’s necessary to repeat it to her, Silk.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5MQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5MR">‘You never know.’ Silk laughed. ‘I might need something from you someday.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5MS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5MT">‘That’s disgusting.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5MU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5MV">‘I know.’ Silk grinned and looked around. ‘Your friend took quite a bit of trouble to look you up,’ he suggested. ‘What was behind it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5N0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5N1">‘He wanted to warn me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5N2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5N3">‘That things were tense in Gar og Nadrak? We knew that already.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5N4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5N5">‘His warning was a great deal more urgent than that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5N6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5N7">‘He didn’t </span><span class="italic" aid="9H5N8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5N9">sound</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NA"> very urgent.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5NB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NC">‘That’s because you don’t know him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5ND"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NE">‘Grandfather,’ Garion said suddenly, ‘how did he manage to see my sword? I thought we’d taken care of that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5NF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NG">‘He sees </span><span class="italic" aid="9H5NH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NI">everything</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NJ">, Garion. He could glance once at a tree and tell you ten years later exactly how many leaves were on it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5NK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NL">‘Is he a sorcerer?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5NM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NN">‘Not as far as I know. He’s just a strange old man who likes the mountains. He doesn’t know what’s going on because he doesn’t </span><span class="italic" aid="9H5NO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NP">want</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NQ"> to know. If he really wanted to, he could probably find out everything that’s happening in the world.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5NR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NS">‘He could make a fortune as a spy, then,’ Silk mused.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5NT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5NU">‘He doesn’t want a fortune. Isn’t that obvious? Any time he needs money, he just goes back to that river bar he mentioned.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5NV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5O0">‘But he said he’d forgotten how to find it,’ Garion protested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5O1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5O2">Belgarath snorted. ‘He’s never forgotten anything in his life.’ Then his eyes grew distant. ‘There are a few people like him in the world – people who have no interest whatsoever in what other people are doing. Maybe that’s not such a bad trait. If I had my life to live over, I might not mind doing it his way.’ He looked around then, his eyes very alert. ‘Let’s take that path over there,’ he suggested, pointing at a scarcely visible track angling off across an open meadow, littered with bits of log bleached white by sun and weather. ‘If what he says is true, I think we’ll want to avoid any large settlements. That path comes out farther north where there aren’t so many people.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5O3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5O4">Not long afterward the terrain began to slope downward, and the three of them moved along briskly, riding down out of the mountains toward the vastness of the forest of Nadrak. The peaks around them subsided into forested foothills. Once they topped a rise, they were able to look out at the ocean of trees lying below. The forest stretched to the horizon and beyond, dark green beneath a blue sky. A faint breeze was blowing, and the sigh of its passage through the mile upon mile of trees below had a kind of endless sadness to it, a regretful memory of summers past and springs that would never come again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5O5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5O6">Some distance up the slope from the forest stood a village, huddled at the side of a vast, open pit that had been gouged, raw and ugly, in the red dirt of the hillside.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5O7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5O8">‘A mine town,’ Belgarath noted. ‘Let’s nose about a bit and see what’s going on.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5O9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5OA">They rode warily down the hill. As they drew closer, Garion could see that the village had that same temporary kind of appearance he had noticed about Yar Gurak. The buildings were constructed in the same way – unpeeled logs and rough stone – and the low-pitched roofs had large rocks laid on them to keep the shingles from blowing off during the winter blizzards. Nadraks seemed not to be concerned about the external appearance of their structures; once the walls and roofs were completed, they appeared quite content to move in and devote their attentions to other matters, without attending to those final finishing touches which gave a house that look of permanence that a Sendar or a Tolnedran would feel absolutely necessary. The entire settlement seemed to reflect an attitude of ‘good enough’ that offended Garion, for some reason.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5OB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5OC">Some of the miners who lived in the village came out into the dirt streets to watch the strangers ride in. Their black leather clothing was stained red by the earth in which they dug, and their eyes were hard and suspicious. An air of fearful wariness hung over the whole place, seasoned with a touch of defiant bellicosity.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5OD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5OE">Silk jerked his head toward a large, low building with a crude painting of a cluster of grapes on a sign banging in the breeze by the double doors at the front. A wide, roofed porch surrounded the building, and leather-garbed Nadraks lounged on benches along the porch, watching a dogfight in progress out in the middle of the street.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5OF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5OG">Belgarath nodded. ‘But let’s go around to the side,’ he suggested, ‘in case we have to leave in a hurry.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5OH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5OI">They dismounted at the side porch, tied their horses to the railing, and went inside.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5OJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5OK">The interior of the tavern was smoky and dim, since windows seemed to be a rare feature in Nadrak buildings. The tables and benches were rough-hewn, and what light there was came from smoking oil lamps that hung on chains from the rafters. The floor was mud-stained and littered with bits of food. Dogs roamed at will under the tables and benches. The smell of stale beer and unwashed bodies hung heavy in the air, and, though it was only early afternoon, the place was crowded. Many of the men in the large room were already far gone with drink. It was noisy, since the Nadraks lounging at the tables or stumbling about the room seemed all habitually to speak at the top of their voices.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5OL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5OM">Belgarath pushed his way toward a table in the corner where a solitary man sat bleary-eyed and slack-lipped, staring into his ale cup.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5ON"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5OO">‘You don’t mind if we share the table, do you?’ the old man demanded of him in an abrupt manner, sitting down without awaiting a reply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5OP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5OQ">‘Would it do any good if I did?’ the man with the cup asked. He was unshaven, and his eyes were pouchy and bloodshot.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5OR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5OS">‘Not much,’ Belgarath told him bluntly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5OT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5OU">‘You’re new here, aren’t you?’ The Nadrak looked at the three of them with only a hint of curiosity, trying with some difficulty to focus his eyes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5OV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5P0">‘I don’t really see that it’s any of your business,’ Belgarath retorted rudely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5P1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5P2">‘You’ve got a sour mouth for a man past his prime,’ the Nadrak suggested, flexing his fingers ominously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5P3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5P4">‘I came here to drink, not fight,’ Silk declared in a harsh tone. ‘I might change my mind later, but right now, I’m thirsty.’ He reached out and caught the arm of a passing servingman. ‘Ale,’ he ordered. ‘And don’t take all day.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5P5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5P6">‘Keep your hands to yourself,’ the servingman told him. ‘Are you with him?’ He pointed at the Nadrak they had joined.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5P7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5P8">‘We’re sitting with him, aren’t we?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5P9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PA">‘You want three cups or four?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5PB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PC">‘I want one – for now. Bring the others what they want, too. I’ll pay for the first time around.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5PD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PE">The servingman grunted sourly and pushed his way off through the crowd, pausing long enough to kick a dog out of his way.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5PF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PG">Silk’s offer seemed to quiet their Nadrak companion’s belligerence. ‘You’ve picked a bad time to come to town,’ he told them. ‘The whole region’s crawling with Mallorean recruiters.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5PH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PI">‘We’ve been up in the mountains,’ Belgarath said. ‘We’ll probably go back in a day or so. Whatever’s happening down here doesn’t interest us very much.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5PJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PK">‘You’d better take an interest while you’re here – unless you’d like to try army life.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5PL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PM">‘Is there a war someplace?’ Silk asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5PN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PO">‘Likely to be – or so they say. Someplace down in Mishrak ac Thull.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5PP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PQ">Silk snorted. ‘I’ve never met a Thull worth fighting.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5PR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PS">‘It’s not the Thulls. It’s supposed to be the Alorns. They’ve got a </span><span class="italic" aid="9H5PT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PU">queen</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5PV"> – if you can imagine such a thing – and she’s moving to invade the Thulls.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5Q0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5Q1">‘A </span><span class="italic" aid="9H5Q2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5Q3">queen?’</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5Q4"> Silk scoffed. ‘Can’t be much of an army, then. Let the Thulls fight her themselves.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5Q5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5Q6">‘Tell that to the Mallorean recruiters,’ the Nadrak suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5Q7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5Q8">‘Did you have to </span><span class="italic" aid="9H5Q9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QA">brew</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QB"> that ale?’ Silk demanded of the servingman, who was returning with four large cups.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5QC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QD">‘There are other taverns, friend,’ the servingman replied. ‘If you don’t like this one, go find another. That’ll be twelve pennies.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5QE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QF">‘Three pennies a cup?’ Silk exclaimed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5QG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QH">‘Times are hard.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5QI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QJ">Grumbling, Silk paid him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5QK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QL">‘Thanks,’ the Nadrak they were sitting with said, taking one of the cups.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5QM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QN">‘Don’t mention it,’ Silk said sourly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5QO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QP">‘What are the Malloreans doing here?’ Belgarath asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5QQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QR">‘Rounding up everyone who can stand up, see lightning, and hear thunder. They do their recruiting with leg-irons, so it’s a little hard to refuse. They’ve got Grolims with them too, and the Grolims keep their gutting knives out in plain sight as a sort of a hint about what might happen to anybody who objects too much.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5QS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QT">‘Maybe you were right when you said we picked a bad time to come down out of the mountains,’ Silk said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5QU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5QV">The Nadrak nodded. ‘The Grolims say that Torak’s stirring in his sleep.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5R0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5R1">‘That’s not very good news,’ Silk replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5R2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5R3">‘I think we could all drink to that.’ The Nadrak lifted his ale cup. ‘You find anything worth digging for up there in the mountains?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5R4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5R5">Silk shook his head. ‘A few traces is all. We’ve been working the streambeds for free gold. We don’t have the equipment to drive shafts back into the rock.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5R6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5R7">‘You’ll never get rich squatting beside a creek and sifting gravel.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5R8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5R9">‘We get by.’ Silk shrugged. ‘Someday maybe we’ll hit a good pocket and we’ll be able to pick up enough to buy some equipment.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5RA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5RB">‘And someday maybe it will rain beer, too.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5RC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5RD">Silk laughed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5RE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5RF">‘You ever thought about taking in another partner?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5RG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5RH">Silk squinted at the unshaven Nadrak. ‘Have you been up there before?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5RI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5RJ">The Nadrak nodded. ‘Often enough to know that I don’t like it – but I think I’d like a stint in the army a lot less.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5RK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5RL">‘Let’s have another drink and talk about it,’ Silk suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5RM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5RN">Garion leaned back, putting his shoulders against the rough log wall. Nadraks didn’t seem to be so bad, once you got past the crudity of their nature. They were a blunt-spoken people and a bit sour-faced, but they did not seem to have that icy animosity toward outsiders he had noted among the Murgos.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5RO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5RP">He let his mind drift back to what the Nadrak had said about a queen. He quickly dismissed the notion that any of the queens staying at Riva might, under any circumstances, have assumed such authority. That left only Aunt Pol. The Nadrak’s information could have been garbled a bit; but in Belgarath’s absence, Aunt Pol </span><span class="italic" aid="9H5RQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5RR">might</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5RS"> have taken charge of things – although that was not like her, at all. What could possibly have happened back there to force her to go to such extremes?</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5RT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5RU">As the afternoon wore on, more and more of the men in the tavern grew reeling drunk, and occasional fights broke out – although the fights usually consisted of shoving matches, since few in the room were sober enough to aim a good blow. Their companion drank steadily and eventually laid his head down on his arms and began to snore. ‘I think we’ve got just about everything we can use here,’ Belgarath suggested quietly. ‘Let’s drift on out. From what our friend here says, I don’t think it’d be a good idea to sleep in town.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5RV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5S0">Silk nodded his agreement, and the three of them rose from the table and made their way through the crowd to the side door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5S1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5S2">‘Did you want to pick up any supplies?’ the little man asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5S3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5S4">Belgarath shook his head. ‘I have a feeling that we want to get out of here as soon as possible.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5S5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5S6">Silk gave him a quick look, and the three of them untied their horses, mounted and rode back out into the red dirt street. They moved at a walk to avoid arousing suspicion, but Garion could feel a sort of tense urgency to put this raw, mud-smeared village behind them. There was something threatening in the air, and the golden late afternoon sun seemed somehow shadowed, as if by an unseen cloud. As they were passing the last rickety house on the downhill edge of the village, they heard an alarmed shout from somewhere back near the center of town. Garion turned quickly and saw a party of perhaps twenty mounted men in red tunics plunging at a full gallop toward the tavern the three of them had just left. With a practiced skill, the scarlet-clad strangers swung down from their horses and immediately covered all the doors to cut off an escape for those inside.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5S7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5S8">‘Malloreans!’ Belgarath snapped. ‘Make for the trees!’ And he drove his heels into his horse’s flanks. They galloped across the weedy, stump-cluttered clearing that surrounded the village, toward the edge of the forest and safety, but there was no outcry or pursuit. The tavern appeared to contain enough fish to fill the Mallorean net. From a safe vantage point beneath spreading tree limbs, Garion, Silk, and Belgarath watched as a disconsolate-looking string of Nadraks, chained together at the ankle, were led out of the tavern into the red dust of the street to stand under the watchful eyes of the Mallorean recruiters.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5S9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5SA">‘It looks like our friend has joined the army, after all,’ Silk observed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="9H5SB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="9H5SC">‘Better him than us,’ Belgarath replied. ‘We might be just a little out of place in the middle of an Angarak horde.’ He squinted at the ruddy disk of the setting sun. ‘Let’s move out. We’ve got a few hours before dark. It looks as if military service might be contagious in this vicinity, and I wouldn’t want to catch it.’</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_10" aid="9H5SD"></div>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>

<link href="kindle:flow:0002?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>

</body>
</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos92188" aid="AFM61"><span class="calibre5" aid="AFM62"><span class="italic" aid="AFM63"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM64">Chapter Three</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="AFM65"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM66">The forest of Nadrak was unlike the Arendish forest lying far to the south. The differences were subtle, and it took Garion several days to put his finger on them. For one thing, the trails they followed had no sense of permanence about them. They were so infrequently traveled that they were not beaten into the loamy soil of the forest floor. In the Arendish forest, the marks of man were everywhere, but here man was an intruder, merely passing through. Moreover, the forest in Arendia had definite boundaries, but this ocean of trees went on to the farthest edge of the continent, and it had stood so since the beginning of the world.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM67"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM68">The forest teemed with life. Tawny deer flickered among the trees, and vast, shaggy bison, with curved black horns shiny as onyx, grazed in clearings. Once a bear, grumbling and muttering irritably, lumbered across the trail in front of them. Rabbits scurried through the undergrowth and partridges exploded into flight from underfoot with a heart-stopping thunder of wings. The ponds and streams abounded with fish, muskrat, otter, and beaver. There were also, they soon discovered, smaller forms of life. The mosquitoes seemed only slightly smaller than sparrows, and there was a nasty little brown fly that bit anything that moved.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM69"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM6A">The sun rose early and set late, dappling the dark forest floor with golden light. Although it was midsummer now, it was never exactly hot, and the air was rich with that smell of urgent growth common to the lands of the north, where summer was short and winter very long.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM6B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM6C">Belgarath seemed not to sleep at all once they entered the forest. Each evening, as Silk and Garion wearily rolled themselves in their blankets, the old sorcerer threaded his way back into the shadowy trees and disappeared. Once, several hours past dusk on a night filled with starlight, Garion awoke briefly and heard the loping touch of paws skittering lightly across a leaf-carpeted clearing; even as he drifted back to sleep, he understood. The great silver wolf who was his grandfather roamed the night, scouring the surrounding forest for any hint of pursuit or danger.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM6D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM6E">The old man’s nocturnal roamings were as silent as smoke, but they did not pass unnoticed. Early one morning, before the sun rose and while the trees were still hazy and half-obscured by ground fog, several shadowy shapes drifted among the dark trunks and stopped not far away. Garion, who had just risen and was preparing to stir up the fire, froze half-bent over. As he slowly straightened, he could feel eyes on him, and his skin prickled peculiarly. Perhaps ten feet away stood a huge, dark gray wolf. The wolf’s expression was serious, and its eyes were as yellow as sunlight. There was an unspoken question in those golden eyes, and Garion realized that he understood that question.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM6F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM6G">‘One wonders why you are doing that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM6H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM6I">‘Doing what?’ Garion asked politely, responding automatically in the language of wolves.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM6J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM6K">‘Going about in that peculiar form.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM6L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM6M">‘It’s necessary to do it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM6N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM6O">‘Ah.’ With exquisite courtesy the wolf did not pursue the matter further. ‘One is curious to know if you don’t find it somewhat restricting,’ he noted however.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM6P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM6Q">‘It’s not as bad as it looks – once one gets used to it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM6R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM6S">The wolf looked unconvinced. He sat down on his haunches. ‘One has seen the other one several times in the past few darknesses,’ he said in the manner of wolves, ‘and one is curious to know why you and he have come into our range.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM6T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM6U">Garion knew instinctively that his answer to that question was going to be very important. ‘We are going from one place to another,’ he replied carefully. ‘It is not our intention to seek dens or mates in your range or to hunt the creatures that are yours.’ He could not have explained how he knew what to say.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM6V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM70">The wolf seemed satisfied with his response. ‘One would be pleased if you would present our esteem to the one with fur like frost,’ he said formally. ‘One has noted that he is worthy of great respect.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM71"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM72">‘One would be pleased to give him your words,’ Garion responded, a bit surprised at how easily the elaborate phrasing came to him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM73"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM74">The wolf lifted his head and sniffed at the air. ‘It is time for us to hunt,’ he said. ‘May you find what you seek.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM75"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM76">‘May your hunt be successful,’ Garion returned.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM77"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM78">The wolf turned and padded back into the fog, followed by his companions.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM79"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM7A">‘On the whole, you handled that rather well, Garion,’ Belgarath said from the deep shadows of a nearby thicket.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM7B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM7C">Garion jumped, a bit startled. ‘I didn’t know you were there,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM7D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM7E">‘You should have,’ the old man replied, stepping out of the shadows.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM7F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM7G">‘How did he know?’ Garion asked. ‘That I’m a wolf sometimes, I mean?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM7H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM7I">‘It shows. A wolf is very alert to that sort of thing.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM7J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM7K">Silk came out from under the tree where he had been sleeping. The little man’s step was wary, but his nose twitched with curiosity. ‘What was that all about?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM7L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM7M">‘The wolves wanted to know what we were doing in their territory,’ Belgarath replied. ‘They were investigating to see if they were going to have to fight us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM7N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM7O">‘Fight?’ Garion was startled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM7P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM7Q">‘It’s customary when a strange wolf enters the hunting range of another pack. Wolves prefer not to fight – it’s a waste of energy – but they will, if the situation demands it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM7R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM7S">‘What happened?’ Silk asked. ‘Why did they just go away like that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM7T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM7U">‘Garion convinced them that we were just passing through.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM7V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM80">‘That was clever of him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM81"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM82">‘Why don’t you stir up the fire, Garion?’ Belgarath suggested. ‘Let’s have some breakfast and move on. It’s still a long way to Mallorea, and we don’t want to run out of good weather.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM83"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM84">Later that same day, they rode down into a valley where a collection of log houses and tents stood beside a fair-sized stream at the edge of a meadow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM85"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM86">‘Fur traders,’ Silk explained to Garion, pointing at the rough settlement. ‘There are places like this on just about every major stream in this part of the forest.’ The little man’s pointed nose began to twitch, and his eyes grew bright. ‘A lot of buying and selling goes on in these little towns.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM87"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM88">‘Never mind,’ Belgarath told him pointedly. ‘Try to keep your predatory instincts under control.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM89"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM8A">‘I wasn’t even considering anything,’ Silk protested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM8B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM8C">‘Really? Aren’t you feeling well?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM8D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM8E">Silk loftily ignored that.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM8F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM8G">‘Wouldn’t it be safer to go around it?’ Garion asked as they rode across the broad meadow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM8H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM8I">Belgarath shook his head. ‘I want to know what’s going on ahead of us, and the quickest way to find out is to talk to people who’ve been there. We’ll drift in, circulate for an hour or so and then drift on out again. Just keep your ears open. If anyone asks, we’re on our way toward the north range to look for gold.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM8J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM8K">There were differences between the hunters and trappers who roamed the streets of this settlement and the miners they had met in the last village. They were more open for one thing – less surly and distinctly less belligerent. Garion surmised that the enforced solitude of their occupation made them appreciate companionship all the more during their infrequent visits to the fur-trading centers. Although they drank probably as much as the miners, their drinking seemed to lead more often to singing and laughter than to fighting.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM8L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM8M">A large tavern stood near the center of the village, and they rode slowly along a dirt street toward it. ‘Side door,’ Belgarath said tersely as they dismounted in front of the tavern, and they led their horses around the building and tied them at the porch railing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM8N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM8O">The interior of the tavern was cleaner, less crowded, and somewhat lighter than the miners’ tavern had been, and it smelled of woods and open air instead of damp, musty earth. The three of them sat at a table not far from the door and ordered cups of ale from a polite servingman. The ale was a rich, dark brown, well chilled, and surprisingly inexpensive.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM8P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM8Q">‘The fur buyers own the place,’ Silk explained, wiping foam from his upper lip. ‘They’ve discovered that a trapper is easier to bargain with if he’s a little drunk, so they make the ale cheap and plentiful.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM8R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM8S">‘I suppose that makes sense,’ Garion admitted, ‘but don’t the trappers know that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM8T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM8U">‘Of course they do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM8V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM90">‘Why do they drink before they do business, then?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM91"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM92">Silk shrugged. ‘They like to drink.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM93"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM94">The two trappers seated at the next table were renewing an acquaintanceship that obviously stretched back a dozen years or more. Their beards were both touched with gray, but they spoke lightheartedly in the manner of much younger men.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM95"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM96">‘You have any trouble with Morindim while you were up there?’ one was asking the other.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM97"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM98">The second shook his head. ‘I put pestilence-markers on both ends of the valley where I set out my traps,’ he replied. ‘A Morind will go a dozen leagues out of his way to avoid a spot that’s got pestilence.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM99"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM9A">The first nodded his agreement. ‘That’s usually the best way. Gredder always claimed that curse-markers worked better; but as it turned out, he was wrong.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM9B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM9C">‘I haven’t seen him in the last few seasons.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM9D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM9E">‘I’d be surprised if you had. The Morindim got him about three years ago. I buried him myself – what was left of him anyway.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM9F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM9G">‘Didn’t know that. Spent a winter with him once over on the headwaters of the Cordu. He was a mean-tempered sort of a man. I’m surprised that the Morindim would cross a curse-marker, though.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM9H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM9I">‘As near as I could judge, some magician came along and uncursed his markers. I found a dried weasel foot hung from one of them with three stems of grass tied around each toe.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM9J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM9K">‘That’s a potent spell. They must have wanted him pretty badly for a magician to take that much trouble.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM9L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM9M">‘You know how he was. He could irritate people ten leagues away just walking by.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM9N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM9O">‘That’s the truth.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM9P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM9Q">‘Not any more, though. His skull’s decorating some Morind magician’s quest-staff now.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM9R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM9S">Garion leaned toward his grandfather. ‘What do they mean when they talk about markers?’ he whispered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM9T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFM9U">‘They’re warnings,’ Belgarath replied. ‘Usually sticks poked into the ground and decorated with bones or feathers. The Morindim can’t read, so you can’t just put up a signboard for them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFM9V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMA0">A stooped old trapper, his leather clothing patched and shiny from wear, shuffled toward the center of the tavern. His lined, bearded face had a slightly apologetic expression on it. Following after him came a young Nadrak woman in a heavy, red felt dress belted about the waist with a glittering chain. There was a leash about her neck, and the old trapper held the end of the tether firmly in his fist. Despite the leash, the young woman’s face had a proud, disdainful look, and she stared at the men in the tavern with barely concealed contempt. When the old trapper reached the center of the room, he cleared his throat to get the attention of the crowd. ‘I’ve got a woman I want to sell,’ he announced loudly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMA1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMA2">Without changing expression the woman spat upon him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMA3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMA4">‘Now you know that’s just going to lower your price, Vella,’ the old man told her in a placating tone of voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMA5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMA6">‘You’re an idiot, Tashor,’ she retorted. ‘No-one here can afford me – you know that.
