Why didn’t you do what I told you to and offer me to the fur buyers?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMA7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMA8">‘The fur buyers aren’t interested in women, Vella,’ Tashor replied in that same mild tone. ‘The price will be better here, believe me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMA9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMAA">‘I wouldn’t believe you if you said the sun was going to rise tomorrow, you old fool.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMAB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMAC">‘The woman, as you can see, is quite spirited,’ Tashor announced rather lamely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMAD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMAE">‘Is he trying to sell his wife?’ Garion demanded, choking on his ale.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMAF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMAG">‘She isn’t his wife,’ Silk corrected. ‘He owns her, that’s all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMAH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMAI">Garion clenched his fists and half-rose, his face mottled with anger, but Belgarath’s hand closed firmly about his wrist. ‘Sit down,’ the old man ordered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMAJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMAK">‘But—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMAL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMAM">‘I said sit down, Garion. This is none of your business.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMAN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMAO">‘Unless you want to buy the woman, of course,’ Silk suggested lightly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMAP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMAQ">‘Is she healthy?’ a lean-faced trapper with a scar across one cheek called to Tashor.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMAR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMAS">‘She is,’ Tashor declared, ‘and she’s got all her teeth, too. Show them your teeth, Vella.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMAT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMAU">‘They aren’t looking at my teeth, idiot,’ she told him, looking directly at the scar-faced trapper with a sultry challenge in her black eyes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMAV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMB0">‘She’s an excellent cook,’ Tashor continued quickly, ‘and she knows remedies for rheumatism and ague. She can dress and tan hides and she doesn’t eat too much. Her breath doesn’t smell too bad – unless she eats onions – and she almost never snores, except when she’s drunk.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMB1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMB2">‘If she’s such a good woman, why do you want to sell her?’ the lean-faced trapper wanted to know.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMB3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMB4">‘I’m getting older,’ Tashor replied, ‘and I’d like a little peace and quiet. Vella’s exciting to be around, but I’ve had all the excitement I need. I think I’d like to settle down someplace – maybe raise some chickens or goats.’ The bent old trapper’s voice sounded a trifle plaintive.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMB5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMB6">‘Oh, this is impossible,’ Vella burst out. ‘Do I have to do everything myself? Get out of the way, Tashor.’ Rudely, she pushed the old trapper aside and glared at the crowd, her black eyes flashing. ‘All right,’ she announced firmly, ‘let’s get down to business. Tashor wants to sell me. I’m strong and healthy. I can cook, cure hides and skins, tend to common illnesses, bargain closely when I buy supplies, and I can brew good beer.’ Her eyes narrowed grimly. ‘I have not gone to any man’s bed, and I keep my daggers sharp enough to persuade strangers not to try to force me. I can play the wood-flute and I know many old stories. I can make curse-markers and pestilence-markers and dream-markers to frighten off the Morindim and once I killed a bear at thirty paces with a bow.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMB7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMB8">‘Twenty paces,’ Tashor corrected mildly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMB9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMBA">‘It was closer to thirty,’ she insisted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMBB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMBC">‘Can you dance?’ the lean trapper with the scarred face asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMBD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMBE">She looked directly at him. ‘Only if you’re seriously interested in buying me,’ she replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMBF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMBG">‘We can talk about that after I see you dance,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMBH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMBI">‘Can you hold a beat?’ she demanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMBJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMBK">‘I can.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMBL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMBM">‘Very well.’ Her hands went to the chain about her waist, and it jingled as she unfastened it. She opened the heavy red dress, stepped out of it, and handed it to Tashor. Then she carefully untied the leash from about her neck and bound a ribbon of red silk about her head to hold back her wealth of lustrous, blue-black hair. Beneath the red felt dress, she wore a filmy rose-colored gown of Mallorean silk that whispered and clung to her as she moved. The silk gown reached to midcalf, and she wore soft leather boots on her feet. Protruding from the top of each boot was the jeweled hilt of a dagger, and a third dagger rode on the leather belt about her waist. Her gown was caught in a tight collar about her throat, but it left her arms bare to the shoulder. She wore a half-dozen narrow gold bracelets about each wrist. With a conscious grace, she bent and fastened a string of small bells to each ankle. Then she lifted her smoothly rounded arms until her hands were beside her face. ‘This is the beat, scar-face,’ she told the trapper. ‘Try to hold it.’ And she began to clap her hands together. The beat was three measured claps followed by four staccato ones. Vella began her dance slowly with a kind of insolent strut. Her gown whispered as she moved, its hem sighing about her lush calves.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMBN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMBO">The lean trapper took up her beat, his callused hands clapping together loudly in the sudden silence as Vella danced.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMBP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMBQ">Garion began to blush. Vella’s movements were subtle and fluid. The bells at her ankles and the bracelets about her wrists played a tinkling counterpoint to the trapper’s beat. Her feet seemed almost to flicker in the intricate steps of her dance, and her arms wove patterns in the air. Other, even more interesting, things were going on inside the rose-colored, gossamer gown. Garion swallowed hard and discovered that he had almost stopped breathing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMBR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMBS">Vella began to whirl, and her long black hair flared out, almost perfectly matching the flare of her gown. Then she slowed and once again dropped back into that proud, sensual strut that challenged every man in the room.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMBT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMBU">They cheered when she stopped, and she smiled a slow, mysterious little smile.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMBV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMC0">‘You dance very well,’ the scar-faced trapper observed in a neutral voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMC1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMC2">‘Naturally,’ she replied. ‘I do everything very well.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMC3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMC4">‘Are you in love with anyone?’ The question was bluntly put.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMC5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMC6">‘No man has won my heart,’ Vella declared flatly. ‘I haven’t seen a man yet who was worthy of me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMC7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMC8">‘That may change,’ the trapper suggested. ‘One goldmark.’ It was a firm offer.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMC9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCA">‘You’re not serious,’ she snorted. ‘Five goldmarks.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMCB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCC">‘One and a half,’ he countered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMCD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCE">‘This is just </span><span class="italic" aid="AFMCF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCG">too</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCH"> insulting.’ Vella raised both hands up in the air, and her face took on a tragic expression. ‘Not a copper less than four.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMCI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCJ">‘Two goldmarks,’ the trapper offered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMCK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCL">‘Unbelievable!’ she exclaimed, spreading both arms. ‘Why don’t you just cut my heart out and have done with it? I couldn’t consider anything less than three and a half.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMCM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCN">‘To save time, why don’t we just say three?’ He said it firmly. ‘With intention that the arrangement become permanent,’ he added, almost as an afterthought.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMCO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCP">‘Permanent?’ Vella’s eyes widened.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMCQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCR">‘I like you,’ he replied. ‘Well, what do you say?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMCS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCT">‘Stand up and let me have a look at you,’ she ordered him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMCU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMCV">Slowly he unwound himself from the chair in which he had lounged. His tall body was as lean as his scarred face, and there was a hard-muscled quality about him. Vella pursed her lips and looked him over. ‘Not bad, is he?’ she murmured to Tashor.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMD0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMD1">‘You could do worse, Vella,’ her owner answered encouragingly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMD2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMD3">‘I’ll consider your offer of three with intentions,’ Vella declared. ‘Have you got a name?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMD4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMD5">‘Tekk,’ the tall trapper introduced himself with a slight bow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMD6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMD7">‘Well then, Tekk,’ Vella told him, ‘don’t go away. Tashor and I need to talk over your offer.’ She gave him an almost shy look. ‘I think I like you, too,’ she added in a much less challenging tone. Then she took hold of the leash that was still wrapped around Tashor’s fist and led him out of the tavern, glancing back over her shoulder once or twice at the lean-faced Tekk.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMD8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMD9">‘That is a </span><span class="italic" aid="AFMDA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDB">lot</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDC"> of woman,’ Silk murmured with a note of profound respect.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMDD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDE">Garion found that he was able to breathe again, though his ears still felt very hot. ‘What did they mean by intention?’ he quietly asked Silk.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMDF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDG">‘Tekk offered an arrangement that usually leads to marriage,’ Silk explained.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMDH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDI">That baffled Garion. ‘I don’t understand at all,’ he confessed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMDJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDK">‘Just because someone owns her doesn’t give him any special rights to her person,’ Silk told him, ‘and those daggers of hers enforce that. One does </span><span class="italic" aid="AFMDL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDM">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDN"> approach a Nadrak woman unless one’s tired of living. </span><span class="italic" aid="AFMDO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDP">She</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDQ"> makes that decision. The wedding customarily takes place after the birth of her first child.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMDR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDS">‘Why was she so interested in the price?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMDT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMDU">‘Because she gets half,’ Silk shrugged.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMDV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFME0">‘She gets half of the money every time she’s sold?’ Garion was incredulous.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFME1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFME2">‘Of course. It’d hardly be fair otherwise, would it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFME3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFME4">The servingman who was bringing them three more cups of ale had stopped and was staring openly at Silk.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFME5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFME6">‘Is something wrong, friend?’ Silk asked him mildly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFME7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFME8">The servingman lowered his eyes quickly. ‘Sorry,’ he mumbled. ‘I just thought – you reminded me of somebody, that’s all. Now that I see you closer, I realize that I was mistaken.’ He put down the cups quickly, turned, and left without picking up the coins Silk had laid on the table.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFME9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMEA">‘I think we’d better leave,’ Silk said quietly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMEB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMEC">‘What’s the matter?’ Garion asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMED"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMEE">‘He knows who I am – and there’s that reward notice that’s being circulated.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMEF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMEG">‘Maybe you’re right,’ Belgarath agreed, rising to his feet.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMEH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMEI">‘He’s talking with those men over there,’ Garion said, watching the servingman, who was in urgent conversation with a group of hunters on the far side of the room and was casting frequent looks in their direction.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMEJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMEK">‘We’ve got about a half a minute to get outside,’ Silk said tensely. ‘Let’s go.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMEL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMEM">The three of them moved quickly toward the door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMEN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMEO">‘You there!’ someone behind them shouted. ‘Wait a minute!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMEP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMEQ">‘Run!’ Belgarath barked, and they bolted outside and hurled themselves into their saddles just as a half-dozen leather-garbed men burst out through the tavern door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMER"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMES">The shout, ‘Stop those men!’ went largely unheeded as they galloped off down the street. Trappers and hunters as a breed were seldom inclined to mix themselves in other men’s affairs, and Garion, Silk, and Belgarath had passed through the village and were splashing across a ford before any kind of pursuit could be organized.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMET"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMEU">Silk was swearing as they entered the forest on the far side of the river, spitting out oaths like melon seeds. His profanity was colorful and wide-ranging, reflecting on the birth, parentage, and uncleanly habits of not only those pursuing them, but of those responsible for circulating the reward notice as well.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMEV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMF0">Belgarath reined in sharply, raising his hand as he did. Silk and Garion hauled their horses to a stop. Silk continued to swear.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMF1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMF2">‘Do you suppose you could cut short your eloquence for a moment?’ Belgarath asked him. ‘I’m trying to listen.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMF3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMF4">Silk muttered a few more choice oaths, then clamped his teeth shut. There were confused shouts far behind them and a certain amount of splashing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMF5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMF6">‘They’re crossing the stream,’ Belgarath noted. ‘It looks as if they plan to take the business seriously. Seriously enough to chase us, at any rate.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMF7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMF8">‘Won’t they give up when it gets dark?’ Garion asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMF9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMFA">‘These are Nadrak hunters,’ Silk said, sounding profoundly disgusted. ‘They’ll follow us for days – just for the enjoyment of the hunt.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMFB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMFC">‘There’s not much we can do about that now,’ Belgarath grunted. ‘Let’s see if we can outrun them.’ And he thumped his heels to his horse.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMFD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMFE">It was midafternoon as they rode at a gallop through the sunlit forest. The undergrowth was scanty, and the tall, straight trunks of fir and pine rose like great columns toward the blue sky overhead. It was a good day for a ride, but not a good day for being chased. No day was good for that.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMFF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMFG">They topped a rise and stopped again to listen. ‘They seem to be falling behind,’ Garion noted hopefully.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMFH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMFI">‘That’s just the drunk ones,’ Silk disagreed sourly. ‘The ones who are serious about all this are probably much closer. You don’t shout when you’re hunting. See – look back there.’ He pointed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMFJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMFK">Garion looked. There was a pale flicker back among the trees. A man on a white horse was riding in their direction, leaning far over in his saddle and looking intently at the ground as he rode.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMFL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMFM">‘If he’s any kind of tracker at all, it will take us a week to shake him off,’ Silk said disgustedly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMFN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMFO">Somewhere, far off among the trees to their right, a wolf howled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMFP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMFQ">‘Let’s keep going,’ Belgarath told them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMFR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMFS">They galloped on then, plunging down the far side of the rise, threading their way among the trees. The thud of their horses’ hoofs was a muffled drumming on the thick loam of the forest floor, and clots of half-decayed debris spattered out behind them as they fled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMFT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMFU">‘We’re leaving a trail as wide as a house,’ Silk shouted to Belgarath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMFV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMG0">‘That can’t be helped for now,’ the old man replied. ‘We need some more distance before we start playing games with the tracks.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMG1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMG2">Another howl drifted mournfully through the forest, from the left this time. It seemed a bit closer than the first had been.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMG3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMG4">They rode on for another quarter of an hour and then they suddenly heard a great babble of confusion to the rear. Men were shouting with alarm, and horses squealed in panic. Garion could also hear savage growls. At Belgarath’s signal, they slowed their horses to listen. The terrified squeals of horses rang sharply through the trees, punctuated by their riders’ curses and frightened shouts. A chorus of howls rose from all around. The forest seemed suddenly full of wolves. The pursuit behind them disintegrated as the horses of the Nadrak reward hunters bolted with screams of sheer panic in all directions.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMG5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMG6">With a certain grim satisfaction, Belgarath listened to the fading sounds behind them. Then, his tongue lolling from his mouth, a huge, dark-furred wolf trotted out of the woods about thirty yards away, stopped, and dropped to his haunches, his yellow eyes gazing intently at them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMG7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMG8">‘Keep a tight grip on your reins,’ Belgarath instructed quietly, stroking the neck of his suddenly wild-eyed mount.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMG9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMGA">The wolf did not say anything, but merely sat and watched.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="AFMGB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="AFMGC">Belgarath returned that steady gaze quite calmly, then finally nodded once in acknowledgment. The wolf rose, turned, and started off into the trees. He stopped once, glanced back over his shoulder at them, and raised his muzzle to lift the deep, bell-toned howl that summoned the other members of his pack to return to their interrupted hunt. Then, with a flicker he was gone, and only the echo of his howl remained.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_11" aid="AFMGD"></div>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
  <link href="kindle:flow:0001?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
<link href="kindle:flow:0002?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
</head>
  <body class="calibre" aid="BE6O0">
</body>
</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos130261" aid="BE6O1"><span class="calibre5" aid="BE6O2"><span class="italic" aid="BE6O3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6O4">Chapter Four</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="BE6O5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6O6">They rode east for the next several days, gradually descending into a broad, marshy valley where the undergrowth was denser and the air noticeably more humid. A brief summer shower rolled in one afternoon, accompanied by great, ripping crashes of thunder, a deluge of pounding rain, and winds that howled among the trees, bending and tossing them and tearing leaves and twigs from the underbrush to whirl and fly among the dark trunks. The storm soon passed, however, and the sun came out again. After that, the weather continued fair, and they made good time.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6O7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6O8">Garion felt a peculiar sense of incompleteness as he rode and he sometimes caught himself looking around for missing friends. The long journey in search of the Orb had established a sort of pattern in his mind, a sense of rightness and wrongness, and this trip felt wrong. Barak was not with them, for one thing, and the big, red-bearded Cherek’s absence made Garion feel oddly insecure. He also missed the hawk-faced, silent Hettar and the armored form of Mandorallen riding always at the front, with the silver-and-blue pennon snapping from the tip of his lance. He was painfully lonely for Durnik the smith and he even missed Ce’Nedra’s spiteful bickering. What had happened at Riva became less and less real to him, and all the elaborate ceremony that had attended his betrothal to the impossible little princess began to fade in his memory, like some half-forgotten dream.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6O9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OA">It was one evening, however, after the horses had been picketed and supper was over and they had rolled themselves in their blankets to sleep, that Garion, staring into the dying embers of their fire, came at last to face the central vacancy that had entered his life. Aunt Pol was not with them, and he missed her terribly. Since childhood, he had felt that, so long as Aunt Pol was nearby, nothing could really go wrong that she could not fix. Her calm, steady presence had been the one thing to which he had always clung. As clearly as if she stood before him, Garion could see her face, her glorious eyes, and the white lock at her brow; the sudden loneliness for her was as sharp as the edge of a knife.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6OB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OC">Everything felt wrong without her. Belgarath was here, certainly, and Garion was fairly sure that his grandfather could deal with any purely physical dangers, but there were other, less obvious perils that the old man either did not consider or chose to ignore. To whom could Garion turn when he was afraid, for example? Being afraid was not the sort of thing that endangered life or limb, but it was still an injury of sorts – and sometimes a deeper and more serious kind of injury. Aunt Pol had always been able to banish his fears, but now she was not here, and Garion was afraid and he could not even admit it. He sighed and pulled his blankets more closely about him and slowly drifted into a troubled sleep.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6OD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OE">It was about noon some days later when they reached the east fork of the River Cordu, a broad, dirty brown flow running through a brushy valley in a generally southerly direction toward the capital at Yar Nadrak. The pale green, waist-high brush extended back several hundred yards from either bank of the river and was silt-smeared by the high waters of the spring runoff. The sultry air above the brush was alive with clouds of gnats and mosquitoes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6OF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OG">A sullen boatman ferried them across to the village standing on the far bank. As they led their horses off onto the ferry landing, Belgarath spoke quietly. ‘I think we’ll want to change direction here,’ he told them. ‘Let’s split up. I’ll go pick up supplies, and the two of you go find the town tavern. See if you can get some information about passes leading up through the north range into the lands of the Morindim. The sooner we get up there, the better. The Malloreans seem to be getting the upper hand here and they could clamp down without much warning. I don’t want to have to start explaining my every move to Mallorean Grolims – not to mention the fact that there’s a great deal of interest in Silk’s whereabouts just now.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6OH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OI">Silk rather glumly agreed. ‘I’d like to get that matter straightened out, but I don’t suppose we really have the time, do we?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6OJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OK">‘No, not really. The summer is very, very short up north, and the crossing to Mallorea is unpleasant, even in the best weather. When you get to the tavern, tell everybody that we want to try our luck in the gold fields of the north range. There’s bound to be somebody around who’ll want to show off his familiarity with trails and passes – particularly if you offer to buy him a few drinks.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6OL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OM">‘I thought you said you knew the way,’ Silk protested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6ON"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OO">‘I know </span><span class="italic" aid="BE6OP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OQ">one</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OR"> way – but it’s a hundred leagues east of here. Let’s see if there’s something a little closer. I’ll come by the tavern after I get the supplies.’ The old man mounted and went off up the dirt street, leading their packhorse behind him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6OS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OT">Silk and Garion had little trouble finding someone in the smelly tavern willing to talk about trails and passes. Quite to the contrary, their first question sparked a general debate.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6OU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6OV">‘That’s the long way around, Besher,’ one tipsy gold hunter interrupted another’s detailed description of a mountain pass. ‘You go </span><span class="italic" aid="BE6P0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6P1">left</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6P2"> at the falls of the stream. It saves you three days.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6P3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6P4">‘I’m telling this, Varn,’ Besher retorted testily, banging his fist down on the scarred table. ‘You can tell them about the way you go when I’m finished.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6P5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6P6">‘It’ll take you all day – just like that trail you’re so fond of. They want to go look for gold, not admire scenery.’ Varn’s long, stubbled jaw thrust out belligerently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6P7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6P8">‘Which way do we go when we get to the long meadow up on top?’ Silk asked quickly, trying to head off the hostilities.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6P9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PA">‘You go right,’ Besher declared, glaring at Varn.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6PB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PC">Varn thought about that as if looking for an excuse to disagree. Finally he reluctantly nodded. ‘Of course that’s the only way you </span><span class="italic" aid="BE6PD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PE">can</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PF"> go,’ he added, ‘but once you get through the juniper grove, you turn left.’ He said it in the tone of a man anticipating contradiction.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6PG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PH">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="BE6PI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PJ">Left?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PK">’ Besher objected loudly. ‘You’re a blockhead, Varn. You go </span><span class="italic" aid="BE6PL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PM">right</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PN"> again.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6PO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PP">‘Watch who you’re calling a blockhead, you jackass!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6PQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PR">Without any further discussion, Besher punched Varn in the mouth, and the two of them began to pummel each other, reeling about and knocking over benches and tables.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6PS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PT">‘They’re both wrong, of course,’ another miner sitting at a nearby table observed calmly, watching the fight with a clinical detachment. ‘You keep going straight after you get through the juniper grove.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6PU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6PV">Several burly men, wearing loose-fitting red tunics over their polished mail shirts, had entered the tavern unnoticed during the altercation, and they stepped forward, grinning, to separate Varn and Besher as the two rolled around on the dirty floor. Garion felt Silk stiffen beside him. ‘Malloreans!’ the little man said softly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6Q0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6Q1">‘What do we do?’ Garion whispered, looking around for a way of escape. But before Silk could answer, a black-robed Grolim stepped through the door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6Q2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6Q3">‘I like to see men who are so eager to fight,’ the Grolim purred in a peculiar accent. ‘The army needs such men.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6Q4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6Q5">‘Recruiters!’ Varn exclaimed, breaking away from the red-garbed Malloreans and dashing toward a side door. For a second it looked as if he might escape; but as he reached the doorway, someone outside rapped him sharply across the forehead with a stout cudgel. He reeled back, suddenly rubber-legged and vacant-eyed. The Mallorean who had hit him came inside, gave him a critical, appraising glance, and then judiciously clubbed him in the head again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6Q6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6Q7">‘Well?’ the Grolim asked, looking around with amusement. ‘What’s it to be? Would any more of you like to run, or would you all prefer to come along quietly?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6Q8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6Q9">‘Where are you taking us?’ Besher demanded, trying to pull his arm out of the grip of one of the grinning recruiters.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6QA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QB">‘To Yar Nadrak first,’ the Grolim replied, ‘and then south to the plains of Mishrak ac Thull and the encampment of his Imperial Majesty ’Zakath, Emperor of all Mallorea. You’ve just joined the army, my friends. All of Angarak rejoices in your courage and patriotism, and Torak himself is pleased with you.’ As if to emphasize his words, the Grolim’s hand strayed to the hilt of the sacrificial knife sheathed at his belt.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="BE6QC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QD">The chain clinked spitefully as Garion, fettered at the ankle, plodded along, one in a long line of disconsolate-looking conscripts, following a trail leading generally southward through the brush along the riverbank. The conscripts had all been roughly searched for weapons – all but Garion, who for some reason had been overlooked. He was painfully aware of the huge sword strapped to his back as he walked along; but, as always seemed to happen, no-one else paid any atention to it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6QE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QF">Before they had left the village, while they were all being shackled, Garion and Silk had held a brief, urgent discussion in the minute finger movements of the Drasnian secret language.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6QG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QH">—</span><span class="italic" aid="BE6QI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QJ">I could pick this lock with my thumbnail</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QK"> – Silk had asserted with a disdainful flip of his fingers. —</span><span class="italic" aid="BE6QL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QM">As soon as it gets dark tonight, I’ll unhook us and we’ll leave. I don’t really think military life would agree with me, and it’s wildly inappropriate for you to be joining an Angarak army just now – all things considered.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QN">—</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6QO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QP">—</span><span class="italic" aid="BE6QQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QR">Where’s Grandfather?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QS"> – Garion had asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6QT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6QU">—</span><span class="italic" aid="BE6QV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6R0">Oh, I imagine he’s about.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6R1">—</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6R2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6R3">Garion, however, was worried, and a whole platoon of ‘what-its’ immediately jumped into his mind. To avoid thinking about them, he covertly studied the Malloreans who guarded them. The Grolim and the bulk of his detachment had moved on, once the captives had been shackled, seeking other villages and other recruits, leaving only five of their number behind to escort this group south. Malloreans were somewhat different from other Angaraks. Their eyes had that characteristic angularity, but their bodies seemed not to have the singleness of purpose which so dominated the western tribes. They were burly, but they did not have the broad-shouldered athleticism of the Murgos. They were tall, but did not have the lean, whippetlike frames of the Nadraks. They were obviously strong, but they did not have the thick-waisted brute power of Thulls. There was about them, moreover, a kind of disdainful superiority when they looked at western Angaraks. They spoke to their prisoners in short, barking commands, and when they talked to each other, their dialect was so thick that it was nearly unintelligible. They wore mail shirts covered by coarse-woven red tunics. They did not ride their horses very well, Garion noted, and their curved swords and broad, round shields seemed to get in their way as they attempted to manage their reins.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6R4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6R5">Garion carefully kept his head down to hide the fact that his features – even more than Silk’s – were distinctly non-Angarak. The guards, however, paid little attention to the conscripts as individuals, but seemed rather to be more interested in them as numbers. They rode continually up and down the sweating column, counting bodies and referring to a document they carried with concerned, even worried expressions. Garion surmised that unpleasant things would happen if the numbers did not match when they reached Yar Nadrak.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6R6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6R7">A faint, pale flicker in the underbrush some distance uphill from the trail caught Garion’s eye, and he turned his head sharply in that direction. A large, silver-gray wolf was ghosting along just at the edge of the trees, his pace exactly matching theirs. Garion quickly lowered his head again, pretended to stumble, and fell heavily against Silk. ‘Grandfather’s out there,’ he whispered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6R8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6R9">‘Did you only just notice him?’ Silk sounded surprised. ‘I’ve been watching him for the last hour or more.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6RA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6RB">When the trail turned away from the river and entered the trees, Garion felt the tension building up in him. He could not be sure what Belgarath was going to do, but he knew that the concealment offered by the forest provided the opportunity for which his grandfather had doubtless been waiting. He tried to hide his growing nervousness as he walked along behind Silk, but the slightest sound in the woods around them made him start uncontrollably.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6RC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6RD">The trail dipped down into a fair-sized clearing, surrounded on all sides by tall ferns, and the Mallorean guards halted the column to allow their prisoners to rest. Garion sank gratefully to the springy turf beside Silk. The effort of walking with one leg shackled to the long chain which bound the conscripts together was considerable, and he found that he was sweating profusely. ‘What’s he waiting for?’ he whispered to Silk.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6RE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6RF">The rat-faced little man shrugged. ‘It’s still a few hours until dark,’ he replied softly. ‘Maybe he wants to wait for that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6RG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6RH">Then, some distance up the trail, they heard the sound of singing. The song was ribald and badly out of tune, but the singer was quite obviously enjoying himself, and the slurring of the words as he drew closer indicated that he was more than a little drunk.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6RI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6RJ">The Malloreans grinned at each other. ‘Another patriot, perhaps,’ one of them smirked, ‘coming to enlist. Spread out, and we’ll gather him up as soon as he comes into the clearing.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6RK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6RL">The singing Nadrak rode into view on a large roan horse. He wore the usual dark, stained leather clothing, and a fur cap perched precariously on one side of his head. He had a scraggly black beard, and he carried a wineskin in one hand. He seemed to be swaying in his saddle as he rode, but something about his eyes showed him not to be quite so drunk as he appeared. Garion stared at him openly as he rode into the clearing with a string of mules behind him. It was Yarblek, the Nadrak merchant they had encountered on the South Caravan Route in Cthol Murgos.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6RM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6RN">‘Ho, there!’ Yarblek greeted the Malloreans in a loud voice. ‘I see you’ve had good hunting. That’s a healthy-looking bunch of recruits you’ve got there.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6RO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6RP">‘The hunting just got easier.’ One of the Malloreans grinned at him, pulling his horse across the trail to block Yarblek’s way.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6RQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6RR">‘You mean me?’ Yarblek laughed uproariously. ‘Don’t be a fool. I’m too busy to play soldier.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6RS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6RT">‘That’s a shame,’ the Mallorean replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6RU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6RV">‘I’m Yarblek, a merchant of Yar Turak and a friend of King Drosta himself. I’m acting on a commission that he personally put into my hands. If you interfere with me in any way, Drosta will have you flayed and roasted alive as soon as you get to Yar Nadrak.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6S0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6S1">The Mallorean looked a trifle less sure of himself. ‘We answer only to ‘Zakath,’ he asserted a bit defensively. ‘King Drosta has no authority over us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6S2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6S3">‘You’re in Gar og Nadrak, friend,’ Yarblek pointed out to him, ‘and Drosta does whatever he likes here. He might have to apologize to ‘Zakath after it’s all over, but by then the five of you will probably be peeled and cooked to a turn.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6S4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6S5">‘I suppose you can prove that you’re on official business?’ the Mallorean guard hedged.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6S6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6S7">‘Of course I can,’ Yarblek replied. He scratched at his head, his face taking on an expression of foolish perplexity. ‘Where did I put that parchment?’ he muttered to himself. Then he snapped his fingers. ‘Oh, yes,’ he said, ‘now I remember. It’s in the pack on that last mule. Here, have a drink, and I’ll go get it.’ He tossed the wineskin to the Mallorean, turned his horse and rode back to the end of his pack string. He dismounted and began rummaging through a canvas pack.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6S8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6S9">‘We’d better have a look at his documents before we decide,’ one of the others advised. ‘King Drosta’s not the sort you want to cross.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6SA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6SB">‘We might as well have a drink while we’re waiting,’ another suggested, eyeing the wineskin.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6SC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6SD">‘That’s one thing we can agree on,’ the first replied, working loose the stopper of the leather bag. He raised the skin with both hands and lifted his chin to drink.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6SE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6SF">There was a solid-sounding thud, and the feathered shaft of an arrow was quite suddenly protruding from his throat, just at the top of his red tunic. The wine gushed from the skin to pour down over his astonished face. His companions gaped at him, then reached for their weapons with cries of alarm, but it was too late. Most of them tumbled from their saddles in the sudden storm of arrows that struck them from the concealment of the ferns. One, however, wheeled his mount to flee, clutching at the shaft buried deep in his side. The horse took no more than two leaps before three arrows sank into the Mallorean’s back. He stiffened, then toppled over limply, his foot hanging up in his stirrup as he fell, and his frightened horse bolted, dragging him, bouncing and flopping, back down the trail.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6SG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6SH">‘I can’t seem to locate that document,’ Yarblek declared, walking back with a wicked grin on his face. He turned the Mallorean he had been speaking to over with his foot. ‘You didn’t really want to see it anyway, did you?’ he asked the dead man.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6SI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6SJ">The Mallorean with the arrow in his throat stared blankly up at the sky, his mouth agape and a trickle of blood running out of his nose.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6SK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6SL">‘I didn’t think so.’ Yarblek laughed coarsely. He drew back his foot and kicked the dead man back over onto his face. Then he turned to smirk at Silk as his archers came out of the dark green ferns. ‘You certainly get around, Silk,’ he said. ‘I thought Taur Urgas had finished you back there in stinking Cthol Murgos.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6SM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6SN">‘He miscalculated,’ Silk replied casually.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6SO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6SP">‘How did you manage to get yourself conscripted into the Mallorean army?’ Yarblek asked curiously, all traces of his feigned drunkenness gone now.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6SQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6SR">Silk shrugged. ‘I got careless.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6SS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6ST">‘I’ve been following you for the last three days.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6SU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6SV">‘I’m touched by your concern.’ Silk lifted his fettered ankle and jingled the chain. ‘Would it be too much trouble for you to unlock this?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6T0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6T1">‘You’re not going to do anything foolish, are you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6T2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6T3">‘Of course not.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6T4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6T5">‘Find the key,’ Yarblek told one of his archers.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6T6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6T7">‘What are you going to do with us?’ Besher asked nervously, eyeing the dead guards with a certain apprehension.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6T8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6T9">Yarblek laughed. ‘What you do once that chain’s off is up to you,’ he answered indifferently. ‘I wouldn’t recommend staying in the vicinity of so many dead Malloreans, though. Somebody might come along and start asking questions.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6TA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6TB">‘You’re just going to let us go?’ Besher demanded incredulously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6TC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6TD">‘I’m certainly not going to feed you,’ Yarblek told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6TE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6TF">The archers went down the chain, unlocking the shackles, and each Nadrak bolted into the bushes as soon as he was free.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6TG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6TH">‘Well, then,’ Yarblek said, rubbing his palms together, ‘now that that’s been taken care of, why don’t we have a drink?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6TI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6TJ">‘That guard spilled all your wine when he fell off his horse,’ Silk pointed out.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6TK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6TL">‘That wasn’t my wine,’ Yarblek snorted. ‘I stole it this morning. You should know I wouldn’t offer my own drink to somebody I planned to kill.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6TM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6TN">‘I wondered about that.’ Silk grinned at him. ‘I thought that maybe your manners had started to slip.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6TO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6TP">Yarblek’s coarse face took on a faintly injured expression.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6TQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6TR">‘Sorry,’ Silk apologized quickly. ‘I misjudged you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6TS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6TT">‘No harm done.’ Yarblek shrugged. ‘A lot of people misunderstand me.’ He sighed. ‘It’s a burden I have to bear.’ He opened a pack on his lead mule and hefted out a small keg of ale. He set it on the ground and broached it with a practiced skill, bashing in its top with his fist. ‘Let’s get drunk,’ he suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6TU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6TV">‘We’d really like to,’ Silk declined politely, ‘but we’ve got some rather urgent business to take care of.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6U0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6U1">‘You have no idea how sorry I am about that,’ Yarblek replied, fishing several cups out of the pack.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6U2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6U3">‘I knew you’d understand.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6U4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6U5">‘Oh, I understand, all right, Silk.’ Yarblek bent and dipped two cups into the ale keg. ‘And I’m as sorry as I can be that your business is going to have to wait. Here.’ He gave Silk one cup and Garion the other. Then he turned and dipped out a cup for himself.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6U6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6U7">Silk looked at him with one raised eyebrow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6U8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6U9">Yarblek sprawled on the ground beside the ale keg, comfortably resting his feet on the body of one of the dead Malloreans. ‘You see, Silk,’ he explained, ‘the whole point of all this is that Drosta wants you – very badly. He’s offering a reward for you that’s just </span><span class="italic" aid="BE6UA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6UB">too</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6UC"> attractive to pass up. Friendship is one thing, but business is business, after all. Now, why don’t you and your young friend make yourselves comfortable? This is a nice, shady clearing with soft moss to lie on. We’ll all get drunk, and you can tell me how you managed to escape from Taur Urgas. Then you can tell me what happened to that handsome woman you had with you down in Cthol Murgos. Maybe I can make enough money from this to be able to afford to buy her. I’m not the marrying kind, but by Torak’s teeth, that’s a fine-looking woman. I’d almost be willing to give up my freedom for her.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6UD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6UE">‘I’m sure she’d be flattered,’ Silk replied. ‘What then?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6UF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6UG">‘What when?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6UH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6UI">‘After we get drunk. What do we do then?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="BE6UJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="BE6UK">‘We’ll probably get sick – that’s what usually happens. After we get well, we’ll run on down to Yar Nadrak. I’ll collect the reward for you, and you’ll be able to find out why King Drosta lek Thun wants to get his hands on you so badly.’ He looked at Silk with an amused expression. ‘You might as well sit down and have a drink, my friend. You aren’t going anywhere just now.’</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_12" aid="BE6UL"></div>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
  <link href="kindle:flow:0001?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
<link href="kindle:flow:0002?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
</head>
  <body class="calibre" aid="CCNA0">
</body>
</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos159600" aid="CCNA1"><span class="calibre5" aid="CCNA2"><span class="italic" aid="CCNA3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNA4">Chapter Five</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="CCNA5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNA6">Yar Nadrak was a walled city, lying at the juncture of the east and west forks of the River Cordu. The forests had been cleared for a league or so in every direction from the capital by the simple expedient of setting fire to it, and the approach to the city passed through a wilderness of burned black snags and rank-growing bramble thickets. The city gates were stout and smeared with tar. Surmounting them was a stone replica of the mask of Torak. That beautiful, inhumanly cruel face gazed down at all who entered, and Garion suppressed a shudder as he rode under it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNA7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNA8">The houses in the Nadrak capital were all very tall and had steeply sloping roofs. The windows of the second storeys all had shutters, and most of the shutters were closed. Any exposed wood on the structures had been smeared with tar to preserve it, and the splotches of the black substance made all the buildings look somehow diseased.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNA9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNAA">There was a sullen, frightened air in the narrow, crooked streets of Yar Nadrak, and the inhabitants kept their eyes lowered as they hurried about their business. There appeared to be less leather involved in the clothing of the burghers of the capital than had been the case in the back country, but even here most garments were black, and only occasionally was there a splash of blue or yellow. The sole exception to this rule was the red tunic worn by the Mallorean soldiers. They seemed to be everywhere, roaming at will up and down the cobblestoned streets, accosting citizens rudely and talking loudly to each other in their heavily accented speech.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNAB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNAC">While the soldiers seemed for the most part to be merely swaggering bullies, young men who concealed their nervousness at being in a strange country with an outward show of bluster and braggadocio, the Mallorean Grolims were quite another matter. Unlike the western Grolims Garion had seen in Cthol Murgos, they rarely wore the polished steel mask, but rather assumed a set, grim expression, thin-lipped and narrow-eyed; as they went about the streets in their hooded black robes, everyone, Mallorean and Nadrak alike, gave way to them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNAD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNAE">Garion and Silk, closely guarded and mounted on a pair of mules, followed the rangy Yarblek into the city. Yarblek and Silk had kept up their banter during the entire ride downriver, exchanging casual insults and reliving past indiscretions. Although he seemed friendly enough, Yarblek nonetheless remained watchful, and his men had guarded Silk and Garion every step of the way. Garion had covertly watched the forest almost continually during the three-day ride, but he had seen no sign of Belgarath and he entered the city in a state of jumpy apprehension. Silk, however, seemed relaxed and confident as always, and his behavior and attitude grated at Garion’s nerves, for some reason.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNAF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNAG">After they had clattered along a crooked street for some distance, Yarblek turned down a narrow, dirty alleyway leading toward the river.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNAH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNAI">‘I thought the palace was that way,’ Silk said to him, pointing toward the center of town.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNAJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNAK">‘It is,’ Yarblek replied, ‘but we aren’t going to the palace. Drosta’s got company there, and he prefers to do business in private.’ The alleyway soon opened out into a seedy-looking street where the tall, narrow-looking houses had fallen somewhat into disrepair. The lanky Nadrak clamped his mouth shut as two Mallorean Grolims rounded a corner just ahead and came in their direction. Yarblek’s expression was openly hostile as the two approached.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNAL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNAM">One of them stopped to return his gaze. ‘You seem to have a problem, friend,’ the Grolim suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNAN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNAO">‘That’s my business, isn’t it?’ Yarblek retorted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNAP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNAQ">‘Indeed it is,’ the Grolim replied coolly. ‘Don’t let it get out of hand, though. Open disrespect for the priesthood is the sort of thing that could get you into serious trouble.’ The black-robed man’s look was threatening.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNAR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNAS">On a sudden impulse, Garion carefully pushed out his mind toward the Grolim, probing very gently, but the thoughts he encountered showed no particular awareness and certainly none of the aura that always seemed to emanate from the mind of a sorcerer.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNAT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNAU">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="CCNAV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNB0">Don’t do that</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNB1">,’ the voice in his mind cautioned him. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="CCNB2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNB3">It’s like ringing a bell or wearing a sign around your neck.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNB4">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNB5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNB6">Garion quickly pulled back his thoughts. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="CCNB7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNB8">I thought all Grolims were sorcerers</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNB9">,’ he replied silently. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="CCNBA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBB">These two are just ordinary men.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBC">’ But the other awareness was gone.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNBD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBE">The two Grolims passed, and Yarblek spat contemptuously into the street. ‘Pigs,’ he muttered. ‘I’m starting to dislike Malloreans almost as much as Murgos.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNBF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBG">‘They seem to be taking over your country, Yarblek,’ Silk observed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNBH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBI">Yarblek grunted. ‘Let one Mallorean in, and before long they’re underfoot everywhere.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNBJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBK">‘Why did you let them in to begin with?’ Silk asked mildly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNBL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBM">‘Silk,’ Yarblek said bluntly, ‘I know you’re a spy, and I’m </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNBN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBO">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBP"> going to discuss politics with you, so quit fishing for information.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNBQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBR">‘Just passing the time of day,’ Silk replied innocently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNBS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBT">‘Why don’t you mind your own business?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNBU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNBV">‘But this </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNC0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNC1">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNC2"> my business, old friend.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNC3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNC4">Yarblek stared hard at him, then suddenly laughed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNC5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNC6">‘Where are we going?’ Silk asked him, looking around at the shabby street. ‘This isn’t the best part of town, as I recall.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNC7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNC8">‘You’ll find out,’ Yarblek told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNC9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNCA">They rode on down toward the river where the smell of floating garbage and open sewers was quite nearly overpowering. Garion saw rats feeding in the gutters, and the men in the street wore shabby clothing and had the furtive look of those who have reason to avoid the police.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNCB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNCC">Yarblek turned his horse abruptly and led them into another narrow, filthy alleyway. ‘We walk from here,’ he said, dismounting. ‘I want to go in the back way.’ Leaving their mounts with one of his men, they went on down the alley, stepping carefully over piles of rotting garbage.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNCD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNCE">‘Down there,’ Yarblek told them, pointing at a short, rickety flight of wooden stairs leading down to a narrow doorway. ‘Once we get inside, keep your heads down. We don’t want too many people noticing that you’re not Nadraks.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNCF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNCG">They went down the creaking steps and slipped through the doorway into a dim, smoky tavern, reeking of sweat, spilled beer, and stale vomit. The fire pit in the center of the room was choked with ashes, and several large logs smoldered there, giving off a great deal of smoke and very little light. Two narrow, dirty windows at the front appeared only slightly less dark than the walls around them, and a single oil lamp hung on a chain nailed to one of the rafters.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNCH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNCI">‘Sit here,’ Yarblek instructed them, nudging at a bench standing against the back wall. ‘I’ll be right back.’ He went off toward the front part of the tavern. Garion looked around quickly, but saw immediately that a pair of Yarblek’s men lounged unobtrusively beside the door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNCJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNCK">‘What are we going to do?’ he whispered to Silk.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNCL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNCM">‘We don’t have much choice but to wait and see what happens,’ Silk replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNCN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNCO">‘You don’t seem very worried.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNCP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNCQ">‘I’m not, really.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNCR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNCS">‘But we’ve been arrested, haven’t we?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNCT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNCU">Silk shook his head. ‘When you arrest somebody, you put shackles on him. King Drosta wants to talk to me, that’s all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNCV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCND0">‘But that reward notice said—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCND1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCND2">‘I wouldn’t pay too much attention to that, Garion. The reward notice was for the benefit of the Malloreans. Whatever Drosta’s up to, he doesn’t want them finding out about it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCND3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCND4">Yarblek threaded his way back through the crowd in the tavern and thumped himself down on the grimy bench beside them. ‘Drosta should be here, shortly,’ he said. ‘You want something to drink while we’re waiting?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCND5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCND6">Silk looked around with a faint expression of distaste. ‘I don’t think so,’ he replied. ‘The ale barrels in places like this usually have a few drowned rats floating in them – not to mention the dead flies and roaches.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCND7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCND8">‘Suit yourself,’ Yarblek said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCND9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDA">‘Isn’t this a peculiar sort of place to find a king?’ Garion asked, looking around at the shabby interior of the tavern.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNDB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDC">‘You have to know King Drosta to understand,’ Silk told him. ‘He has some rather notorious appetites, and these riverfront dives suit him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNDD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDE">Yarblek laughed in agreement. ‘Our monarch’s a lusty sort of fellow,’ he noted, ‘but don’t ever make the mistake of thinking he’s stupid – a little crude, perhaps, but not stupid. He can come to a place like this, and no Mallorean will take the trouble to follow him. He’s found that it’s a good way to conduct business that he prefers not to have reported back to ‘Zakath.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNDF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDG">There was a stir near the front of the tavern, and two heavy-shouldered Nadraks in black leather tunics and pointed helmets pushed their way through the door. ‘Make way!’ one of them barked. ‘And everybody rise!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNDH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDI">‘Those who are </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNDJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDK">able</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDL"> to rise,’ the other added dryly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNDM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDN">A wave of jeers and catcalls ran through the crowd as a thin man in a yellow satin doublet and a furtrimmed green velvet cloak entered. His eyes were bulging and his face was deeply scarred with old pockmarks. His movements were quick and jerky, and his expression was a curious mixture of sardonic amusement and a kind of desperate, unsatisfied hunger.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNDO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDP">‘All hail his Majesty, Drosta lek Thun, King of the Nadraks!’ one drunken man proclaimed in a loud voice, and the others in the tavern laughed coarsely, jeering and whistling and stamping their feet.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNDQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDR">‘My faithful subjects,’ the pockmarked man replied with a gross smirk. ‘Drunks, thieves, and procurers. I bask in the warm glow of your love for me.’ His contempt seemed directed almost as much at himself as at the ragged, unwashed crowd.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNDS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDT">They whistled in unison and stamped their feet derisively.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNDU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNDV">‘How many tonight, Drosta?’ someone shouted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNE0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNE1">‘As many as I can.’ The king leered. ‘It’s my duty to spread royal blessings wherever I go.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNE2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNE3">‘Is that what you call it?’ someone else demanded raucously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNE4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNE5">‘It’s as good a name as any,’ Drosta replied with a shrug.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNE6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNE7">‘The royal bedchamber awaits,’ the tavern owner declaimed with a mocking bow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNE8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNE9">‘Along with the royal bedbugs, I’m sure,’ Drosta added. ‘Ale for every man not too drunk to swill it down. Let my loyal subjects drink to my vitality.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNEA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNEB">The crowd cheered as the king pushed toward a stairway leading to the upper storeys of the building. ‘My duty awaits me,’ he proclaimed, pointing with a grand gesture up the stairs. ‘Let all take note of how eagerly I go to embrace that stern responsibility.’ And he mounted the stairs to the derisive applause of the assembled riffraff.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNEC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNED">‘What now?’ Silk asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNEE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNEF">‘We’ll wait a bit,’ Yarblek replied. ‘It would be a little obvious if we went up immediately.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNEG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNEH">Garion shifted uncomfortably on the bench. A very faint, nervous kind of tingle had begun just behind his ears, a sort of prickling sensation that seemed to crawl over his skin. He had an unpleasant thought or two about the possibility of lice or fleas migrating from the scum in the tavern in search of fresh blood, but dismissed that idea. The tingling did not seem to be external.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNEI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNEJ">At a table not far away, a shabbily dressed man, apparently far gone in drink, had been snoring with his head buried in his arms. In the middle of a snore he raised his face briefly and winked. It was Belgarath. He let his face drop back onto his arms as a wave of relief swept through Garion.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNEK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNEL">The drunken crowd in the tavern grew steadily more rowdy. A short, ugly fight broke out near the fire pit, and the revelers at first cheered, then joined in, kicking at the two who rolled about on the floor.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNEM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNEN">‘Let’s go up,’ Yarblek said shortly, rising to his feet. He pushed through the crowd and started upstairs.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNEO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNEP">‘Grandfather’s here,’ Garion whispered to Silk as they followed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNEQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNER">‘I saw him,’ Silk replied shortly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNES"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNET">The stairs led to a dim upper hallway with dirty, threadbare carpeting on the floor. At the far end, King Drosta’s two bored-looking guards leaned against the wall on either side of a solid door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNEU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNEV">‘My name’s Yarblek,’ Silk’s friend told them as he reached the door. ‘Drosta’s expecting me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNF0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNF1">The guards glanced at each other, then one tapped on the door. ‘That man you wanted to see is here, your Majesty.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNF2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNF3">‘Send him in.’ Drosta’s voice was muffled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNF4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNF5">‘He isn’t alone,’ the guard advised.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNF6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNF7">‘That’s all right.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNF8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNF9">‘Go ahead,’ the guard said to Yarblek, unlatching the door and pushing it open.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNFA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNFB">The king of the Nadraks was sprawled on a rumpled bed with his arms about the thin shoulders of a pair of dirty, scantily dressed young girls with tangled hair and hopeless-looking eyes. ‘Yarblek,’ the depraved monarch greeted the merchant, ‘what kept you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNFC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNFD">‘I didn’t want to attract attention by following you immediately, Drosta.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNFE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNFF">‘I almost got sidetracked.’ Drosta leered at the two girls. ‘Aren’t they luscious?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNFG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNFH">‘If you like the type.’ Yarblek shrugged. ‘I prefer a little more maturity.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNFI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNFJ">‘That’s good, too,’ Drosta admitted, ‘but I love them all. I fall in love twenty times a day. Run along, my pretties,’ he told the girls. ‘I’ve got some business to take care of just now. I’ll send for you later.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNFK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNFL">The two girls immediately left, closing the door quietly behind them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNFM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNFN">Drosta sat up on the bed, scratching absently at one armpit. His stained and rumpled yellow doublet was unbuttoned, and his bony chest was covered with coarse black hair. He was thin, almost emaciated, and his scrawny arms looked like two sticks. His hair was lank and greasy, and his beard was so thin that it was little more than a few scraggly-looking black hairs sprouting from his chin. The pockmarks on his face were deep, angry red scars, and his neck and hands were covered with an unwholesome, scabby-looking rash. There was a distinctly unpleasant odor about him. ‘Are you sure this is the man I want?’ he asked Yarblek. Garion looked at the Nadrak King sharply. The coarseness had gone out of his voice, and his tone was incisive, direct, the tone of a man who was all business. Garion made a few quick mental adjustments. Drosta lek Thun was not at all what he seemed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNFO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNFP">‘I’ve known him for years, Drosta,’ Yarblek replied. ‘This is Prince Kheldar of Drasnia. He’s also known as Silk and sometimes Ambar of Kotu or Radek of Boktor. He’s a thief, a swindler, and a spy. Aside from that, he’s not too bad.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNFQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNFR">‘We are delighted to meet so famous a man,’ King Drosta declared. ‘Welcome, Prince Kheldar.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNFS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNFT">‘Your Majesty,’ Silk replied, bowing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNFU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNFV">‘I’d have invited you to the palace,’ Drosta continued, ‘but I’ve got some house guests with the unfortunate habit of sticking their noses into my business.’ He laughed dryly. ‘Luckily, I found out very soon that Malloreans are a priggish race. They won’t follow me into places like this, so we’ll be able to talk freely.’ He looked around at the cheap, gaudy furnishings and red draperies with a sort of amused toleration. ‘Besides,’ he added, ‘I like it here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNG0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNG1">Garion stood with his back against the wall near the door, trying to remain as unobtrusive as possible, but Drosta’s nervous eyes picked him out. ‘Can he be trusted?’ the king demanded of Silk.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNG2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNG3">‘Completely,’ Silk assured him. ‘He’s my apprentice. I’m teaching him the business.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNG4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNG5">‘Which business? Stealing or spying?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNG6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNG7">Silk shrugged. ‘It amounts to the same thing. Yarblek says you wanted to see me. I assume it has something to do with current matters rather than any past misunderstandings.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNG8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNG9">‘You’re quick, Kheldar,’ Drosta replied approvingly. ‘I need your help and I’m willing to pay for it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNGA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGB">Silk grinned. ‘I’m fond of the word pay.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNGC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGD">‘So I’ve heard. Do you know what’s going on here in Gar og Nadrak?’ Drosta’s eyes were penetrating, and his veneer of gross self-indulgence had fallen completely away.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNGE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGF">‘I </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNGG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGH">am</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGI"> in the intelligence service, your Majesty,’ Silk pointed out.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNGJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGK">Drosta grunted, stood up, and went to a table where a decanter of wine and several glasses stood. ‘Drink?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNGL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGM">‘Why not?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNGN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGO">Drosta filled four glasses, took one for himself and paced nervously about the room with an angry expression. ‘I don’t </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNGP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGQ">need</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGR"> any of this, Kheldar,’ he burst out. ‘My family’s spent generations – centuries – weaning Gar og Nadrak away from the domination of the Grolims. Now they’re about to drag us back into howling barbarism again, and I don’t have any choice but to go along with it. I’ve got a quarter of a million Malloreans roaming around at will inside my borders and an army I can’t even count poised just to the south. If I raise so much as one word of protest, ‘Zakath will crush my kingdom with one fist.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNGS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGT">‘Would he really do that?’ Silk asked, taking a chair at the table.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNGU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNGV">‘With just about as much emotion as you’d feel about swatting a fly,’ Drosta replied. ‘Have you ever met him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNH0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNH1">Silk shook his head.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNH2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNH3">‘You’re lucky,’ Drosta told him with a shudder. ‘Taur Urgas is a madman, but, much as I hate him, he’s still human. ‘Zakath is made out of ice. I’ve </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNH4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNH5">got</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNH6"> to get in touch with Rhodar.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNH7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNH8">‘Ah,’ Silk said. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="CCNH9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHA">That’s</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHB"> what this is all about, then.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNHC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHD">‘You’re a nice enough fellow, Kheldar,’ Drosta told him dryly, ‘but I wouldn’t go to all this trouble just for the pleasure of your company. You’ve got to carry my message to Rhodar. I’ve tried to get word to him, but I can’t catch up with him. He won’t stay in one place long enough. How can a fat man move so cursed fast?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNHE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHF">‘He’s deceptive,’ Silk said shortly. ‘Exactly what have you got in mind?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNHG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHH">‘An alliance,’ Drosta replied bluntly. ‘My back’s against the wall. Either I ally myself with Rhodar, or I get swallowed up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNHI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHJ">Silk carefully set down his glass. ‘That’s a very large suggestion, your Majesty. In the present situation, it’s going to take a great deal of fast talking to arrange.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNHK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHL">‘That’s why I sent for you, Kheldar. We’re staring the end of the world right in the face. You’ve got to get to Rhodar and persuade him to pull his army back from the Thull border.
