Make him stop this insanity before it goes too far.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNHM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHN">‘Making my uncle do things is a little beyond my abilities, King Drosta,’ Silk replied carefully. ‘I’m flattered that you think I’ve got that much influence with him, but things have usually been the other way around between us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNHO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHP">‘Don’t you understand what’s going on, Kheldar?’ King Drosta’s voice was anguished, and he gesticulated almost wildly as he spoke. ‘Our only hope of survival lies in not giving the Murgos and the Malloreans any kind of reason to unite. We should work to stir up trouble between them, not to provide them with a common enemy. Taur Urgas and ‘Zakath hate each other with a passion so intense that it’s almost holy. There are more Murgos than grains of sand and more Malloreans than stars. The Grolims can babble their gibberish about the awakening of Torak until their tongues fall out, but Taur Urgas and ‘Zakath have taken the field for just one reason – each of them wants to destroy the other and make himself overking of Angarak. They’re headed directly toward a war of mutual extinction. We can be rid of both of them if we just don’t interfere.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNHQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHR">‘I think I see what you mean,’ Silk murmured.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNHS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHT">‘’Zakath is ferrying his Malloreans across the Sea of the East to his staging area near Thull Zelik, and Taur Urgas has the southern Murgos massed near Rak Goska. Inevitably, they’re going to move on each other. We’ve </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNHU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNHV">got</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNI0"> to stay out of the way and let them fight. Make Rhodar pull back before he spoils everything.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNI1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNI2">‘Have you talked with the Thulls about this?’ Silk asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNI3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNI4">Drosta snorted with contempt. ‘What’s the point? I’ve tried to explain this to King Gethell, but talking to him is like talking to a pile of manure. The Thulls are so afraid of the Grolims that all you have to do is mention Torak’s name and they go all to pieces. Gethell’s a Thull through and through. There’s nothing between his ears but sand.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNI5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNI6">‘There’s just one problem with all of this, Drosta,’ Silk told the agitated monarch. ‘I can’t carry your message to King Rhodar.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNI7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNI8">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="CCNI9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNIA">Can’t?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNIB">’ Drosta exploded. ‘What do you mean, you </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNIC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNID">can’t</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNIE">?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNIF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNIG">‘My uncle and I aren’t on the best of terms just now,’ Silk lied smoothly. ‘We had a little misunderstanding a few months ago, and about the first thing he’d do, if he saw me coming, is have me put in chains – and I’m almost certain things would go downhill from there.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNIH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNII">Drosta groaned. ‘We’re all doomed then,’ he declared, seeming to slump in on himself. ‘You were my last hope.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNIJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNIK">‘Let me think a moment,’ Silk said. ‘We might be able to salvage something out of this yet.’ He stared at the floor, chewing absently on a fingernail as he turned the problem over in his mind. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="CCNIL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNIM">I</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNIN"> can’t go,’ he concluded. ‘That’s obvious. But that doesn’t mean that somebody else couldn’t.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNIO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNIP">‘Who else would Rhodar trust?’ Drosta demanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNIQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNIR">Silk turned to Yarblek, who had been listening to the conversation intently with a worried frown. ‘Are you in any kind of trouble in Drasnia at the moment?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNIS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNIT">‘Not that I know of.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNIU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNIV">‘All right,’ Silk continued. ‘There’s a fur dealer in Boktor – Geldahar’s his name.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJ0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJ1">‘Fat man? Sort of cross-eyed?’ Yarblek asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJ2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJ3">‘That’s him. Why don’t you take a shipment of furs and go to Boktor? While you’re trying to sell Geldahar the furs, tell him that the salmon run is late this year.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJ4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJ5">‘I’m sure he’ll be fascinated to hear that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJ6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJ7">‘It’s a code-word,’ Silk explained with exaggerated patience. ‘As soon as you say that, he’ll see to it that you get into the palace to see Queen Porenn.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJ8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJ9">‘I’ve heard that she’s a lovely woman,’ Yarblek said, ‘but that’s a long trip just to see a pretty girl. I can probably find a pretty girl just down the hall.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJB">‘You’re missing the point, Yarblek,’ Silk told him. ‘Porenn is Rhodar’s queen, and he trusts her even more than he used to trust me. She’ll know that I sent you, and she’ll pass anything you tell her on to my uncle. Rhodar will be reading Drosta’s message three days after you ride into Boktor. I guarantee it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJD">‘You’d let a </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNJE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJF">woman</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJG"> know about all this?’ Drosta objected violently. ‘Kheldar, you’re insane. The only woman safe with a secret is one who’s had her tongue cut out.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJI">Silk shook his head firmly. ‘Porenn’s in control of Drasnian intelligence right now, Drosta. She already knows most of the secrets in the world. You’re never going to get an emissary through an Alorn army to Rhodar, so forget that. There’ll be Chereks with him, and they’ll kill any Angarak on sight. If you want to communicate with Rhodar, you’re going to have to use Drasnian intelligence as an intermediary, and that means going through Porenn.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJK">Drosta looked dubious. ‘Maybe,’ he concluded after a moment’s thought. ‘I’ll try anything at this point – but why should Yarblek get involved? Why can’t </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNJL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJM">you</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJN"> carry my message to the Drasnian queen?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJP">Silk looked a trifle pained. ‘That wouldn’t be a good idea at all, I’m afraid,’ he replied. ‘Porenn was rather central to my difficulties with my uncle. I’m definitely unwelcome at the palace just now.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJR">One of King Drosta’s shaggy eyebrows shot up. ‘So </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNJS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJT">that’s</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNJU"> the way it is.’ He laughed. ‘Your reputation’s well-earned, I see.’ He turned to Yarblek. ‘It’s up to you, then. Make the necessary arrangements for the trip to Boktor.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNJV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNK0">‘You already owe me money, Drosta,’ Yarblek replied bluntly, ‘the reward for bringing in Kheldar, remember?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNK1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNK2">Drosta shrugged. ‘Write it down someplace.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNK3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNK4">Yarblek shook his head stubbornly. ‘Not hardly. Let’s keep your account current. You’re known as a slow payer, once you’ve got what you want.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNK5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNK6">‘Yarblek,’ Drosta said plaintively, ‘I’m your king.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNK7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNK8">Yarblek inclined his head somewhat mockingly. ‘I honor and respect your Majesty,’ he said, ‘but business is business, after all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNK9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKA">‘I don’t carry that much money with me,’ Drosta protested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNKB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKC">‘That’s all right, Drosta. I can wait.’ Yarblek crossed his arms and sat down in a large chair with the air of a man planning to stay for quite some time.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNKD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKE">The king of the Nadraks stared at him helplessly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNKF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKG">Then the door opened and Belgarath stepped into the room, still dressed in the rags he had worn in the tavern downstairs. There was no furtiveness about his entrance, and he moved like a man on serious business.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNKH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKI">‘What </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNKJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKK">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKL"> this?’ Drosta exclaimed incredulously. ‘Guards!’ he bawled, ‘get this drunken old man out of here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNKM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKN">‘They’re asleep, Drosta,’ Belgarath replied calmly. ‘Don’t be too harsh with them, though. It’s not their fault.’ He closed the door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNKO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKP">‘Who are you? What do you think you’re doing?’ Drosta demanded. ‘Get out of here!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNKQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKR">‘I think you’d better take a closer look, Drosta,’ Silk advised with a dry little chuckle. ‘Appearances can be deceiving sometimes, and you shouldn’t be so quick to try to throw somebody out. He might have something important to say to you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNKS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKT">‘Do you know him, Kheldar?’ Drosta asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNKU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNKV">‘Just about everybody in the world knows him,’ Silk replied. ‘Or </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNL0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNL1">of</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNL2"> him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNL3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNL4">Drosta’s face creased into a puzzled frown, but Yarblek had started from his chair, his lean face suddenly pale. ‘Drosta!’ he gasped. ‘Look at him. Think a minute. You know who he is.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNL5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNL6">Drosta stared at the shabby-looking old man, and his bulging eyes slowly opened even wider. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="CCNL7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNL8">You!</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNL9">’ he blurted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNLA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNLB">Yarblek was still gaping at Belgarath. ‘He’s been involved in it from the very beginning. I should have put it together down in Cthol Murgos – him, the woman, all of it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNLC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNLD">‘What are you doing in Gar og Nadrak?’ Drosta asked in an awed voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNLE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNLF">‘Just passing through, Drosta,’ Belgarath replied. ‘If you’re quite finished with your discussion here, I need these two Alorns. We have an appointment, and we’re running a little behind schedule.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNLG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNLH">‘I always thought you were a myth.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNLI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNLJ">‘I like to encourage that as much as I can,’ Belgarath told him. ‘It makes moving around a lot easier.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNLK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNLL">‘Are you mixed up in what the Alorns are doing?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNLM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNLN">‘They’re acting more or less on my suggestions, yes. Polgara’s keeping an eye on them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNLO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNLP">‘Can </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNLQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNLR">you</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNLS"> get word to them and tell them to disengage?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNLT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNLU">‘That won’t really be necessary, Drosta. I wouldn’t worry too much about ‘Zakath and Taur Urgas, if I were you. There are more important things afoot than their squabbles.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNLV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNM0">‘So </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNM1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNM2">that’s</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNM3"> what Rhodar’s doing,’ Drosta said in sudden comprehension. ‘Is it really that late?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNM4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNM5">‘It’s even later than you think,’ the old sorcerer answered. He crossed to the table and poured himself some of Drosta’s wine. ‘Torak’s already stirring, and the whole matter’s likely to be settled before the snow flies.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNM6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNM7">‘This is going too far, Belgarath,’ Drosta said. ‘I might try to maneuver my way around Taur Urgas and ‘Zakath, but I’m </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNM8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNM9">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNMA"> going to cross Torak.’ He turned decisively toward the door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNMB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNMC">‘Don’t do anything rash, Drosta,’ Belgarath advised him calmly, sitting in a chair and taking a sip of his wine. ‘Grolims can be most unreasonable, and the fact that I’m here in Yar Nadrak could only be viewed as the result of some collusion on your part. They’d have you bent backward over an altar and your heart sizzling in the coals before you ever got the chance to explain – king or no king.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNMD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNME">Drosta froze in his tracks, his pockmarked face going very pale. For a moment, he seemed to be struggling with himself. Then his shoulders slumped and his resolution seemed to wilt. ‘You’ve got me by the throat, haven’t you, Belgarath?’ he said with a short laugh. ‘You’ve managed to make me outsmart myself, and now you’re going to use that to force me to betray the God of Angarak.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNMF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNMG">‘Are you really all that fond of him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNMH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNMI">‘Nobody’s fond of Torak. I’m </span><span class="italic" aid="CCNMJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNMK">afraid</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNML"> of him, and that’s a better reason to stay on the good side of him than any sentimental attachment. If he wakes up—’ The king of the Nadraks shuddered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNMM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNMN">‘Have you ever given much thought to the kind of world we’d have if he didn’t exist?’ Belgarath suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNMO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNMP">‘That’s too much to even wish for. He’s a God. No one could hope to defeat him. He’s too powerful for that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNMQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNMR">‘There are things more powerful than Gods, Drosta – two that I can think of offhand, and those two are rushing toward a final meeting. It probably wouldn’t be a good idea to put yourself between them at this point.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNMS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNMT">But something else had occurred to Drosta. He turned slowly with a look of stunned incredulity and stared directly at Garion. He shook his head and wiped at his eyes, like a man trying to clear away a fog. Garion became painfully aware of the great sword strapped across his back. Drosta’s bulging eyes widened even more as the realization of what he was seeing erased the Orb’s suggestion that his brain not record what stood in plain sight before him. His expression became awed, and desperate hope dawned on his ugly face. ‘Your Majesty,’ he stammered, bowing with profound respect.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNMU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNMV">‘Your Majesty,’ Garion replied, politely inclining his head.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNN0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNN1">‘It looks as if I’m forced to wish you good luck,’ Drosta said in a quiet voice. ‘Despite what Belgarath says, I think you’re going to need it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="CCNN2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="CCNN3">‘Thank you, King Drosta,’ Garion said.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_13" aid="CCNN4"></div>

<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos204088" aid="DB7S1"><span class="calibre5" aid="DB7S2"><span class="italic" aid="DB7S3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7S4">Chapter Six</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="DB7S5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7S6">‘Do you think we can trust Drosta?’ Garion asked Silk as they followed Belgarath along the garbage-littered alley behind the tavern.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7S7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7S8">‘Probably about as far as we could throw him,’ Silk replied. ‘He was honest about </span><span class="italic" aid="DB7S9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7SA">one</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7SB"> thing though. His back’s to the wall. That might make him bargain with Rhodar in good faith – initially at least.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7SC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7SD">When they reached the street at the end of the alley, Belgarath glanced up once at the evening sky. ‘We’d better hurry,’ he said. ‘I want to get out of the city before they close the gates. I left our horses in a thicket a mile or so outside the walls.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7SE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7SF">‘You went back for them?’ Silk sounded a little surprised.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7SG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7SH">‘Of course I did. I don’t plan to walk all the way to Morindland.’ He led them up the street away from the river.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7SI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7SJ">They reached the city gates in fading light just as the guards were preparing to close them for the night. One of the Nadrak soldiers raised his hand as if to bar their way, then apparently changed his mind and motioned them through irritably, muttering curses under his breath. The huge, tar-smeared gate boomed shut behind them, and there was the clinking rattle of heavy chains from inside as the bolts were thrown and locked. Garion glanced up once at the carved face of Torak which brooded down at them from above the gate, then deliberately turned his back.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7SK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7SL">‘Are we likely to be followed?’ Silk asked Belgarath as they walked along the dirt highway leading away from the city.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7SM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7SN">‘I wouldn’t be very surprised,’ Belgarath replied. ‘Drosta knows – or suspects – a great deal about what we’re doing. Mallorean Grolims are very subtle, and they can pick the thoughts out of his head without his knowing it. That’s probably why they don’t bother to follow him when he goes off on his little excursions.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7SO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7SP">‘Shouldn’t you take some steps?’ Silk suggested as they moved through the gathering twilight.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7SQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7SR">‘We’re getting a bit too close to Mallorea to be making unnecessary noise,’ Belgarath told him. ‘Zedar can hear me moving around from a long way off, and Torak’s only dozing now. I’d rather not take the chance of waking him up with any more loud clatter.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7SS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7ST">They walked along the highway toward the shadowy line of rank undergrowth at the edge of the open fields surrounding the city. The sound of frogs from the marshy ground near the river was very loud in the twilight.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7SU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7SV">‘Torak isn’t really asleep any more then?’ Garion asked finally. He had harbored somewhere at the back of his mind the vague hope that they might be able to creep up on the sleeping God and catch him unaware.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7T0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7T1">‘No, not really,’ his grandfather replied. ‘The sound of your hand touching the Orb shook the whole world. Not even Torak could sleep through that. He isn’t really awake yet, but he’s not entirely asleep, either.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7T2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7T3">‘Did it really make all that much noise?’ Silk asked curiously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7T4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7T5">‘They probably heard it on the other side of the universe. I left the horses over there.’ The old man pointed toward a shadowy willow grove several hundred yards to the left of the road.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7T6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7T7">From behind them there was the rattle of a heavy chain, startling the frogs into momentary silence.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7T8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7T9">‘They’re opening the gate,’ Silk said. ‘They wouldn’t do that unless somebody gave them an official reason to.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7TA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7TB">‘Let’s hurry,’ Belgarath said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7TC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7TD">The horses stirred and nickered as the three of them pushed their way through the rustling willows in the rapidly descending darkness. They led the horses out of the grove, mounted, and rode back toward the highway.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7TE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7TF">‘They know we’re out here somewhere,’ Belgarath said. ‘There’s not much point being coy about it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7TG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7TH">‘Just a second,’ Silk said. He dismounted and rummaged through one of the canvas bags tied to their packhorse. He pulled something out of the bag, then climbed back on his horse. ‘Let’s go then.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7TI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7TJ">They pushed into a gallop, thudding along the dirt road under a starry, moonless sky toward the denser shadows where the forest rose at the edge of the scrubby, burned-off expanse surrounding the Nadrak capital.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7TK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7TL">‘Can you see them?’ Belgarath called to Silk, who was bringing up the rear and looking back over his shoulder.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7TM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7TN">‘I think so,’ Silk shouted back. ‘They’re about a mile behind.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7TO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7TP">‘That’s too close.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7TQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7TR">‘I’ll take care of it as soon as we get into the woods,’ Silk replied confidently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7TS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7TT">The dark forest loomed closer and closer as they galloped along the hard-packed road. Garion could smell the trees now.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7TU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7TV">They plunged into the black shadows under the trees and felt that slight extra warmth that always lies in a forest. Silk reined in sharply. ‘Keep going,’ he told them, swinging out of his saddle. ‘I’ll catch up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7U0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7U1">Belgarath and Garion rode on, slowing a bit in order to pick the road out of the darkness. After several minutes, Silk caught up with them. ‘Listen,’ the little man said, pulling his horse to a stop. His teeth flashed in the shadows as he grinned.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7U2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7U3">‘They’re coming,’ Garion warned urgently as he heard a rumble of hoofs. ‘Hadn’t we better—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7U4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7U5">‘Listen,’ Silk whispered sharply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7U6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7U7">From behind there were several startled exclamations and the heavy sound of men falling. A horse squealed and ran off somewhere.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7U8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7U9">Silk laughed wickedly. ‘I think we can press on,’ he said gaily. ‘They’ll be delayed for a bit while they round up their horses.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7UA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7UB">‘What did you do?’ Garion asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7UC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7UD">Silk shrugged. ‘I stretched a rope across the road, about chest-high on a mounted man. It’s an old trick, but sometimes old tricks are the best. They’ll have to be cautious now, so we should be able to lose them by morning.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7UE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7UF">‘Let’s go, then,’ Belgarath said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7UG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7UH">‘Where are we headed?’ Silk asked as they moved into a canter.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7UI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7UJ">‘We’ll make directly for the north range,’ the old man replied. ‘Too many people know we’re here, so let’s get to the land of the Morindim as soon as we can.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7UK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7UL">‘If they’re really after us, they’ll follow us all the way, won’t they?’ Garion asked, looking back nervously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7UM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7UN">‘I don’t think so,’ Belgarath told him. ‘They’ll be a long way behind by the time we get there. I don’t think they’ll risk going into Morind territory just to follow a cold trail.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7UO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7UP">‘Is it </span><span class="italic" aid="DB7UQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7UR">that</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7US"> dangerous, Grandfather?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7UT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7UU">‘The Morindim do nasty things to strangers if they catch them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7UV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7V0">Garion thought about that. ‘Won’t </span><span class="italic" aid="DB7V1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7V2">we</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7V3"> be strangers too?’ he asked. ‘To the Morindim, I mean?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7V4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7V5">‘I’ll take care of that when we get there.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7V6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7V7">They galloped on through the remainder of the velvety night, leaving their now-cautious pursuers far behind. The blackness beneath the trees was dotted with the pale, winking glow of fireflies, and crickets chirped interminably. As the first light of morning began to filter through the forest, they reached the edge of another burned-off area, and Belgarath reined in to peer cautiously out at the rank scrub, dotted here and there with charred snags. ‘We’d better have something to eat,’ he suggested. ‘The horses need some rest, and we can catch a bit of sleep before we go on.’ He looked around in the gradually increasing light. ‘Let’s get away from the road, though.’ He turned his horse and led them off along the edge of the burn. After several hundred yards, they reached a small clearing that jutted out into the coarse brush. A spring trickled water into a mossy pool at the very edge of the trees, and the grass in the clearing was intensely green. The outer edge of the opening was hemmed in by brambles and a tangle of charred limbs. ‘This looks like a good place,’ Belgarath decided.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7V8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7V9">‘Not really,’ Silk disagreed. He was staring at a crudely squared-off block of stone standing in the center of the clearing. There were ugly black stains running down the sides of the stone.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7VA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7VB">‘For our purposes it is,’ the old man replied. ‘The altars of Torak are generally avoided, and we don’t particularly want company.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7VC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7VD">They dismounted at the edge of the trees, and Belgarath began rummaging through one of the packs for bread and dried meat. Garion was in a curiously abstracted mood. He was tired, and his weariness made him a bit light-headed. Quite deliberately, he walked across the springy turf to the blood-stained altar; he stared at it, his eyes meticulously recording details without considering their implication. The blackened stone sat solidly in the center of the clearing, casting no shadow in the pale dawn light. It was an old altar, and had not been used recently. The stains that had sunk into the pores of the rock were black with age, and the bones littering the ground around it were half-sunk in the earth and were covered with a greenish patina of moss. A scurrying spider darted into the vacant eye socket of a mossy skull, seeking refuge in the dark, vaulted emptiness. Many of the bones were broken and showed the marks of the small, sharp teeth of forest scavengers who would feed on anything that was dead. A cheap, tarnished silver brooch lay with its chain tangled about a lumpy vertebra, and not far away a brass buckle, green with verdigris, still clung to a bit of moldering leather.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7VE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7VF">‘Come away from that thing, Garion,’ Silk told him with a note of revulsion in his voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7VG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7VH">‘It sort of helps to look at it,’ Garion replied quite calmly, still staring at the altar and the bones. ‘It gives me something to think about beside being afraid.’ He squared his shoulders, and his great sword shifted on his back. ‘I don’t really think the world needs this sort of thing. Maybe it’s time somebody did something about it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7VI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7VJ">When he turned around, Belgarath was looking at him, his wise old eyes narrowed. ‘It’s a start,’ the sorcerer observed. ‘Let’s eat and get some sleep.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7VK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7VL">They took a quick breakfast, picketed their horses, and rolled themselves in their blankets under some bushes at the edge of the clearing. Not even the presence of the Grolim altar nor the peculiar resolve it had stirred in him was enough to keep Garion from falling asleep immediately.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7VM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7VN">It was almost noon when he awoke, pulled from sleep by a faint whispering sound in his mind. He sat up quickly, looking around to find the source of that disturbance, but neither the forest nor the brush-choked burn seemed to hold any threat. Belgarath stood not far away, looking up at the summer sky where a large, blue-banded hawk was circling.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7VO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7VP">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB7VQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7VR">What are you doing here?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7VS">’ The old sorcerer did not speak aloud but rather cast the question at the sky with his mind. The hawk spiraled down to the clearing, flared his wings to avoid the altar, and landed on the turf. He looked directly at Belgarath with fierce yellow eyes, then shimmered and seemed to blur. When the shimmering was gone, the misshapen sorcerer Beldin stood in his place. He was still as ragged, dirty, and irritable as he had been the last time Garion had seen him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7VT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB7VU">‘Is this all the farther you’ve managed to come?’ he demanded harshly of Belgarath. ‘What have you been doing – stopping at every tavern along the way?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB7VV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB800">‘We ran into a small delay,’ Belgarath replied calmly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB801"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB802">Beldin grunted with a sour look. ‘If you keep dawdling along like this, it will take you the rest of the year to get to Cthol Mishrak.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB803"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB804">‘We’ll get there, Beldin. You worry too much.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB805"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB806">‘Somebody has to. You’re being followed, you know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB807"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB808">‘How far back are they?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB809"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80A">‘Five leagues or so.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB80B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80C">Belgarath shrugged. ‘That’s far enough. They’ll give up when we get to Morindland.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB80D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80E">‘What if they don’t?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB80F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80G">‘Have you been spending time with Polgara lately?’ Belgarath asked dryly. ‘I thought I’d gotten away from all the “what-ifs.”’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB80H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80I">Beldin shrugged, a gesture made grotesque by the hump on his back. ‘I saw her last week,’ he reported. ‘She has some interesting plans for you, you know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB80J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80K">‘She came to the Vale?’ Belgarath sounded surprised.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB80L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80M">‘Passed through. She was with the red-haired girl’s army.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB80N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80O">Garion threw off his blanket. ‘With </span><span class="italic" aid="DB80P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80Q">whose</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80R"> army?’ he demanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB80S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80T">‘What’s going on down there?’ Belgarath asked sharply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB80U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB80V">Beldin scratched at his tangled hair. ‘I never really got the straight of it,’ he admitted. ‘All I know is that the Alorns are following that little redheaded Tolnedran. She calls herself the Rivan Queen – whatever that means.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB810"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB811">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB812"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB813">Ce’Nedra?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB814">’ Garion was incredulous, though, for some reason, he knew that he shouldn’t be.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB815"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB816">‘I guess she went through Arendia like a pestilence,’ Beldin continued. ‘After she passed, there wasn’t an able-bodied man left in the kingdom. Then she went on down into Tolnedra and goaded her father into convulsions – I didn’t know that he was subject to fits.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB817"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB818">‘It crops up in the Borune line once in a while,’ Belgarath said. ‘It’s nothing all that serious, but they try to keep it quiet.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB819"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81A">‘Anyway,’ the hunchback went on, ‘while Ran Borune was still frothing at the mouth, his daughter stole his legions. She’s persuaded about half the world to take up arms and follow her.’ He gave Garion a quizzical look. ‘You’re supposed to marry her, aren’t you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB81B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81C">Garion nodded, not trusting himself to speak.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB81D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81E">Beldin grinned suddenly. ‘You might want to give some thought to running away.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB81F"><span class="italic" aid="DB81G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81H">‘Ce’Nedra?’</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81I"> Garion blurted again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB81J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81K">‘His wits seem a bit scrambled,’ Beldin observed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB81L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81M">‘He’s been under a strain, and his nerves aren’t too good just now,’ Belgarath replied. ‘Are you going back to the Vale?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB81N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81O">Beldin nodded. ‘The twins and I are going to join Polgara when the campaign starts. She might need some help if the Grolims come at her in force.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB81P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81Q">‘Campaign?’ Belgarath exclaimed. ‘What campaign? I told them just to march up and down and make a lot of noise. I specifically told them </span><span class="italic" aid="DB81R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81S">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81T"> to invade.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB81U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB81V">‘They ignored you, it seems. Alorns aren’t noted for restraint in such matters. Apparently they got together and decided to take steps. The fat one seems fairly intelligent. He wants to get a Cherek fleet into the Sea of the East to commit a few constructive atrocities on Mallorean shipping. The rest of it seems to be pretty much diversionary.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB820"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB821">Belgarath started to swear. ‘You can’t let them out of your sight for a single instant,’ he raged. ‘How could Polgara lend herself to this idiocy?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB822"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB823">‘The plan does have a certain merit, Belgarath. The more Malloreans they drown now, the fewer we have to fight later.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB824"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB825">‘We never planned to fight them, Beldin. The Angaraks won’t unite unless Torak comes back to weld them together again – </span><span class="italic" aid="DB826"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB827">or</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB828"> unless they’re faced with a common enemy. We just talked with Drosta lek Thun, the Nadrak King, and he’s so sure that the Murgos and the Malloreans are about to go to war with each other that he wants to ally himself with the west just to get clear of it. When you get back, see if you can talk some sense into Rhodar and Anheg. I’ve got enough problems already.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB829"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB82A">‘Your problems are only starting, Belgarath. The twins had a visitation a couple days ago.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB82B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB82C">‘A what?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB82D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB82E">Beldin shrugged. ‘What else would you call it? They were working on something – quite unrelated to all this – and the pair of them suddenly went into a trance and began to babble at me. At first they were just repeating that gibberish from the Mrin Codex – you know the place – where the Mrin Prophet’s mind broke down and he degenerated into animal noises for a while. Anyway, they went back over that part – only this time it came out coherently.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB82F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB82G">‘What did they say?’ Belgarath demanded, his eyes burning.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB82H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB82I">‘Are you sure you want to know?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB82J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB82K">‘Of course I want to know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB82L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB82M">‘All right. It went like this: “Behold, the heart of the stone shall relent, and the beauty that was destroyed shall be restored, and the eye that is not shall be made whole again.”’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB82N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB82O">Belgarath stared at him. ‘That’s it?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB82P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB82Q">‘That’s it,’ Beldin told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB82R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB82S">‘But what does it mean?’ Garion asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB82T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB82U">‘Just what it says, Belgarion,’ Beldin replied. ‘For some reason the Orb is going to restore Torak.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB82V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB830">Garion began to tremble as the full impact of Beldin’s words struck him. ‘Torak’s going to win, then,’ he said numbly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB831"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB832">‘It didn’t say anything about winning or losing, Belgarion,’ Beldin corrected him. ‘All it said was that the Orb is going to undo what it did to Torak when he used it to crack the world. It doesn’t say anything about </span><span class="italic" aid="DB833"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB834">why</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB835">.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB836"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB837">‘That’s always been the trouble with the Prophecy,’ Belgarath observed. ‘It can mean any one of a dozen different things.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB838"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB839">‘Or all of them,’ Beldin added. ‘That’s what makes it so difficult to understand sometimes. We tend to concentrate on just one thing, but Prophecy includes everything at the same time. I’ll work on it and see if I can wring some sense out of it. If I come up with anything, I’ll let you know. I’d better be getting back.’ He leaned slightly forward and curled his arms out in a vaguely winglike gesture. ‘Watch out for the Morindim,’ he told Belgarath. ‘You’re a fair sorcerer, but magic’s altogether different, and sometimes it gets away from you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB83A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83B">‘I think I can handle it if I have to,’ Belgarath replied tartly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB83C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83D">‘Maybe,’ Beldin said. ‘If you can manage to stay sober.’ He shimmered back into the form of the hawk, beat his wings twice, and spiraled up out of the clearing and into the sky. Garion watched him until he was only a circling speck.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB83E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83F">‘That was a strange visit,’ Silk said, rolling out of his blankets. ‘It looks as if quite a bit’s been going on since we left.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB83G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83H">‘And none of it very good,’ Belgarath added sourly. ‘Let’s get moving. We’re really going to have to hurry now. If Anheg gets his fleet into the Sea of the East and starts sinking Mallorean troop ships, ’Zakath might decide to march north and come across the land bridge. If we don’t get there first, it could get very crowded up there.’ The old man scowled darkly. ‘I’d like to put my hands on your uncle just about now,’ he added. ‘I’d sweat a few pounds off him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB83I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83J">They quickly saddled their horses and rode back along the edge of the sunlit forest toward the road leading north.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB83K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83L">Despite the rather lame assurances of the two sorcerers, Garion rode slumped in despair. They were going to lose, and Torak was going to kill him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB83M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83N">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB83O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83P">Stop feeling so sorry for yourself</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83Q">,’ the inner voice told him finally.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB83R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83S">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB83T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83U">Why did you get me into this?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB83V">’ Garion demanded bitterly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB840"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB841">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB842"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB843">We’ve discussed that before.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB844">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB845"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB846">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB847"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB848">He’s going to kill me.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB849">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB84A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84B">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB84C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84D">What gives you that idea?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84E">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB84F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84G">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB84H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84I">That’s what the Prophecy said.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84J">’ Garion stopped abruptly as a thought occurred to him. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB84K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84L">You said it yourself. You’re the Prophecy, aren’t you?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84M">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB84N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84O">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB84P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84Q">It’s a misleading term – and I didn’t say anything about winning or losing.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84R">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB84S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84T">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB84U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB84V">Isn’t that what it means?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB850">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB851"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB852">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB853"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB854">No. It means exactly what it says.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB855">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB856"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB857">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB858"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB859">What else could it mean?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85A">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB85B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85C">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB85D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85E">You’re getting more stubborn every day. Stop worrying so much about meanings and just do what you have to do. You almost had it right, back there.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85F">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB85G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85H">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB85I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85J">If all you’re going to do is talk in riddles, why bother with it at all? Why go to all the trouble of saying things that nobody’s able to understand?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85K">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB85L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85M">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB85N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85O">Because it’s necessary to say it. The word determines the event. The word puts limits on the event and shapes it. Without the word, the event is merely a random happening. That’s the whole purpose of what you call prophecy – to separate the significant from the random.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85P">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB85Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85R">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB85S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85T">I don’t understand.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB85U">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB85V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB860">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB861"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB862">I didn’t think you would, but you asked, after all. Now stop worrying about it. It has nothing to do with you.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB863">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB864"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB865">Garion wanted to protest, but the voice was gone. The conversation, however, had made him feel a little better – not much, but a little. To take his mind off it, he pulled his horse in beside Belgarath’s as they reentered the forest on the far side of the burn. ‘Exactly who are the Morindim, Grandfather?’ he asked. ‘Everybody keeps talking about them as if they were terribly dangerous.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB866"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB867">‘They are,’ Belgarath replied, ‘but you can get through their country if you’re careful.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB868"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB869">‘Are they on Torak’s side?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB86A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB86B">‘The Morindim aren’t on anybody’s side. They don’t even live in the same world with us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB86C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB86D">‘I don’t follow that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB86E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB86F">‘The Morindim are like the Ulgos used to be – before UL accepted them. There were several groups of Godless Ones. They all wandered off in various directions. The Ulgos went to the west, the Morindim went north. Other groups went south or east and disappeared.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB86G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB86H">‘Why didn’t they just stay where they were?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB86I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB86J">‘They couldn’t. There’s a kind of compulsion involved in the decisions of the Gods. Anyway, the Ulgos finally found themselves a God. The Morindim didn’t. The compulsion to remain separated from other people is still there. They live in that treeless emptiness up there beyond the north range – small nomadic bands, mostly.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB86K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB86L">‘What did you mean when you said that they don’t live in the same world with us?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB86M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB86N">‘The world is a pretty terrible place for a Morind – a demon-haunted place. They worship devils and they live more in dreams than they do in reality. Their society is dominated by the dreamers and the magicians.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB86O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB86P">‘There aren’t really any devils, are there?’ Garion asked skeptically.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB86Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB86R">‘Oh, yes. The devils are very real.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB86S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB86T">‘Where do they come from?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB86U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB86V">Belgarath shrugged. ‘I haven’t any idea. They do exist, though, and they’re completely evil. The Morindim control them by the use of magic.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB870"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB871">‘Magic? Is that different from what we do?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB872"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB873">‘Quite a bit. We’re sorcerers – at least that’s what we’re called. What we do involves the Will and the Word, but that’s not the only way to do things.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB874"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB875">‘I don’t quite follow.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB876"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB877">‘It’s not really all that complicated, Garion. There are several ways to tamper with the normal order of things. Vordai’s a witch. What she does involves the use of spirits – usually benign, mischievous sometimes – but not actually wicked. A magician uses devils – evil spirits.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB878"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB879">‘Isn’t that sort of dangerous?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB87A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB87B">Belgarath nodded. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="DB87C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB87D">Very</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB87E"> dangerous,’ he replied. ‘The magician tries to control the demon with spells – formulas, incantations, symbols, mystic diagrams – that sort of thing. As long as he doesn’t make any mistakes, the demon is his absolute slave and has to do what he tells it to do. The demon doesn’t want to be a slave, so it keeps looking for a way to break the spell.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB87F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB87G">‘What happens if it does?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB87H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB87I">‘It generally devours the magician on the spot. That happens rather frequently. If you lose your concentration or summon a demon too strong for you, you’re in trouble.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB87J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB87K">‘What did Beldin mean when he said that you weren’t very good at magic?’ Silk asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB87L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB87M">‘I’ve never spent that much time trying to learn about it,’ the old sorcerer replied. ‘I have alternatives, after all, and magic is dangerous and not very dependable.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB87N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB87O">‘Don’t use it then,’ Silk suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB87P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB87Q">‘I hadn’t really planned to. Usually the threat of magic is enough to keep the Morindim at a distance. Actual confrontations are rather rare.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB87R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB87S">‘I can see why.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB87T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB87U">‘After we get through the north range, we’ll disguise ourselves. There are a number of markings and symbols that will make the Morindim avoid us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB87V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB880">‘That sounds promising.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="DB881"><span class="calibre_1" aid="DB882">‘Of course we have to get there first,’ the old man pointed out. ‘Let’s pick up the pace a bit. We’ve still got a long way to go.’ And he pushed his horse into a gallop.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_14" aid="DB883"></div>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
  <link href="kindle:flow:0001?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
<link href="kindle:flow:0002?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
</head>
  <body class="calibre" aid="E9OE0">
</body>
</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos241138" aid="E9OE1"><span class="calibre5" aid="E9OE2"><span class="italic" aid="E9OE3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OE4">Chapter Seven</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="E9OE5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OE6">They rode hard for the better part of a week, moving steadily northward and avoiding the scattered settlements which dotted the Nadrak forest. Garion noticed that the nights grew steadily shorter; by the time they reached the foothills of the north range, darkness had virtually disappeared. Evening and morning merged into a few hours of luminous twilight as the sun dipped briefly below the horizon before bursting into view once more.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OE7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OE8">The north range marked the upper edge of the Nadrak forest. It was not so much a mountainous region as it was a string of peaks, a long finger of upthrusting terrain reaching out toward the east from the broad ranges that formed the spine of the continent. As they rode up a scarcely defined trail toward a saddle that stretched between two snowy peaks, the trees around them grew more stunted and finally disappeared entirely. Beyond that point, there would be no more trees. Belgarath stopped at the edge of one of these last groves and cut a half-dozen long saplings.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OE9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OEA">The wind that came down off the peaks had a bitter chill to it and the arid smell of perpetual winter. When they reached the boulder-strewn summit, Garion looked out for the first time at the immense plain stretching below. The plain, unmarked by trees, was covered with tall grass that bent before the vagrant wind in long, undulating waves. Rivers wandered aimlessly across that emptiness, and a thousand shallow lakes and ponds scattered, blue and glistening under a northern sun, toward the horizon.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OEB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OEC">‘How far does it reach?’ Garion asked quietly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OED"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OEE">‘From here to the polar ice,’ Belgarath replied. ‘Several hundred leagues.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OEF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OEG">‘And no-one lives out there but the Morindim?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OEH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OEI">‘Nobody wants to. For most of the year, it’s buried in snow and darkness. You can go for six months up here without ever seeing the sun.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OEJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OEK">They rode down the rocky slope toward the plain and found a low-roofed, shallow cave at the base of the granite cliff that seemed to be the demarcation line between the mountains and the foothills. ‘We’ll stop here for a while,’ Belgarath told them, reining in his tired mount. ‘We’ve got some preparations to make, and the horses need some rest.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OEL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OEM">They were all kept quite busy for the next several days while Belgarath radically altered their appearances. Silk set crude traps among the maze of rabbit runs twisting through the tall grass, and Garion roamed the foothills in search of certain tuberous roots and a peculiar-smelling white flower. Belgarath sat at the mouth of the cave, fashioning various implements from his saplings. The roots Garion had gathered yielded a dark brown stain, and Belgarath carefully applied it to their skins. ‘The Morindim are dark-skinned,’ he explained as he sat painting Silk’s arms and back with the stain. ‘Somewhat darker than Tolnedrans or Nyissans. This will wear off after a few weeks, but it will last long enough to get us through.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OEN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OEO">After he had stained all their skins into swarthiness, he crushed the odd-smelling flowers to produce a jet black ink. ‘Silk’s hair is the right color already,’ he said, ‘and mine will get by, but Garion’s just won’t do.’ He diluted some of the ink with water and dyed Garion’s sandy hair black. ‘That’s better,’ he grunted when he had finished, ‘and there’s enough left for the tattoos.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OEP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OEQ">‘Tattoos?’ Garion asked, startled at the thought.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OER"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OES">‘The Morindim decorate themselves extensively.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OET"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OEU">‘Will it hurt?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OEV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OF0">‘We’re not really going to tattoo ourselves, Garion,’ Belgarath told him with a pained look. ‘They take too long to heal. Besides, I’m afraid your Aunt would go into hysterics if I took you back to her with designs engraved all over you. This ink will last long enough for us to get through Morindland. It will wear off – eventually.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OF1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OF2">Silk was sitting cross-legged in front of the cave, looking for all the world like a tailor as he sewed fresh rabbit pelts to their clothing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OF3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OF4">‘Won’t they start to smell after a few days?’ Garion asked, wrinkling his nose.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OF5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OF6">‘Probably,’ Silk admitted, ‘but I don’t have time to cure the pelts.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OF7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OF8">Later, as Belgarath was carefully drawing the tattoos on their faces, he explained the guise they were going to assume. ‘Garion will be the quester,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OF9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFA">‘What’s that?’ Garion asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OFB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFC">‘Don’t move your face,’ Belgarath told him, frowning as he drew lines under Garion’s eyes with a raven-feather quill. ‘The quest is a Morind ritual. It’s customary for a young Morind of a certain rank to undertake a quest before he assumes a position of authority in his clan. You’ll wear a white fur headband and carry that red spear I fixed up for you. It’s ceremonial,’ he cautioned, ‘so don’t try to stab anybody with it. That’s very bad form.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OFD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFE">‘I’ll remember that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OFF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFG">‘We’ll disguise your sword to look like some sort of relic or something. A magician </span><span class="italic" aid="E9OFH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFI">might</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFJ"> see past the Orb’s suggestion that it’s not there – depending on how good he is. One other thing – the quester is absolutely forbidden to speak under any circumstances, so keep your mouth shut. Silk will be your dreamer. He’ll wear a white fur band on his left arm. Dreamers speak in riddles and gibberish for the most part, and they tend to fall into trances and have fits.’ He glanced over at Silk. ‘Do you think you can handle that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OFK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFL">‘Trust me,’ Silk replied, grinning.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OFM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFN">‘Not very likely,’ Belgarath grunted. ‘I’ll be Garion’s magician. I’ll carry a staff with a horned skull on it that will make most Morindim avoid us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OFO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFP">‘Most?’ Silk asked quickly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OFQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFR">‘It’s considered bad manners to interfere with a quest, but it happens now and then.’ The old man looked critically at Garion’s tattoos. ‘Good enough,’ he said and turned to Silk with his quill.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OFS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFT">When it was all done, the three of them were scarcely recognizable. The markings the old man had carefully drawn on their arms and faces were not pictures so much as they were designs. Their faces had been changed into hideous devil masks, and the exposed parts of their bodies were covered with symbols etched in black ink. They wore fur-covered trousers and vests and bone necklaces clattered about their necks. Their stained arms and shoulders were bared and intricately marked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OFU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OFV">Then Belgarath went down into the valley lying just below the cave, seeking something. It did not take his probing mind long to find what he needed. As Garion watched with revulsion, the old man casually violated a grave. He dug up a grinning human skull and carefully tapped the dirt out of it. ‘I’ll need some deer horns,’ he told Garion. ‘Not too large and fairly well-matched.’ He squatted, fierce-looking in his furs and tattoos, and began to scrub at the skull with handfuls of dry sand.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OG0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OG1">There were weather-bleached horns lying here and there in the tall grass, since the deer of the region shed their antlers each winter. Garion gathered a dozen or so and returned to the cave to find his grandfather boring a pair of holes in the top of the skull. He critically examined the horns Garion had brought him, selected a pair of them and screwed them down into the holes. The grating sound of horn against bone set Garion’s teeth on edge. ‘What do you think?’ Belgarath asked, holding up the horned skull.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OG2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OG3">‘It’s grotesque,’ Garion shuddered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OG4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OG5">‘That was the general idea,’ the old man replied. He attached the skull firmly to the top of a long staff, decorated it with several feathers and then rose to his feet. ‘Let’s pack up and leave,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OG6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OG7">They rode down through the treeless foothills and out into the bending, waist-high grass as the sun swung down toward the southwestern horizon to dip briefly behind the peaks of the range they had just crossed. The smell of the uncured pelts Silk had sewn to their clothing was not very pleasant, and Garion did his best not to look at the hideously altered skull surmounting Belgarath’s staff as they rode.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OG8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OG9">‘We’re being watched,’ Silk mentioned rather casually after an hour or so of riding.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OGA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OGB">‘I was sure we would be,’ Belgarath replied. ‘Just keep going.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OGC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OGD">Their first meeting with the Morindim came just as the sun rose. They had paused on the sloping gravel bank of a meandering stream to water their mounts, and a dozen or so fur-clad riders, their dark faces tattooed into devil masks, cantered up to the opposite bank and stopped. They did not speak, but looked hard at the identifying marks Belgarath had so painstakingly contrived. After a brief, whispered consultation, they turned their horses and rode back away from the stream. Several minutes later, one came galloping back, carrying a bundle wrapped in a fox skin. He paused, dropped the bundle on the bank of the stream, and then rode off again without looking back.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OGE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OGF">‘What was that all about?’ Garion asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OGG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OGH">‘The bundle’s a gift – of sorts,’ Belgarath answered. ‘It’s an offering to any devils who might be accompanying us. Go pick it up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OGI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OGJ">‘What’s in it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OGK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OGL">‘A bit of this, a bit of that. I wouldn’t open it, if I were you. You’re forgetting that you’re not supposed to talk.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OGM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OGN">‘There’s nobody around,’ Garion replied, turning his head this way and that, looking for any sign of their being watched.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OGO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OGP">‘Don’t be too sure of that,’ the old man replied. ‘There could be a hundred of them hiding in the grass. Go pick up the gift and we’ll move along. They’re polite enough, but they’ll be a lot happier when we take our devils out of their territory.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OGQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OGR">They rode on across the flat, featureless plain with a cloud of flies, drawn by the smell of their untanned fur garments, plaguing them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OGS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OGT">Their next meeting, several days later, was less congenial. They had moved into a hilly region where huge, rounded, white boulders rose out of the grass and where shaggy-coated wild oxen with great, sweeping horns grazed. A high overcast had moved in, and the gray sky diffused the light, making the brief twilight that marked the passage of one day into the next an only slightly perceptible darkening. They were riding down a gentle slope toward a large lake, which lay like a sheet of lead under the cloudy sky, when there suddenly arose from the tall grass all around them tattooed and fur-clad warriors holding long spears and short bows that appeared to be made of bone.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OGU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OGV">Garion reined in sharply and looked at Belgarath for instruction.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OH0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OH1">‘Just look straight at them,’ his grandfather told him quietly, ‘and remember that you’re not permitted to speak.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OH2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OH3">‘More of them coming,’ Silk said tersely, jerking his chin toward the crest of a nearby hill where perhaps a dozen Morindim, mounted on paint-decorated ponies, were approaching at a walk.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OH4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OH5">‘Let me do the talking,’ Belgarath said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OH6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OH7">‘Gladly.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OH8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OH9">The man in the lead of the mounted group was burlier than most of his companions, and the black tattooing on his face had been outlined with red and blue, marking him as a man of some significance in his clan and making the devil mask of his features all the more hideous. He carried a large wooden club, painted with strange symbols and inlaid with rows of sharp teeth taken from various animals. The way he carried it indicated that it was more a badge of office than a weapon. He rode without a saddle and with a single bridle strap. He pulled his pony to a stop perhaps thirty yards away. ‘Why have you come into the lands of the Weasel Clan?’ he demanded abruptly. His accent was strange and his eyes were flat with hostility.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OHA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OHB">Belgarath drew himself up indignantly. ‘Surely the Headman of the Weasel Clan has seen the quest-mark before,’ he replied coldly. ‘We have no interest in the lands of the Weasel Clan, but follow the commands of the Devil-Spirit of the Wolf Clan in the quest he has laid upon us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OHC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OHD">‘I have not heard of the Wolf Clan,’ the Headman replied. ‘Where are their lands?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OHE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OHF">‘To the west,’ Belgarath replied. ‘We have traveled for two waxings and wanings of the Moon-Spirit to reach this place.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OHG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OHH">The Headman seemed impressed by that.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OHI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OHJ">A Morind with long white braids and with a thin, dirty-looking beard drew his pony in beside that of the Headman. In his right hand he carried a staff surmounted by the skull of a large bird. The gaping beak of the skull had been decorated with teeth, giving it a ferocious appearance. ‘What is the name of the Devil-Spirit of the Wolf Clan?’ he demanded. ‘I may know him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OHK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OHL">‘That is doubtful, Magician of the Weasel Clan,’ Belgarath answered politely. ‘He seldom goes far from his people. In any case, I cannot speak his name, since he has forbidden it to any but the dreamers.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OHM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OHN">‘Can you say what his aspect is and his attributes?’ the white-braided magician asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OHO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OHP">Silk made a long-gurgling sound in the back of his throat, stiffened in his saddle and rolled his eyes gruesomely back in his head until only the whites showed. With a convulsive, jerking motion, he thrust both arms into the air. ‘Beware the Devil Agrinja, who stalks unseen behind us,’ he intoned in a hollow, oracular voice. ‘I have seen his three-eyed face and his hundred-fanged mouth in my dreams. The eye of mortal man may not behold him, but his seven-clawed hands reach out even now to rend apart all who would stand in the path of his chosen quester, the spear-bearer of the Wolf Clan. I have seen him feed in my nightmares. The ravener approaches and he hungers for man-meat. Flee his hunger.’ He shuddered, dropping his arms and slumping forward in his saddle as if suddenly exhausted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OHQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OHR">‘You’ve been here before, I see,’ Belgarath muttered under his breath. ‘Try to restrain your creativity, though. Remember that </span><span class="italic" aid="E9OHS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OHT">I</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OHU"> might have to produce what you dream up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OHV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OI0">Silk cast him a sidelong wink. His description of the Devil had made a distinct impression on the Morindim. The mounted men looked about nervously, and those standing in the waist-high grass moved involuntarily closer together, grasping their weapons in trembling hands.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OI1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OI2">Then a thin Morind with a white fur band around his left arm pushed through the cluster of frightened warriors. His right leg ended in a clubfoot, and he lurched grotesquely as he walked. He fixed Silk with a glare of pure hatred, then threw both hands wide, quivering and jerking. His back arched and he toppled over, threshing in the grass in the throes of an apparent seizure. He went completely stiff and then he started to speak. ‘The Devil-Spirit of the Weasel Clan, dread Horja, speaks to me. He demands to know why the Devil Agrinja sends his quester into the lands of the Weasel Clan. The Devil Horja is too awful to look upon. He has </span><span class="italic" aid="E9OI3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OI4">four</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OI5"> eyes and a hundred and </span><span class="italic" aid="E9OI6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OI7">ten</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OI8"> teeth, and each of his six hands has </span><span class="italic" aid="E9OI9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OIA">eight</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OIB"> claws. He feeds on the bellies of men and he hungers.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OIC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OID">‘An imitator,’ Silk sniffed disdainfully, his head still down. ‘He can’t even think up his own dream.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OIE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OIF">The magician of the Weasel Clan gave the dreamer lying supine in the grass a look of disgust, then turned back to Belgarath. ‘The Devil-Spirit Horja defies the Devil-Spirit Agrinja,’ he declared. ‘He bids him to begone or he will rip out the belly of the quester of Agrinja.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OIG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OIH">Belgarath swore under his breath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OII"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OIJ">‘What now?’ Silk muttered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OIK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OIL">‘I have to fight him,’ Belgarath replied sourly. ‘That’s what this was leading up to from the beginning. White-braids there is trying to make a name for himself. He’s probably been attacking every magician who crosses his path.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OIM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OIN">‘Can you handle him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OIO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OIP">‘We’re about to find out.’ Belgarath slid out of his saddle. ‘I warn you to stand aside,’ he boomed, ‘lest I loose the hunger of our Devil-Spirit upon you.’ With the tip of his staff he drew a circle on the ground and a five-pointed star within the circle. Grimly, he stepped into the center of the design.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OIQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OIR">The white-braided magician of the Weasel Clan sneered and also slid off his pony. Quickly he drew a similar symbol on the ground and stepped into its protection.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OIS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OIT">‘That’s it,’ Silk muttered to Garion. ‘Once the symbols are drawn, neither one can back down.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OIU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OIV">Belgarath and the white-braided magician had each begun muttering incantations in a language Garion had never heard, brandishing their skull-surmounted staffs at each other. The dreamer of the Weasel Clan, suddenly realizing that he was in the middle of the impending battle, miraculously recovered from his seizure, scrambled to his feet, and lurched away with a terrified expression.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJ0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJ1">The Headman, trying to maintain his dignity, carefully backed his pony out of the immediate vicinity of the two muttering old men.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJ2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJ3">Atop a large, white boulder, twenty yards or so to the left of the two magicians, there was a shimmering disturbance in the air, somewhat like heatwaves rising from a red tile roof on a hot day. The movement caught Garion’s eye, and he stared in puzzlement at the strange phenomenon.
