As he watched, the shimmering became more pronounced, and it seemed that the shattered pieces of a rainbow infused it, flickering, shifting, undulating in waves almost like varihued flames rising from an invisible fire. As Garion watched, fascinated, a second shimmering became apparent, rising above the tall grass off to the right. The second disturbance also began to gather shards of color into itself. As he stared, first at one, then at the other, Garion saw – or imagined that he saw – a shape beginning to emerge in the center of each. The shapes at first were amorphous, shifting, changing, gathering form from the coruscating colors flashing about them in the shimmering air. Then it seemed that the shapes, having reached a certain point, flashed to completion, coalescing quite suddenly with a great rushing together, and two towering forms faced each other, snarling and slavering with mindless hatred. Each stood as high as a house, and their shoulders bulked wide. Their skins were multihued, with waves of color rippling through them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJ4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJ5">The one standing in the grass had a third eye glaring balefully from between its other two, and his great arms ended in seven-clawed hands stretched out with a hideously hungry curving. His jutting, muzzlelike mouth gaped wide, filled with row upon row of needlelike teeth as he roared a thunderous howl of hatred and dreadful hunger.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJ6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJ7">Crouched upon the boulder stood the other. He had a great cluster of shoulders at the top of his trunk, and a nest of long, scaly arms that writhed out in all directions like snakes, each arm terminating in a widespread, many-clawed hand. Two sets of eyes, one atop the other, glared insanely from beneath heavy brow-ridges, and his muzzle, like that of the other figure, sprouted a forest of teeth. He raised that awful face and bellowed, his jaws drooling foam.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJ8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJ9">But even as the two monsters glared at each other, there seemed to be a kind of writhing struggle going on inside them. Their skins rippled, and large moving lumps appeared in odd places on their chests and sides. Garion had the peculiar feeling that there was something else – something quite different and perhaps even worse – trapped inside each apparition. Growling, the two devils advanced upon each other, but despite their apparent eagerness to fight, they seemed almost driven, whipped toward the struggle. It was as if there was a dreadful reluctance in them, and their grotesque faces jerked this way and that, each snarling first at his opponent and then at the magician who controlled him. That reluctance, Garion perceived, stemmed from something deep inside the nature of each Devil. It was the enslavement, the compulsion to do the bidding of another, that they hated. The chains of spell and incantation in which Belgarath and the white-braided Morind had bound them were an intolerable agony, and there were whimpers of that agony mingled with their snarls.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJB">Belgarath was sweating. Droplets of perspiration trickled down his dark-stained face. The incantations which held the Devil Agrinja locked within the apparition he had created to bind it rippled endlessly from his tongue. The slightest faltering of either the words or the image he had formed in his mind would break his power over the beast he had summoned, and it would turn upon him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJD">Writhing like things attempting to tear themselves apart from within, Agrinja and Horja closed on each other, grappling, clawing, tearing out chunks of scaly flesh with their awful jaws. The earth shuddered beneath them as they fought.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJF">Too stunned to even be afraid, Garion watched the savage struggle. As he watched, he noted a peculiar difference between the two apparitions. Agrinja was bleeding from his wounds – a strange, dark blood, so deep red as to be almost black. Horja, however, did not bleed. Chunks ripped from his arms and shoulders were like bits of wood. The white-braided magician saw that difference as well, and his eyes grew suddenly afraid. His voice became shrill as he desperately cast incantations at Horja, struggling to keep the Devil under his control. The moving lumps beneath Horja’s skin became larger, more agitated. The vast Devil broke free from Agrinja and stood, his chest heaving and a dreadful hope burning in his eyes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJH">White-braids was screaming now. The incantations tumbled from his mouth, faltering, stumbling. And then one unpronounceable formula tangled his tongue. Desperately he tried it again, and once again it stuck in his teeth.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJJ">With a bellow of triumph the Devil Horja straightened and seemed to explode. Bits and fragments of scaly hide flew in all directions as the monster shuddered free of the illusion which had bound him. He had two great arms and an almost human face surmounted by a pair of curving, needle-pointed horns. He had hoofs instead of feet, and his grayish skin dripped slime. He turned slowly and his burning eyes fixed on the gibbering magician.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJL">‘Horja!’ the white-braided Morind shrieked, ‘I command you to—’ The words faltered as he gaped in horror at the Devil which had suddenly escaped his control. ‘Horja! I am your master!’ But Horja was already stalking toward him, his great hoofs crushing the grass as, step by step, he moved toward his former master.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJN">In wild-eyed panic, the white-braided Morind flinched back, stepping unconsciously and fatally out of the protection of the circle and star drawn upon the ground.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJP">Horja smiled then, a chilling smile, bent and caught the shrieking magician by each ankle, ignoring the blows rained on his head and shoulders by the skull-topped staff. Then the monster stood up, lifting the struggling man to hang upside down by the legs. The huge shoulders surged with an awful power, and, leering hideously, the Devil deliberately and with a cruel slowness tore the magician in two.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJR">The Morindim fled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJT">Contemptuously the immense Devil hurled the chunks of his former master after them, spattering the grass with blood and worse. Then, with a savage hunting cry, he leaped in pursuit of them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OJU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OJV">The three-eyed Agrinja had stood, still locked in a half-crouch, watching the destruction of the white-braided Morind almost with indifference. When it was over, he turned to cast eyes burning with hatred upon Belgarath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OK0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OK1">The old sorcerer, drenched with sweat, raised his skull-staff in front of him, his face set with extreme concentration. The interior struggle rippled more intensely within the form of the monster, but gradually Belgarath’s will mastered and solidified the shape. Agrinja howled in frustration, clawing at the air until all hint of shifting or changing was gone. Then the dreadful hands dropped, and the monster’s head bowed in defeat.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OK2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OK3">‘Begone,’ Belgarath commanded almost negligently, and Agrinja instantly vanished.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OK4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OK5">Garion suddenly began to tremble violently. His stomach heaved; he turned, tottered a few feet away, and fell to his knees and began to retch.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OK6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OK7">‘What happened?’ Silk demanded in a shaking voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OK8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OK9">‘It got away from him,’ Belgarath replied calmly. ‘I think it was the blood that did it. When he saw that Agrinja was bleeding and that Horja wasn’t, he realized that he’d forgotten something. That shook his confidence, and he lost his concentration. Garion, stop that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OKA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OKB">‘I can’t,’ Garion groaned, his stomach heaving violently again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OKC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OKD">‘How long will Horja chase the others?’ Silk asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OKE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OKF">‘Until the sun goes down,’ Belgarath told him. ‘I imagine that the Weasel Clan is in for a bad afternoon.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OKG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OKH">‘Is there any chance that he’ll turn around and come after us?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OKI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OKJ">‘He has no reason to. We didn’t try to enslave him. As soon as Garion gets his stomach under control again, we can go on. We won’t be bothered any more.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OKK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OKL">Garion stumbled to his feet, weakly wiping his mouth.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OKM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OKN">‘Are you all right?’ Belgarath asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OKO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OKP">‘Not really,’ Garion replied, ‘but there’s nothing left to come up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OKQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OKR">‘Get a drink of water and try not to think about it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OKS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OKT">‘Will you have to do that any more?’ Silk asked, his eyes a bit wild.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OKU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OKV">‘No,’ Belgarath pointed. There were several riders along the crest of a hill perhaps a mile away. ‘The other Morindim in the area watched the whole thing. The word will spread, and nobody will come anywhere near us now. Let’s mount up and get going. It’s still a long way to the coast.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OL0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OL1">In bits and pieces, as they rode for the next several days, Garion picked up as much information as he really wanted about the dreadful contest he had witnessed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OL2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OL3">‘It’s the </span><span class="italic" aid="E9OL4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OL5">shape</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OL6"> that’s the key to the whole thing,’ Belgarath concluded. ‘What the Morindim call Devil-Spirits don’t look that much different from humans. You form an illusion drawn out of your imagination and force the spirit into it. As long as you can keep it locked up in that illusion, it has to do what you tell it to. If the illusion falters for any reason, the spirit breaks free and resumes its real form. After that, you have no control over it whatsoever. I have a certain advantage in these matters. Changing back and forth from a man to a wolf has sharpened my imagination a bit.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OL7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OL8">‘Why did Beldin say you were a bad magician then?’ Silk asked curiously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OL9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OLA">‘Beldin’s a purist,’ the old man shrugged. ‘He feels that it’s necessary to get everything into the shape – down to the last scale and toenail. It isn’t, really, but he feels that way about it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OLB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OLC">‘Do you suppose we could talk about something else?’ Garion asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OLD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OLE">They reached the coastline a day or so later. The sky had remained overcast, and the Sea of the East lay sullen and rolling under dirty gray clouds. The beach along which they rode was a broad shingle of black, round stones littered with chunks of white, bleached driftwood. Waves rolled foaming up the beach, only to slither back with an endless, mournful sigh. Sea birds hung in the stiff breeze, screaming.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OLF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OLG">‘Which way?’ Silk asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OLH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OLI">Belgarath looked around. ‘North,’ he replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OLJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OLK">‘How far?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OLL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OLM">‘I’m not positive. It’s been a long time, and I can’t be sure exactly where we are.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OLN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OLO">‘You’re not the best guide in the world, old friend,’ Silk complained.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OLP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OLQ">‘You can’t have everything.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OLR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OLS">They reached the land bridge two days later, and Garion stared at it in dismay. It was not at all what he had expected, but consisted of a series of round, wave-eroded white boulders sticking up out of the dark water and running in an irregular line off toward a dark smudge on the horizon. The wind was blowing out of the north, carrying with it a bitter chill and the smell of polar ice. Patches of white froth stretched from boulder to boulder as the swells ripped themselves to tatters on submerged reefs.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OLT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OLU">‘How are we supposed to cross that?’ Silk objected.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OLV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OM0">‘We wait until low tide,’ Belgarath explained. ‘The reefs are mostly out of the water then.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OM1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OM2">‘Mostly?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OM3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OM4">‘We might have to wade a bit from time to time. Let’s strip these furs off our clothes before we start. It will give us something to do while we’re waiting for the tide to turn, and they’re starting to get a bit fragrant.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OM5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OM6">They took shelter behind a pile of driftwood far up on the beach and removed the stiff, smelly furs from their clothing. Then they dug food out of their packs and ate. Garion noted that the stain that had darkened the skin on his hands had begun to wear thin and that the tattoo-drawings on the faces of his companions had grown noticeably fainter.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OM7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OM8">It grew darker, and the period of twilight that separated one day from the next seemed longer than it had no more than a week ago.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OM9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OMA">‘Summer’s nearly over up here,’ Belgarath noted, looking out at the boulders gradually emerging from the receding water in the murky twilight.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OMB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OMC">‘How much longer before low tide?’ Silk asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OMD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OME">‘Another hour or so.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OMF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OMG">They waited. The wind pushed at the pile of driftwood erratically and brushed the tall grass along the upper edge of the beach, bending and tossing it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OMH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OMI">Finally Belgarath stood up. ‘Let’s go,’ he said shortly. ‘We’ll lead the horses. The reefs are slippery, so be careful how you set your feet down.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OMJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OMK">The passage along the reef between the first steppingstones was not all that bad, but once they moved farther out, the wind became a definite factor. They were frequently drenched with stinging spray, and every so often a wave, larger than the others, broke over the top of the reef and swirled about their legs, tugging at them. The water was brutally cold.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OML"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OMM">‘Do you think we’ll be able to make it all the way across before the tide comes back in again?’ Silk shouted over the noise.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OMN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OMO">‘No,’ Belgarath shouted back. ‘We’ll have to sit it out on top of one of the larger rocks.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OMP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OMQ">‘That sounds unpleasant.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OMR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OMS">‘Not nearly so unpleasant as swimming.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OMT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9OMU">They were perhaps halfway across when it became evident that the tide had turned. Waves more and more frequently broke across the top of the reef, and one particularly large one pulled the legs of Garion’s horse out from under him. Garion struggled to get the frightened animal up again, pulling at the reins as the horse’s hoofs scrambled and slid on the slippery rocks of the reef. ‘We’d better find a place to stop, Grandfather,’ he yelled above the crash of the waves. ‘We’ll be neck-deep in this before long.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9OMV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9ON0">‘Two more islands,’ Belgarath told him. ‘There’s a bigger one up ahead.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9ON1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9ON2">The last stretch of reef was completely submerged, and Garion flinched as he stepped down into the icy water. The breaking waves covered the surface with froth, making it impossible to see the bottom. He moved along blindly, probing the unseen path with numb feet. A large wave swelled and rose up as far as his armpits, and its powerful surge swept him off his feet. He clung to the reins of his horse, floundering and sputtering as he fought to get back up.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9ON3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9ON4">And then they were past the worst of it. They moved along the reef with the water only ankle-deep now; a few moments later, they climbed up onto the large, white boulder. Garion let out a long, explosive breath as he reached safety. The wind, blowing against his wet clothing, chilled him to the bone but at least they were out of the water.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9ON5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9ON6">Later, as they sat huddled together on the leeward side of the boulder, Garion looked out across the sullen black sea toward the low, forbidding coastline lying ahead. The beaches, like those of Morindland behind them, were black gravel, and the low hills behind them were dark under the scudding gray cloud. Nowhere was there any sign of life, but there was an implicit threat in the very shape of the land itself.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9ON7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9ON8">‘Is that it?’ he asked finally in a hushed voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="E9ON9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="E9ONA">Belgarath’s face was unreadable as he gazed across the open water toward the coast ahead. ‘Yes,’ he replied. ‘That’s Mallorea.’</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_15" aid="E9ONB"></div>

<blockquote class="calibre_21" id="filepos283950" aid="F8901"><blockquote class="calibre8" aid="F8902"><blockquote class="calibre_22" aid="F8903"><span class="calibre1" aid="F8904"><span class="italic" aid="F8905"><span class="bold" aid="F8906"><span class="calibre_1" aid="F8907">Part Two</span></span></span></span></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote class="calibre_23" aid="F8908"><blockquote class="calibre8" aid="F8909"><blockquote class="calibre_22" aid="F890A"><span class="calibre1" aid="F890B"><span class="bold" aid="F890C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="F890D">MISHRAK AC THULL</span></span></span></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><br class="calibre3"/><p class="calibre_" aid="F890E"><img class="calibre_26" src="kindle:embed:0004?mime=image/jpeg"/>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
  <link href="kindle:flow:0001?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
<link href="kindle:flow:0002?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>

  <body class="calibre" aid="G6PI0">
</body>
</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos284470" aid="G6PI1"><span class="calibre5" aid="G6PI2"><span class="italic" aid="G6PI3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PI4">Chapter Eight</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="G6PI5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PI6">The crown had been Queen Islena’s first mistake. It was heavy and it always gave her a headache. Her decision to wear it had come originally out of a sense of insecurity. The bearded warriors in Anheg’s throne room intimidated her, and she felt the need of a visible symbol of her authority. Now she was afraid to appear without it. Each day she put it on with less pleasure and entered the main hall of Anheg’s palace with less certainty.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PI7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PI8">The sad truth was that Queen Islena of Cherek was completely unprepared to rule. Until the day when, dressed in regal crimson velvet and with her gold crown firmly in place, she had marched into the vaulted throne room at Val Alorn to announce that she would rule the kingdom in her husband’s absence, Islena’s most momentous decisions had involved which gown she would wear and how her hair was to be arranged. Now it seemed that the fate of Cherek hung in the balance each time she was faced with a choice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PI9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PIA">The warriors lounging indolently with their ale cups about the huge, open fire pit or wandering aimlessly about on the rush-strewn floor were no help whatsoever. Each time she entered the throne room, all conversation broke off and they rose to watch as she marched to the banner-hung throne, but their faces gave no hint of their true feelings toward her. Irrationally, she concluded that the whole problem had to do with the beards. How could she possibly know what a man was thinking when his face was sunk up to the ears in hair? Only the quick intervention of Lady Merel, the cool blond wife of the Earl of Trellheim, had stopped her from ordering a universal shave.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PIB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PIC">‘You can’t, Islena,’ Merel had told her flatly, removing the quill from the queen’s hand, even as she had been in the act of signing the hastily drawn-up proclamation. ‘They’re attached to their beards like little boys attached to a favorite toy. You can’t make them cut off their whiskers.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PID"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PIE">‘I’m the Queen.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PIF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PIG">‘Only as long as they permit you to be. They accept you out of respect for Anheg, and that’s as far as it goes. If you tamper with their pride, they’ll take you off the throne.’ And that dreadful threat had ended the matter then and there.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PIH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PII">Islena found herself relying more and more on Barak’s wife, and it was not long before the two of them, one in green and the other in royal crimson, were seldom apart. Even when Islena faltered, Merel’s icy stare quelled the hints of disrespect which cropped up from time to time – usually when the ale had been distributed a bit too freely. It was Merel, ultimately, who made the day-to-day decisions which ran the kingdom. When Islena sat upon the throne, Merel, her blond braids coiled about her head to form her own crown, stood to one side in plain view of the hesitant queen. Cherek was ruled by the expressions on her face. A faint smile meant yes; a frown, no; a scarcely perceptible shrug, maybe. It worked out fairly well.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PIJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PIK">But there was one person who was not intimidated by Merel’s cool gaze. Grodeg, the towering, white-bearded High Priest of Belar, inevitably requested private audience with the queen, and once Merel left the council room, Islena was lost.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PIL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PIM">Despite Anheg’s call for a general mobilization, the members of the Bear-cult had not yet left to join the campaign. Their promises to join the fleet later all sounded sincere, but their excuses and delays grew more and more obvious as time went on. Islena knew that Grodeg was behind it all. Nearly every able-bodied man in the kingdom was off with the fleet, which was even now rowing up the broad expanse of the Aldur River to join Anheg in central Algaria. The household guard in the palace at Val Alorn had been reduced to grizzled old men and downy-cheeked boys. Only the Bear-cult remained, and Grodeg pushed his advantage to the limit.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PIN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PIO">He was polite enough, bowing to the queen when the occasion demanded, and never mentioning her past links with the cult, but his offers to help became more and more insistent; and when Islena faltered at his suggestions concerning this matter or that, he smoothly acted to implement them as if her hesitancy had been acceptance. Little by little, Islena was losing control, and Grodeg, with the armed might of the cult behind him, was taking charge. More and more the cult members infested the palace, giving orders, lounging about the throne room and openly grinning as they watched Islena’s attempts to rule.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PIP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PIQ">‘You’re going to have to do something, Islena,’ Merel said firmly one evening when the two were alone in the queen’s private apartment. She was striding about the carpeted room, her hair gleaming like soft gold in the candlelight, but there was nothing soft in her expression.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PIR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PIS">‘What can I do?’ Islena pleaded, wringing her hands. ‘He’s never openly disrespectful, and his decisions always </span><span class="italic" aid="G6PIT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PIU">seem</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PIV"> to be in the best interests of Cherek.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJ0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJ1">‘You need help, Islena,’ Merel told her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJ2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJ3">‘Whom can I turn to?’ The Queen of Cherek was almost in tears.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJ4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJ5">The Lady Merel smoothed the front of her green velvet gown. ‘I think it’s time that you wrote to Porenn,’ she declared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJ6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJ7">‘What do I say?’ Islena begged of her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJ8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJ9">Merel pointed at the small table in the corner where parchment and ink lay waiting. ‘Sit down,’ she instructed, ‘and write what I tell you to write.’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="G6PJA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJB">Count Brador, the Tolnedran ambassador, was definitely growing tiresome, Queen Layla decided. The plump little queen marched purposefully toward the chamber where she customarily gave audiences and where the ambassador awaited her with his satchel full of documents.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJD">The courtiers in the halls bowed as she passed, her crown slightly askew and her heels clicking on the polished oak floors, but Queen Layla uncharacteristically ignored them. This was not the time for polite exchanges or idle chitchat. The Tolnedran had to be dealt with, and she had delayed too long already.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJF">The ambassador was an olive-skinned man with receding hair and a hooked nose. He wore a brown mantle with the gold trim that indicated his relationship to the Borunes. He lounged rather indolently in a large, cushioned chair near the window of the sunny room where he and Queen Layla were to meet. He rose as she entered and bowed with exquisite grace. ‘Your Highness,’ he murmured politely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJH">‘My dear Count Brador,’ Queen Layla gushed at him, putting on her most helpless and scatterbrained expression, ‘please do sit down. I’m sure we know each other well enough by now to skip all these tedious formalities.’ She sank into a chair, fanning herself with one hand. ‘It’s turned warm, hasn’t it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJJ">‘Summers are lovely here in Sendaria, your Highness,’ the count replied, settling back in his chair. ‘I wonder – have you had the chance to think over the proposals I gave you at our last meeting?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJL">Queen Layla stared at him blankly. ‘Which proposals were those, Count Brador?’ She gave a helpless little giggle. ‘Please forgive me, but my mind seems to be absolutely gone these days. There are so many details. I wonder how my husband keeps them all straight.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJN">‘We were discussing the administration of the port at Camaar, your Highness,’ the count reminded her gently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJP">‘We were?’ The queen gave him a blank look of total incomprehension, secretly delighted at the flicker of annoyance that crossed his face. It was her best ploy. By pretending to have forgotten all previous conversations, she forced him to begin at the beginning every time they met. The count’s strategy, she knew, depended upon a gradual build-up to his final proposal, and her pretended forgetfulness neatly defeated that. ‘Whatever led us into such a tedious subject as that?’ she added.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJR">‘Surely your Highness recalls,’ the count protested with just the slightest hint of annoyance. ‘The Tolnedran merchant vessel, </span><span class="italic" aid="G6PJS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJT">Star of Tol Horb</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PJU">, was kept standing at anchor for a week and a half in the harbor before moorage could be found for her. Every day’s delay in unloading her was costing a fortune.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PJV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PK0">‘Things are so hectic these days,’ the queen of Sendaria sighed. ‘It’s the manpower shortage, you understand. Everybody who hasn’t gone off to war is busy freighting supplies to the army. I’ll send a very stern note to the port authorities about it, though. Was there anything else, Count Brador?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PK1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PK2">Brador coughed uncomfortably. ‘Uh – your Highness has already forwarded just such a note,’ he reminded her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PK3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PK4">‘I have?’ Queen Layla feigned astonishment. ‘Wonderful. That takes care of everything then, doesn’t it? And you’ve dropped by to thank me.’ She smiled girlishly. ‘How exquisitely courteous of you.’ She leaned forward to put one hand impulsively on his wrist, quite deliberately knocking the rolled parchment he was holding out of his hand. ‘How clumsy of me,’ she exclaimed, bending quickly to pick up the parchment before he could retrieve it. Then she sat back in her chair, tapping the rolled document absently against her cheek as if lost in thought.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PK5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PK6">‘Uh – actually, your Highness, our discussions had moved somewhat beyond your note to the port authorities,’ Brador told her, nervously eyeing the parchment she had so deftly taken from him. ‘You may recall that I offered Tolnedran assistance in administering the port. I believe we agreed that such assistance might help to alleviate the manpower shortage your Highness just mentioned.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PK7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PK8">‘What an absolutely marvelous idea,’ Layla exclaimed. She brought her plump little fist down on the arm of her chair as if in an outburst of enthusiasm. At that prearranged signal, two of her younger children burst into the room, arguing loudly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PK9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PKA">‘Mother!’ Princess Gelda wailed in outrage, ‘Fernie stole my red ribbon!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PKB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PKC">‘I did not!’ Princess Ferna denied the charge indignantly. ‘She gave it to me for my blue beads.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PKD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PKE">‘Did not!’ Gelda snapped.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PKF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PKG">‘Did so!’ Ferna replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PKH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PKI">‘Children, children,’ Layla chided them. ‘Can’t you see that Mother’s busy? What will the dear count think of us?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PKJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PKK">‘But she stole it, Mother!’ Gelda protested. ‘She stole my red ribbon.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PKL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PKM">‘Did not!’ Ferna said, spitefully sticking her tongue out at her sister.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PKN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PKO">Trailing behind them with a look of wide-eyed interest came little Prince Meldig, Queen Layla’s youngest child. In one hand the prince held a jam pot, and his face was liberally smeared with the contents. ‘Oh, that’s just impossible,’ Layla exclaimed, jumping to her feet. ‘You girls are supposed to be watching him.’ She bustled over to the jam-decorated prince, crumpled the parchment she was holding and began wiping his face with it. Abruptly she stopped. ‘Oh dear,’ she said as if suddenly realizing what she was doing. ‘Was this important, Count Brador?’ she asked the Tolnedran, holding out the rumpled, sticky document.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PKP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PKQ">Brador’s shoulders, however, had slumped in defeat. ‘No, your Highness,’ he replied in a voice filled with resignation, ‘not really. The royal house of Sendaria has me quite outnumbered, it appears.’ He rose to his feet. ‘Perhaps another time,’ he murmured, bowing. ‘With your Highness’s permission,’ he said, preparing to leave.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PKR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PKS">‘You mustn’t forget this, Count Brador,’ Layla said, pressing the parchment into his cringing hands.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PKT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PKU">The count’s face had a faintly martyred expression as he withdrew. Queen Layla turned back to her children, who were grinning impishly at her. She began to scold them in a loud voice until she was certain the count was well out of earshot, then she knelt, embraced them all and began to laugh.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PKV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PL0">‘Did we do it right, Mother?’ Princess Gelda asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PL1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PL2">‘You were absolutely perfect,’ Queen Layla replied, still laughing.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="G6PL3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PL4">Sadi the eunuch had grown careless, lulled somewhat by the air of polite civility that had pervaded the palace at Sthiss Tor for the past year, and one of his associates, seizing upon his unwariness, had taken the opportunity to poison him. Sadi definitely did not appreciate being poisoned. The antidotes all tasted vile, and the after-effects left him weak and light-headed. Thus it was that he viewed the appearance of the mail-shirted emissary of King Taur Urgas with thinly veiled irritation.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PL5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PL6">‘Taur Urgas, King of the Murgos, greets Sadi, chief servant of Immortal Salmissra,’ the Murgo declaimed with a deep bow as he entered the cool, dimly lighted study from which Sadi conducted most of the nation’s affairs.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PL7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PL8">‘The servant of the Serpent Queen returns the greetings of the right arm of the Dragon-God of Angarak.’ Sadi mouthed the formula phrases almost indifferently. ‘Do you suppose we could get to the point? I’m feeling a bit indisposed at the moment.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PL9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLA">‘I was very pleased at your recovery,’ the ambassador lied, his scarred face carefully expressionless. ‘Has the poisoner been apprehended yet?’ He drew up a chair and sat down at the polished table Sadi used for a desk.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PLB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLC">‘Naturally,’ Sadi replied, absently rubbing his hand over his shaved scalp.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PLD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLE">‘And executed?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PLF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLG">‘Why would we want to do that? The man’s a professional poisoner. He was only doing his job.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PLH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLI">The Murgo looked a bit startled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PLJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLK">‘We look upon a good poisoner as a national asset,’ Sadi told him. ‘If we start killing them every time they poison somebody, very soon there won’t be any of them left, and you never know when </span><span class="italic" aid="G6PLL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLM">I</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLN"> might want somebody poisoned.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PLO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLP">The Murgo ambassador shook his head incredulously. ‘You people have an amazing amount of tolerance, Sadi,’ he said in his harshly accented voice. ‘What about his employer?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PLQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLR">‘That’s another matter,’ Sadi replied. ‘His employer is currently entertaining the leeches at the bottom of the river. Is your visit official, or did you merely stop by to inquire after my health?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PLS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLT">‘A bit of each, Excellency.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PLU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PLV">‘You Murgos are an economical race,’ Sadi observed dryly. ‘What does Taur Urgas want this time?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PM0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PM1">‘The Alorns are preparing to invade Mishrak ac Thull, your Excellency.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PM2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PM3">‘So I’ve heard. What’s that got to do with Nyissa?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PM4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PM5">‘Nyissans have no reason to be fond of Alorns.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PM6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PM7">‘Nor any to be fond of Murgos, either,’ Sadi pointed out.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PM8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PM9">‘It was Aloria that invaded Nyissa following the death of the Rivan King,’ the Murgo reminded him, ‘and it was Cthol Murgos that provided the market for Nyissa’s primary export.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PMA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PMB">‘My dear fellow, please get to the point,’ Sadi said, rubbing his scalp wearily. ‘I’m not going to operate on the basis of long-past insults or long-forgotten favors. The slave trade is no longer significant, and the scars left by the Alorn invasion disappeared centuries ago. What does Taur Urgas want?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PMC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PMD">‘My king wishes to avoid bloodshed,’ the Murgo stated. ‘The Tolnedran legions form a significant part of the armies massing in Algaria. If a threat – just a threat, mind you – of unfriendly activity suddenly appeared on his unprotected southern frontier, Ran Borune would recall those legions. Their loss would persuade the Alorns to abandon this adventure.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PME"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PMF">‘You want </span><span class="italic" aid="G6PMG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PMH">me</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PMI"> to invade Tolnedra?’ Sadi demanded incredulously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PMJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PMK">‘Naturally not, Lord Sadi. His Majesty merely wishes your permission to move certain forces through your territory to pose the threat on Tolnedra’s southern border. No blood need be shed at all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PML"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PMM">‘Except Nyissan blood, once the Murgo army withdraws. The legions would swarm down across the River of the Woods like angry hornets.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PMN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PMO">‘Taur Urgas would be more than willing to leave garrisons behind to guarantee the integrity of Nyissan territory.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PMP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PMQ">‘I’m sure he would,’ Sadi observed dryly. ‘Advise your king that his proposal is quite unacceptable at this particular time.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PMR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PMS">‘The King of Cthol Murgos is a powerful man,’ the Murgo said firmly, ‘and he remembers those who thwart him even more keenly than he remembers his friends.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PMT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PMU">‘Taur Urgas is a madman,’ Sadi told him bluntly. ‘He wants to avoid trouble with the Alorns so that he can concentrate on ‘Zakath. Despite his insanity, however, he’s </span><span class="italic" aid="G6PMV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PN0">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PN1"> so foolish as to send an army into Nyissa uninvited. An army must eat, and Nyissa’s a bad place to forage for food – as history has demonstrated. The most tempting fruit has bitter juice.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PN2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PN3">‘A Murgo army carries its own food,’ the ambassador replied stiffly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PN4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PN5">‘Good for them. But where do they plan to find drinking water? I don’t believe we’re getting anywhere with this. I’ll convey your proposal to her Majesty. She, of course, will make the final decision. I suspect, however, that you’ll need to offer something much more attractive than a permanent Murgo occupation to persuade her to consider the matter favorably. Was that all?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PN6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PN7">The Murgo rose to his feet, his scarred face angry. He bowed coldly to Sadi and withdrew without further conversation.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PN8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PN9">Sadi thought about it for a while. He could gain a great deal of advantage at a minimal cost if he played this right. A few carefully worded dispatches to King Rhodar in Algaria would put Nyissa among the friends of the west. If Rhodar’s army should happen to win, Nyissa would benefit. If, on the other hand, it appeared that the west was about to lose, the proposal of Taur Urgas could be accepted. In either case, Nyissa would be on the winning side. The whole notion appealed to Sadi enormously. He stood up, his iridescent silk robe rustling, and went to a nearby cabinet. He took out a crystal decanter containing a dark blue liquid and carefully measured some of the thick syrup into a small glass and drank it. Almost immediately a euphoric calm came over him as his favorite drug took effect. A moment or two later, he felt that he was ready to face his queen. He was even smiling as he walked from his study into the dim corridor leading to the throne room.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PNA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PNB">As always, Salmissra’s chamber was dimly lighted by oil lamps hanging on long silver chains from the shadowy ceiling. The chorus of eunuchs still knelt adoringly in the queen’s presence, but they no longer sang her praises. Noise of any kind irritated Salmissra now, and it was wise not to irritate her. The Serpent Queen still occupied the divanlike throne beneath the towering statue of Issa. She dozed interminably, stirring her mottled coils with the seething dry hiss of scale rubbing against scale. But even in restless doze, her tongue flickered nervously. Sadi approached the throne, perfunctorily prostrated himself on the polished stone floor, and waited. His scent on the air would announce him to the hooded serpent who was his queen.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PNC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PND">‘Yes, Sadi?’ she whispered finally, her voice a dusty hiss.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PNE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PNF">‘The Murgos wish an alliance, my Queen,’ Sadi informed her. ‘Taur Urgas wants to threaten the Tolnedrans from the south to force Ran Borune to withdraw his legions from the Thullish border.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PNG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PNH">‘Interesting,’ she replied indifferently. Her dead eyes bored into him and her coils rustled. ‘What do you think?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PNI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PNJ">‘Neutrality costs nothing, Divine Samissra,’ Sadi replied. ‘Alliance with either side would be premature.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PNK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PNL">Salmissra turned, her mottled hood flaring as she regarded her reflection in the mirror beside her throne. The crown still rested on her head, as polished and glistening as her scales. Her tongue flickered, and her eyes, flat as glass, looked at the mirror. ‘Do what you think best, Sadi,’ she told him in an uncaring tone.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PNM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PNN">‘I’ll deal with the matter, my Queen,’ Sadi said, putting his face to the floor in preparation to leave.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PNO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PNP">‘I have no need of Torak now,’ she mused, still staring at the mirror. ‘Polgara saw to that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PNQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PNR">‘Yes, my Queen,’ Sadi agreed in a neutral voice, beginning to rise.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PNS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PNT">She turned to look at him. ‘Stay a while, Sadi. I’m lonely.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PNU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PNV">Sadi sank immediately back to the polished floor.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PO0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PO1">‘I have such strange dreams sometimes, Sadi,’ she hissed. ‘Such very strange dreams. I seem to remember things – things that happened when my blood was warm and I was a woman. Strange thoughts come to me in my dreams, and strange hungers.’ She looked directly at him, her hood flaring again as her pointed face stretched out toward him. ‘Was I really like that, Sadi? It all seems like something seen through smoke.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PO2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PO3">‘It was a difficult time, my Queen,’ Sadi replied candidly. ‘For all of us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PO4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PO5">‘Polgara was right, you know,’ she continued in that expiring whisper. ‘The potions enflamed me. I think it’s better this way – no passions, no hungers, no fears.’ She turned back to her mirror. ‘You may go now, Sadi.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PO6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PO7">He rose and started toward the door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PO8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PO9">‘Oh, Sadi.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6POA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6POB">‘Yes, my Queen?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6POC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6POD">‘If I caused you trouble before, I’m sorry.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6POE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6POF">He stared at her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6POG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6POH">‘Not very much, of course – but just a little.’ Then she returned to her reflection.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6POI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6POJ">Sadi was trembling as he closed the door behind him. Sometime later, he sent for Issus. The shabby, one-eyed hireling entered the chief eunuch’s study with a certain hesitancy, and his face was a bit apprehensive.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6POK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6POL">‘Come in, Issus,’ Sadi told him calmly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6POM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PON">‘I hope you aren’t holding any grudges, Sadi,’ Issus said nervously, looking about to be sure they were alone. ‘There was nothing personal in it, you know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6POO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6POP">‘It’s all right, Issus,’ Sadi assured him. ‘You were only doing what you were paid to do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6POQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6POR">‘How did you manage to detect it?’ Issus asked with a certain professional curiosity. ‘Most men are too far gone for the antidote to work before they realize they’ve been poisoned.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6POS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6POT">‘Your concoction leaves just the faintest aftertaste of lemon,’ Sadi replied. ‘I’ve been trained to recognize it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6POU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6POV">‘Ah,’ Issus said. ‘I’ll have to work on that. Otherwise it’s a very good poison.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PP0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PP1">‘An excellent poison, Issus,’ Sadi agreed. ‘That brings us to the reason I sent for you. There’s a man I think I can dispense with.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PP2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PP3">Issus’ single eye brightened, and he rubbed his hands together. ‘The usual fee?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PP4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PP5">‘Naturally.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PP6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PP7">‘Who is he?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PP8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PP9">‘The Murgo ambassador.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PPA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PPB">Issus’ face clouded for a moment. ‘He’ll be difficult to get to.’ He scratched at his stubbled scalp.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PPC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PPD">‘You’ll find a way. I have the utmost confidence in you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PPE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PPF">‘I’m the best,’ Issus agreed with no trace of false modesty.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PPG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PPH">‘The ambassador’s pressing me in certain negotiations that I need to delay,’ Sadi continued. ‘His sudden demise should interrupt things a bit.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PPI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PPJ">‘You don’t really have to explain, Sadi,’ Issus told him. ‘I don’t need to know why you want him killed.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PPK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PPL">‘But you do need to know </span><span class="italic" aid="G6PPM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PPN">how.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PPO"> For various reasons, I’d like for this to look very natural. Could you arrange for him – and perhaps a few others in his household – to come down with some kind of fever? Something suitably virulent?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PPP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PPQ">Issus frowned. ‘That’s tricky. Something like that can get out of hand. You might end up infecting an entire neighborhood, and there would be very few survivors.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PPR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PPS">Sadi shrugged. ‘One sometimes must make sacrifices. Can you do it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PPT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PPU">Issus nodded gravely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PPV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQ0">‘Do it then, and I’ll compose a letter expressing my regrets to King Taur Urgas.’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="G6PQ1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQ2">Queen Silar sat at her loom in the great hall of the Algar Stronghold, humming softly to herself as her fingers passed the shuttle back and forth with a drowsy, clicking sound. Sunlight streamed down from the narrow windows set high up in the wall, filling the huge, narrow room with a diffused golden light. King Cho-Hag and Hettar were away from the Stronghold, preparing a huge encampment some few leagues out from the base of the eastern escarpment for the army of Alorns, Arends, Sendars, and Tolnedrans approaching from the west. Although he was still within the borders of the kingdom, Cho-Hag had formally transferred authority to his wife, extracting a pledge of support from all of the assembled Clan-Chiefs.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQ3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQ4">The Queen of Algaria was a silent woman, and her calm face seldom betrayed her emotions. She had spent her entire life in the background, often so unobtrusively that people did not even realize that she was present. She had, however, kept her eyes and her ears open. Her crippled husband, moreover, had confided in her. His quiet, dark-haired queen knew exactly what was going on.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQ5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQ6">Elvar, Archpriest of Algaria, stood, white-robed and much puffed-up with his own importance, reading to her the set of carefully prepared proclamations which would effectively transfer all power to him. His tone was condescending as he explained them to her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQ7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQ8">‘Is that all?’ she asked when he had finished.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQ9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQA">‘It’s really for the best, your Highness,’ he told her loftily. ‘All the world knows that women are unsuited to rule. Shall I send for pen and ink?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQC">‘Not just yet, Elvar,’ she replied calmly, her hands busy at her loom.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQE">‘But—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQG">‘You know, I just had the oddest thought,’ she said, looking directly at him. ‘You’re the Archpriest of Belar here in Algaria, but you never go out of the Stronghold. Isn’t that a bit peculiar?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQI">‘My duties, your Highness, compel me—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQK">‘Isn’t your first duty to the people – and to the children of Belar? We’ve been terribly selfish keeping you here when your heart must be yearning to be out among the clans, overseeing the religious instruction of the children.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQM">He stared at her, his mouth suddenly agape.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQO">‘And all the other priests as well,’ she continued. ‘They all seem to be concentrated here at the Stronghold, pressed into administrative duties. A priest is too valuable a man for such tasks. This situation must be corrected immediately.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQQ">‘But—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQS">‘No, Elvar. My duty as queen is absolutely clear. The children of Algaria must come first. I release you from all your duties here at the Stronghold so that you may return to your chosen vocation.’ She smiled suddenly. ‘I’ll even draw up an itinerary for you myself,’ she said brightly. She thought a moment. ‘The times are troubled,’ she added, ‘so perhaps I’d better provide you with an escort – several trustworthy men from my own clan who can be depended upon to make sure that you aren’t interrupted in your travels or distracted from your preaching by any disturbing messages from abroad.’ She looked at him again. ‘That will be all, Elvar. You’d probably better go pack. It will be a number of seasons before you return, I imagine.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PQU">The Archpriest of Belar was making strangled noises.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PQV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PR0">‘Oh, one other thing.’ The queen carefully chose another skein of yarn and held it up to the sunlight. ‘It’s been years since anyone made a survey of the herds. As long as you’re going to be out there anyway, I think I’d like an accurate count of all the calves and colts in Algaria. It will give you something to occupy your mind. Send me a report from time to time, won’t you?’ She returned to her weaving. ‘You’re dismissed, Elvar,’ she said placidly, not even bothering to look up as the Archpriest, shaking with rage, tottered away to make preparations for his roving imprisonment.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="G6PR1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PR2">Lord Morin, High Chamberlain to his Imperial Majesty, Ran Borune XXIII, sighed as he entered the Emperor’s private garden. Another tirade was undoubtedly in the offing, and Morin had already heard it all a dozen times at least. The Emperor had an extraordinary capacity for repeating himself sometimes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PR3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PR4">Ran Borune, however, was in an odd mood. The bald, beak-nosed little Emperor sat pensively in his chair beneath a shady ardor, listening to the trilling of his canary. ‘He’s never spoken again, did you know that, Morin?’ the Emperor said as his chamberlain approached across the close-clipped grass. ‘Just that one time when Polgara was here.’ He looked at the little golden bird again, his eyes sad. Then he sighed. ‘I think I came out second best in that bargain. Polgara gave me a canary and took Ce’Nedra in exchange.’ He looked around at his sun-drenched garden and the cool marble walls surrounding it. ‘Is it just my imagination, Morin, or does the palace seem sort of cold and empty now?’ He lapsed once more into moody silence, staring with unseeing eyes at a bed of crimson roses.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PR5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PR6">Then there was an odd sound, and Lord Morin looked sharply at the Emperor, half afraid that his ruler was about to go into another seizure. But there was no evidence of that. Instead, Morin perceived that Ran Borune was chuckling. ‘Did you see how she tricked me, Morin?’ The Emperor laughed. ‘She deliberately goaded me into that fit. What a son she would have made! She could have been the greatest Emperor in Tolnedra’s history.’ Ran Borune was laughing openly now, his secret delight at Ce’Nedra’s cleverness suddenly emerging.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PR7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PR8">‘She </span><span class="italic" aid="G6PR9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRA">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRB"> your daughter after all, your Majesty,’ Lord Morin observed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PRC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRD">‘To think that she could raise an army of that size when she’s barely sixteen,’ the Emperor marveled. ‘What a splendid child!’ He seemed quite suddenly to have recovered from the gloomy peevishness that had dogged him since his return to Tol Honeth. His laughter trailed away after several moments, and his bright little eyes narrowed shrewdly. ‘Those legions she stole from me are likely to become fractious without professional leadership,’ he mused.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PRE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRF">‘I’d say that’s Ce’Nedra’s problem, your Majesty,’ Morin replied. ‘Or Polgara’s.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PRG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRH">‘Well—’ The Emperor scratched one ear. ‘I don’t know, Morin. The situation out there isn’t too clear.’ He looked at his chamberlain. ‘Are you acquainted with General Varana?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PRI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRJ">‘The Duke of Anadile? Of course, your Majesty. A thoroughly professional sort of fellow – solid, unassuming, extremely intelligent.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PRK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRL">‘He’s an old friend of the family,’ Ran Borune confided. ‘Ce’Nedra knows him and she would listen to his advice. Why don’t you go to him, Morin, and suggest that he might want to take a leave of absence – perhaps go to Algaria and have a look at things?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PRM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRN">‘I’m certain that he’d be overjoyed at the idea of a vacation,’ Lord Morin agreed. ‘Garrison life in the summertime can be very tedious.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PRO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRP">‘It’s just a suggestion,’ the Emperor stressed. ‘His presence in the war zone would have to be strictly unofficial.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PRQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRR">‘Naturally, your Majesty.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PRS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRT">‘And if he just </span><span class="italic" aid="G6PRU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PRV">happened</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PS0"> to make a few suggestions – or even provide a bit of leadership, we certainly wouldn’t have any knowledge of it, would we? After all, what a private citizen does with his own time is </span><span class="italic" aid="G6PS1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PS2">his</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PS3"> business, right?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PS4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PS5">‘Absolutely, your Majesty.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PS6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PS7">The Emperor grinned broadly. ‘And we’ll all stick to that story, won’t we, Morin?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PS8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PS9">‘Like glue, your Majesty,’ Morin replied gravely.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="G6PSA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PSB">The crown prince of Drasnia burped noisily in his mother’s ear, sighed, and promptly fell asleep on her shoulder. Queen Porenn smiled at him, tucked him back in his cradle, and turned again to the stringy-appearing man in nondescript clothing who sprawled in a nearby chair. The emaciated man was known only by the peculiar name ‘Javelin.’ Javelin was the chief of the Drasnian intelligence service and one of Porenn’s closest advisers.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PSC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PSD">‘Anyway,’ he continued his report, ‘the Tolnedran girl’s army is about two days’ march from the Stronghold. The engineers are moving along ahead of schedule with the hoists on top of the escarpment, and the Chereks are preparing to begin the portage from the east bank of the Aldur.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PSE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PSF">‘Everything seems to be going according to plan, then,’ the queen said, resuming her seat at the polished table near the window.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PSG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PSH">‘There’s a bit of trouble in Arendia,’ Javelin noted. ‘The usual ambushes and bickerings – nothing really serious. Queen Layla’s got the Tolnedran, Bravor, so completely off-balance that he might as well not even be in Sendaria.’ He scratched at his long, pointed jaw. ‘There’s peculiar information coming out of Sthiss Tor. The Murgos are trying to negotiate something, but their emissaries keep dying. We’ll try to get somebody closer to Sadi to find out exactly what’s going on. Let’s see – what else? Oh, the Honeths have finally united behind one candidate – a pompous, arrogant jackass who’s offended just about everybody in Tol Honeth. They’ll try to buy the crown for him, but he’d be hopelessly incompetent as emperor. Even with all their money, it’s going to be difficult for them to put him on the throne. I guess that’s about all, your Highness.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PSI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PSJ">‘I’ve had a letter from Islena in Val Alorn,’ Queen Porenn told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PSK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PSL">‘Yes, your Highness,’ Javelin replied urbanely, ‘I know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PSM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PSN">‘Javelin, have you been reading my mail again?’ she demanded with a sudden flash of irritation.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PSO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PSP">‘Just trying to stay current with what’s going on in the world, Porenn.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PSQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PSR">‘I’ve told you to stop that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PSS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PST">‘You didn’t really expect me to do it, did you?’ He seemed actually surprised.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PSU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PSV">She laughed. ‘You’re impossible.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PT0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PT1">‘Of course I am. I’m supposed to be.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PT2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PT3">‘Can we get any help to Islena?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PT4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PT5">‘I’ll put some people on it,’ he assured her. ‘We can probably work through Merel, the wife of the Earl of Trellheim. She’s starting to show some signs of maturity and she’s close to Islena.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PT6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PT7">‘I think we’d better have a close look at our own intelligence service, too,’ Porenn suggested. ‘Let’s pin down everyone who might have any connections with the Bear-cult. The time might come when we’ll have to take steps.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PT8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PT9">Javelin nodded his agreement.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PTA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PTB">There was a light tapping at the door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PTC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PTD">‘Yes?’ Porenn answered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PTE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PTF">The door opened and a servant thrust his head into the room. ‘Excuse me, your Highness,’ he said, ‘but there’s a Nadrak merchant here – a man named Yarblek. He says he wants to discuss the salmon run.’ The servant looked perplexed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="G6PTG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="G6PTH">Queen Porenn straightened in her chair. ‘Send him in,’ she ordered, ‘at once.’</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_17" aid="G6PTI"></div>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
  <link href="kindle:flow:0001?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
<link href="kindle:flow:0002?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
</head>
  <body class="calibre" aid="H5A40">
</body>
</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos331914" aid="H5A41"><span class="calibre5" aid="H5A42"><span class="italic" aid="H5A43"><span class="bold" aid="H5A44"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A45">Chapter Nine</span></span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="H5A46"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A47">The speeches were over. The orations that had caused Princess Ce’Nedra such agony had done their work, and she found herself less and less in the center of things. At first the days opened before her full of glorious freedom. The dreadful anxiety that had filled her at the prospect of addressing vast crowds of men two or three times a day was gone now. Her nervous exhaustion disappeared, and she no longer awoke in the middle of the night trembling and terrified. For almost an entire week she reveled in it, luxuriated in it. Then, of course, she became dreadfully bored.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A48"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A49">The army she had gathered in Arendia and northern Tolnedra moved like a great sea in the foothills of Ulgoland. The Mimbrate knights, their armor glittering in the bright sunlight and their long, streaming, many-colored pennons snapping in the breeze, moved at the forefront of the host, and behind them, spreading out across the rolling green hills, marched the solid mass of Ce’Nedra’s infantry, Sendars, Asturians, Rivans, and a few Chereks. And there, solidly in the center, forming the very core, marched the gleaming ranks of the legions of Imperial Tolnedra, their crimson standards aloft and the white plumes on their helmets waving in time to their measured steps. It was very stirring for the first few days to ride at the head of the enormous force, moving at her command toward the east, but the novelty of it all soon wore thin.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A4A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A4B">Princess Ce’Nedra’s gradual drift away from the center of command was largely her own fault. The decisions now had to do more often than not with logistics – tedious little details concerning bivouac areas and field-kitchens – and Ce’Nedra found discussions of such matters tiresome. Those details, however, dictated the snail’s pace of her army.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A4C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A4D">Quite suddenly, to everyone’s astonishment, King Fulrach of Sendaria became the absolute commander of the host. It was he who decided how far they would march each day, when they would rest and where they would set up each night’s encampment. His authority derived directly from the fact that the supply wagons were his. Quite early during the march down through northern Arendia, the dumpy-looking Sendarian monarch had taken one look at the rather sketchy plans the Alorn kings had drawn up for feeding the troops, had shaken his head in disapproval, and then had taken charge of that aspect of the campaign himself. Sendaria was a land of farms, and her storehouses bulged. Moreover, at certain seasons, every road and lane in Sendaria crawled with wagons. With an almost casual efficiency, King Fulrach issued a few orders, and soon whole caravans of heavily laden wagons moved down through Arendia to Tolnedra and then turned eastward to follow the army. The pace of the army was dictated by those creaking supply wagons.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A4E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A4F">They were only a few days into the Ulgo foothills when the full weight of King Fulrach’s authority became clear.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A4G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A4H">‘Fulrach,’ King Rhodar of Drasnia objected when the King of the Sendars called a halt for yet another rest period, ‘if we don’t move any faster than this, it will take us all summer to get to the eastern escarpment.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A4I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A4J">‘You’re exaggerating, Rhodar,’ King Fulrach replied mildly. ‘We’re making pretty good time. The supply wagons are heavy, and the wagon horses have to be rested every hour.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A4K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A4L">‘This is impossible,’ Rhodar declared. ‘I’m going to pick up the pace.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A4M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A4N">‘That’s up to you, of course.’ The brown-bearded Sendar shrugged, coolly eyeing Rhodar’s vast paunch. ‘But if you exhaust my wagon horses today, you won’t eat tomorrow.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A4O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A4P">And that ended that.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A4Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A4R">The going in the steep passes of Ulgoland was even slower. Ce’Nedra entered that land of thick forests and rocky crags with apprehension. She vividly remembered the flight with Grul the Eldrak and the attacks of the Algroths and the Hrulgin that had so terrified her that previous winter. There were few meetings with the monsters that lurked in the Ulgo mountains, however. The army was so large that even the fiercest creatures avoided it. Mandorallen, the Baron of Vo Mandor, rather regretfully reported only brief sightings.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A4S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A4T">‘Mayhap if I were to ride a day’s march in advance of our main force, I might find opportunity to engage some of the more frolicsome beasts,’ he mused aloud one evening, staring thoughtfully into the fire.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A4U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A4V">‘You never get enough, do you?’ Barak asked him pointedly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A50"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A51">‘Never mind, Mandorallen,’ Polgara told the great knight. ‘The creatures aren’t hurting us, and the Gorim of Ulgo would be happier if we didn’t bother them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A52"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A53">Mandorallen sighed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A54"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A55">‘Is he always like that?’ King Anheg asked Barak curiously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A56"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A57">‘You have absolutely no idea,’ Barak replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A58"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A59">The slow march through Ulgoland, regardless of how much it chafed Rhodar, Brand, and Anheg, did, however, conserve the strength of the army, and they came down onto the plains of Algaria in surprisingly good shape.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A5A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5B">‘We’ll go on to the Algarian Stronghold,’ King Rhodar decided as the army poured down out of the last pass and fanned out across the rolling grasslands. ‘We need to regroup a bit, and I don’t see any point in moving to the base of the escarpment until the engineers are ready for us. Besides, I’d prefer not to announce the size of our army to any Thull who happens to glance down from the top of the cliff.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A5C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5D">And so, in easy stages, the army marched across Algaria, trampling a mile-wide swath through the tall grass. Vast herds of cattle paused briefly in their grazing to watch with mild-eyed astonishment as the horde marched by, then returned to their feeding under the protective watch of mounted Algar clansmen.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A5E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5F">The encampment that was set up around the towering Stronghold in south central Algaria stretched for miles, and the watch fires at night seemed almost a reflection of the stars. Once she was comfortably quartered in the Stronghold, Princess Ce’Nedra found herself even more removed from the day-to-day command of her troops. Her hours seemed filled with tedium. This is not to say that she did not receive reports. A rigorous schedule of training was instituted, in part because large portions of the army were not professional soldiers, but primarily to avoid the idleness that led to discipline problems. Each morning, Colonel Brendig, the sober-faced Sendarian baronet who seemed utterly devoid of humor, reported the progress of the previous day’s training with excruciating thoroughness, along with all sorts of other tedious little details – most of which Ce’Nedra found extremely distasteful.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A5G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5H">One morning after Brendig had respectfully withdrawn, Ce’Nedra finally exploded. ‘If he mentions the word “sanitation” one more time, I think I’ll scream,’ she declared to Adara and Polgara. The princess was pacing up and down, flinging her arms in the air in exasperation.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A5I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5J">‘It </span><span class="italic" aid="H5A5K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5L">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5M"> fairly important in an army of this size, Ce’Nedra,’ Adara calmly pointed out.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A5N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5O">‘But does he have to </span><span class="italic" aid="H5A5P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5Q">talk</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5R"> about it all the time? It’s a disgusting subject.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A5S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5T">Polgara, who had been patiently teaching the little blond waif, Errand, how to lace up his boots, looked up, assessed Ce’Nedra’s mood in a single glance, and then made a suggestion. ‘Why don’t you young ladies take some horses and go for a ride? A bit of fresh air and exercise seems definitely to be in order.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A5U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A5V">It took only a short while for them to find the blond Mimbrate girl, Ariana. They knew exactly where to look. It took a bit longer, however, to wrench her away from her rapt contemplation of Lelldorin of Wildantor. Lelldorin, with the aid of his cousin Torasin, was struggling to teach a group of Arendish serfs the basics of archery. Torasin, a fiery young Asturian patriot, had joined the army late. There had been, Ce’Nedra gathered, some unpleasantness between the two young men, but the prospect of war and glory had finally been too much for Torasin to resist. He had overtaken the army in the western foothills of Ulgoland, mounted on a horse half-dead from hard riding. His reconciliation with Lelldorin had been emotional, and now the two were closer than ever. Ariana, however, watched only Lelldorin.
