Her eyes glowed as she gazed at him with an adoration so totally mindless that it was frightening.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A60"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A61">The three girls, dressed in soft leather Algar riding clothes, cantered out through the encampment in bright midmorning sunlight, followed inevitably by Olban, youngest son of the Rivan Warder, and a detachment of guards. Ce’Nedra did not know exactly what to make of Olban. Since a hidden Murgo had made an attempt on her life in the Arendish forest, the young Rivan had appointed himself the chief of her personal bodyguards, and absolutely nothing could move him to abandon that duty. For some reason, he seemed almost grateful for the opportunity to serve, and Ce’Nedra was glumly certain that only physical force could make him stop.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A62"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A63">It was a warm, cloudless day, and the blue sky stretched over the incredible expanse of the Algarian plain, where tall grass bent before a vagrant breeze. Once they were out of sight of the encampment, Ce’Nedra’s spirits rose enormously. She rode the white horse King Cho-Hag had given her, a patient, even-tempered animal she had named Noble. Noble was probably not a good name for him, since he was a lazy horse. A great part of his placidity arose from the fact that his new owner was so tiny that she had virtually no weight. Moreover, in an excess of affection, Ce’Nedra babied him outrageously, slipping apples and bits of sweets to him whenever possible. As a result of his light exercise and rich diet, Noble was developing a noticeable portliness.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A64"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A65">In the company of her two friends, and trailed by the watchful young Olban, the princess, mounted on her stout white horse, rode out across the grassland, exulting in the sense of freedom their ride brought to her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A66"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A67">They reined in at the base of a long, sloping hill to rest their mounts. Noble, puffing like a bellows, cast a reproachful look over his shoulder at his tiny mistress, but she heartlessly ignored his unspoken complaint. ‘It’s an absolutely wonderful day for a ride,’ she exclaimed enthusiastically.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A68"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A69">Ariana sighed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A6A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6B">Ce’Nedra laughed at her. ‘Oh, come now, it’s not as if Lelldorin were going someplace, Ariana, and it’s good for men to miss us a little once in a while.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A6C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6D">Ariana smiled rather wanly, then sighed again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A6E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6F">‘Perhaps it’s not as good for us to miss them, however,’ Adara murmured without any trace of a smile.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A6G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6H">‘What </span><span class="italic" aid="H5A6I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6J">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6K"> that lovely fragrance?’ Ce’Nedra asked suddenly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A6L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6M">Adara lifted her porcelain face to sniff at the light breeze, then suddenly looked around as if trying to pinpoint their exact location. ‘Come with me,’ she said with an uncharacteristic note of command in her voice, and she led them around the base of the hill to the far side. About halfway up the grassy slope there was a patch of low, dark green bushes covered with pale lavender flowers. There had been that morning a hatch of blue butterflies, and the winged creatures hovered in an ecstatic cloud over the flowers. Without pausing, Adara pressed her mount up the slope and swung down from her saddle. There with a low cry she knelt almost reverently, gathering the bushes in her arms as if embracing them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A6N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6O">When Ce’Nedra drew closer, she was amazed to see tears welling up in her gentle friend’s gray eyes, although Adara was actually smiling. ‘Whatever is wrong, Adara?’ she asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A6P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6Q">‘They’re </span><span class="italic" aid="H5A6R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6S">my</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6T"> flowers,’ Adara replied in a vibrant voice. ‘I didn’t realize that they’d grow and spread this way.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A6U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A6V">‘What are you talking about?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A70"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A71">‘Garion created this flower last winter – just for me. There was only one – just one. I saw it come into existence right there in his hand. I’d forgotten it until just now. Look how far it’s spread in just one season.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A72"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A73">Ce’Nedra felt a sudden pang of jealousy. Garion had never created a flower for </span><span class="italic" aid="H5A74"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A75">her.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A76"> She bent and pulled one of the lavender blooms from a bush, tugging perhaps just a bit harder than necessary. ‘It’s lopsided,’ she sniffed, looking at the flower critically. Then she bit her lip, wishing she hadn’t said that.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A77"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A78">Adara gave her a quick look of protest.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A79"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A7A">‘I’m only teasing, Adara,’ Ce’Nedra said quickly with a false little laugh. In spite of herself, still wanting to find something else wrong with the flower, she bent her face to the small, crooked blossom in her hand. Its fragrance seemed to erase all of her cares and to lift her spirits tremendously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A7B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A7C">Ariana had also dismounted, and she too was breathing in the gentle odor of the flowers, although there was a slight frown on her face. ‘Might I gather some few of thy blossoms, Lady Adara?’ she inquired. ‘Methinks they have some strange property concealed within their blushing petals that may be of some interest to Lady Polgara – some healing agent too subtle for my limited familiarity with unguents and aromatic herbs to discern.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A7D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A7E">Rather predictably, Ce’Nedra, having gone one way, suddenly reversed herself. ‘Marvelous!’ she exclaimed, clapping her hands with delight. ‘Wouldn’t it be wonderful if your flower turned out to be a great medicine, Adara? Some miraculous cure? We could call it “Adara’s rose,” and sick men would bless your name forever.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A7F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A7G">‘It doesn’t exactly look like a rose, Ce’Nedra,’ Adara pointed out.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A7H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A7I">‘Nonsense,’ Ce’Nedra brushed the distinction aside. ‘I’m supposed to be a queen, after all, so if I say it’s a rose, then it’s a rose, and that’s that. We’ll take the flowers back to Lady Polgara at once.’ She turned back to her tubby horse, who was lazily regarding the flowers as if wondering whether or not to eat a few of them. ‘Come, Noble,’ the princess said to him with extravagant overstatement. ‘We’ll gallop back to the Stronghold.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A7J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A7K">Noble winced visibly at the word ‘gallop.’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="H5A7L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A7M">Polgara examined the flowers carefully, but, to the disappointment of the princess and her friends, she would not commit herself immediately concerning their medicinal value. A bit subdued, the little princess returned quietly to her quarters and her duties.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A7N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A7O">Colonel Brendig was awaiting her. Upon reflection, Ce’Nedra concluded that Colonel Brendig was by far the most practical man she had ever met. No detail was too small for him. In a lesser man, such concern with little things might have been passed off as mere fussiness, but the colonel’s belief that big things were made up of little things gave his patient attention to detail a certain dignity. He seemed to be everywhere in the camp; in his wake, tent-ropes were tightened, cluttered heaps of equipment were arranged into neat stacks, and casually open doublets were quickly buttoned up.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A7P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A7Q">‘I hope that her Majesty found her ride refreshing,’ the colonel said politely, bowing as Ce’Nedra entered the room.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A7R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A7S">‘Thank you, Colonel Brendig,’ the princess replied. ‘My Majesty did.’ She was in a whimsical frame of mind, and it was always a delight to tease this sober-faced Sendar.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A7T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A7U">A brief smile touched Brendig’s lips, and then he immediately got down to the business of the midday report. ‘I’m pleased to advise your Majesty that the Drasnian engineers have nearly completed the hoists atop the escarpment,’ he reported. ‘All that remains is the rigging of the counterweights which will help to lift the Cherek warships.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A7V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A80">‘That’s nice,’ Ce’Nedra said with the vacant, empty-headed smile she knew drove him absolutely wild.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A81"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A82">Brendig’s jaw tightened slightly, but his face betrayed no other sign of his momentary flash of irritation. ‘The Chereks are beginning to remove the masts and rigging from their ships in preparation for the portage,’ he continued, ‘and the fortified positions up on top of the escarpment are several days ahead of schedule.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A83"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A84">‘How wonderful!’ Ce’Nedra exclaimed, clapping her hands with a great show of girlish delight.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A85"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A86">‘Your Majesty, </span><span class="italic" aid="H5A87"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A88">please</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A89">,’ Brendig complained.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A8A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8B">‘I’m sorry, Colonel Brendig,’ Ce’Nedra apologized, affectionately patting his hand. ‘For some reason you bring out the very worst in me. Don’t you </span><span class="italic" aid="H5A8C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8D">ever</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8E"> smile?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A8F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8G">He looked at her with an absolutely straight face. ‘I am smiling, your Majesty,’ he said. ‘Oh – you have a visitor from Tolnedra.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A8H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8I">‘A visitor? Who?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A8J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8K">‘A General Varana, the Duke of Anadile.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A8L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8M">‘Varana? Here? What on earth is he doing in Algaria? Is he alone?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A8N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8O">‘There are a number of other Tolnedran gentlemen with him,’ Brendig replied. ‘They aren’t in uniform, but they have the general bearing of military men. They </span><span class="italic" aid="H5A8P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8Q">say</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8R"> that they’re here as private observers. General Varana expressed a desire to pay his respects whenever it might be convenient.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A8S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8T">‘Of course, Colonel Brendig,’ Ce’Nedra said with an enthusiasm that was no longer feigned. ‘Please send for him at once.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A8U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A8V">Ce’Nedra had known General Varana since her earliest childhood. He was a stocky man with graying, curly hair and a stiff left knee that gave him a noticeable limp. He was blessed with that wry, understated sense of humor so characteristic of the Anadilian family. Of all the noble houses of Tolnedra, the Borunes were most comfortable with the Anadiles. Both families were southern, for one thing, and the Anadiles usually sided with the Borunes in disputes with the powerful families of the north. Although Anadile was only a duchy, there had never been any hint of subservience in the family’s alliances with the Grand Dukes of the House of Borune. Indeed, Anadilian dukes, more often than not, poked gentle fun at their more powerful neighbors. Serious historians and statesmen had long considered it a misfortune for the Empire that the talented House of Anadile had not enough wealth to make a serious bid for the Imperial Throne.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A90"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A91">When General Varana politely limped into the room where Ce’Nedra impatiently awaited him, there was a faint smile hovering on his lips and a quizzical lift to one of his eyebrows. ‘Your Majesty,’ he greeted her with a bow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A92"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A93">‘Uncle Varana,’ the princess exclaimed, flying to embrace him. Varana was not, in fact, her uncle, but she had always thought of him as such.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A94"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A95">‘What have you gone and done now, my little Ce’Nedra?’ He laughed, enfolding her in his thick-muscled arms. ‘You’re turning the world upside-down, you know. What’s a Borune doing in the middle of Algaria with an Alorn army at her back?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A96"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A97">‘I’m going to invade Mishrak ac Thull,’ she declared impishly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A98"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A99">‘Really? Whatever for? Did King Gethell of Thulldom insult the House of Borune in some way? I hadn’t heard about it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A9A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A9B">‘It’s an Alorn matter,’ Ce’Nedra replied airily.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A9C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A9D">‘Oh, I see. That explains it, I suppose. Alorns don’t need reasons for the things they do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A9E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A9F">‘You’re laughing at me,’ she accused him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A9G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A9H">‘Of course I am, Ce’Nedra. The Anadiles have been laughing at the Borunes for thousands of years.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A9I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A9J">She pouted. ‘It’s </span><span class="italic" aid="H5A9K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A9L">very</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A9M"> serious, Uncle Varana.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A9N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A9O">‘Naturally it is,’ he agreed, gently touching her out-thrust lower lip with one thick finger, ‘but that’s no reason not to laugh about it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A9P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A9Q">‘You’re impossible,’ Ce’Nedra said helplessly, laughing in spite of herself. ‘What are you doing here?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A9R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A9S">‘Observing,’ he told her. ‘Generals do that a lot. You’ve got the only war that’s going on just now, so several of us thought we’d drop by and have a look. Morin suggested it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A9T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5A9U">‘My father’s chamberlain?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5A9V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AA0">‘I think that’s his function, yes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AA1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AA2">‘Morin wouldn’t do that – not on his own.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AA3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AA4">‘Really? What astonishing news.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AA5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AA6">Ce’Nedra frowned, nibbling absently at a lock of her hair. Varana reached out and took the lock out from between her teeth. ‘Morin doesn’t do anything unless my father tells him to,’ Ce’Nedra mused, once again lifting the curl to her lips.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AA7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AA8">Varana took the lock out of her fingers again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AA9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AAA">‘Don’t do that,’ she told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AAB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AAC">‘Why not? That’s the way I broke you of sucking your thumb.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AAD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AAE">‘This is different. I’m thinking.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AAF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AAG">‘Think with your mouth closed.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AAH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AAI">‘This was my father’s idea, wasn’t it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AAJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AAK">‘I wouldn’t presume to say I knew the Emperor’s mind,’ he replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AAL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AAM">‘Well, I would. What’s that old fox up to?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AAN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AAO">‘That’s hardly respectful, child.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AAP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AAQ">‘You say you’re here to observe?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AAR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AAS">He nodded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AAT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AAU">‘And perhaps make a few suggestions?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AAV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AB0">He shrugged. ‘If anyone cares to listen. I’m not here officially, you understand. Imperial policy forbids that. Your claim to the Rivan throne is not formally recognized in Tol Honeth.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AB1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AB2">She cast a sidelong glance at him through her thick eyelashes. ‘These suggestions you might make – if you happened to be near a Tolnedran legion that seemed to need a bit of direction, is it at all possible that one of these suggestions might be “forward march?”’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AB3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AB4">‘That situation might arise, yes,’ he admitted gravely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AB5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AB6">‘And you have a number of other officers of the general staff with you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AB7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AB8">‘I think several of them </span><span class="italic" aid="H5AB9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABA">do</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABB">, in fact, serve occasionally on that body.’ His eyes were twinkling with suppressed mirth.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ABC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABD">Ce’Nedra lifted the lock again, and General Varana took it away from her once more.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ABE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABF">‘How would you like to meet King Rhodar of Drasnia?’ she asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ABG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABH">‘I’d be honored to meet his Majesty.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ABI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABJ">‘Why don’t we go to see him, then?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ABK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABL">‘Why don’t we?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ABM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABN">‘Oh, I love you, Uncle.’ She laughed, throwing her arms about him again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ABO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABP">They found King Rhodar in conference with the other leaders of the army in a large airy chamber King Cho-Hag had set aside for their use. There was no longer any pretence of formality among the leaders of the army, and most of them sprawled in comfortable horsehide chairs, watching as the crimson-robed Rhodar measured off distances with a piece of string on a large map that covered one entire wall. ‘It doesn’t really seem all that far to me,’ he was saying to King Cho-Hag.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ABQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABR">‘That’s because your map is flat, Rhodar,’ Cho-Hag replied. ‘The country’s very hilly through there. Believe me, it will take three days.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ABS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABT">King Rhodar made an indelicate sound of disgust. ‘I guess we’ll have to give up the idea, then. I’d like to burn out those forts, but I’m not going to start ordering suicide missions. Three days’ ride is just too far.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ABU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ABV">‘Your Majesty,’ Ce’Nedra said politely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AC0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AC1">‘Yes, child?’ Rhodar was still frowning at the map.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AC2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AC3">‘I’d like for you to meet someone.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AC4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AC5">King Rhodar turned.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AC6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AC7">‘Your Majesty,’ Ce’Nedra said formally, ‘may I present his Grace, the Duke of Anadile? General Varana, his Majesty, King Rhodar of Drasnia.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AC8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AC9">The two men bowed politely to each other, their eyes probing, assessing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ACA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ACB">‘The general’s reputation precedes him,’ King Rhodar noted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ACC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ACD">‘But his Majesty’s skill as a military man has been kept a secret,’ Varana replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ACE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ACF">‘Do you think that satisfies the demands of courtesy?’ Rhodar asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ACG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ACH">‘If not, we can both lie a little bit later on about how excruciatingly polite we were to each other,’ Varana suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ACI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ACJ">King Rhodar flashed him a quick grin. ‘All right, what’s Tolnedra’s leading tactician doing in Algaria?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ACK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ACL">‘Observing, your Majesty.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ACM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ACN">‘You’re going to stick to that story?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ACO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ACP">‘Naturally. For political reasons, Tolnedra must maintain a neutral posture in this affair. I’m certain that Drasnian intelligence has briefed your Majesty on the realities of the situation. The five spies you have in the Imperial palace are thoroughly professional.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ACQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ACR">‘Six, actually,’ King Rhodar noted in passing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ACS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ACT">General Varana raised one eyebrow. ‘I suppose we should have known,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ACU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ACV">‘It changes from time to time,’ Rhodar shrugged. ‘You know our strategic situation?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AD0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AD1">‘I’ve been filled in, yes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AD2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AD3">‘What’s your assessment – as an observer?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AD4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AD5">‘You’re in trouble.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AD6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AD7">‘Thanks,’ Rhodar said dryly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AD8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AD9">‘The numbers dictate that you take a defensive posture.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ADA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ADB">Rhodar shook his head. ‘That might work if all we had to worry about was Taur Urgas and the Southern Murgos, but ‘Zakath is landing more troops at Thull Zelik every day. If we fortify and try to sit tight, and he decides to move against us, he’ll be able to bury us in Malloreans by autumn. The key to the whole situation is putting Anheg’s fleet into the Sea of the East to stop those troop ships. We’re going to have to gamble a bit in order to pull that off.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ADC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ADD">Varana studied the map. ‘If you’re going to go down the River Mardu, you’ll have to neutralize the Thullish capital,’ he said, pointing at Thull Mardu. ‘It’s an island – like Tol Honeth – and it’s right in the middle of the river. You’ll never get a fleet past it as long as a hostile force holds it. You’ll have to take the city.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ADE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ADF">‘That had already occurred to us,’ King Anheg said from where he sprawled in his chair with his ever-present ale cup in his hand.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ADG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ADH">‘You know Anheg?’ Rhodar asked the general.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ADI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ADJ">Varana nodded. ‘By reputation,’ he replied. He bowed to King Anheg. ‘Your Majesty,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ADK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ADL">‘General,’ Anheg responded, inclining his head.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ADM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ADN">‘If Thull Mardu is heavily defended, it will cost you a third of your army to take it,’ Varana continued.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ADO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ADP">‘We’re going to lure the garrison out,’ Rhodar told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ADQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ADR">‘How?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ADS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ADT">‘That’s going to be up to Korodullin and me,’ King Cho-Hag said quietly. ‘Once we get to the top of the escarpment, the Mimbrate knights are going to move out and crush every city and town in the uplands, and my clansmen will strike down into the farming regions to burn every standing crop.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5ADU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5ADV">‘They’ll realize that’s only a diversion, your Majesty,’ Varana pointed out.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AE0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AE1">‘Naturally,’ Brand agreed in his rumbling voice, ‘but a diversion from what? We don’t think they’ll fully realize that Thull Mardu is our main objective. We’ll try our best to make our depredations as general as possible. The loss of those towns and crops might be acceptable at first, but it won’t be long before they’ll have to take steps to protect them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AE2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AE3">‘And you think they’ll pull the garrison out of Thull Mardu to meet you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AE4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AE5">‘That’s the idea,’ King Rhodar replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AE6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AE7">Varana shook his head. ‘They’ll bring Murgos up from Rak Goska and Malloreans from Thull Zelik. Then instead of a quick raid on Thull Mardu, you’ll have a general war on your hands.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AE8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AE9">‘That’s what </span><span class="italic" aid="H5AEA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AEB">you’d</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AEC"> do, General Varana,’ King Rhodar disagreed, ‘but you aren’t ‘Zakath or Taur Urgas. Our strategy’s based on our assessment of those two men. Neither of them will commit his forces unless he’s convinced that we pose a major threat. Each of them wants to save as much of his army as possible. In their view, we’re only an incidental annoyance – and an excuse to put an army into the field. For them, the real war starts when they attack each other. Each of them will hold back, and King Gethell of the Thulls will have to meet us on his own with only token support from the Murgos and the Malloreans. If we move fast enough, we’ll have Anheg’s fleet into the Sea of the East and all our troops pulled back to the escarpment before they realize what we’re up to.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AED"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AEE">‘And then?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AEF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AEG">‘And then Taur Urgas will stay in Rak Goska as if his foot were nailed to the floor.’ King Anheg chuckled. ‘I’ll be in the Sea of the East drowning Malloreans by the shipload, and he’ll be cheering me on every step of the way.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AEH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AEI">‘And ‘Zakath won’t dare risk those troops he already has at Thull Zelik by moving against us,’ Brand added. ‘If he loses too many men, Taur Urgas will have the upper hand.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AEJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AEK">General Varana considered that. ‘A three-way deadlock, then,’ he mused. ‘Three armies in the same region, and not one of them willing to move.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AEL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AEM">‘The very best kind of war.’ King Rhodar grinned. ‘Nobody gets hurt.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AEN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AEO">‘Tactically, your only problem is gauging the severity of your raids before you attack Thull Mandu,’ Varana noted. ‘They’ll have to be serious enough to pull the garrison out of the city, but not so serious as to alarm ‘Zakath or Taur Urgas. That’s a very fine line to walk, gentlemen.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AEP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AEQ">Rhodar nodded. ‘That’s why we’re so delighted to have Tolnedra’s foremost tactician here to advise us,’ he said, bowing floridly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AER"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AES">‘Please, your Majesty,’ General Varana interposed, lifting one hand. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="H5AET"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AEU">Suggest</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AEV">, not advise. An observer can only suggest. The term advice implies partisanship that is not in line with the Empire’s position of strict neutrality.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AF0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AF1">‘Ah,’ King Rhodar said. He turned to King Cho-Hag. ‘We must make arrangements for the comfort of the Imperial suggester and his staff,’ he declared with a broad grin.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AF2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AF3">Ce’Nedra watched with secret delight as these two brilliant men began what was obviously going to be a firm friendship. ‘I’ll leave you gentlemen to your entertainments,’ she told them. ‘Military discussions give me a headache, so I’ll rely on you not to get me in trouble.’ She curtsied to them with a winsome little smile and withdrew.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AF4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AF5">Two days later, Relg arrived from Ulgoland with the contingent of his leaf-mailed countrymen sent by the Gorim. Taiba, who had hovered silently in the background since the army had arrived at the Stronghold, joined Ce’Nedra and Lady Polgara to greet the Ulgos as the wagons which carried them creaked up the hill toward the main gate. The beautiful Marag woman wore a plain, even severe, linen dress, but her violet eyes were glowing. Relg, his cowled leaf-mail shirt covering his head and shoulders like lizard skin, climbed down from the lead wagon and only perfunctorily answered the greetings of Barak and Mandorallen. His large eyes searched the group gathered at the gate until they found Taiba, and then a kind of tension seemed to go out of him. Without speaking, he walked toward her. Their meeting was silent, and they did not touch, though Taiba’s hand moved involuntarily toward him several times. They stood in the golden sunlight with their eyes lost in each other’s faces, drawing about them a profound kind of privacy that absolutely ignored the presence of others. Taiba’s eyes remained constantly on Relg’s face, but there was in them nothing of that vacant, placid adoration that filled Ariana’s eyes when she looked at Lelldorin. There was rather a question – even a challenge. Relg’s answering look was the troubled gaze of a man torn between two overpowering compulsions. Ce’Nedra watched them for a few moments, but was finally forced to avert her eyes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AF6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AF7">The Ulgos were quartered in dim, cavernous rooms built into the foundations of the Stronghold where Relg could lead his countrymen through the painful process of adjusting their eyes to the light of day and training them to ignore the unreasoning panic which assailed all Ulgos when they were exposed to the open sky.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AF8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AF9">That evening another smaller contingent arrived from the south. Three men, two in white robes and one in filthy rags, appeared at the gate demanding entrance. The Algars at the gate admitted them immediately, and one guard was sent to Lady Polgara’s candlelit apartment to inform her of their arrival.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AFA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFB">‘You’d better bring them here,’ she advised the poor man, who was ashen-faced and trembling. ‘They haven’t been in the company of other men for a very long time, and crowds might make them nervous.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AFC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFD">‘At once, Lady Polgara,’ the shaking Algar said, bowing. He hesitated for a moment. ‘Would he </span><span class="italic" aid="H5AFE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFF">really</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFG"> do that to me?’ he blurted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AFH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFI">‘Would who do what to you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AFJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFK">‘The ugly one. He said that he was going to—’ The man stopped, suddenly realizing to whom he was speaking. His face turned red. ‘I don’t think I should repeat what he said, Lady Polgara – but it was an awful thing to threaten a man with.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AFL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFM">‘Oh,’ she said. ‘I believe I know what you mean. It’s one of his favorite expressions. I think you’re safe. He only says that to get people’s attention. I’m not even sure you </span><span class="italic" aid="H5AFN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFO">can</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFP"> do it to somebody and keep him alive at the same time.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AFQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFR">‘I’ll bring them at once, Lady Polgara.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AFS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFT">The sorceress turned to look at Ce’Nedra, Adara, and Ariana, who had joined her for supper. ‘Ladies,’ she said gravely, ‘we’re about to have guests. Two of them are the sweetest men in the world, but the third is a bit uncontrolled in his use of language. If you’re at all sensitive about such things, you’d better leave.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AFU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AFV">Ce’Nedra, remembering her encounter with the three in the Vale of Aldur, rose immediately.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AG0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AG1">‘Not yet, Ce’Nedra,’ Polgara told her. ‘You’ll have to stay, I’m afraid.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AG2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AG3">Ce’Nedra swallowed hard. ‘I really would leave, if I were you,’ she advised her friends.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AG4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AG5">‘Is he </span><span class="italic" aid="H5AG6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AG7">that</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AG8"> bad?’ Adara asked. ‘I’ve heard men swear before.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AG9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGA">‘Not like this one,’ Ce’Nedra warned.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AGB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGC">‘You’ve managed to make me very curious,’ Adara smiled. ‘I think I’ll stay.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AGD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGE">‘Don’t say I didn’t warn you,’ Ce’Nedra murmured.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AGF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGG">Beltira and Belkira were as saintly as Ce’Nedra remembered them, but the misshapen Beldin was even uglier and nastier. Ariana fled before he had even finished greeting Lady Polgara. Adara turned deathly pale, but bravely kept her seat. Then the hideous little man turned to greet Ce’Nedra with a few raucous questions that made the princess blush to the roots of her hair. Adara prudently withdrew at that point.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AGH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGI">‘What’s wrong with your wenches, Pol?’ Beldin asked innocently, scratching at his matted hair. ‘They seemed a little vaporish.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AGJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGK">‘They’re well-bred ladies, Uncle,’ Polgara replied. ‘Certain expressions are offensive to their ears.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AGL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGM">‘Is </span><span class="italic" aid="H5AGN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGO">that</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGP"> all?’ He laughed coarsely. ‘This redheaded one seems a bit less delicate.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AGQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGR">‘Your remarks offend me as much as they offend my companions, Master Beldin,’ Ce’Nedra retorted stiffly, ‘but I don’t think I’ll be routed by the foul mouthings of an ill-bred hunchback.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AGS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGT">‘Not bad,’ he complimented her, sprawling uncouthly in a chair, ‘but you’ve got to learn to relax. An insult’s got a certain rhythm and flow to it that you haven’t quite picked up yet.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AGU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AGV">‘She’s very young, Uncle,’ Polgara reminded him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AH0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AH1">Beldin leered at the princess. ‘Isn’t she, though?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AH2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AH3">‘Stop that,’ Polgara told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AH4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AH5">‘We’ve come—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AH6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AH7">‘—to join your expedition,’ the twins said. ‘Beldin feels—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AH8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AH9">‘—that you might encounter Grolims, and—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AHA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AHB">‘—need our help.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AHC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AHD">‘Isn’t that pathetic?’ Beldin demanded. ‘They still haven’t learned to talk straight.’ He looked at Polgara. ‘Is this all the army you’ve got?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AHE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AHF">‘The Chereks will be joining us at the river,’ she replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AHG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AHH">‘You should have talked faster,’ he told Ce’Nedra. ‘You haven’t got nearly enough men. Southern Murgos proliferate like maggots in dead meat, and Malloreans spawn like blowflies.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AHI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AHJ">‘We’ll explain our strategy to you in good time, Uncle,’ Polgara promised him. ‘We are </span><span class="italic" aid="H5AHK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AHL">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AHM"> going to meet the armies of Angarak head on. What we’re doing here is only diversionary.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AHN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AHO">He grinned a hideous little grin. ‘I’d have given a lot to see your face when you found out that Belgarath had slipped away from you,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AHP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AHQ">‘I wouldn’t dwell on that, Master Beldin,’ Ce’Nedra advised. ‘Lady Polgara was not pleased by Belgarath’s decision, and it might not be prudent to raise it again.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AHR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AHS">‘I’ve seen Pol’s little tantrums before.’ He shrugged. ‘Why don’t you send somebody out for a pig or a sheep, Pol? I’m hungry.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AHT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AHU">‘It’s customary to cook it first, Uncle.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="H5AHV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="H5AI0">He looked puzzled. ‘What for?’ he asked.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_18" aid="H5AI1"></div>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>

  <body class="calibre" aid="I3QM0">
