</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos383819" aid="I3QM1"><span class="calibre5" aid="I3QM2"><span class="italic" aid="I3QM3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QM4">Chapter Ten</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="I3QM5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QM6">Three days later the army began to move out from the Algar Stronghold toward the temporary encampment the Algars had erected on the east bank of the Aldur River. The troops of each nation moved in separate broad columns, trampling a vast track through the knee-high grass. In the center column the legions of Tolnedra, standards raised, marched with parade-ground perfection. The appearance of the legions had improved noticeably since the arrival of General Varana and his staff. The mutiny on the plains near Tol Vordue had given Ce’Nedra a large body of men, but no senior officers, and once the danger of surprise inspections was past, a certain laxity had set in. General Varana had not mentioned the rust spots on the breastplates nor the generally unshaven condition of the troops. His expression of mild disapproval had seemed to be enough. The hard-bitten sergeants who now commanded the legions had taken one look at his face and had immediately taken steps. The rust spots vanished, and shaving regularly once again became popular. There were, to be sure, a few contusions here and there on some freshly shaved faces, mute evidence that the heavy-fisted sergeants had found it necessary to vigorously persuade their troops that the holiday was over.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QM7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QM8">To one side of the legions rode the glittering Mimbrate knights, their varicolored pennons snapping in the breeze from the up-raised forest of their lances. Their faces shone with enthusiasm and little else. Ce’Nedra privately suspected that a large part of their fearsome reputation stemmed from that abysmal lack of anything remotely resembling thought. With only a little encouragement, a force of Mimbrates would cheerfully mount an assault on winter or a changing tide.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QM9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QMA">On the other flank of the marching legions came the green- and brown-clad bowmen of Asturia. The placement was quite deliberate. The Asturians were no more blessed with intelligence than their Mimbrate cousins, and it was generally considered prudent to interpose other troops between the two Arendish forces to avoid unpleasantness.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QMB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QMC">Beyond the Asturians marched the grim-faced Rivans, all in gray, and accompanying them were the few Chereks who were not with the fleet, which even now was in the process of being prepared for the portage to the base of the escarpment. Flanking the Mimbrates marched the Sendarian militiamen in their homemade uniforms, and at the rear of the host, the creaking lines of King Fulrach’s supply wagons stretched back to the horizon. The Algar clans, however, did not ride in orderly columns, but rather in little groups and clusters as they drove herds of spare horses and half-wild cattle along on the extreme flanks of the host.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QMD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QME">Ce’Nedra, in her armor and mounted on her white horse, rode in the company of General Varana. She was trying, without much success, to explain her cause to him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QMF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QMG">‘My dear child,’ the general said finally, ‘I’m a Tolnedran and a solider. Neither of those conditions encourages me to accept any kind of mysticism. My primary concerns at this moment have to do with feeding this multitude. Your supply lines stretch all the way back across the mountains and then up through Arendia. That’s a very long way, Ce’Nedra.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QMH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QMI">‘King Fulrach’s taken care of that, Uncle,’ she told him rather smugly. ‘All the time we’ve been marching, his Sendars have been freighting supplies along the Great North Road to Aldurford and then barging them upriver to the camp. There are whole acres of supply dumps waiting for us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QMJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QMK">General Varana nodded approvingly. ‘It appears that Sendars make perfect quartermasters,’ he observed. ‘Is he bringing weapons as well?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QML"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QMM">‘I think they said something about that,’ Ce’Nedra replied. ‘Arrows, spare lances for the knights, that sort of thing. They seemed to know what they were doing, so I didn’t ask too many questions.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QMN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QMO">‘That’s foolish, Ce’Nedra,’ Varana said bluntly. ‘When you’re running an army, you should know every detail.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QMP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QMQ">‘I’m not running the army, Uncle,’ she pointed out. ‘I’m leading it. King Rhodar’s running it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QMR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QMS">‘And what will you do if something happens to him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QMT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QMU">Ce’Nedra suddenly went cold.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QMV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QN0">‘You </span><span class="italic" aid="I3QN1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QN2">are</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QN3"> going to war, Ce’Nedra, and people </span><span class="italic" aid="I3QN4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QN5">do</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QN6"> get killed and injured in wars. You’d better start taking an interest in what’s going on around you, my little princess. Going off to war with your head wrapped in a pillow isn’t going to improve your chances of success, you know.’ He gave her a very direct look. ‘Don’t chew your fingernails, Ce’Nedra,’ he added. ‘It makes your hands unsightly.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QN7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QN8">The encampment at the river was vast, and in the very center stood King Fulrach’s main supply dump, a virtual city of tents and neatly stacked equipment. A long string of flat-bottomed barges were moored to the riverbank, patiently waiting to be unloaded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QN9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNA">‘Your people have been busy,’ King Rhodar observed to the dumpy-looking Sendarian monarch as they rode along a narrow alleyway between mountainous heaps of canvas-covered produce and stacks of stoutly boxed equipment. ‘How did you know what to have them bring?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QNB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNC">‘I took notes while we were coming down through Arendia,’ King Fulrach replied. ‘It wasn’t too hard to see what we were going to need – boots, arrows, spare swords, and the like. At present, about all we’re bringing in is food. The Algar herds will provide fresh meat, but men get sick on a steady diet of nothing but meat.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QND"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNE">‘You’ve already got enough food here to feed the army for a year,’ King Anheg noted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QNF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNG">Fulrach shook his head. ‘Forty-five days,’ he corrected meticulously. ‘I want thirty days’ worth here and two weeks’ worth in the forts the Drasnians are building up on top of the escarpment. That’s our margin of safety. As long as the barges replenish our food supplies daily, we’ll always have that much on hand. Once you decide what your goals are, the rest is just simple mathematics.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QNH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNI">‘How do you know how much a man’s going to eat in one day?’ Rhodar asked, eyeing the high-piled foodstuffs. ‘Some days I’m hungrier than others.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QNJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNK">Fulrach shrugged. ‘It averages out. Some eat more, some eat less; but in the end, it all comes out about the same.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QNL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNM">‘Fulrach, sometimes you’re so practical, you almost make me sick,’ Anheg said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QNN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNO">‘Somebody has to be.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QNP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNQ">‘Don’t you Sendars have any sense of adventure? Don’t you </span><span class="italic" aid="I3QNR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNS">ever</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNT"> do something without planning it all out in advance?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QNU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QNV">‘Not if we can help it,’ the King of Sendaria replied mildly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QO0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QO1">Near the center of the supply dump a number of large pavilions had been erected for the use of the leaders of the army and their supporting staff. About midafternoon, after she had bathed and changed clothes, Princess Ce’Nedra went over to the main tent to see what was happening.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QO2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QO3">‘They’re anchored about a mile downriver,’ Barak was reporting to his cousin. ‘They’ve been here for about four days now. Greldik’s more or less in charge.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QO4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QO5">‘Greldik?’ Anheg looked surprised. ‘He doesn’t have any official position.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QO6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QO7">‘He knows the river.’ Barak shrugged. ‘Over the years he’s sailed just about any place where there’s water and a chance to make some profit. He tells me that the sailors have been drinking pretty steadily since they anchored. They know what’s coming.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QO8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QO9">Anheg chuckled. ‘We’d better not disappoint them, then. Rhodar, how much longer will it be before your engineers are ready to start lifting my ships up the escarpment?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QOA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QOB">‘A week or so,’ King Rhodar replied, looking up from his midafternoon snack.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QOC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QOD">‘It will be close enough,’ Anheg concluded. He turned back to Barak. ‘Tell Greldik that we’ll start the portage tomorrow morning – before the sailors have time to sober up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QOE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QOF">Ce’Nedra had not fully understood the meaning of the word ‘portage’ until she arrived the following morning at the riverbank to find the sweating Chereks hauling their ships out of the water and manhandling them along by main strength on wooden rollers. She was appalled at the amount of effort required to move a ship even a few inches.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QOG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QOH">She was not alone in that. Durnik the smith took one shocked look at the procedure and immediately went looking for King Anheg. ‘Excuse me, your Honor,’ he said respectfully, ‘but isn’t this bad for the boats – as well as the men?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QOI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QOJ">‘Ships,’ Anheg corrected. ‘They’re called ships. A boat is something else.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QOK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QOL">‘Whatever you call them – won’t banging them along over those logs spring their seams?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QOM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QON">Anheg shrugged. ‘They all leak quite a bit anyway,’ he replied. ‘And it’s always been done this way.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QOO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QOP">Durnik quickly saw the futility of trying to talk to the King of Cherek. He went instead to Barak, who was rather glumly considering the huge ship his crew had rowed upriver to meet him. ‘She looks very impressive when she’s afloat,’ the big red-bearded man was saying to his friend, Captain Greldik, ‘but I think she’ll be even more impressive when we have to pick her up and carry her.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QOQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QOR">‘You’re the one who wanted the biggest warship afloat,’ Greldik reminded him with a broad smirk. ‘You’ll have to buy enough ale to float that whale of yours before your crew’s drunk enough to try to portage her – not to mention the fact that it’s customary for a captain to join in when the time comes to portage.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QOS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QOT">‘Stupid custom,’ Barak growled sourly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QOU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QOV">‘I’d say you’re in for a bad week, Barak.’ Greldik’s grin grew broader.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QP0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QP1">Durnik took the two seamen aside and began talking earnestly with them, drawing diagrams on the sandy riverbank with a stick. The more he talked, the more interested they became.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QP2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QP3">What emerged from their discussions a day later were a pair of low-slung cradles with a dozen wheels on each side. As the rest of the Chereks jeered, the two ships were carefully slid out of the water onto the cradles and firmly lashed in place. The jeering faded noticeably, however, when the crews of the two ships began trundling their craft across the plain. Hettar, who happened to ride by, watched for a few moments with a puzzled frown. ‘Why are you pulling them by hand,’ he asked, ‘when you’re in the middle of the largest herd of horses in the world?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QP4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QP5">Barak’s eyes went very wide, and then an almost reverent grin dawned on his face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QP6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QP7">The jeers that had risen as Barak’s and Greldik’s ships had been maneuvered onto their wheeled carriages turned rather quickly into angry mutterings as the carriages, pulled by teams of Algar horses, rolled effortlessly toward the escarpment past men straining with every ounce of strength to move their ships a few inches at a time. To leave it all to artistry, Barak and Greldik ordered their men to lounge indolently on the decks of their ships, drinking ale and playing dice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QP8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QP9">King Anheg stared very hard at his impudently grinning cousin as the big ship rolled past. His expression was profoundly offended. ‘That’s going </span><span class="italic" aid="I3QPA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPB">too</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPC"> far!’ he exploded, jerking off his dented crown and throwing it down on the ground.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QPD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPE">King Rhodar put on a perfectly straight face. ‘I’d be the first to admit that it’s probably not nearly as good as moving them by hand, Anheg. I’m sure there are some rather profound philosophical reasons for all that sweating and grunting and cursing, but it </span><span class="italic" aid="I3QPF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPG">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPH"> faster, wouldn’t you say? And we really ought to move right along with this.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QPI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPJ">‘It’s unnatural,’ Anheg growled, still glaring at the two ships, which were already several hundred yards away.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QPK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPL">Rhodar shrugged. ‘Anything’s unnatural the first time you try it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QPM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPN">‘I’ll think about it,’ Anheg said darkly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QPO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPP">‘I wouldn’t think for too long,’ Rhodar suggested. ‘Your popularity as a monarch is going to go downhill with every mile – and Barak’s the sort of man who’ll parade that contraption of his back and forth in front of your sailors every step of the way to the escarpment.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QPQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPR">‘He </span><span class="italic" aid="I3QPS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPT">would</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QPU"> do that, wouldn’t he?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QPV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQ0">‘I think you can count on it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQ1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQ2">King Anheg sighed bitterly. ‘Go fetch that unwholesomely clever Sendarian blacksmith,’ he sourly instructed one of his men. ‘Let’s get this over with.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQ3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQ4">Later that day the leaders of the army gathered again in the main tent for a strategy meeting. ‘Our biggest problem now is to conceal the size of our forces,’ King Rhodar told them all. ‘Instead of marching everybody to the escarpment all at once and then milling around at the base of the cliff, it might be better to move the troops in small contingents and have them go directly up to the forts on top as soon as they arrive.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQ5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQ6">‘Will such a piecemeal approach not unduly delay our progress?’ King Korodullin asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQ7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQ8">‘Not all that much,’ Rhodar replied. ‘We’ll move your knights and Cho-Hag’s clansmen up first so you can start burning cities and crops. That will give the Thulls something to think about beside how many infantry regiments we’re bringing up. We don’t want them to start counting noses.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQ9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQA">‘Couldn’t we build false campfires and so on to make it appear that we have more men?’ Lelldorin suggested brightly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQC">‘The whole idea is to make our army appear smaller, not bigger,’ Brand explained gently in his deep voice. ‘We don’t want to alarm Taur Urgas or ‘Zakath sufficiently to make them commit their forces. It will be an easy campaign if all we have to deal with are King Gethell’s Thulls. If the Murgos and the Malloreans intervene, we’ll be in for a serious fight.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQE">‘And that’s the one thing we definitely want to avoid,’ King Rhodar added.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQG">‘Oh,’ Lelldorin said, a bit abashed, ‘I didn’t think of that.’ A slow flush rose in his cheeks.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQI">‘Lelldorin,’ Ce’Nedra said, hoping to help him cover his embarrassment, ‘I think I’d like to go out and visit with the troops for a bit. Would you accompany me?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQK">‘Of course, your Majesty,’ the young Asturian agreed, quickly rising to his feet.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQM">‘That’s not a bad idea,’ Rhodar agreed. ‘Encourage them a bit, Ce’Nedra. They’ve walked a long way, and their spirits may be sagging.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQO">Lelldorin’s cousin Torasin, dressed in his customary black doublet and hose, also rose to his feet. ‘I’ll go along, if I may,’ he said. He grinned rather impudently at King Korodullin. ‘Asturians are good plotters, but rather poor strategists, so I probably wouldn’t be able to add much to the discussions.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQQ">The King of Arendia smiled at the young man’s remark. ‘Thou art pert, young Torasin, but methinks thou art not so fervent an enemy of the crown of Arendia as thou dost prented.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQS">Torasin bowed extravagantly, still grinning. Once they were outside the tent, he turned to Lelldorin. ‘I could almost learn to like that man – if it weren’t for all those thees and thous,’ he declared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QQU">‘It’s not so bad – once you get used to it,’ Lelldorin replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QQV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QR0">Torasin laughed. ‘If I had someone as pretty as Lady Ariana for a friend, she could thee me and thou me all she wanted,’ he said. He looked archly at Ce’Nedra. ‘Which troops did you wish to encourage, your Majesty?’ he bantered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QR1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QR2">‘Let’s visit your Asturian countrymen,’ she decided. ‘I don’t think I’d care to take you two into the Mimbrate camp – unless your swords had been taken away from you and your mouths had been bricked up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QR3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QR4">‘Don’t you trust us?’ Lelldorin asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QR5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QR6">‘I </span><span class="italic" aid="I3QR7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QR8">know</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QR9"> you,’ she replied with a little toss of her head. ‘Where are the Asturians encamped?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QRA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QRB">‘That way,’ Torasin answered, pointing toward the south end of the supply dump.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QRC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QRD">Smells of cooking were carried by the breeze from the Sendarian field kitchens, and those smells reminded the princess of something. Instead of randomly circulating among the Asturian tents, she found herself quite deliberately searching for some specific people.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QRE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QRF">She found Lammer and Detton, the two serfs who had joined her army on the outskirts of Vo Wacune, finishing their afternoon meal in front of a patched tent. They both looked better fed than they had when she had first seen them, and they were no longer dressed in rags. When they saw her approaching, they scrambled awkwardly to their feet.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QRG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QRH">‘Well, my friends,’ she asked, trying to put them at ease, ‘how do you find army life?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QRI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QRJ">‘We don’t have anything to complain about, your Ladyship,’ Detton replied respectfully.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QRK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QRL">‘Except for all the walking,’ Lammer added. ‘I hadn’t realized that the world was this big.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QRM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QRN">‘They gave us boots,’ Detton told her, holding up one foot so that she could see his boot. ‘They were a bit stiff at first, but the blisters have all healed now.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QRO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QRP">‘Are you getting enough to eat?’ Ce’Nedra asked them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QRQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QRR">‘Plenty,’ Lammer said. ‘The Sendars even cook it for us. Did you know that there aren’t any serfs in the kingdom of the Sendars, my Lady? Isn’t that astonishing? It gives a man something to think about.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QRS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QRT">‘It does indeed,’ Detton agreed. ‘They grow all that food, and everybody always has plenty to eat and clothes to wear and a house to sleep in, and there’s not a single serf in the whole kingdom.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QRU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QRV">‘I see that they’ve given you equipment, too,’ the princess said, noting that the two now wore conical leather helmets and stiff leather vests.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QS0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QS1">Lammer nodded and pulled off his helmet. ‘It’s got steel plates in it to keep a man from getting his brains knocked out,’ he told her. ‘They lined us all up as soon as we got here and gave every man a helmet and these hard leather tunics.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QS2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QS3">‘They gave each of us a spear and a dagger, too,’ Detton said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QS4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QS5">‘Have they shown you how to use them?’ Ce’Nedra asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QS6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QS7">‘Not yet, your Ladyship,’ Detton replied. ‘We’ve been concentrating on learning how to shoot arrows.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QS8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QS9">Ce’Nedra turned to her two companions. ‘Could you see that somebody takes care of that?’ she said. ‘I want to be sure that everybody knows how to defend himself, at least.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QSA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QSB">‘We’ll see to it, your Majesty,’ Lelldorin answered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QSC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QSD">Not far away, a young serf was seated cross-legged in front of another tent. He lifted a handmade flute to his lips and began to play. Ce’Nedra had heard some of the finest musicians in the world performing at the palace in Tol Honeth, but the serf boy’s flute caught at her heart and brought tears to her eyes. His melody soared toward the azure sky like an unfettered lark.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QSE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QSF">‘How exquisite,’ she exclaimed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QSG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QSH">Lammer nodded. ‘I don’t know much about music,’ he said, ‘but the boy seems to play well. It’s a shame he’s not right in the head.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QSI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QSJ">Ce’Nedra looked at him sharply. ‘What do you mean?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QSK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QSL">‘He comes from a village in the southern part of the forest of Arendia. I’m told it’s a very poor village and that the lord of the region is very harsh with his serfs. The boy’s an orphan, and he was put to watching the cows when he was young. One time one of the cows strayed, and the boy was beaten half to death. He can’t talk any more.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QSM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QSN">‘Do you know his name?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QSO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QSP">‘Nobody seems to know it,’ Detton replied. ‘We take turns looking out for him – making sure he’s fed and has a place to sleep. There’s not much else you can do for him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QSQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QSR">A small sound came from Lelldorin, and Ce’Nedra was startled to see tears streaming openly down the earnest young man’s face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QSS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QST">The boy continued his playing, his melody heartbreakingly true, and his eyes sought out Ce’Nedra’s and met them with a kind of grave recognition.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QSU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QSV">They did not stay much longer. The princess knew that her rank and position made the two serfs uncomfortable. She had made sure that they were all right and that her promise to them was being kept, and that was all that really mattered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QT0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QT1">As Ce’Nedra, Lelldorin, and Torasin walked toward the camp of the Sendars, they suddenly heard the sound of squabbling on the other side of a large tent.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QT2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QT3">‘I’ll pile it any place I want to,’ one man was saying belligerently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QT4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QT5">‘You’re blocking the street,’ another man replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QT6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QT7">‘Street?’ the first snorted. ‘What are you talking about? This isn’t a town. There aren’t any streets.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QT8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QT9">‘Friend,’ the second man explained with exaggerated patience, ‘we have to bring the wagons through here to get to the main supply dump. Now please move your equipment so I can get through. I still have a lot to do today.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QTA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QTB">‘I’m not going to take orders from a Sendarian teamster who’s found an easy way to avoid fighting. I’m a soldier.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QTC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QTD">‘Really?’ the Sendar replied dryly. ‘How much fighting have you seen?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QTE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QTF">‘I’ll fight when the time comes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QTG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QTH">‘It may come quicker than you’d expected if you don’t get your gear out of my way. If I have to get down off this wagon to move it myself, it’s likely to make me irritable.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QTI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QTJ">‘I’m all weak with fright,’ the soldier retorted sarcastically.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QTK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QTL">‘Are you going to move it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QTM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QTN">‘No.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QTO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QTP">‘I tried to warn you, friend,’ the teamster said in a resigned tone.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QTQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QTR">‘If you touch my gear, I’ll break your head.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QTS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QTT">‘No. You’ll </span><span class="italic" aid="I3QTU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QTV">try</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QU0"> to break my head.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QU1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QU2">There was a sudden sound of scuffling and several heavy blows.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QU3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QU4">‘Now get up and move your gear like I told you to,’ the teamster said. ‘I don’t have all day to stand around and argue with you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QU5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QU6">‘You hit me when I wasn’t looking,’ the soldier complained.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QU7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QU8">‘Do you want to watch the next one coming?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QU9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QUA">‘All right, don’t get excited. I’m moving it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QUB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QUC">‘I’m glad we understand each other.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QUD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QUE">‘Does that sort of thing happen very often?’ Ce’Nedra asked quietly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QUF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QUG">Torasin, grinning broadly, nodded. ‘Some of your troops feel the need to bluster, your Majesty,’ he replied, ‘and the Sendarian wagonneers usually don’t have the time to listen. Fistfights and street-brawling are second nature to those fellows, so their squabbles with the soldiers almost always end up the same way. It’s very educational, really.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QUH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QUI">‘Men!’ Ce’Nedra said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QUJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QUK">In the camp of the Sendars they met Durnik. With him there was an oddly matched pair of young men.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QUL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QUM">‘A couple of old friends,’ Durnik said as he introduced them. ‘Just arrived on the supply barges. I think you’ve met Rundorig, Princess. He was at Faldor’s farm when we visited there last winter.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QUN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QUO">Ce’Nedra did in fact remember Rundorig. The tall, hulking young man, she recalled, was the one who was going to marry Garion’s childhood sweetheart, Zubrette. She greeted him warmly and gently reminded him that they had met before. Rundorig’s Arendish background made his mind move rather slowly. His companion, however, was anything but slow. Durnik introduced him as Doroon, another of Garion’s boyhood friends. Doroon was a small, wiry young man with a protruding Adam’s apple and slightly bulging eyes. After a few moments of shyness, his tongue began to run away with him. It was a bit hard to follow Doroon. His mind flitted from idea to idea, and his mouth raced along breathlessly, trying to keep up.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QUP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QUQ">‘It was sort of rough going up in the mountains, your Ladyship,’ he replied in answer to her question about their trip from Sendaria, ‘what with how steep the road was and all. You’d think that as long as the Tolnedrans were building a highway, they’d have picked leveler ground – but they seem to be fascinated by straight lines – only that’s not always the easiest way. I wonder why they’re like that.’ The fact that Ce’Nedra herself was Tolnedran seemed not to have registered on Doroon.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QUR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QUS">‘You came along the Great North Road?’ she asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QUT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QUU">‘Yes – until we got to a place called Aldurford. That’s a funny kind of name, isn’t it? Although it makes sense if you stop and think about it. But that was after we got out of the mountains where the Murgos attacked us. You’ve never </span><span class="italic" aid="I3QUV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QV0">seen</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QV1"> such a fight.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QV2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QV3">‘Murgos?’ Ce’Nedra asked him sharply, trying to pin down his skittering thoughts.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QV4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QV5">He nodded eagerly. ‘The man who was in charge of the wagons – he’s a great big fellow from Muros, I think he said – wasn’t it Muros he said he came from, Rundorig? Or maybe it was Camaar – for some reason I always get the two mixed up. What was I talking about?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QV6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QV7">‘The Murgos,’ Durnik supplied helpfully.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QV8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QV9">‘Oh, yes. Anyway, the man in charge of the wagons said that there had been a lot of Murgos in Sendaria before the war. They pretended that they were merchants, but they weren’t – they were spies. When the war started, they all went up into the mountains, and now they come out of the woods and try to ambush our supply wagons – but we were ready for them, weren’t we Rundorig? Rundorig hit one of the Murgos with a big stick when the Murgo rode past our wagon – knocked him clear off his horse. Whack! Just like that! Knocked him clear off his horse. I’ll bet </span><span class="italic" aid="I3QVA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QVB">he</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QVC"> was surprised.’ Doroon laughed a short little laugh, and then his tongue raced off again, describing in jerky, helter-skelter detail the trip from Sendaria.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QVD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QVE">Princess Ce’Nedra was strangely touched by her meeting with Garion’s two old friends. She felt, moreover, a tremendous burden of responsibility as she realized that she had reached into almost every life in the west with her campaign. She had separated husbands from their wives and fathers from their children; and she had carried simple men, who had never been further than the next village, a thousand leagues and more to fight in a war they probably did not even begin to understand.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QVF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QVG">The next morning the leaders of the army rode the few remaining leagues to the installations at the base of the escarpment. As they topped a rise, Ce’Nedra reined Noble in sharply and gaped in openmouthed astonishment as she saw the eastern escarpment for the first time. It was impossible! Nothing could be so vast! The great black cliff reared itself above them like an enormous wave of rock, frozen and for ever marking the boundary between east and west, and seemingly blocking any possibility of ever passing in either direction. It immediately stood as a kind of stark symbol of the division between the two parts of the world – a division that could no more be resolved than that enormous cliff could be leveled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QVH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QVI">As they rode closer, Ce’Nedra noted a great deal of bustling activity both at the foot of the escarpment and along its upper rim. Great hawsers stretched down from overhead, and Ce’Nedra saw elaborately intertwined pulleys along the foot of the huge cliffs.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QVJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QVK">‘Why are the pulleys at the bottom?’ King Anheg demanded suspiciously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QVL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QVM">King Rhodar shrugged. ‘How should I know? I’m not an engineer.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QVN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QVO">‘All right, if you’re going to be that way about it, I’m not going to let your people touch a single one of my ships until somebody tells me why the pulleys are down here instead of up there.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QVP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QVQ">King Rhodar sighed and beckoned to an engineer who was meticulously greasing a huge pulley block. ‘Have you got a sketch of the rigging handy?’ the portly monarch asked the grease-spattered workman.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QVR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QVS">The engineer nodded, pulled a rolled sheet of grimy parchment out from under his tunic, and handed it to his king. Rhodar glanced at it and handed it to Anheg.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QVT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3QVU">Anheg stared at the complex drawing, struggling to trace out which line went where, and more importantly why it went there. ‘I can’t read this,’ he complained.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3QVV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R00">‘Neither can I,’ Rhodar told him pleasantly, ‘but you wanted to know why the pulleys are down here instead of up there. The drawing tells you why.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R01"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R02">‘But I can’t read it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R03"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R04">‘That’s not my fault.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R05"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R06">Not far away a cheer went up as a boulder half the size of a house and entwined in a nest of ropes rose majestically up the face of the cliff to the accompaniment of a vast creaking of hawsers.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R07"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R08">‘You’ll have to admit that that’s impressive, Anheg,’ Rhodar said. ‘Particularly when you note that the entire rock is being lifted by those eight horses over there – with the help of that counterweight, of course.’ He pointed at another block of stone which was just as majestically coming down from the top of the escarpment.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R09"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R0A">Anheg squinted at the two rocks. ‘Durnik,’ he said over his shoulder, ‘do you understand how all those work?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R0B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R0C">‘Yes, King Anheg,’ the smith replied. ‘You see, the counterweight off-balances the—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R0D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R0E">‘Don’t explain it to me, please,’ Anheg said. ‘As long as somebody I know and trust understands, that’s all that’s really important.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R0F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R0G">Later that same day, the first Cherek ship was lifted to the top of the escarpment. King Anheg watched the procedure for a moment or two, then winced and turned his back. ‘It’s unnatural,’ he muttered to Barak.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R0H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R0I">‘You’ve taken to using that expression a great deal lately,’ Barak noted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R0J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R0K">Anheg scowled at his cousin.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R0L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R0M">‘I just mentioned it, that’s all,’ Barak said innocently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R0N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R0O">‘I don’t like changes, Barak. They make me nervous.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R0P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R0Q">‘The world moves on, Anheg. Things change every day.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R0R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R0S">‘That doesn’t necessarily mean that I have to like it,’ the King of Cherek growled. ‘I think I’ll go to my tent for a drink or two.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R0T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R0U">‘Want some company?’ Barak offered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R0V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R10">‘I thought you wanted to stand around and watch the world change.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R11"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R12">‘It can do that without my supervision.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="I3R13"><span class="calibre_1" aid="I3R14">‘And probably will,’ Anheg added moodily. ‘All right, let’s go. I don’t want to watch this anymore.’ And the two of them went off in search of something to drink.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_19" aid="I3R15"></div>

  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
