</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos426307" aid="J2B81"><span class="calibre5" aid="J2B82"><span class="italic" aid="J2B83"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B84">Chapter Eleven</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="J2B85"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B86">Mayaserana, Queen of Arendia, was in a pensive mood. She sat at her embroidery in the large, sunny nursery high in the palace at Vo Mimbre. Her infant son, the crown prince of Arendia, cooed and gurgled in his cradle as he played with the string of brightly colored beads that had been the ostensible gift of the crown prince of Drasnia. Mayaserana had never met Queen Porenn, but the shared experience of motherhood made her feel very close to the reputedly exquisite little blonde on her far northern throne.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B87"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B88">Seated in a chair not far from the queen sat Nerina, Baroness of Vo Ebor. Each lady wore velvet, the queen in deep purple, and the Baroness in pale blue, and each wore the high, conical white headdress so admired by the Mimbrate nobility. At the far end of the nursery, an elderly lutanist softly played a mournful air in a minor key.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B89"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B8A">The Baroness Nerina appeared to be even more melancholy than her queen. The circles beneath her eyes had grown deeper and deeper in the weeks since the departure of the Mimbrate knights, and she seldom smiled. Finally she sighed and laid aside her embroidery.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B8B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B8C">‘The sadness of thy heart doth resound in thy sighing, Nerina,’ the queen said gently. ‘Think not so of dangers and separation, lest thy spirits fail thee utterly.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B8D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B8E">‘Instruct me in the art of banishing care, Highness,’ Nerina replied, ‘for I am in sore need of such teaching. My heart is bowed beneath a burden of concern, and try though I might to control them, my thoughts, like unruly children, return ever to the dreadful peril of my absent lord and our dearest friend.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B8F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B8G">‘Be comforted in the knowledge that thy burden is shared by every lady in all of Mimbre, Nerina.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B8H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B8I">Nerina sighed again. ‘My care, however, lies in more mournful certainty. Other ladies, their affections firm-fixed on one beloved, can dare to hope that he might return from dreadful war unscathed; but I, who love two, can find no reason for such optimism. I must needs lose one at the least, and the prospect doth crush my soul.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B8J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B8K">There was a quiet dignity in Nerina’s open acceptance of the implications of the two loves that had become so entwined in her heart that they could no longer be separated. Mayaserana, in one of those brief flashes of insight which so sharply illuminated understanding, perceived that Nerina’s divided heart lay at the very core of the tragedy that had lifted her, her husband, and Sir Mandorallen into the realms of sad legend. If Nerina could but love one more than the other, the tragedy would end, but so perfectly balanced was her love for her husband with her love for Sir Mandorallen that she had reached a point of absolute stasis, for ever frozen between the two of them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B8L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B8M">The queen sighed. Nerina’s divided heart seemed somehow a symbol of divided Arendia, but, though the gentle heart of the suffering baroness might never be made one, Mayaserana was resolved to make a last effort to heal the breach between Mimbre and Asturia. To that end, she had summoned to the palace a deputation of the more stable leaders of the rebellious north, and her summons had appeared over a title she rarely used, Duchess of Asturia. At her instruction, the Asturians were even now drawing up a list of their grievances for her consideration.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B8N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B8O">Later on that same sunny afternoon, Mayaserana sat alone on the double throne of Arendia, painfully aware of the vacancy beside her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B8P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B8Q">The leader and spokesman of the group of Asturian noblemen was a Count Reldegen, a tall, thin man with iron gray hair and beard, who walked with the aid of a stout cane. Reldegen wore a rich green doublet and black hose, and, like the rest of the deputation, his sword was belted at his side. The fact that the Asturians came armed into the queen’s presence had stirred some angry muttering, but Mayaserana had refused to listen to urgings that their weapons be taken from them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B8R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B8S">‘My Lord Reldegen,’ the queen greeted the Asturian as he limped toward the throne.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B8T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B8U">‘Your Grace,’ he replied with a bow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B8V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B90">‘Your </span><span class="italic" aid="J2B91"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B92">Majesty</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B93">,’ a Mimbrate courtier corrected him in a shocked voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B94"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B95">‘Her Grace summoned us as the Duchess of Asturia,’ Reldegen informed the courtier coolly. ‘That title commands more respect from us than other, more recent embellishments.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B96"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B97">‘Gentlemen, please,’ the queen said firmly. ‘Prithee, let us not commence hostilities anew. Our purpose here is to examine the possibilities of peace. I entreat thee, my Lord Reldegen, speak to the purpose. Unburden thyself of the causes of that rancor which hath so hardened the heart of Asturia. Speak freely, my Lord, and with no fear of reprisal for thy words.’ She looked quite sternly at her advisers. ‘It is our command that no man be taken to task for what is spoken here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B98"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B99">The Mimbrates glowered at the Asturians, and the Asturians scowled back.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B9A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B9B">‘Your Grace,’ Reldegen began, ‘our chief complaint lies, I think, in the simple fact that our Mimbrate overlords refuse to recognize our titles. A title’s an empty thing, really, but it implies a responsibility which has been denied to us. Most of us here are indifferent to the privileges of rank, but we keenly feel the frustration of being refused the chance to discharge our obligations. Our most talented men are compelled to waste their lives in idleness, and might I point out, your Grace, that the loss of that talent injures Arendia even more than it injures us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B9C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B9D">‘Well spoken, my Lord,’ the queen murmured.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B9E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B9F">‘Might I respond, your Majesty,’ the aged, white-bearded Baron of Vo Serin inquired.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B9G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B9H">‘Certainly, my Lord,’ Mayaserana replied. ‘Let us all be free and open with one another.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B9I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B9J">‘The titles of the Asturian gentlemen are theirs for the asking,’ the baron declared. ‘For five centuries the crown hath awaited but the required oath of fealty to bestow them. No title may be granted or recognized until its owner swears allegiance to the crown.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B9K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B9L">‘Unfortunately, my Lord,’ Reldegen said, ‘we are unable to so swear. The oaths of our ancestors to the Duke of Asturia are still in force, and we are still bound by them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B9M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B9N">‘The Asturian Duke of whom thou speakest died five hundred years ago,’ the old baron reminded him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B9O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B9P">‘But his line did not die with him,’ Reldegen pointed out. ‘Her Grace is his direct descendant, and our pledges of loyalty are still in force.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B9Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B9R">The queen stared first at one and then at the other. ‘I pray thee,’ she said, ‘correct me if my perception is awry. Is the import of what hath been revealed here that Arendia hath been divided for half a millennium by an ancient </span><span class="italic" aid="J2B9S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B9T">formality</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2B9U">?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2B9V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BA0">Reldegen pursed his lips thoughtfully. ‘There’s a bit more to it than that, your Grace, but that does seem to be the core of the problem.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BA1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BA2">‘Five hundred years of strife and bloodshed over a </span><span class="italic" aid="J2BA3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BA4">technicality</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BA5">?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BA6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BA7">Count Reldegen struggled with it. He started to speak several times, but broke off each time with a look of helpless perplexity. In the end he began to laugh. ‘It </span><span class="italic" aid="J2BA8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BA9">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BAA"> sort of Arendish, isn’t it?’ he asked rather whimsically.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BAB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BAC">The old Baron of Vo Serin gave him a quick look, then he too began to chuckle. ‘I pray thee, my Lord Reldegen, lock this discovery in thy heart lest we all become the subject of general mirth. Let us not confirm the suspicion that abject stupidity is our most prevailing trait.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BAD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BAE">‘Why was this absurdity not discovered previously?’ Mayaserana demanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BAF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BAG">Count Reldegen shrugged sadly. ‘I suppose because Asturians and Mimbrates don’t talk to each other, your Grace. We were always too eager to get to the fighting.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BAH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BAI">‘Very well,’ the queen said crisply, ‘what is required to rectify this sorry confusion?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BAJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BAK">Count Reldegen looked at the baron. ‘A proclamation perhaps?’ he suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BAL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BAM">The old man nodded thoughtfully. ‘Her Majesty could release thee from thy previous oath. It hath not been common practice, but there are precedents.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BAN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BAO">‘And then we all swear fealty to her as Queen of Arendia?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BAP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BAQ">‘That would seem to satisfy all the demands of honor and propriety, yes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BAR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BAS">‘But I’m the same person, am I not?’ the queen objected.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BAT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BAU">‘Technically thou art not, your Majesty,’ the baron explained. ‘The Duchess of Asturia and the Queen of Arendia are separate entities. Thou art indeed two persons in one body.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BAV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BB0">‘This is most confusing, gentlemen,’ Mayaserana observed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BB1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BB2">‘That’s probably why no-one noticed it before, your Grace,’ Reldegen told her. ‘Both you and your husband have two titles and two separate formal identities.’ He smiled briefly. ‘I’m surprised that there was room on the throne for such a crowd.’ His face grew serious. ‘It won’t be a cure-all, your Grace,’ he added. ‘The divisions between Mimbre and Asturia are so deep-seated that they’ll take generations to erase.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BB3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BB4">‘And wilt thou also swear fealty to my husband?’ the queen asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BB5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BB6">‘As the King of Arendia, yes; as the Duke of Mimbre, never.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BB7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BB8">‘That will do for a start, my Lord. Let us see then to this proclamation. Let us with ink and parchment bandage our poor Arendia’s most gaping wound.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BB9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BBA">‘Beautifully put, your Grace,’ Reldegen said admiringly.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="J2BBB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BBC">Ran Borune XXIII had spent almost his entire life inside the Imperial compound at Tol Honeth. His infrequent trips to the major cities of Tolnedra had, for the most part, been made inside closed carriages. It was entirely probable that Ran Borune had never walked a continuous mile in his life, and a man who has not walked a mile has no real conception of what a mile is. From the very outset, his advisers despaired of ever making him understand the concept of distance.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BBD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BBE">The suggestion that ultimately resolved the difficulty came from a rather surprising source. A sometime tutor named Jeebers – a man who had narrowly escaped imprisonment or worse the previous summer – put forth the suggestion diffidently. Master Jeebers now did everything diffidently. His near brush with Imperial displeasure had forever extinguished the pompous self-importance that had previously marred his character. A number of his acquaintances were surprised to discover that they even liked the balding, skinny man now.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BBF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BBG">Master Jeebers had pointed out that if the Emperor could only see things in exact scale, he might then understand. Like so many good ideas that had surfaced from time to time in Tolnedra, this one immediately got out of hand. An entire acre of the Imperial grounds was converted into a scale replica of the border region of eastern Algaria and the opposing stretches of Mishrak ac Thull. To give it all perspective, a number of inch-high human figures were cast in lead to aid the Emperor in conceptualizing the field of operations.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BBH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BBI">The Emperor immediately announced that he’d really like to have more of the lead figures to aid his understanding of the masses of men involved, and a new industry was born in Tol Honeth. Overnight lead became astonishingly scarce.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BBJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BBK">In order that he might better see the field, the Emperor mounted each morning to the top of a thirty-foot-high tower that had hastily been erected for that purpose. There, with the aid of a great-voiced sergeant of the Imperial guard, the Emperor deployed his leaden regiments of infantry and cavalry in precise accordance with the latest dispatches from Algaria.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BBL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BBM">The general staff very nearly resigned their commissions en masse. They were, for the most part, men of advanced middle age, and joining the Emperor atop his tower each morning involved some strenuous climbing. They all tried at various times to explain to the beak-nosed little man that they could see just as well from the ground, but Ran Borune would have none of it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BBN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BBO">‘Morin, he’s killing us,’ one portly general complained bitterly to the Emperor’s chamberlain. ‘I’d rather go off to war than climb that ladder four times a day.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BBP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BBQ">‘Move the Drasnian pikemen four paces to the left!’ the sergeant bellowed from the top of the tower, and a dozen men on the ground began redeploying the tiny lead figures.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BBR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BBS">‘We all must serve in the capacity our Emperor chooses for us,’ Lord Morin replied philosophically.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BBT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BBU">‘I don’t see </span><span class="italic" aid="J2BBV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BC0">you</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BC1"> climbing the ladder,’ the general accused.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BC2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BC3">‘Our Emperor has chosen another capacity for me,’ Morin said rather smugly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BC4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BC5">That evening the weary little Emperor sought his bed. ‘It’s very exciting, Morin,’ he murmured drowsily, holding the velvet-lined case that contained the solid gold figures representing Ce’Nedra and Rhodar and the rest of the army’s leaders close to his chest, ‘but it’s very tiring, too.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BC6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BC7">‘Yes, your Majesty.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BC8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BC9">‘There always seems to be so much that I still have to do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BCA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BCB">‘That’s the nature of command, your Majesty,’ Morin observed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BCC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BCD">But the Emperor had already dropped off.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BCE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BCF">Lord Morin removed the case from the Emperor’s hands and carefully pulled the covers up around the sleeping man’s shoulders. ‘Sleep, Ran Borune,’ he said very gently. ‘You can play with your little toy soldiers again tomorrow.’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="J2BCG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BCH">Sadi the eunuch had quietly left the palace at Sthiss Tor by a secret doorway that opened behind the slaves’ quarters onto a shabby back street that twisted and turned in the general direction of the harbor. He had quite deliberately waited for the cover of the afternoon rainstorm and had dressed himself in the shabby clothing of a dockworker. Accompanying him was the one-eyed assassin, Issus, who also wore nondescript clothing. Sadi’s security precautions were routine, but his choice of Issus as his companion was not. Issus was not a member of the palace guard nor of Sadi’s personal retinue, but Sadi was not concerned on this afternoon’s outing with appearances or proprieties. Issus was by and large uncorrupted by palace politics and had a reputation for unswerving loyalty to whomever was paying him at the moment.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BCI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BCJ">The two passed down the rainswept street to a certain disreputable establishment frequented by lower-class workers, and went through a rather noisy taproom to the maze of cubicles at the back, where other entertainments were provided. At the end of a foul-smelling hallway, a lean, hard-eyed woman, whose arms were covered from wrist to elbow with cheap, gaudy bracelets, pointed wordlessly at a scarred door, then turned abruptly and disappeared through another doorway.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BCK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BCL">Behind the door lay a filthy room with only a bed for furniture. On the bed were two sets of clothing that smelled of tar and salt water, and sitting on the floor were two large tankards of lukewarm ale. Wordlessly, Sadi and Issus changed clothes. From beneath the soiled pillow, Issus pulled a pair of wigs and two sets of false whiskers.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BCM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BCN">‘How can they drink this?’ Sadi demanded, sniffing at one of the tankards and wrinkling his nose.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BCO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BCP">Issus shrugged. ‘Alorns have peculiar tastes. You don’t have to drink it all, Sadi. Splash most of it on your clothes. Drasnian sailors spill a lot of ale when they’re out in search of amusement. How do I look?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BCQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BCR">Sadi gave him a quick glance. ‘Ridiculous,’ he replied. ‘Hair and a beard don’t really suit you, Issus.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BCS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BCT">Issus laughed. ‘And they look particularly out of place on </span><span class="italic" aid="J2BCU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BCV">you.’</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BD0"> He shrugged and carefully poured ale down the front of his tar-spattered tunic. ‘I suppose we look enough like Drasnians to get by, and we certainly smell like Drasnians. Hook your beard on a little tighter, and let’s get moving before it stops raining.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BD1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BD2">‘Are we going out the back?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BD3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BD4">Issus shook his head. ‘If we’re being followed, the back will be watched. We’ll leave the way ordinary Drasnian sailors leave.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BD5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BD6">‘And how is that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BD7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BD8">‘I’ve made arrangements to have us thrown out.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BD9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDA">Sadi had never been thrown out of any place before, and he found the experience not particularly amusing. The two burly ruffians who unceremoniously pitched him into the street were a bit rough about it, and Sadi picked up several scrapes and abrasions in the process.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BDB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDC">Issus staggered to his feet and stood bawling curses at the closed door, then lurched over and pulled Sadi up out of the mud. Together they reeled in apparent drunkenness down the street toward the Drasnian enclave. Sadi noted that there had been two men in a doorway across the street when he and Issus had been ejected and that the two did not move to follow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BDD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDE">Once they entered the Drasnian enclave, Issus led the way rather quickly to the house of Droblek, the Drasnian port authority. They were admitted immediately and conveyed at once to a dimly lighted but comfortable room where the enormously fat Droblek sat sweating. With him was Count Melgon, the aristocratic ambassador from Tolnedra.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BDF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDG">‘Novel attire for the chief eunuch of Salmissra’s household,’ Count Melgon observed as Sadi pulled off his wig and false beard.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BDH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDI">‘Just a bit of deception, my Lord Ambassador,’ Sadi replied. ‘I didn’t particularly want this meeting to become general knowledge.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BDJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDK">‘Can he be trusted?’ Droblek asked bluntly, pointing at Issus.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BDL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDM">Sadi’s expression became whimsical. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="J2BDN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDO">Can</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDP"> you be trusted, Issus?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BDQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDR">‘You’ve paid me for up to the end of the month.’ Issus shrugged. ‘After that, we’ll see. I might get a better offer.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BDS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDT">‘You see?’ Sadi said to the two seated men. ‘Issus can be trusted until the end of the month – at least as much as anybody in Sthiss Tor can be trusted. One thing I’ve noticed about Issus – he’s a simple, uncomplicated man. Once you buy him, he stays bought. I think it’s referred to as professional ethics.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BDU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BDV">Droblek grunted sourly. ‘Do you suppose we could get to the point? Why did you go to so much trouble to arrange this meeting? Why didn’t you just summon us to the palace?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BE0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BE1">‘My dear Droblek,’ Sadi murmured, ‘you know the kind of intrigue that infests the palace. I’d prefer that what passes between us remain more or less confidential. The matter itself is rather uncomplicated. I’ve been approached by the emissary of Taur Urgas.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BE2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BE3">The two regarded him with no show of surprise.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BE4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BE5">‘I gather that you two already knew.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BE6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BE7">‘We’re hardly children, Sadi,’ Count Melgon told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BE8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BE9">‘I am at present in negotiations with the new ambassador from Rak Goska,’ Sadi mentioned.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BEA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BEB">‘Isn’t that the third one so far this summer?’ Melgon asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BEC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BED">Sadi nodded. ‘The Murgos seem to be particularly susceptible to certain fevers which abound in the swamps.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BEE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BEF">‘We’ve noticed that,’ Droblek said dryly. ‘What is your prognosis for the present emissary’s continued good health?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BEG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BEH">‘I don’t imagine he’s any more immune than his countrymen. He’s already beginning to feel unwell.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BEI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BEJ">‘Maybe he’ll be lucky and recover,’ Droblek suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BEK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BEL">‘Not very likely,’ Issus said with an ugly laugh.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BEM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BEN">‘The tendency of Murgo ambassadors to die unexpectedly has succeeded in keeping the negotiations moving very slowly,’ Sadi continued. ‘I’d like for your gentlemen to inform King Rhodar and Ran Borune that these delays will probably continue.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BEO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BEP">‘Why?’ Droblek asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BEQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BER">‘I want them to understand and appreciate my efforts in their present campaign against the Angarak kingdoms.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BES"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BET">‘Tolnedra has no involvement in that campaign,’ Melgon asserted quickly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BEU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BEV">‘Of course not.’ Sadi smiled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BF0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BF1">‘Just how far are you willing to go, Sadi?’ Droblek asked curiously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BF2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BF3">‘That depends almost entirely upon who’s winning at any given moment,’ Sadi replied urbanely. ‘If the Rivan Queen’s campaign in the east begins to run into difficulties, I suspect that the pestilence will subside and the Murgo emissaries will stop dying so conveniently. I’d almost have to make an accommodation with Taur Urgas at that point.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BF4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BF5">‘Don’t you find that just a bit contemptible, Sadi?’ Droblek asked acidly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BF6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BF7">Sadi shrugged. ‘We’re a contemptible sort of people, Droblek,’ he admitted, ‘but we survive. That’s no mean accomplishment for a weak nation lying between two major powers. Tell Rhodar and Ran Borune that I’ll stall the Murgos off for as long as things continue to go in their favor. I want them both to be aware of their obligation to me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BF8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BF9">‘And will you advise them when your position is about to change?’ Melgon asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BFA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFB">‘Of course not,’ Sadi replied. ‘I’m corrupt, Melgon. I’m not stupid.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BFC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFD">‘You’re not much of an ally, Sadi,’ Droblek told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BFE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFF">‘I never pretended to be. I’m looking out for myself. At the moment, my interests and yours happen to coincide, that’s all. I </span><span class="italic" aid="J2BFG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFH">do</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFI">, however, expect to be remembered for my assistance.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BFJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFK">‘You’re trying to play it both ways, Sadi,’ Droblek accused him bluntly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BFL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFM">‘I know.’ Sadi smiled. ‘Disgusting, isn’t it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="J2BFN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFO">Queen Islena of Cherek was in an absolute panic. This time Merel had gone too far. The advice they had received from Porenn had </span><span class="italic" aid="J2BFP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFQ">seemed</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFR"> quite sound – had indeed raised the possibility of a brilliant stroke which would disarm Grodeg and the Bear-cult once and for all. The imagined prospect of the helpless rage into which this would plummet the towering ecclesiast was almost a satisfaction in itself. Like so many people, Queen Islena took such pleasure in an imagined triumph the real thing became almost too much trouble. The victories of the imagination involved no risks, and a confrontation with an enemy always ended satisfactorily when both sides of the conversation came from one’s own daydreams. Left to her own devices, Islena would probably have been content to let it go at that.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BFS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFT">Merel, however, was less easily satisfied. The plan devised by the little queen of Drasnia had been quite sound, but it suffered from one flaw – they did not have enough men to bring it off. Merel, however, had located an ally with certain resources and had brought him into the queen’s inner circle. A group of men in Cherek had not accompanied Anheg and the fleet to Algaria largely because they were not the sort of men who made good sailors. At Merel’s stern-faced insistence, the Queen of Cherek suddenly developed an overpowering enthusiasm for hunting. It was in the forest, safe from prying ears, that the details of the coup were worked out.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BFU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BFV">‘When you kill a snake, you cut off its head,’ Torvik the huntsman had pointed out as he, Merel, and Islena sat in a forest glade while Torvik’s men roved through the woods harvesting enough game to make it appear that Islena had spent her day in a frenzy of slaughter. ‘You don’t accomplish all that much by snipping pieces off its tail an inch or so at a time,’ the broad-shouldered huntsman continued. ‘The Bear-cult isn’t really that concentrated in one place. With a little luck, we can gather up all the important members presently in Val Alorn in one sweep. That should irritate our snake enough to make him stick his neck out. Then we’ll simply chop off his head.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BG0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BG1">Torvik’s use of such terminology had made the queen wince. She had not been entirely sure that the blunt, grizzled forester had been speaking figuratively.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BG2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BG3">And now it had been done. Torvik and his huntsmen had moved quietly through the dark streets of Val Alorn for the entire night, gathering up the sleeping members of the Bear-cult, marching them in groups to the harbor and then locking them in the holds of waiting ships. Because of their years of experience, the hunters had been very thorough in rounding up their quarry. By morning, the only members of the Bear-cult left in the city were the High Priest of Belar and the dozen or so underpriests lodged in the temple.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BG4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BG5">Queen Islena sat, pale and trembling, on the throne of Cherek. She wore her purple gown and her gold crown. In her hand she held a scepter. The scepter had a comforting weight to it and could possibly be used as a weapon in an emergency. The queen was positive that an emergency was about to descend on her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BG6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BG7">‘This is all your fault, Merel,’ she bitterly accused her blond friend. ‘If you’d just left things alone, we wouldn’t be in this mess.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BG8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BG9">‘We’d be in a worse one,’ Merel replied coldly. ‘Pull yourself together, Islena. It’s done now, and you can’t undo it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BGA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGB">‘Grodeg terrifies me,’ Islena blurted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BGC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGD">‘He won’t be armed. He won’t be able to hurt you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BGE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGF">‘I’m only a woman,’ Islena quailed. ‘He’ll roar at me in that awful voice of his, and I’ll go absolutely to pieces.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BGG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGH">‘Stop being such a coward, Islena,’ Merel snapped. ‘Your timidity’s brought Cherek right to the edge of disaster. Every time Grodeg’s raised his voice to you, you’ve given him anything he wanted – just because you’re afraid of harsh talk. Are you a child? Does noise frighten you that much?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BGI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGJ">‘You forget yourself, Merel,’ Islena flared suddenly. ‘I </span><span class="italic" aid="J2BGK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGL">am</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGM"> queen, after all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BGN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGO">‘Then by all the Gods, </span><span class="italic" aid="J2BGP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGQ">be</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGR"> queen! Stop behaving like a silly, frightened serving girl. Sit up straight on your throne as if you had some iron in your backbone – and pinch your cheeks. You’re as pale as a bedsheet.’ Merel’s face hardened. ‘Listen to me, Islena,’ she said. ‘If you give even one hint that you’re starting to weaken, I’ll have Torvik run his spear into Grodeg right here in the throne room.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BGS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGT">‘You wouldn’t!’ Islena gasped. ‘You </span><span class="italic" aid="J2BGU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BGV">can’t</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BH0"> kill a priest.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BH1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BH2">‘He’s a man – just like any other man,’ Merel declared harshly. ‘If you stick a spear in his belly, he’ll die.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BH3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BH4">‘Not even Anheg would dare to do that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BH5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BH6">‘I’m not Anheg.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BH7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BH8">‘You’ll be cursed!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BH9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BHA">‘I’m not afraid of curses.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BHB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BHC">Torvik came into the throne room, a broad-bladed boarspear held negligently in one big hand. ‘He’s coming,’ he announced laconically.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BHD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BHE">‘Oh, dear,’ Islena quavered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BHF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BHG">‘Stop that!’ Merel snapped.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BHH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BHI">Grodeg was livid with rage as he strode into the throne room. His white robe was rumpled as if he had thrown it on hastily, and his white hair and beard were uncombed. ‘I will speak with the queen alone!’ he thundered as he approached across the rush-strewn floor.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BHJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BHK">‘That is the queen’s decision to make, not yours, my Lord High Priest,’ Merel advised him in a flinty voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BHL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BHM">‘Does the wife of the Earl of Trellheim speak for the throne?’ Grodeg demanded of Islena.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BHN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BHO">Islena faltered, then saw Torvik standing directly behind the tall priest. The boarspear in his hand was no longer so negligently grasped. ‘Calm yourself, revered Grodeg,’ the queen said, quite suddenly convinced that the life of the infuriated priest hinged not only on her words but even on her tone of voice. At the tiniest quaver, Merel would give the signal, and Torvik would sink that broad, sharp blade into Grodeg’s back with about as much emotion as he showed about swatting a fly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BHP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BHQ">‘I want to see you alone,’ Grodeg repeated stubbornly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BHR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BHS">‘No.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BHT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BHU">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="J2BHV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BI0">No?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BI1">’ he roared incredulously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BI2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BI3">‘You heard me, Grodeg,’ she told him. ‘And stop shouting at me. My hearing is quite good.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BI4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BI5">He gaped at her, then quickly recovered. ‘Why have all my friends been arrested?’ he demanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BI6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BI7">‘They were not arrested, my Lord High Priest,’ the queen replied. ‘They have all volunteered to join my husband’s fleet.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BI8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BI9">‘Ridiculous!’ he snorted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BIA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BIB">‘I think you’d better choose your words a bit more carefully, Grodeg,’ Merel told him. ‘The queen’s patience with your impertinence is wearing thin.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BIC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BID">‘Impertinence?’ he exclaimed. ‘How </span><span class="italic" aid="J2BIE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BIF">dare</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BIG"> you speak that way to me?’ He drew himself up and fixed a stern eye on the queen. ‘I insist upon a private audience,’ he told her in a thunderous voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BIH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BII">The voice which had always cowed her before quite suddenly irritated Islena. She was trying to save this idiot’s life, and he kept shouting at her. ‘My Lord Grodeg,’ she said with an unaccustomed hint of steel in her voice, ‘if you bellow at me one more time, I’ll have you muzzled.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BIJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BIK">His eyes widened in amazement.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BIL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BIM">‘We have nothing to discuss in private, my Lord,’ the queen continued. ‘All that remains is for you to receive your instructions – which you will follow to the letter. It is our decree that you will proceed directly to the harbor, where you will board the ship which is waiting to transport you to Algaria. There you will join the forces of Cherek in the campaign against the Angaraks.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BIN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BIO">‘I refuse!’ Grodeg retorted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BIP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BIQ">‘Think carefully, my Lord Grodeg,’ Merel purred. ‘The queen has given you a royal command. Refusal could be considered treason.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BIR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BIS">‘I am the High Priest of Belar,’ Grodeg ground out between clenched teeth, obviously having great difficulty in modulating his voice. ‘You wouldn’t dare ship me off like some peasant conscript.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BIT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BIU">‘I wonder if the High Priest of Belar might like to make a small wager on that,’ Torvik said with deceptive mildness. He set the butt of his spear on the floor, took a stone from the pouch at his belt and began to hone the already razor-sharp blade. The steely sound had an obviously chilling effect on Grodeg.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BIV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJ0">‘You will go to the harbor now, Grodeg,’ Islena told him, ‘and you will get on that ship. If you do not, you will go to the dungeon, where you will keep the rats company until my husband returns. Those are your choices; join Anheg or join the rats. Decide quickly. You’re starting to bore me, and quite frankly, I’m sick of the sight of you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="J2BJ1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJ2">Queen Porenn of Drasnia was in the nursery, ostensibly feeding her infant son. Out of respect for the queen’s person, she was unspied upon while she was nursing. Porenn, however, was not alone. Javelin, the bone-thin chief of Drasnian intelligence, was with her. For the sake of appearance, Javelin was dressed in a serving maid’s gown and cap, and he looked surprisingly feminine in the disguise he wore with no apparent trace of self-consciousness.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BJ3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJ4">‘Are there really that many cultists in the intelligence service?’ the queen asked, a little dismayed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BJ5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJ6">Javelin sat with his back politely turned. ‘I’m afraid so, your Highness. We should have been more alert, but we had other things on our minds.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BJ7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJ8">Porenn thought about it for a moment, unconsciously rocking her suckling baby. ‘Islena’s moving already, isn’t she?’ she asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BJ9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJA">‘That’s the word I received this morning,’ Javelin replied. ‘Grodeg’s on his way to the mouth of the Aldur River already, and the queen’s men are moving out into the countryside, rounding up every member of the cult as they go.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BJB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJC">‘Will it in any way hamper our operations to jerk that many people out of Boktor?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BJD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJE">‘We can manage, your Highness,’ Javelin assured her. ‘We might have to speed up the graduation of the current class at the academy and finish their training on the job, but we’ll manage.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BJF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJG">‘Very well then, Javelin,’ Porenn decided. ‘Ship them all out. Get every cult member out of Boktor, and separate them. I want them sent to the most miserable duty posts you can devise, and I don’t want any of them within fifty leagues of any other one. There will be no excuses, no sudden illnesses, and no resignations. Give each of them something to do, and then </span><span class="italic" aid="J2BJH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJI">make</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJJ"> him do it. I want every Bear-cultist who’s crept into the intelligence service out of Boktor by nightfall.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="J2BJK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="J2BJL">‘It will be my pleasure, Porenn,’ Javelin said. ‘Oh, incidentally, that Nadrak merchant, Yarblek, is back from Yar Nadrak, and he wants to talk to you about the salmon runs again. He seems to have this obsessive interest in fish.’</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_20" aid="J2BJM"></div>
