<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos471107" aid="K0RQ1"><span class="calibre5" aid="K0RQ2"><span class="italic" aid="K0RQ3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQ4">Chapter Twelve</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="K0RQ5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQ6">The raising of the Cherek fleet to the top of the eastern escarpment took a full two weeks, and King Rhodar chafed visibly at the pace of the operation.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RQ7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQ8">‘You knew this was going to take time, Rhodar,’ Ce’Nedra said to him as he fumed and sweated, pacing back and forth with frequent dark looks at the towering cliff face. ‘Why are you so upset?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RQ9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQA">‘Because the ships are right out in the open, Ce’Nedra,’ he replied testily. ‘There’s no way to hide them or disguise them while they’re being raised. Those ships are the key to our whole campaign, and if somebody on the other side starts putting a few things together, we might have to meet all of Angarak instead of just the Thulls.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RQB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQC">‘You worry too much,’ she told him. ‘Cho-Hag and Korodullin are burning everything in sight up there. ‘Zakath and Taur Urgas have other things to think about beside what we’re hauling up the cliff.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RQD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQE">‘It must be wonderful to be so unconcerned about things,’ he said sarcastically.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RQF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQG">‘Be nice, Rhodar,’ she said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RQH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQI">General Varana, still scrupulously dressed in his Tolnedran mantle, limped toward them with that studiously diffident expression that indicated he was about to make another suggestion.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RQJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQK">‘Varana,’ King Rhodar burst out irritably, ‘why don’t you put on your uniform?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RQL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQM">‘Because I’m not really officially here, your Majesty,’ the general replied calmly. ‘Tolnedra </span><span class="italic" aid="K0RQN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQO">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQP"> neutral in this affair, you’ll recall.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RQQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQR">‘That’s a fiction, and we all know it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RQS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQT">‘A necessary one, however. The Emperor is still holding diplomatic channels open to Taur Urgas and ‘Zakath. Those discussions would deteriorate if someone saw a Tolnedran general swaggering around in full uniform.’ He paused briefly. ‘Would a small suggestion offend your Majesty?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RQU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RQV">‘That all depends on the suggestion,’ Rhodar retorted. Then he made a face and apologized. ‘I’m sorry, Varana. This delay’s making me bad-tempered. What did you have in mind?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RR0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RR1">‘I think you might want to give some thought to moving your command operations up to the top about now. You’ll want things running smoothly by the time the bulk of your infantry arrives, and it usually takes a couple of days to iron out the wrinkles when you set things up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RR2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RR3">King Rhodar stared at a Cherek ship being hoisted ponderously up the cliff face. ‘I’m not going to ride up on one of those, Varana,’ he declared flatly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RR4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RR5">‘It’s absolutely safe, your Majesty,’ Varana assured him. ‘I’ve made the trip myself several times. Even Lady Polgara went up that way just this morning.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RR6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RR7">‘Polgara could fly down if something went wrong,’ Rhodar said. ‘I don’t have her advantages. Can you imagine the size of the hole I’d make in the ground if I fell that far?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RR8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RR9">‘The alternative is extremely strenuous, your Majesty. There are several ravines running down from the top. They’ve been leveled out a bit so that the horses can go up, but they’re still </span><span class="italic" aid="K0RRA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRB">very</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRC"> steep.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RRD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRE">‘A little sweating won’t hurt me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RRF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRG">Varana shrugged. ‘As your Majesty wishes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RRH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRI">‘I’ll keep you company, Rhodar,’ Ce’Nedra offered brightly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RRJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRK">He gave her a suspicious look.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RRL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRM">‘I don’t really trust machines either,’ she confessed. ‘I’ll go change clothes, and then we can start.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RRN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRO">‘You want to do it </span><span class="italic" aid="K0RRP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRQ">today</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRR">?’ His voice was plaintive.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RRS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRT">‘Why put it off?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RRU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RRV">‘I can think of a dozen reasons.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RS0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RS1">The term ‘very steep’ turned out to be a gross understatement. ‘Precipitous’ might have been more accurate. The incline made riding horses out of the question, but ropes had been strung along the steeper stretches to aid in the climb. Ce’Nedra, dressed in one of her short Dryad tunics, scampered hand over hand up the ropes with the agility of a squirrel. King Rhodar’s pace, however, was much slower.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RS2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RS3">‘Please stop groaning, Rhodar,’ she told him after they had climbed for an hour or so. ‘You sound like a sick cow.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RS4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RS5">‘That’s hardly fair, Ce’Nedra,’ he wheezed, stopping to mop his streaming face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RS6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RS7">‘I never promised to be fair,’ she retorted with an impish grin. ‘Come along, we still have a long way to go.’ And she flitted up another fifty yards or so.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RS8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RS9">‘Don’t you think you’re a little underdressed?’ he puffed disapprovingly, staring up at her. ‘Proper ladies don’t show off so much leg.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RSA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RSB">‘What’s wrong with my legs?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RSC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RSD">‘They’re bare – that’s what’s wrong with them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RSE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RSF">‘Don’t be such a prig. I’m comfortable. That’s all that matters. Are you coming or not?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RSG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RSH">Rhodar groaned again. ‘Isn’t it almost time for lunch?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RSI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RSJ">‘We just had lunch.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RSK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RSL">‘Did we? I’d forgotten already.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RSM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RSN">‘You always seem to forget your last meal – usually before the crumbs have been brushed away.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RSO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RSP">‘That’s the nature of a fat man, Ce’Nedra.’ He sighed. ‘The last meal is history. It’s the next one that’s important.’ The stared mournfully up the brutal trail ahead and groaned again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RSQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RSR">‘This was all your idea,’ she heartlessly reminded him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RSS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RST">The sun was low in the west when they reached the top. As King Rhodar collapsed, Princess Ce’Nedra looked around curiously. The fortifications which had been erected along the top of the escarpment were extensive and quite imposing. The walls were of earth and stone and were perhaps thirty feet high. Through an open gate the princess saw a series of other, lower walls, each fronted by a ditch bristling with sharpened stakes and thorny brambles. At various points along the main wall rose imposing blockhouses, and within the walls were neat rows of huts for the soldiers.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RSU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RSV">The forts swarmed with men, and their various activities raised an almost perpetual cloud of dust. A party of Algar clansmen, smoke-stained and mounted on spent-looking horses, rode slowly in through the gate; and a few moments later, a contingent of gleaming Mimbrate knights, pennons snapping from their lances and the great hoofs of their chargers clattering on the stony ground, rode out in search of yet another town to destroy.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RT0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RT1">The huge hoists at the edge of the escarpment creaked and groaned under the weight of the Cherek ships being raised from the plain below; some distance away, within the fortified walls, the growing fleet sat awaiting the final portage to the headwaters of the upper River Mardu, some fifty leagues distant.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RT2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RT3">Polgara, accompanied by Durnik and the towering Barak, approached to greet the princess and the prostrate King of Drasnia.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RT4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RT5">‘How was the climb?’ Barak inquired.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RT6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RT7">‘Ghastly,’ Rhodar wheezed. ‘Does anybody have anything to eat? I think I’ve melted off about ten pounds.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RT8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RT9">‘It doesn’t show,’ Barak told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RTA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RTB">‘That sort of exertion isn’t really good for you, Rhodar,’ Polgara told the gasping monarch. ‘Why were you so stubborn about it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RTC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RTD">‘Because I have an absolute horror of heights,’ Rhodar replied. ‘I’d climb ten times as far to avoid being hauled up that cliff by those contraptions. The idea of all that empty air under me makes my flesh creep.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RTE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RTF">Barak grinned. ‘That’s a lot of creeping.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RTG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RTH">‘Will somebody </span><span class="italic" aid="K0RTI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RTJ">please</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RTK"> give me something to eat?’ Rhodar asked in an anguished tone of voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RTL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RTM">‘A bit of cold chicken?’ Durnik offered solicitously, handing him a well-browned chicken leg.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RTN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RTO">‘Where did you ever find a chicken?’ Rhodar exclaimed, eagerly seizing the leg.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RTP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RTQ">‘The Thulls brought some with them,’ Durnik told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RTR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RTS">‘Thulls?’ Ce’Nedra gasped. ‘What are Thulls doing here?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RTT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RTU">‘Surrendering,’ Durnik replied. ‘Whole villages of them have been showing up for the past week or so. They walk up to the edge of the ditches along the front of the fortifications and sit down and wait to be captured. They’re very patient about it. Sometimes it’s a day or so before anybody has the time to go out and capture them, but they don’t seem to mind.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RTV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RU0">‘Why do they want to be captured?’ Ce’Nedra asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RU1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RU2">‘There aren’t any Grolims here,’ Durnik explained. ‘No altars to Torak and no sacrificial knives. The Thulls seem to feel that getting away from that sort of thing is worth the inconvenience of being captured. We take them in and put them to work on the fortifications. They’re good workers, if you give them the proper supervision.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RU3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RU4">‘Is that entirely safe?’ Rhodar asked around a mouthful of chicken. ‘There might be spies among them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RU5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RU6">Durnik nodded. ‘We know,’ he said, ‘but the spies are usually Grolims. A Thull doesn’t have the mental equipment to be a spy, so the Grolims have to do it themselves.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RU7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RU8">Rhodar lowered his chicken leg in astonishment. ‘You’re letting Grolims inside the fortifications?’ he demanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RU9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RUA">‘It’s nothing all that serious,’ Durnik told him. ‘The Thulls know who the Grolims are, and we let them deal with the problem. They usually take them a mile or so along the escarpment and then throw them off. At first they wanted to do it right here, but some of their elders pointed out that it might not be polite to drop Grolims down on top of the men working below, so they take them some place where they won’t bother anybody when they fall. A very considerate people, the Thulls. One could almost get to like them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RUB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RUC">‘You’ve sunburned your nose, Ce’Nedra,’ Polgara told the little princess. ‘Didn’t you think of wearing a hat?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RUD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RUE">‘Hats give me a headache.’ Ce’Nedra shrugged. ‘A little sunburn won’t hurt me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RUF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RUG">‘You have an appearance to maintain, dear,’ Polgara pointed out. ‘You’re not going to look very queenly with your nose peeling.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RUH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RUI">‘It’s nothing to worry about, Lady Polgara. You can fix it, can’t you? You know—’ Ce’Nedra made a little gesture with her hand that was meant to look magical.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RUJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RUK">Polgara gave her a long, chilly look.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RUL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RUM">King Anheg of Cherek, accompanied by the broad-shouldered Rivan Warder, approached them. ‘Did you have a nice climb?’ he asked Rhodar pleasantly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RUN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RUO">‘How would you like a punch in the nose?’ Rhodar asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RUP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RUQ">King Anheg laughed coarsely. ‘My,’ he said, ‘aren’t we grumpy today? I’ve just had some news from home that ought to brighten your disposition a bit.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RUR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RUS">‘Dispatches?’ Rhodar groaned, hauling himself wearily to his feet.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RUT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RUU">Anheg nodded. ‘They sent them up from down below while you were getting your exercise. You’re not going to believe what’s been going on back there.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RUV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RV0">‘Try me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RV1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RV2">‘You absolutely won’t believe it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RV3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RV4">‘Anheg, spit it out.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RV5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RV6">‘We’re about to get some reinforcements. Islena and Porenn have been very busy these last few weeks.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RV7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RV8">Polgara looked at him sharply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RV9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVA">‘Do you know something?’ Anheg said, holding out a folded dispatch. ‘I wasn’t even aware of the fact that Islena knew how to read and write, and now I get this.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RVB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVC">‘Don’t be cryptic, Anheg,’ Polgara told him. ‘What have the ladies been up to?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RVD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVE">‘I gather that after we left, the Bear-cult began to make itself a bit obnoxious. Grodeg apparently felt that with the men out of the way, he could take over. He started throwing his weight around in Val Alorn, and cult members began to surface in the headquarters of Drasnian intelligence in Boktor. It looks as if they’ve been making preparations for something for years. Anyway, Porenn and Islena began passing information back and forth, and when they realized how close Grodeg was to getting his hands on real power in the two kingdoms, they took steps. Porenn ordered all the cult members out of Boktor – sent them to the most miserable duty posts she could think of – and Islena rounded up the Bear-cult in Val Alorn – every last one of them – and shipped them out to join the army.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RVF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVG">‘They did </span><span class="italic" aid="K0RVH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVI">what</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVJ">?’ Rhodar gasped.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RVK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVL">‘Isn’t it amazing?’ A slow grin spread across Anheg’s coarse face. ‘The beauty of the whole thing is that Islena could get away with it, while I couldn’t. Women aren’t supposed to be aware of the subtleties involved in arresting priests and noblemen – the need for evidence against them and so on – so what would be gross impropriety on my part will be laughed off as ignorance on hers. I’ll have to apologize to Grodeg, of course, but it will be after the fact. The cult will be here, and they’ll have no honest reason to go back home.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RVM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVN">Rhodar’s answering grin was every bit as wicked as Anheg’s. ‘How did Grodeg take it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RVO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVP">‘He was absolutely livid. I guess Islena faced him down personally. She gave him the choice of joining us or going to the dungeon.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RVQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVR">‘You can’t put the High Priest of Belar in a dungeon,’ Rhodar exclaimed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0RVS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVT">‘Islena didn’t know that, and Grodeg </span><span class="italic" aid="K0RVU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0RVV">knew</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S00"> that she didn’t. She’d have had him chained to the wall in the deepest hole she could find before anybody had gotten around to telling her that it was illegal. Can’t you just see my Islena delivering that kind of ultimatum to the old windbag?’ There was a note of fierce pride in Anheg’s voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S01"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S02">King Rhodar’s face grew very sly. ‘There’s bound to be some rather hot fighting in this campaign sooner or later,’ he noted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S03"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S04">Anheg nodded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S05"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S06">‘The Bear-cult prides itself on its fighting ability, doesn’t it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S07"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S08">Anheg nodded again, grinning.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S09"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S0A">‘They’d be perfect for spearheading any attacks, wouldn’t they?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S0B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S0C">Anheg’s grin grew positively vicious.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S0D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S0E">‘I imagine that their casualties will be heavy,’ the King of Drasnia suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S0F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S0G">‘It’s in a good cause, after all,’ Anheg replied piously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S0H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S0I">‘If you two have quite finished gloating, I think it’s time I got the princess in out of the sun,’ Polgara told the two grinning monarchs.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S0J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S0K">The fortified positions atop the escarpment bustled with activity for the next several days. Even as the last of the Cherek ships were raised up the cliffs, the Algars and Mimbrates extended their depredations out into the Thullish countryside. ‘There aren’t any crops standing for fifty leagues in any direction,’ Hettar reported back. ‘We’ll have to go out farther to find anything else to burn.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S0L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S0M">‘You find many Murgos?’ Barak asked the hawk-faced man.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S0N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S0O">‘A few.’ Hettar shrugged. ‘Not enough to make it interesting, but we run across one every now and then.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S0P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S0Q">‘How’s Mandorallen doing?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S0R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S0S">‘I haven’t seen him for a few days,’ Hettar replied. ‘There’s a lot of smoke coming from the direction he went, though, so I imagine he’s keeping busy.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S0T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S0U">‘What’s the country like out there?’ King Anheg asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S0V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S10">‘Not bad, once you get past the uplands. The part of Thulldom along the escarpment here is pretty forbidding.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S11"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S12">‘What do you mean by forbidding? I’ve got to haul ships through that country.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S13"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S14">‘Rock, sand, a few thornbushes and no water,’ Hettar replied. ‘And it’s hotter than the backdoor of a furnace.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S15"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S16">‘Thanks,’ Anheg said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S17"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S18">‘You wanted to know,’ Hettar told him. ‘Excuse me.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S19"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1A">I need a fresh horse and some more torches.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S1B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1C">‘You’re going out again?’ Barak asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S1D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1E">‘It’s something to do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S1F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1G">Once the last of the ships had been raised, the Drasnian hoists began lifting tons of food and equipment that soon swelled King Fulrach’s supply dumps within the forts to overflowing. The Thullish prisoners proved to be an invaluable asset, carrying whatever burden they were told to carry without complaint or hesitation. Their coarse features shone with such simpleminded gratitude and eagerness to please that Ce’Nedra found it impossible to hate them, even though they were technically the enemy. Slowly, bit by bit, the princess discovered the facts that made the lives of the Thullish people such an unrelieved horror. There was not a family among them that had not lost several members to the knives of the Grolims – husbands, wives, children, and parents had all been selected for sacrifice, and the thought uppermost in every Thull’s life was to avoid the same fate at any cost. The perpetual terror had erased every hint of human affection from the Thull’s makeup. He lived in dreadful isolation, without love, without companionship, without any feeling but constant anxiety and dread. The reputedly insatiable appetite of Thullish women had nothing whatsoever to do with morals or lack of them. It was a simple matter of survival. To escape the knife, a Thullish woman was forced to remain perpetually pregnant. She was not driven by lust, but by fear, and her fear dehumanized her entirely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S1H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1I">‘How can they live that way?’ the princess burst out to Lady Polgara as the two of them returned to their makeshift quarters in the stout blockhouse which had been erected inside the walls for the use of the leaders of the army. ‘Why don’t they rebel and drive the Grolims out?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S1J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1K">‘And just who’s supposed to lead a rebellion, Ce’Nedra?’ Polgara asked her calmly. ‘The Thulls know that there are Grolims who can pick the thoughts from a man’s mind as easily as you’d pick fruit in an orchard. If a Thull even considered organizing some kind of resistance, he’d be the next one dragged to the altar.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S1L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1M">‘But their lives are so </span><span class="italic" aid="K0S1N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1O">horrible</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1P">,’ Ce’Nedra objected.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S1Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1R">‘Perhaps we can change that,’ Polgara said. ‘In a way what we’re trying to do is not only for the benefit of the west, but for the Angaraks as well. If we win, they’ll be liberated from the Grolims. They might not thank us at first, but in time they might learn to appreciate it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S1S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1T">‘Why shouldn’t they thank us?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S1U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S1V">‘Because if we win, dear, it will be because we’ve killed their God. That’s a very hard thing to thank someone for.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S20"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S21">‘But Torak is a monster.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S22"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S23">‘He’s still their God,’ Polgara replied. ‘The loss of one’s God is a very subtle and terrible injury. Ask the Ulgos what it’s like to live without one. It’s been five thousand years since UL became their God, and they still remember what it was like before he accepted them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S24"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S25">‘We </span><span class="italic" aid="K0S26"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S27">are</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S28"> going to win, aren’t we?’ Ce’Nedra asked suddenly, all her fears flooding to the surface.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S29"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2A">‘I don’t know, Ce’Nedra,’ Polgara answered quietly. ‘No-one does – not me, not Beldin, not my father, not even Aldur. All we can do is try.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S2B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2C">‘What will happen if we lose?’ the princess asked in a tiny, frightened voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S2D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2E">‘We’ll be enslaved in exactly the same way the Thulls are,’ Polgara replied quietly. ‘Torak will become King and God over the entire world. The other Gods will be banished for ever, and the Grolims will be unleashed upon us all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S2F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2G">‘I won’t live in that kind of world,’ Ce’Nedra declared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S2H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2I">‘None of us would care to.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S2J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2K">‘Did you ever meet Torak?’ the princess asked suddenly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S2L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2M">Polgara nodded. ‘Once or twice – the last time was at Vo Mimbre just before his duel with Brand.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S2N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2O">‘What’s he really like?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S2P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2Q">‘He’s a God. The force of his mind is overwhelming. When he speaks to you, you must listen to him – and when he commands, you </span><span class="italic" aid="K0S2R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2S">must</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2T"> obey him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S2U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S2V">‘Not </span><span class="italic" aid="K0S30"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S31">you</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S32">, certainly.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S33"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S34">‘I don’t think you understand, dear.’ Polgara’s face was grave, and her glorious eyes were as distant as the moon. Without seeming to think about it, she reached out, picked up Errand and sat him on her lap. The child smiled at her and, as he so often did, he reached out and touched the white lock at her brow. ‘There’s a compulsion in Torak’s voice that’s almost impossible to resist,’ she continued. ‘You </span><span class="italic" aid="K0S35"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S36">know</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S37"> that he’s twisted and evil, but when he speaks to you, your will to resist crumbles, and you’re suddenly very weak and afraid.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S38"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S39">‘Surely </span><span class="italic" aid="K0S3A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3B">you</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3C"> weren’t afraid.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S3D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3E">‘You still don’t understand. Of course I was afraid. We all were – even my father. Pray that you never meet Torak. He’s not some petty Grolim like Chamdar or a scheming old wizard like Ctuchik. He’s a God. He’s hideously maimed, and at some point he was thwarted. Something he needed – something so profound that no human could even conceive of it – was denied to him, and that refusal or rejection drove him mad. His madness is not like the madness of Taur Urgas, who, in spite of everything is still human. Torak’s madness is the madness of a God – a being who can </span><span class="italic" aid="K0S3F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3G">make</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3H"> his diseased imaginings come to pass. Only the Orb can truly withstand him. I could perhaps resist him for a time, but if he lays the full force of his will upon me, ultimately I’ll have to give him what he wants – and what he wants from me is too dreadful to think about.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S3I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3J">‘I don’t exactly follow you, Lady Polgara.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S3K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3L">Garion’s Aunt looked gravely at the tiny girl. ‘Perhaps you don’t at that,’ she said. ‘It has to do with a part of the past that the Tolnedran Historical Society chooses to ignore. Sit down, Ce’Nedra, and I’ll try to explain.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S3M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3N">The princess sat on a rude bench in their rough chamber. Polgara’s mood was unusual – very quiet, even pensive. She placed her arms about Errand and held him close, nestling her cheek against his blond curls as if taking comfort from the contact with this small boy. ‘There are two Prophecies, Ce’Nedra,’ she explained in her rich voice, ‘but the time is coming when there will only be one. Everything that is or was or is yet to be will become a part of whichever Prophecy prevails. Every man, every woman, every child has two possible destinies. For some, the differences are not all that great, but in my case, they’re rather profound.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S3O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3P">‘I don’t quite understand.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S3Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3R">‘In the Prophecy which we serve – the one that has brought us here – I am Polgara the sorceress, daughter to Belgarath and guardian to Belgarion.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S3S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3T">‘And in the other?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S3U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S3V">‘In the other, I am the bride of Torak.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S40"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S41">Ce’Nedra gasped.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S42"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S43">‘And now you see why I was afraid,’ Polgara continued. ‘I’ve been terrified of Torak since my father first explained this to me when I was no older than you are now. I’m not so much afraid for myself, but more because I know that if I falter – if Torak’s will overpowers mine – then the Prophecy we serve will fail. Torak will not only win me, but all of mankind as well. At Vo Mimbre, he called to me, and I felt – very briefly – the awful compulsion to run to him. But I defied him. I’ve never done anything in my life that was so hard to do. It was </span><span class="italic" aid="K0S44"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S45">my</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S46"> defence, however, that drove him into the duel with Brand, and only in that duel could the power of the Orb be released against him. My father gambled everything on the strength of my will. The old wolf is a great gambler sometimes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S47"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S48">‘Then if—’ Ce’Nedra could not say it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S49"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S4A">‘If Garion loses?’ Polgara said it so calmly that it was quite obvious that she had considered the possibility many times before. ‘Then Torak will come to claim his bride, and there will be no power on earth sufficient to stop him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S4B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S4C">‘I would sooner die,’ the princess blurted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S4D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S4E">‘So would I, Ce’Nedra, but that option may not be open to me. Torak’s will is so much stronger than mine that he may be able to take from me the ability or even the desire to will myself out of existence. If it should happen, it may very well be that I’ll be deliriously happy to be his chosen and beloved – but deep inside, I think that a part of me will be screaming and will continue to scream in horror down through all the endless centuries to the very end of days.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S4F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S4G">It was too horrible to think about. Unable to restrain herself, the princess threw herself on her knees, clasped her arms about Polgara and Errand, and burst into tears.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="K0S4H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="K0S4I">‘Now, now, there’s no need to cry, Ce’Nedra,’ Polgara told her gently, smoothing the sobbing girl’s hair with her hand. ‘Garion has still not reached the City of Endless Night, and Torak is still asleep. There’s a little time left. And who knows? We might even win.’</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_21" aid="K0S4J"></div>

<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos506949" aid="KVCC1"><span class="calibre5" aid="KVCC2"><span class="italic" aid="KVCC3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCC4">Chapter Thirteen</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="KVCC5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCC6">Once the Cherek fleet had been raised, the pace of activities within the fortifications began to quicken. King Rhodar’s infantry units began to arrive from the encampment at the Aldur River to make the tortuous climb up the narrow ravines to the top of the escarpment; lines of wagons from the main supply dumps freighted food and equipment to the base of the cliff where the great hoists waited to lift the supplies up the mile-high basalt face; and the Mimbrate and Algar raiding parties moved out, usually before dawn, in their now far-flung search for as yet unravaged towns and crops. The depredations of the raiders, their short, savage sieges of poorly fortified Thullish towns and villages, and the mile-wide swaths of fire that they cut through fields of ripe grain had finally swung the sluggish Thulls into poorly organized attempts at resistance. The Thulls, however, inevitably raced to the last point of Mimbrate attack and arrived hours or even days too late, to discover only smoking ruins, dead soldiers, and terrified and dispossessed townsmen, or, when they attempted to intercept the swiftly moving Algars, they normally found only acre upon acre of blackened earth. The raiders had moved on, and the desperate attempts of the Thulls to catch up with them were entirely futile.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCC7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCC8">The notion of attacking the forts from which the raiders operated did not occur to the Thulls, or if it did, it was quickly dismissed. The Thulls were not emotionally suited to attacking heavily defended fortifications. They much preferred dashing about, chasing fires, and complaining bitterly to their Murgo and Mallorean allies about the lack of support they were receiving. The Malloreans of Emperor ‘Zakath stead-fastly refused to emerge from their staging areas around Thull Zelik. The Murgos of Taur Urgas, however, did make a few sorties in southern Thulldom, in part as a gesture toward the notion of Angarak unity – but more, King Rhodar surmised, as a part of their overall maneuvering for position. Murgo scouts were even occasionally discovered in the vicinity of the forts themselves. In order to sweep the area clear of these prying Murgo eyes, patrols went out every day from the forts to range through the arid hills. The parched, rocky valleys near the forts were randomly searched by Drasnian pikemen and platoons of legionnaires. Algar clansmen, supposedly resting from their long-range raids, amused themselves with an impromptu game they called ‘Murgo hunting.’ They made a great show of their frequent excursions and piously insisted that they were sacrificing their rest time out of a sense of responsibility for the security of the forts. They did not, of course, fool anybody with their protestations.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCC9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCA">‘The area </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCCB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCC">does</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCD"> need to be patroled, Rhodar,’ King Cho-Hag insisted. ‘My children are performing a necessary duty, after all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCCE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCF">‘Duty?’ Rhodar snorted. ‘Put an Algar on a horse and show him a hill he hasn’t seen the backside of yet, and he’ll always find an excuse to go take a look.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCCG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCH">‘You wrong us,’ Cho-Hag replied with a look of hurt innocence.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCCI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCJ">‘I </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCCK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCL">know</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCM"> you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCCN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCO">Ce’Nedra and her two closest companions had watched the periodic departure of the lighthearted Algar horsemen with increasingly sour expressions. Though Ariana was perhaps more sedentary in her habits and was accustomed, as all Mimbrate ladies were, to waiting quite patiently while the men were out playing, Adara, Garion’s Algar cousin, felt her confinement most keenly. Like all Algars, she felt a deep-seated need to have the wind in her face and the thunder of hoofs in her ears. She grew petulant after a time and sighed often.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCCP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCQ">‘And what shall we do today, ladies?’ Ce’Nedra asked the two of them brightly one morning after breakfast. ‘How shall we amuse ourselves until lunchtime?’ She said it rather extravagantly, since she already had plans for the day.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCCR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCS">‘There is always embroidery,’ Ariana suggested. ‘It doth pleasantly occupy the fingers and eyes while leaving the mind and lips free for conversation.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCCT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCCU">Adara sighed deeply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCCV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCD0">‘Or maybe we might go and observe my lord as he instructs his serfs in their warlike preparations.’ Ariana usually found some excuse to watch Lelldorin for at least half of each day.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCD1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCD2">‘I’m not sure that I’m up to watching a group of men murder hay bales with arrows again today,’ Adara said a bit waspishly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCD3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCD4">Ce’Nedra moved quickly to head off any incipient bickering. ‘We could make an inspection tour,’ she suggested archly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCD5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCD6">‘Ce’Nedra, we’ve looked at every blockhouse and every hut within the walls a dozen times already,’ Adara said with some asperity, ‘and if I have some polite old sergeant explain the workings of a catapult to me one more time, I think I’ll scream.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCD7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCD8">‘We have not, however, inspected the outer fortifications, have we?’ the princess asked slyly. ‘Wouldn’t you say that’s part of our duty too?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCD9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCDA">Adara looked at her quickly, and then a slow smile appeared on her face. ‘Absolutely,’ she agreed. ‘I’m surprised that we hadn’t thought of that before. We’ve been most neglectful, haven’t we?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCDB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCDC">Ariana’s face took on a worried frown. ‘King Rhodar, I fear, would be most strenuous in his objections to such a plan.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCDD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCDE">‘Rhodar isn’t here,’ Ce’Nedra pointed out. ‘He’s off with King Fulrach taking an inventory of the supply dumps.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCDF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCDG">‘Lady Polgara would most certainly not approve,’ Ariana suggested, though her tone indicated that she was weakening.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCDH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCDI">‘Lady Polgara is conferring with Beldin the sorcerer,’ Adara mentioned, her eyes dancing mischievously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCDJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCDK">Ce’Nedra smirked. ‘That rather leaves us to our own devices, doesn’t it, ladies?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCDL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCDM">‘We shall be soundly scolded upon our return,’ Ariana said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCDN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCDO">‘And we will all be very contrite, won’t we?’ Ce’Nedra giggled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCDP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCDQ">A quarter of an hour later, the princess and her two friends, dressed in soft black leather Algar riding clothes, passed at a canter out through the central gate of the vast fort. They were accompanied by Olban, the youngest son of the Rivan Warder. Olban had not liked the idea, but Ce’Nedra had given him no time to object and definitely no time to send a message to anyone who could step in and stop the whole excursion. Olban looked worried, but, as always, he accompanied the little Rivan Queen without question.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCDR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCDS">The stake-studded trenches in front of the walls were very interesting, but one trench looked much like another, and it took a rare mind indeed to find much pleasure in the finer points of excavation.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCDT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCDU">‘Very nice,’ Ce’Nedra said brightly to a Drasnian pikeman standing guard atop a high mound of dirt. ‘Splendid ditches – and all those excellently sharp stakes.’ She looked out at the arid landscape before the fortifications. ‘Where did you ever find all the wood for them?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCDV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCE0">‘The Sendars brought it in, your Majesty,’ he replied, ‘from someplace up north, I think. We had the Thulls cut and sharpen the stakes for us. They’re quite good stake-makers – if you tell them what you want.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCE1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCE2">‘Didn’t a mounted patrol go out this way about a half an hour ago?’ Ce’Nedra asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCE3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCE4">‘Yes, your Majesty. Lord Hettar of Algaria and some of his men. They went off that way.’ The guard pointed toward the south.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCE5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCE6">‘Ah,’ Ce’Nedra said. ‘If anyone should ask, tell them that we’re going out to join him. We should return in a few hours.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCE7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCE8">The guard looked a bit dubious about that, but Ce’Nedra moved quickly to head off any objections. ‘Lord Hettar promised to wait for us just beyond the south end of the fortifications,’ she told him. She turned to her companions. ‘We really mustn’t keep him waiting too long. You ladies took absolutely </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCE9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCEA">too</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCEB"> much time changing clothes.’ She smiled winsomely at the guard. ‘You know how it is,’ she said. ‘The riding habit must be just so, and the hair absolutely </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCEC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCED">has</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCEE"> to be brushed one last time. Sometimes it takes for ever. Come along, ladies. We must hurry, or Lord Hettar will be vexed with us.’ With a brainless little giggle, the princess wheeled Noble and rode south at a gallop.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCEF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCEG">‘Ce’Nedra,’ Ariana exclaimed in a shocked voice once they were out of earshot, ‘you </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCEH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCEI">lied</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCEJ"> to him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCEK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCEL">‘Of course.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCEM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCEN">‘But that’s dreadful.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCEO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCEP">‘Not nearly as dreadful as spending another day embroidering daisies on a stupid petticoat,’ the princess replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCEQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCER">They left the fortifications and crossed a low, burned-brown string of hills. The broad valley beyond was enormous. Dun brown and treeless mountains reared up fully twenty miles away at the valley’s far end. They cantered down into that vast emptiness, feeling dwarfed into insignificance by the colossal landscape. Their horses seemed no more than ants crawling toward the indifferent mountains.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCES"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCET">‘I hadn’t realized it was so big,’ Ce’Nedra murmured, shading her eyes to gaze at the distant hilltops.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCEU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCEV">The floor of the valley was as flat as a tabletop, and it was only sparsely sprinkled with low, thorny bushes. The ground was scattered with round, fist-sized rocks, and the dust spurted, yellow and powdery, from each step of their horses’ hoofs. Although it was scarcely midmorning, the sun was already a furnace, and shimmering heatwaves rippled the valley floor ahead, making the dusty, gray-green bushes seem to dance in the windless air.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCF0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCF1">It grew hotter. There was no trace of moisture anywhere, and the sweat dried almost instantly on the flanks of their panting horses.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCF2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCF3">‘I think we should give some thought to going back,’ Adara said, reining in her mount. ‘There’s no way we can reach those hills at the end of the valley.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCF4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCF5">‘She’s right, your Majesty,’ Olban told the princess. ‘We’ve already come too far.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCF6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCF7">Ce’Nedra pulled Noble to a stop, and the white horse drooped his head as if on the verge of absolute exhaustion. ‘Oh, quit feeling sorry for yourself,’ she chided him irritably. This was not going at all as she had expected. She looked around. ‘I wonder if we could find some shade somewhere,’ she said. Her lips were dry, and the sun seemed to hammer down on her unprotected head.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCF8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCF9">‘The terrain doth not suggest such comfort, princess,’ Ariana said, looking around at the flat emptiness of the rock-strewn valley floor.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCFA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCFB">‘Did anyone think to bring any water?’ Ce’Nedra asked, dabbing at her forehead with a kerchief.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCFC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCFD">No-one had.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCFE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCFF">‘Maybe we </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCFG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCFH">should</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCFI"> go back,’ she decided, looking about rather regretfully. ‘There’s nothing to see out here, anyway.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCFJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCFK">‘Riders coming,’ Adara said sharply, pointing toward a mounted group of men emerging from an indented gulley that lay like a fold on the flanks of a rounded hill a mile or so away.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCFL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCFM">‘Murgos?’ Olban demanded with a sharp intake of his breath. His hand went immediately to his sword.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCFN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCFO">Adara raised her hand to shade her eyes and stared at the approaching horsemen intently. ‘No,’ she replied. ‘They’re Algars. I can tell by the way they ride.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCFP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCFQ">‘I hope they have some water with them,’ Ce’Nedra said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCFR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCFS">The dozen or so Algar riders rode directly toward them with a great cloud of yellow dust rising behind them. Adara suddenly gasped, and her face went very pale.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCFT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCFU">‘What is it?’ Ce’Nedra asked her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCFV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCG0">‘Lord Hettar is with them,’ Adara said in a choked voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCG1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCG2">‘How can you possibly recognize anybody at that distance?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCG3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCG4">Adara bit her lip, but did not reply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCG5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCG6">Hettar’s face was fierce and unforgiving as he reined in his sweating horse. ‘What are you doing out here?’ he demanded bluntly. His hawk-like face and black scalp lock gave him a wild, even frightening appearance.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCG7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCG8">‘We thought we’d go riding, Lord Hettar,’ Ce’Nedra replied brightly, trying to outface him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCG9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCGA">Hettar ignored that. ‘Have you lost your mind, Olban?’ he harshly asked the young Rivan. ‘Why did you permit the ladies to leave the forts?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCGB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCGC">‘I do not tell her Majesty what to do,’ Olban answered stiffly, his face red.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCGD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCGE">‘Oh, come now, Hettar,’ Ce’Nedra protested. ‘What’s the harm in our taking a little ride?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCGF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCGG">‘We killed three Murgos not a mile from here just yesterday,’ Hettar told her. ‘If you want exercise, run around the inside of the forts for a few hours. Don’t just ride out unprotected in hostile territory. You’ve acted very foolishly, Ce’Nedra. We’ll go back now.’ His face was grim as a winter sea, and his tone left no room for discussion.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCGH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCGI">‘We had just made the same decision, my Lord,’ Adara murmured, her eyes downcast.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCGJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCGK">Hettar looked sternly at the condition of their horses. ‘You’re an Algar, Lady Adara,’ he said pointedly. ‘Didn’t it occur to you to bring water for your mounts? Surely you know better than to take a horse out in this kind of heat without any precautions at all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCGL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCGM">Adara’s pale face grew stricken.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCGN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCGO">Hettar shook his head in disgust. ‘Water their horses,’ he curtly told one of his men, ‘and then we’ll escort them back. Your excursion is over, ladies.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCGP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCGQ">Adara’s face was flaming with a look of almost unbearable shame. She twisted this way and that in her saddle, trying to avoid Hettar’s stern, unforgiving stare. No sooner had her horse been watered than she jerked her reins and dug her heels into his flanks. Her startled mount scrambled his hoofs in the gravel and leaped away, running back the way they had come across the rock-littered valley floor.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCGR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCGS">Hettar swore and drove his mount after her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCGT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCGU">‘Whatever is she doing?’ Ce’Nedra exclaimed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCGV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCH0">‘Lord Hettar’s rebuke hath stung our gentle companion beyond her endurance,’ Ariana observed. ‘His good opinion is dearer to her than her life itself.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCH1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCH2">‘Hettar?’ Ce’Nedra was stunned.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCH3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCH4">‘Hath not thine eye informed thee how it doth stand with our dear friend?’ Ariana asked in mild surprise. ‘Thou art strangely unobservant, Princess.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCH5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCH6">‘Hettar?’ Ce’Nedra repeated. ‘I had no idea.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCH7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCH8">‘Mayhap it is because I am Mimbrate,’ Ariana concluded. ‘The ladies of my people are most sensitive to the signs of gentle affection in others.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCH9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCHA">It took perhaps a hundred yards for Hettar to overtake Adara’s plunging horse. He seized her reins in one fist and jerked her roughly to a stop, speaking sharply to her, demanding to know what she was doing. Adara twisted this way and that in her saddle, trying to keep him from seeing her face as he continued to chide her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCHB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCHC">Then a flicker of movement no more than twenty feet from the two of them caught Ce’Nedra’s eye. Astonishingly, a mail-shirted Murgo rose up out of the sand between two scrubby bushes, shaking off the sheet of brown-splotched canvas beneath which he had lain concealed. As he rose, his short bow was already drawn.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCHD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCHE">‘Hettar!’ Ce’Nedra screamed as the Murgo raised his bow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCHF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCHG">Hettar’s back was to the Murgo, but Adara saw the man aiming his arrow at the Algar’s unprotected back. With a desperate move, she ripped her reins from Hettar’s grip and drove her horse into his. His mount lurched back, stumbled and fell, throwing the unprepared man to the ground even as Adara, flailing her horse’s flanks with the ends of her reins, plunged directly at the Murgo.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCHH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCHI">With only the faintest flicker of annoyance, the Murgo released his arrow at the charging girl.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCHJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCHK">Even at that distance, Ce’Nedra could hear the distinct sound the arrow made when it struck Adara. It was a sound she would remember with horror for the remainder of her life. Adara doubled sharply, her free hand clutching at the arrow buried low in her chest, but her plunging gallop did not falter nor change as she rode the Murgo down. He tumbled and rolled beneath the churning hoofs of her horse, then lurched again to his feet as soon as she had passed over him, his hand jerking at his sheathed sword. But Hettar was already upon him, sabre flashing in the glaring sunlight. The Murgo screamed once as he fell.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCHL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCHM">Hettar, his dripping sabre still in his hand, turned angrily to Adara. ‘What a stupid thing,’ he roared at her, but his shout cut off suddenly. Her horse had come to a stop a few yards beyond the Murgo, and she drooped in her saddle, her dark hair falling like a veil across her pale face and both of her hands pressed to her chest. Then, slowly, she toppled from her saddle.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCHN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCHO">With a strangled cry, Hettar dropped his sabre and ran to her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCHP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCHQ">‘Adara!’ the princess wailed, her hands going to her face in horror even as Hettar gently turned the stricken girl over. The arrow, still standing out of her lower chest, throbbed with the rhythm of her faltering heart-beat.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCHR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCHS">When the rest of them reached the pair, Hettar was holding Adara in his arms, staring into her pale face with a stricken look. ‘You little fool,’ he was murmuring in a broken voice. ‘You little fool.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCHT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCHU">Ariana slid from her saddle even before her horse stopped moving and ran to Hettar’s side. ‘Do not move her, my Lord,’ she told him sharply. ‘The arrow hath pierced her lung, and shouldst thou move her, it’s keen edge will gash out her life.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCHV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCI0">‘Take it out,’ Hettar said from between clenched teeth.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCI1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCI2">‘Nay, my Lord. To pull the arrow now will do more damage than to leave it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCI3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCI4">‘I can’t bear to see it sticking out of her like that,’ he almost sobbed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCI5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCI6">‘Then don’t look, my Lord,’ Ariana said bluntly, kneeling beside Adara and placing a cool, professional hand on the wounded girl’s throat.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCI7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCI8">‘She’s not dead, is she?’ Hettar almost begged.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCI9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIA">Ariana shook her head. ‘Gravely wounded, but her life doth still pulse within her. Instruct thy men to improvise a litter at once, my Lord. We must convey our dear friend to the fortress and Lady Polgara’s ministrations immediately, lest her life drain away.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCIB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIC">‘Can’t </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCID"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIE">you</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIF"> do something?’ he croaked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCIG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIH">‘Not here in this sun-blasted desolation, my Lord. I have neither instruments nor medications, and the wound may be past my skill. The Lady Polgara is her only hope. The litter, my Lord. Quickly!’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="KVCII"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIJ">Polgara’s face was somber, and her eyes as hard as flint when she emerged from Adara’s sickroom late that afternoon.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCIK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIL">‘How is she?’ Hettar demanded. He had been pacing up and down in the main corridor of the blockhouse for hours, stopping every so often to strike savagely at the crudely built stone walls with his impotent fists.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCIM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIN">‘Somewhat improved,’ Polgara replied. ‘The crisis is past, but she’s still terribly weak. She’s asking for you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCIO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIP">‘She </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCIQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIR">will</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIS"> recover, won’t she?’ Hettar’s question had a note of fear in it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCIT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCIU">‘Probably – if there aren’t any complications. She’s young, and the wound looked more serious than it actually was. I gave her something that will make her very talkative, but don’t stay too long. She needs rest.’ Polgara’s eyes moved to Ce’Nedra’s tear-streaked face. ‘Come to my room after you’ve seen her, your Majesty,’ she said firmly. ‘You and I have something to discuss.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCIV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJ0">Adara’s porcelain face was framed by the tumbled mass of her dark brown hair spreading across the pillow. She was very pale, but, though her eyes had a slightly unfocused look about them, they were very bright. Ariana sat quietly at the bedside.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJ1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJ2">‘How do you feel, Adara?’ Ce’Nedra asked in the quiet but cheerful voice one always assumes with the sick.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJ3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJ4">Adara gave her a wan little smile.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJ5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJ6">‘Are you in any pain?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJ7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJ8">‘No,’ Adara’s voice had a little dying fall to it. ‘No pain, but I feel very light-headed and strange.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJ9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJA">‘Why did you do that, Adara?’ Hettar asked very directly. ‘You didn’t have to ride right at the Murgo like that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJC">‘You spend too much time with horses, my Lord Sha-dar,’ Adara told him with a faint smile. ‘You’ve forgotten how to understand the feelings of your own kind.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJE">‘What’s that supposed to mean?’ He sounded puzzled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJG">‘Exactly what it says, my Lord Hettar. If a mare looked admiringly at a stallion, you’d know how things stood immediately, wouldn’t you? But when it comes to people, you simply can’t see at all, can you?’ She coughed weakly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJI">‘Are you all right?’ he asked sharply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJK">‘I’m surprisingly well – considering the fact that I’m dying.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJM">‘What are you talking about? You’re not dying.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJO">She smiled slightly. ‘Please don’t,’ she told him. ‘I know what an arrow in the chest means. That’s why I wanted to see you. I wanted to look at your face once more. I’ve been watching your face for such a long time now.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJQ">‘You’re tired,’ he said brusquely. ‘You’ll feel better after you’ve slept.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJS">‘I’ll sleep, all right,’ she said ruefully, ‘but I doubt that I’ll feel anything afterward. The sleep I’m going to is the sleep one doesn’t wake up from.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCJU">‘Nonsense.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCJV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCK0">‘Of course it is, but it’s true nonetheless.’ She sighed. ‘Well, dear Hettar, you’ve finally escaped me, haven’t you? I gave you a good chase, though. I even asked Garion to see if he could use sorcery on you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCK1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCK2">‘Garion?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCK3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCK4">She nodded slightly. ‘You see how desperate I was? He said he couldn’t, though.’ She made a little face. ‘What good is sorcery if you can’t use it to make someone fall in love?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCK5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCK6">‘Love?’ he repeated in a startled voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCK7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCK8">‘What did you think we were talking about, Lord Hettar? The weather?’ She smiled fondly at him. ‘Sometimes you can be impossibly dense.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCK9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCKA">He stared at her in amazement.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCKB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCKC">‘Don’t be alarmed, my Lord. In a little while, I’ll stop chasing you, and you’ll be free.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCKD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCKE">‘We’ll talk about that when you’re better,’ he told her gravely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCKF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCKG">‘I’m not going to get better. Haven’t you been listening? I’m dying, Hettar.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCKH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCKI">‘No,’ he said, ‘as a matter of fact, you’re not dying. Polgara assured us that you’re going to be all right.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCKJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCKK">Adara looked quickly at Ariana.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCKL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCKM">‘Thine injury is not mortal, dear friend,’ Ariana confirmed gently. ‘Truly, thou art not dying.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCKN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCKO">Adara closed her eyes. ‘How inconvenient,’ she murmured, a faint blush coming to her cheeks. She opened her eyes again. ‘I apologize, Hettar. I wouldn’t have said any of this if I’d known that my meddling physicians were going to save my life. As soon as I’m up and about, I’ll return to my own clan. I won’t bother you again with my foolish outbursts.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCKP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCKQ">Hettar looked down at her, his hard-angled face expressionless. ‘I don’t think I’d like that,’ he told her, gently taking her hand. ‘There are things you and I need to talk about. This isn’t the time or the place, but don’t go trying to make yourself inaccessible.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCKR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCKS">‘You’re just being kind.’ She sighed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCKT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCKU">‘No. Practical. You’ve given me something to think about beside killing Murgos. It’s probably going to take me a while to get used to the idea, but after I’ve thought it over, we’ll definitely need to talk.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCKV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCL0">She bit her lip and tried to hide her face. ‘What a stupid mess I’ve made of things,’ she said. ‘If I were somebody else, I’d laugh at me. It would really be better if we didn’t see each other again.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCL1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCL2">‘No,’ he said firmly, still holding her hand, ‘it wouldn’t. And don’t try to hide from me, because I’ll find you – even if I have to have every horse in Algaria go looking for you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCL3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCL4">She gave him a startled look.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCL5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCL6">‘I </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCL7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCL8">am</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCL9"> a Sha-dar, remember? Horses do what I tell them to.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCLA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCLB">‘That’s not fair,’ she objected.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCLC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCLD">He gave her a quizzical little smile. ‘And trying to have Garion use sorcery on me </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCLE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCLF">was</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCLG">?’ he asked her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCLH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCLI">‘Oh, dear!’ She blushed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCLJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCLK">‘She must rest now,’ Ariana told them. ‘Thou canst speak with her further on the morrow.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCLL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCLM">When they were back out in the hallway, Ce’Nedra turned on the tall man. ‘You might have said something a bit more encouraging,’ she scolded him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCLN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCLO">‘It would have been premature,’ he replied. ‘We’re a rather reserved people, Princess. We don’t say things just to be talking. Adara understands the situation.’ Hettar seemed as fierce as ever, his sharp-angled face hard, and his manelike scalp lock flowing over one leather-armored shoulder. His eyes, however, had softened slightly, and there was a faintly puzzled crease between his brows. ‘Didn’t Polgara want to see you?’ he asked. It was polite, but it was a dismissal nonetheless.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCLP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCLQ">Ce’Nedra stalked away, muttering to herself about the lack of consideration that seemed to infect the male half of the population.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCLR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCLS">Lady Polgara sat quietly in her room, waiting. ‘Well?’ she said when the princess entered. ‘Would you care to explain?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCLT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCLU">‘Explain what?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCLV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCM0">‘The reason for the idiocy that almost cost Adara her life.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCM1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCM2">‘Surely you don’t think it was </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCM3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCM4">my</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCM5"> fault,’ Ce’Nedra protested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCM6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCM7">‘Whose fault was it, then? What were you doing out there?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCM8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCM9">‘We just went for a little ride. It’s so boring being cooped up all the time.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCMA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCMB">‘Boring. What a fascinating reason to kill your friends.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCMC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCMD">Ce’Nedra gaped at her, her face suddenly very pale.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCME"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCMF">‘Why do you think we built these fortifications to begin with, Ce’Nedra? It was to provide us with some measure of protection.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCMG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCMH">‘I didn’t know there were Murgos out there,’ the princess wailed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCMI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCMJ">‘Did you bother to find out?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCMK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCML">The entire implication of what she had done quite suddenly came crashing in on Ce’Nedra. She began to tremble violently, and her shaking hand went to her mouth. It </span><span class="italic" aid="KVCMM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCMN">was</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCMO"> her fault! No matter how she might twist and turn and try to evade the responsibility, her foolishness had nearly killed one of her dearest friends. Adara had almost paid with her life for a bit of childish thoughtlessness. Ce’Nedra buried her face in her hands in a sudden storm of weeping.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCMP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCMQ">Polgara let her cry for several moments, giving her ample time to accept her guilt; and when she finally spoke, there was no hint of forgiveness in her voice. ‘Tears won’t wash out blood, Ce’Nedra,’ she said. ‘I thought I could at least begin to trust your judgment, but it appears that I was wrong. You may leave now. I don’t believe I have anything more to say to you this evening.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="KVCMR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="KVCMS">Sobbing, the princess fled.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_22" aid="KVCMT"></div>

    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
