</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos545653" aid="LTSU1"><span class="calibre5" aid="LTSU2"><span class="italic" aid="LTSU3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSU4">Chapter Fourteen</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="LTSU5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSU6">‘Is this place all like this?’ King Anheg asked as the army trudged through one of the flat, gravel-strewn valleys with the bare, sun-baked mountains around it dancing in the shimmering heat. ‘I haven’t seen a tree since we left the forts.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSU7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSU8">‘The country changes about twenty leagues out, your Majesty,’ Hettar replied quietly, lounging in his saddle as they rode in the blazing sunlight. ‘We start to hit trees when we begin coming down out of the uplands. They’re a kind of low, scraggly spruce, but they break up the monotony a bit.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSU9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUA">The column behind them stretched out for miles, dwarfed into a thin line by the enormous emptiness and marked more by the cloud of yellow dust raised by thousands of feet than by the presence of men and horses. The Cherek ships, covered with canvas, jolted along over the rocky ground on their low, wheeled cradles, and the dust hung over them in the stifling heat like a gritty blanket.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSUB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUC">‘I’d pay a lot for a breeze right now,’ Anheg said wistfully, wiping his face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSUD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUE">‘Just leave things the way they are, Anheg,’ Barak advised him. ‘It wouldn’t take much to start a dust storm.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSUF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUG">‘How much farther is it to the river?’ King Rhodar asked plaintively, looking at the unchanging landscape. The heat was having a brutal effect on the corpulent monarch. His face was beet red, and he was soaked and dripping with sweat.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSUH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUI">‘Still about forty leagues,’ Hettar replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSUJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUK">General Varana, mounted on a roan stallion, cantered back from the vanguard of the column. The general wore a short leather kilt and a plain breastplate and helmet bearing no marks of his rank. ‘The Mimbrate knights just flushed out another pocket of Murgos,’ he reported.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSUL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUM">‘How many?’ King Rhodar asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSUN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUO">‘Twenty or so. Three or four got away, but the Algars are chasing them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSUP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUQ">‘Shouldn’t our patrols be farther out?’ King Anheg fretted, mopping his face again. ‘Those ships don’t look </span><span class="italic" aid="LTSUR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUS">that</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUT"> much like wagons. I’d rather not have to fight my way down the River Mardu – if we ever get there.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSUU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSUV">‘I’ve got people moving around out there, Anheg,’ King Cho-Hag assured him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSV0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSV1">‘Has anyone run across any Malloreans yet?’ Anheg asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSV2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSV3">‘Not so far,’ Cho-Hag replied. ‘All we’ve seen so far are Thulls and Murgos.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSV4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSV5">‘It looks as if ‘Zakath is holding firm at Thull Zelik,’ Varana added.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSV6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSV7">‘I wish I knew more about him,’ Rhodar said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSV8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSV9">‘The Emperor’s emissaries report that he’s a very civilized man,’ Varana said. ‘Cultured, urbane, very polite.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSVA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSVB">‘I’m sure there’s another side to him,’ Rhodar disagreed. ‘The Nadraks are terrified of him, and it takes a lot to frighten a Nadrak.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSVC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSVD">‘As long as he stays at Thull Zelik, I don’t care what kind of man he is,’ Anheg declared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSVE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSVF">Colonel Brendig rode forward from the toiling column of infantry and wagons stretched out behind them. ‘King Fulrach asks that we halt the column for a rest period,’ he reported.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSVG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSVH">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="LTSVI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSVJ">Again?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSVK">’ Anheg demanded irritably.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSVL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSVM">‘We’ve marched for two hours, your Majesty,’ Brendig pointed out. ‘Marching in all this heat and dust is very exhausting for infantry. The men won’t be much good in a fight if they’re all wrung out from walking.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSVN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSVO">‘Halt the column, Colonel,’ Polgara told the Sendarian baronet. ‘We can rely on Fulrach’s judgment in these matters.’ She turned to the King of Cherek. ‘Stop being so peevish, Anheg,’ she chided him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSVP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSVQ">‘I’m being broiled alive, Polgara,’ he complained.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSVR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSVS">‘Try walking for a few miles,’ she told him sweetly. ‘That may give you some insight into how the infantry feels.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSVT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTSVU">Anheg scowled, but remained silent.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTSVV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT00">Princess Ce’Nedra pulled in her sweating mount as the column halted. The princess had spoken very little since Adara had been wounded. The dreadful sense of her responsibility for her friend’s nearly fatal injury had sobered her enormously, and she had retreated into a kind of shell that was totally unnatural for her. She removed the loose-woven straw hat that a captive Thull had made for her back at the fort and squinted at the blistering sky.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT01"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT02">‘Put the hat back on, Ce’Nedra,’ Lady Polgara told her. ‘I don’t want you getting sunstroke.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT03"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT04">Ce’Nedra obediently put her hat back on. ‘He’s coming back,’ she reported, pointing at a speck in the sky high above them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT05"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT06">‘Will you excuse me?’ General Varana said, turning his horse to leave.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT07"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT08">‘You’re being absurd, Varana,’ King Rhodar told the Tolnedran. ‘Why do you insist on refusing to admit he can do things you don’t want to believe in?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT09"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0A">‘It’s a matter of principle, your Majesty,’ the general replied. ‘Tolnedrans do not believe in sorcery. I am a Tolnedran, therefore I do not admit that it exists.’ He hesitated. ‘I must concede, however, that his information is surprisingly accurate – however he gets it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT0B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0C">A large, blue-banded hawk fell suddenly out of the broiling air like a stone, flared his wings at the last moment, and settled on the ground directly in front of them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT0D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0E">General Varana resolutely turned his back and stared with apparently deep interest at a featureless hill some five miles distant.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT0F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0G">The hawk began to shimmer and change even as he folded his wings. ‘Are you stopping </span><span class="italic" aid="LTT0H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0I">again</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0J">?’ Beldin demanded irascibly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT0K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0L">‘We have to rest the troops, Uncle,’ Polgara replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT0M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0N">‘This isn’t a Sunday stroll, Pol,’ Beldin retorted. He began to scratch one armpit, befouling the air around him with a string of rancid curses.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT0O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0P">‘What’s the matter?’ Polgara asked mildly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT0Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0R">‘Lice,’ he grunted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT0S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0T">‘How did you get lice?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT0U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT0V">‘I visited some other birds to ask if they’d seen anything. I think I picked them up in a vulture’s nest.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT10"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT11">‘What could possibly possess you to go consorting with vultures?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT12"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT13">‘Vultures aren’t that bad, Pol. They perform a necessary function, and the chicks do have a certain charm. The she-vulture had been picking at a dead horse about twenty leagues south of here. After she told me about it, I went down to take a look. There’s a Murgo column coming this way.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT14"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT15">‘How many?’ General Varana asked quickly, his back still turned to them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT16"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT17">‘A thousand or so,’ Beldin shrugged. ‘They’re pushing hard. They’ll probably intercept you tomorrow morning.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT18"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT19">‘A thousand Murgos aren’t that much to worry about,’ King Rhodar said, frowning. ‘Not to an army of this size. But what’s the point of throwing a thousand men away? What does Taur Urgas hope to accomplish?’ He turned to Hettar. ‘Do you suppose you could ride ahead and ask Korodullin and the Baron of Vo Mandor to join us. I think we ought to have a conference.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT1A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT1B">Hettar nodded and loped his horse ahead toward the gleaming ranks of the Mimbrate knights at the head of the column.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT1C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT1D">‘Were there any Grolims with the Murgos, Uncle?’ Polgara asked the filthy hunchback.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT1E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT1F">‘Not unless they were well-hidden,’ he replied. ‘I didn’t probe too much, though. I didn’t want to give myself away.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT1G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT1H">General Varana abruptly abandoned his careful study of the hills around them and turned his horse about to join them. ‘My first guess would be that the Murgo column is a token gesture from Taur Urgas. He probably wants to get on the good side of King Gethell; and since the Malloreans won’t leave Thull Zelik, he can pick up some advantage by committing a few troops to aid in the defense of the Thullish towns and villages we’ve been destroying.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT1I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT1J">‘That makes sense, Rhodar,’ Anheg agreed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT1K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT1L">‘Maybe,’ Rhodar said dubiously. ‘Taur Urgas doesn’t think like a rational man, though.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT1M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT1N">King Korodullin, flanked by Mandorallen and the Baron of Vo Ebor, thundered back to join them. Their armor flashed in the sun, and all three were flushed and miserable-looking in their steel casings.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT1O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT1P">‘How can you stand all that?’ Rhodar asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT1Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT1R">‘Custom, your Majesty,’ Korodullin replied. ‘The armor doth inflict some discomfort, but we have learned to endure it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT1S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT1T">General Varana quickly sketched in the situation for them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT1U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT1V">Mandorallen shrugged. ‘It is of no moment. I will take some few dozen men and smash this threat from the south.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT20"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT21">Barak looked at King Anheg. ‘You see what I mean about him?’ he said. ‘Now you can understand why I was so nervous all the time we were chasing across Cthol Murgos.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT22"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT23">King Fulrach had ridden forward to join the conference, and he cleared his throat diffidently. ‘Might I make a suggestion?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT24"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT25">‘We eagerly await the practical wisdom of the King of the Sendars,’ Korodullin replied with extravagant courtesy.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT26"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT27">‘The Murgo column doesn’t really pose much of a threat, does it?’ Fulrach inquired.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT28"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT29">‘Not really, your Majesty,’ Varana replied. ‘At least, now that we know that they’re out there. We think that they’re some kind of minor relief column sent to placate the Thulls. Their presence in our vicinity is probably entirely accidental.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT2A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT2B">‘I don’t want them getting close enough to recognize my ships, though,’ Anheg declared firmly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT2C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT2D">‘We’ll take care of that, Anheg,’ Rhodar told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT2E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT2F">‘Any one of the elements of our army might easily overcome so slight a threat,’ Fulrach continued, ‘but mightn’t it be better – from a morale standpoint – to give the victory to the entire army?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT2G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT2H">‘I don’t quite follow you, Fulrach,’ Anheg said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT2I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT2J">‘Instead of letting Sir Mandorallen annihilate these thousand Murgos all by himself, why not select a contingent from each part of the army to deal with them? Not only will that give us some experience in tactical coordination, but it’ll give all the men a sense of pride. An easy victory now will stiffen their backs when we run into more difficult times later.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT2K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT2L">‘Fulrach, sometimes you positively amaze me,’ Rhodar declared. ‘I think the whole trouble is that you don’t </span><span class="italic" aid="LTT2M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT2N">look</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT2O"> that clever.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT2P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT2Q">The contingents that were to turn south to meet the approaching Murgos were selected by lot, once again at the suggestion of King Fulrach. ‘That way there’ll be no suspicion in the army that this is some kind of elite force,’ he noted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT2R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT2S">While the rest of the column pushed on toward the headwaters of the River Mardu, the miniature army under the command of Barak, Hettar, and Mandorallen veered to the south to intercept the enemy spearhead.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT2T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT2U">‘They’ll be all right, won’t they?’ Ce’Nedra nervously asked Polgara as she watched them growing smaller and smaller as they rode off across the arid valley toward the solid line of mountains to the south.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT2V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT30">‘I’m certain they will, dear,’ Polgara replied confidently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT31"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT32">The princess, however, did not sleep that night. For the first time, members of her army were committed to a real battle, and she tossed and turned the entire night, imagining all manner of disasters.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT33"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT34">About midmorning of the following day, however, the special force returned. There were a few bandages here and there and perhaps a dozen empty saddles, but the look of victory shone on every face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT35"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT36">‘Very nice little fight,’ Barak reported. The huge man was grinning broadly. ‘We caught them just before sundown. They never knew what hit them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT37"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT38">General Varana, who had accompanied the force to observe, was a bit more precise as he described the engagement to the assembled kings. ‘The general tactics did work pretty much as we’d planned,’ he said. ‘The Asturian archers swept the column with an arrow storm to begin with, and then the infantry units moved into position at the top of a long slope. We interspersed legionnaires, Drasnian pikemen, Sendars and the Arendish serf units evenly along the entire front with the archers behind them to continue harassing the enemy with arrows. As we expected, the Murgos charged. As soon as they’d committed themselves, the Chereks and Rivans moved into position behind them, and the Algars began slashing their flanks. When the Murgo assault began to falter, the Mimbrate knights made their charge.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT39"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3A">‘It was absolutely splendid!’ Lelldorin exclaimed, his eyes very bright. There was a bandage around the young Asturian’s upper arm, but he seemed to have forgotten that it was there as he gesticulated wildly. ‘Just at the point when the Murgos were completely confused, there was a sound like thunder, and the knights came curving around the side of a hill with their lances advanced and their pennons streaming. They bore down on the Murgos – a wave of solid steel – and the hoofs of their horses shook the earth. And then at the last moment, they all lowered their lances. It was like watching a wave break. And then they hit the Murgos with a great crash, and they didn’t even slow down. They rode through them as if they weren’t even there! They absolutely crushed them, and then we all ran in to finish up. It was glorious!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT3B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3C">‘He’s as bad as Mandorallen, isn’t he?’ Barak observed to Hettar.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT3D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3E">‘I think it’s in their blood,’ Hettar replied sagely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT3F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3G">‘Did any of them get away?’ Anheg asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT3H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3I">Barak gave his cousin an evil grin. ‘After it got dark, we could hear a few of them trying to crawl away. That’s when Relg and his Ulgos went out to tidy up. Don’t worry, Anheg. Nobody’s going to report back to Taur Urgas.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT3J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3K">‘He </span><span class="italic" aid="LTT3L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3M">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3N"> likely to be waiting for news, isn’t he?’ Anheg grinned.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT3O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3P">‘I hope he’s patient, then,’ Barak replied, ‘because he’ll be waiting for a long time.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT3Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3R">Ariana, her face somber, took Lelldorin to task very firmly for his lack of discretion, even as she tended his wound. Her words far surpassed a simple scolding. She grew eloquent, and her lengthy, involuted sentences gave her remonstrance a depth and scope that reduced her young man very nearly to tears. His wound, admittedly minor, became a symbol of his careless lack of regard for her. Her expression grew martyred, and his grew anguished. Ce’Nedra observed how neatly Ariana twisted each of the young man’s lame excuses into an even greater personal injury, and filed this excellent technique away in a compartment of her complex little mind for future use. True, Garion was somewhat brighter than Lelldorin, but the tactic would probably work on him too, if she practiced a little.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT3S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3T">Taiba’s meeting with Relg, on the other hand, involved no words. The beautiful Marag woman who had emerged from the slave pens beneath Rak Cthol only to enter a slavery even more profound, flew to the Ulgo fanatic’s side upon his return. With a low cry, she unthinkingly embraced him. Relg flinched away from her, but the almost automatic, ‘Don’t touch me,’ seemed to die on his lips, and his eyes went very wide as she clung to him. Then Taiba remembered his aversion and helplessly let her arms drop, but her violet eyes glowed as they drank in his pale, large-eyed face. Then slowly, almost as if he were putting his arm into a fire, Relg reached out and took her hand. A brief look of incredulity crossed her face, followed almost immediately by a slow blush. They looked into each other’s eyes for a moment, then walked off together, hand in hand. Taiba’s eyes were demurely downcast, but there hovered about her rich, sensual mouth a tiny little smile of triumph.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT3U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT3V">The victory over the Murgo column raised the spirits of the army tremendously. The heat and dust no longer seemed to sap their energy as it had during the first few days of the march, and a growing sense of camaraderie grew between the diversified units as they pushed steadily eastward.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT40"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT41">It took them four more days of steady marching to reach the headwaters of the River Mardu and another day to push on down along the tumbling flow to a spot where the ships could safely be launched. Hettar and his Algar patrols ranged far ahead and reported that there remained only one more stretch of rapids about ten leagues ahead before the river settled into tranquility on the Thullish plain.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT42"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT43">‘We can portage around the rapids,’ King Anheg declared. ‘Let’s get these ships into the water. We’ve lost enough time already.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT44"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT45">There was a rather high earthbank at that point, but the army attacked it vigorously with shovels and mattocks, and it was soon reduced to a sloping ramp. One by one the ships were rolled down the ramp into the water.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT46"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT47">‘We’ll need a while to raise the masts,’ Anheg said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT48"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT49">‘Leave that until later,’ Rhodar told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT4A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT4B">Anheg looked at him sharply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT4C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT4D">‘You’re not going to be able to use your sails anyway, Anheg, and the masts stick up too high. The stupidest Thull in the world will know what’s going on if he sees a forest of ship masts coming down the river toward him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT4E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT4F">It was evening by the time the ships had all been launched and Polgara led the princess, Ariana and Taiba on board Barak’s ship. A breeze coming upriver gently rippled the surface of the water and set the ship to rocking slowly. Beyond the watchfires, the Thullish grassland stretched as if for ever beneath a purpling sky where, one by one, the stars were emerging.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT4G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT4H">‘How far is it to Thull Mardu?’ Ce’Nedra asked Barak.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT4I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT4J">The big man pulled at his beard, squinting downriver. ‘One day to the rapids,’ he replied, ‘then one day to make the portage around them. Then about two days after that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT4K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT4L">‘Four days,’ she said in a small voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT4M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT4N">He nodded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT4O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT4P">‘I wish it was over,’ she sighed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="LTT4Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="LTT4R">‘All in good time, Ce’Nedra,’ he told her. ‘All in good time.’</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_23" aid="LTT4S"></div>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>

<link href="kindle:flow:0002?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>

</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos571082" aid="MSDG1"><span class="calibre5" aid="MSDG2"><span class="italic" aid="MSDG3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDG4">Chapter Fifteen</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="MSDG5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDG6">The ships were horribly crowded, even though scarcely half the army could squeeze aboard them. The Algar clansmen and the Mimbrate knights patrolled the banks as the Chereks rowed downriver toward the rapids, and those infantry elements that could not be carried by the ships rode in close files on the spare horses of the cavalry.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDG7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDG8">The Thullish grasslands on either side of the river were gently rolling, long hillsides covered with deep, sun-browned grass. Just back from the river there were sparse clusters of the twisted, sprucelike trees that had dotted the lower foothills, and near the water itself rose thickets of willow and creeping brambles. The sky remained clear, and it was still hot, though the river added enough moisture to the air to alleviate the parched aridity that had plagued men and horses alike in the vast, stony uplands. It was an alien landscape for all of them, and the cavalry patrolling the banks rode warily with their hands close to their weapons.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDG9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGA">And then they rounded a wide bend and saw the white, tumbling water of the rapids ahead. Barak swung the tiller of his big ship over and beached her. ‘Looks like it’s time to get out and walk,’ he grunted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDGB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGC">A dispute had arisen near the bow of the ship. The brown-bearded King Fulrach was loudly protesting the decision to leave his supply wagons behind at the rapids. ‘I didn’t bring them all this way just to leave them sitting here,’ he declared with uncharacteristic heat.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDGD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGE">‘They take too long to get anyplace,’ Anheg told him. ‘We’re in a hurry, Fulrach. I’ve got to get my ships past Thull Mardu before the Murgos or the Malloreans wake up to what we’re doing.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDGF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGG">‘You didn’t object to having them along when you got hungry or thirsty in the uplands,’ Fulrach told him angrily.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDGH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGI">‘That was then. This is now. I’ve got to take care of my ships.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDGJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGK">‘And </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDGL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGM">I’m</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGN"> going to take care of my wagons.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDGO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGP">‘They’ll be all right, Fulrach,’ Rhodar said placatingly. ‘We </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDGQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGR">do</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGS"> have to hurry, and your wagons can’t move fast enough to keep up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDGT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDGU">‘If somebody comes along and burns them, you’re going to get very hungry before we get back to the forts, Rhodar.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDGV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDH0">‘We’ll leave men to guard them, Fulrach. Be reasonable. You worry too much.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDH1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDH2">‘Somebody’s got to. You Alorns seem to forget that the fighting’s only half of it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDH3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDH4">‘Stop acting like an old woman, Fulrach,’ Anheg said bluntly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDH5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDH6">Fulrach’s face grew very cold. ‘I don’t know that I care for that last remark, Anheg,’ he said stiffly. Then he turned on his heel and stalked away.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDH7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDH8">‘What’s got into him?’ the King of Cherek asked innocently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDH9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHA">‘Anheg, if you don’t learn how to keep your mouth shut, we might have to muzzle you,’ Rhodar told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDHB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHC">‘I thought we came here to fight Angaraks,’ Brand said mildly. ‘Have the rules been changed?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDHD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHE">The irritable bickering among her friends worried Ce’Nedra, and she went to Polgara with her concern.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDHF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHG">‘It’s nothing all that important, dear,’ the lady replied as she scrubbed Errand’s neck. ‘The upcoming battle’s got them a bit edgy, that’s all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDHH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHI">‘But they’re men,’ Ce’Nedra protested, ‘trained warriors.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDHJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHK">‘What does that have to do with it?’ Polgara asked, reaching for a towel.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDHL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHM">The princess couldn’t think of an answer.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDHN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHO">The portage at the rapids went smoothly, and the ships reentered the river below the tumbling stretch of seething whitewater by late afternoon. Ce’Nedra by now was virtually ill as a result of the almost unbearable tension. All the months she had spent in raising the army and marching eastward were about to come to a final culmination. Within two days, they would hurl themselves at the walls of Thull Mardu. Was it the right time? Was it, in fact, really necessary? Couldn’t they just portage around the city and avoid the battle entirely? Although the Alorn kings had assured her that the city </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDHP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHQ">had</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHR"> to be neutralized, Ce’Nedra’s doubts grew with each mile. What if this was a mistake? The princess worried and fretted and worried some more as she stood at the prow of Barak’s ship, staring at the broad river winding through the Thullish grasslands.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDHS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHT">Finally, just at evening of the second day after the portage, Hettar galloped back and reined in his horse on the north bank of the river. He motioned with his arm, and Barak swung his tiller over, angling the big ship in closer to the bank.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDHU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDHV">‘The city’s about two leagues ahead,’ the tall Algar called across the intervening space. ‘If you get too much closer, they’ll see you from the walls.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDI0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDI1">‘This is close enough, then,’ Rhodar decided. ‘Pass the word to anchor the ships. We’ll wait here until dark.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDI2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDI3">Barak nodded and made a quick gesture to a waiting sailor. The man quickly raised a tall pole with a bit of bright red bunting nailed to its tip, and the fleet behind them slowed in answer to the signal. There was a creaking of windlasses as the anchors settled to the bottom, and the ships rocked and swung sluggishly in the current.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDI4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDI5">‘I still don’t like this part,’ Anheg growled morosely. ‘Too many things can go wrong in the dark.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDI6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDI7">‘They’ll go wrong for them, too,’ Brand told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDI8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDI9">‘We’ve been over it a dozen times, Anheg,’ Rhodar said. ‘We all agreed that it’s the best plan.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDIA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDIB">‘It’s never been done before,’ Anheg said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDIC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDID">‘That’s the whole point, isn’t it?’ Varana suggested. ‘The people inside the city won’t expect it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDIE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDIF">‘Are you </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDIG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDIH">sure</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDII"> your men will be able to see where they’re going?’ Anheg demanded of Relg.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDIJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDIK">The zealot nodded. He was wearing his cowled leaf-mail shirt and was carefully testing the edge of his hook-pointed knife. ‘What you think of as darkness is normal light for us,’ he replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDIL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDIM">Anheg scowled at the purpling sky overhead. ‘I </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDIN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDIO">hate</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDIP"> being the first one to try something new,’ he announced.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDIQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDIR">They waited as evening settled on the plain. From the thickets at the river’s edge, birds clucked sleepily, and the frogs began their evening symphony. Slowly out of the gathering darkness, the cavalry units began to group up along the banks. The Mimbrate knights on their great chargers massed into ranks, and the Algar clansmen spread like a dark sea beyond them. Commanding the south bank were Cho-Hag and Korodullin. The north was led by Hettar and Mandorallen.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDIS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDIT">Slowly it grew darker.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDIU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDIV">A young Mimbrate knight who had been injured during the attack on the Murgo column stood leaning against the rail, looking pensively out into the twilight. The knight had dark, curly hair and the snowy complexion of a young girl. His shoulders were broad, his neck columnar, and his eyes had an open innocence in them. His expression, however, was faintly melancholy.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJ0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJ1">The waiting had become unbearable, and Ce’Nedra </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDJ2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJ3">had</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJ4"> to talk to someone. She leaned on the rail beside the young man. ‘Why so sad, Sir Knight?’ she asked him quietly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJ5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJ6">‘Because I am forbidden to take part in this night’s adventure by reason of this slight injury, your Majesty,’ he replied, touching his splinted arm. He seemed unsurprised by her presence or by the fact that she had spoken to him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJ7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJ8">‘Do you hate the Angaraks so much that missing the chance to kill them causes you pain?’ Ce’Nedra’s question was gently mocking.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJ9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJA">‘Nay, my Lady,’ he answered. ‘I have no malice in me for any man, whatever his race. What I lament is being denied the chance to try my skills in the contest.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJC">‘Contest? Is that how you think of it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJE">‘Assuredly, your Majesty. In what other light should it be considered? I hold no personal rancor toward the men of Angarak, and it is improper to hate thine opponent in a test of arms. Some few men have fallen beneath my lance or my sword at diverse tourneys, but I have never hated any of them. Much to the contrary, I have had some affection for them as we strove with one another.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJG">‘But you were trying to cripple them.’ Ce’Nedra was startled at the young man’s casual attitude.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJI">‘It is a part of the contest, your Majesty. A true test of arms may not be decided save by the injury or death of one of the combatants.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJK">‘What’s your name, Sir Knight?’ she asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJM">‘I am Sir Beridel,’ he replied, ‘son of Sir Andorig, Baron of Vo Enderig.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJO">‘The man with the apple tree?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJQ">‘The very same, your Majesty.’ The young man seemed pleased that she had heard of his father and the strange duty Belgarath had imposed on him. ‘My father now rides at the right hand of King Korodullin. I would ride with them this night but for this stroke of ill fortune.’ He looked sadly at his broken arm.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJS">‘There will be other nights, Sir Beridel,’ she assured him, ‘and other contests.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDJU">‘Truly, your Majesty,’ he agreed. His face brightened momentarily, but then he sighed and went back to his somber brooding.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDJV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDK0">Ce’Nedra drifted away, leaving him to his thoughts.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDK1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDK2">‘You can’t really talk to them, you know,’ a rough voice said to her from the shadows. It was Beldin, the ugly hunchback.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDK3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDK4">‘He doesn’t seem to be afraid of anything,’ Ce’Nedra said a bit nervously. The foul-mouthed sorcerer always made her nervous.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDK5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDK6">‘He’s a Mimbrate Arend,’ Beldin snorted. ‘He doesn’t have enough brains to be afraid.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDK7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDK8">‘Are all the men in the army like him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDK9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKA">‘No. Most of them </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDKB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKC">are</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKD"> afraid, but they’ll go through with the attack anyway – for a variety of reasons.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDKE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKF">‘And you?’ she could not help asking. ‘Are you afraid too?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDKG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKH">‘My fears are a bit more exotic,’ he said dryly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDKI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKJ">‘Such as?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDKK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKL">‘We’ve been at this for a very long time – Belgarath, Pol, the twins and I – and I’m more concerned about something going wrong than I am about my own personal safety.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDKM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKN">‘How do you mean, wrong?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDKO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKP">‘The Prophecy is very complex – and it doesn’t say everything. The two possible outcomes of all this are still absolutely balanced as far as I can tell. Something very, very slight could tip that balance one way or the other. It could be something that I’ve overlooked. That’s what I’m afraid of.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDKQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKR">‘All we can do is the best we can.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDKS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKT">‘That might not be enough.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDKU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDKV">‘What else can we do?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDL0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDL1">‘I don’t know – and that’s what worries me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDL2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDL3">‘Why worry about something if you can’t do anything about it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDL4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDL5">‘Now you’re starting to sound like Belgarath. He tends to shrug things off and trust to his luck sometimes. I like things a little neater.’ He stared off into the darkness. ‘Stay close to Pol tonight, little girl,’ he said after a moment. ‘Don’t get separated from her. It might take you someplace you hadn’t planned to go, but you’re supposed to stay with her, no matter what.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDL6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDL7">‘What does that mean?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDL8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDL9">‘I don’t </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDLA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLB">know</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLC"> what it means,’ he retorted irritably. ‘All I know is that you and she and the blacksmith and that stray child you picked up are supposed to stay together. Something unexpected is going to happen.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDLD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLE">‘You mean a disaster? We must warn the others.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDLF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLG">‘We don’t </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDLH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLI">know</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLJ"> that it’s a disaster,’ he replied. ‘That’s the whole problem. It might be necessary, and if it is, we don’t want to tamper with it. I think we’ve about run this discussion into the ground. Go find Polgara and stay with her.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDLK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLL">‘Yes, Beldin,’ Ce’Nedra said meekly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDLM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLN">As the stars began to come out, the anchors were raised and the Cherek fleet began to slip quietly downriver toward Thull Mardu. Though they were still some miles above the city, commands were issued in hoarse whispers, and the men all took great care to avoid making noise as they shifted their weapons and equipment, tightening belts, giving their armor quick, last-minute checks and settling their helmets more firmly on their heads.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDLO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLP">Amidships, Relg was leading his Ulgos in a quiet religious service, muttering the harsh gutturals of the Ulgo tongue in a scarcely audible murmur. Their pale faces had been smeared with soot, and they looked like so many shadows as they knelt in prayer to their strange God.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDLQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLR">‘They’re the key to the whole thing,’ Rhodar observed quietly to Polgara as he watched the devotions of the Ulgos. ‘Are you sure that Relg is all right for this? Sometimes he seems a bit unstable.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDLS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLT">‘He’ll be fine,’ Polgara replied. ‘The Ulgos have even more reason to hate Torak than you Alorns do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDLU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDLV">The drifting ships slowly rounded a wide bend in the river, and there, a half-mile downstream, stood the walled city of Thull Mardu, rising from its island in the middle of the river. There were a few torches atop the walls, and a faint glow rising from within. Barak turned and, shielding it with his body, he briefly uncovered a muffled lantern, letting out a single flicker of light. The anchors sank very slowly through the dark waters toward the riverbottom; with a very faint creak of ropes, the ships slowed, then stopped.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDM0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDM1">Somewhere inside the city a dog began to bark excitedly. Then a door banged open, and the barking cut off suddenly with a yelp of pain.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDM2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDM3">‘I don’t have much use for a man who kicks his own dog,’ Barak muttered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDM4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDM5">Relg and his men moved very quietly to the rail and began to clamber down ropes into the small boats waiting below.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDM6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDM7">Ce’Nedra watched breathlessly, straining with her eyes to see in the darkness. The very faint starlight briefly showed her several shadows drifting down toward the city. Then the shadows were gone. Behind them there was a faint splash of an oar, followed by an angrily hissed admonition. The princess turned and saw a moving tide of small boats coming downriver from the anchored fleet. The spearhead of the assault slid silently by, following Relg and his Ulgos toward the fortified island city of the Thulls.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDM8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDM9">‘Are you sure there are enough of them?’ Anheg whispered to Rhodar.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDMA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDMB">The rotund King of Drasnia nodded. ‘All they have to do is secure a landing place for us and hold the gate once the Ulgos get it open,’ he murmured. ‘There’s enough of them for that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDMC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDMD">A faint night breeze rippled the surface of the river, setting the ship to rocking. Unable to bear the suspense any longer, Ce’Nedra lifted her fingertips to the amulet Garion had given her so many months before. As always, a buzz of conversation filled her ears.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDME"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDMF">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="MSDMG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDMH">Yaga, tor gohek vilta</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDMI">.’ It was Relg’s harsh voice, speaking in a whisper. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="MSDMJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDMK">Ka tak. Veed!</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDML">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDMM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDMN">‘Well?’ Polgara asked, one eyebrow slightly raised.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDMO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDMP">‘I can’t tell what they’re saying,’ Ce’Nedra replied helplessly. ‘They’re talking in Ulgo.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDMQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDMR">A strangled groan quite suddenly seemed to come from the amulet itself and then was quickly and horribly cut off.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDMS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDMT">‘I – I think they just killed somebody,’ Ce’Nedra said in a quavering voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDMU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDMV">‘It’s started then,’ Anheg said with a certain grim satisfaction.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDN0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDN1">Ce’Nedra pulled her fingertips from the amulet. She could no longer bear to listen to the sound of men dying in the dark.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDN2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDN3">They waited.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDN4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDN5">Then someone screamed, a scream filled with a terrible agony.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDN6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDN7">‘That’s it!’ Barak declared. ‘That’s the signal! Pull the anchor!’ he shouted to his men.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDN8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDN9">Very suddenly beneath the high, dark walls of Thull Mardu, two separate fires flared up, and shadowy figures could be seen moving about them. At the same moment, there was a clanking rattle of heavy chains inside the city and a creaking groan as a broad gate swung ponderously down to form a bridge across the narrow north channel of the river.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDNA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDNB">‘Man your oars!’ Barak roared to his crew. He swung his tiller hard over, steering toward the rapidly lowering bridge.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDNC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDND">More torches appeared along the tops of the walls, and there were shouts of alarm. Somewhere an iron bell began to clang a note of desperate urgency.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDNE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDNF">‘It worked!’ Anheg exclaimed, gleefully pounding Rhodar on the back. ‘It actually worked!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDNG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDNH">‘Of course it worked,’ Rhodar replied, his voice also jubilant. ‘Don’t pound on me so hard, Anheg. I bruise easily.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDNI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDNJ">All need for silence was gone now, and a great roar went up from the massed fleet following in Barak’s wake. Torches flared, and the faces of the troops lining the rails were bathed in their ruddy glow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDNK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDNL">A great splash suddenly erupted from the river twenty yards to the right of Barak’s ship, showering everyone on deck with a deluge of water.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDNM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDNN">‘Catapult!’ Barak shouted, pointing at the walls looming ahead. Like a huge, preying insect, the heavy-beamed frame of the siege engine balanced atop the wall, its long throwing arm already cocking back to cast another boulder at the approaching fleet. Then the arm stopped as a storm of arrows swept the top of the wall clean. A crowd of Drasnians, easily identifiable by the long pikes they carried, overran the position.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDNO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDNP">‘Watch out, down there,’ one of them roared into the confusion at the base of the wall, and the siege engine ponderously toppled outward and fell with a crash onto the rocks below.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDNQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDNR">There was a thunder of hoofs across the now-lowered bridge, and the Mimbrate knights crashed into the city.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDNS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDNT">‘As soon as we tie up to the bridge, I want you and the princess and the other ladies to go to the north bank,’ King Rhodar said tersely to Polgara. ‘Get back out of harm’s way. This will probably take the rest of the night, and there’s no point in exposing any of you to any accidents.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDNU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDNV">‘Very well, Rhodar,’ Polgara agreed. ‘And don’t </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDO0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDO1">you</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDO2"> do anything foolish, either. You’re a rather large target, you know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDO3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDO4">‘I’ll be all right, Polgara – but I’m not going to miss this.’ He laughed then, a strangely boyish laugh. ‘I haven’t had so much fun in years,’ he declared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDO5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDO6">Polgara gave him a quick look. ‘Men!’ she said in a tone that said everything.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDO7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDO8">A guard of Mimbrate knights escorted the ladies and Errand perhaps a thousand yards upstream to an indented cove on the north bank of the stream, well away from the press of the horsemen rushing toward the beleaguered city. The cove had a gently sloping sand beach and was protected on three sides by steep, grass-covered banks. Durnik the smith and Olban quickly raised a tent for them, built a small fire, and then climbed up the bank to watch the attack.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDO9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDOA">‘It’s going according to plan,’ Durnik reported from his vantage point. ‘The Cherek ships are lining up side by side across the south channel. As soon as they get the planking in place, the troops on the other side will be able to cross.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDOB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDOC">‘Can you tell if the men inside have taken the south gate yet?’ Olban demanded, peering toward the city.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDOD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDOE">‘I can’t tell for sure,’ Durnik replied. ‘There’s fighting going on in that part of the city, though.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDOF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDOG">‘I’d give anything to be there,’ Olban lamented.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDOH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDOI">‘You stay right where you are, young man,’ Polgara told him firmly. ‘You appointed yourself bodyguard to the Rivan Queen, and you’re not going to go running off just because things are more interesting someplace else.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDOJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDOK">‘Yes, Lady Polgara,’ the young Rivan answered, suddenly abashed. ‘It’s just—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDOL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDOM">‘Just what?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDON"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDOO">‘I wish I knew what was happening, that’s all. My father and my brothers are in the middle of the fighting, and I have to stand here and watch.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDOP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDOQ">A sudden great belch of flame shot up from inside the walls to illuminate the river with sooty red light.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDOR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDOS">Polgara sighed. ‘Why do they always have to burn things?’ she asked sadly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDOT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDOU">‘It adds to the confusion, I suppose,’ Durnik replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDOV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDP0">‘Perhaps,’ Polgara said, ‘but I’ve seen this happen too many times before. It’s always the same. There always has to be a fire. I don’t believe I care to watch any more of this.’ She turned her back on the burning city and walked slowly away from the riverbank.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDP1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDP2">The night was interminable. Toward dawn, as the stars began to fade from the paling sky, the Princess Ce’Nedra, drawn with fatigue, stood atop a grassy bank near the cove, watching with a kind of sick fascination as the city of Thull Mardu died. Entire districts seemed to be in flames, and great fountains of orange sparks belched toward the sky as roofs caved in and buildings collapsed. What had seemed so stirring, so glorious in her anticipation had turned out to be something quite different in reality, and she was sick at what she had done. She still, nonetheless, brought her fingertips up to touch the amulet at her throat. She </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDP3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDP4">had</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDP5"> to know what was happening. No matter how horrible the events were in the city, not knowing what was happening was even worse.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDP6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDP7">‘Sort of a nice little fight,’ she heard King Anheg say. The King of Cherek seemed to be someplace very high – atop the walls of the city perhaps.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDP8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDP9">‘Pretty routine,’ Barak, Earl of Trellheim, replied. ‘The Murgo garrison fought pretty well, but the Thulls kept falling all over themselves trying to surrender.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDPA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDPB">‘What did you do with all of them?’ King Cho-Hag asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDPC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDPD">‘We herded them into the central square,’ Barak answered. ‘They’ve been amusing themselves by killing the Grolims we flushed out of the temple.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDPE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDPF">Anheg suddenly chuckled, an evil sort of sound. ‘How’s Grodeg?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDPG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDPH">‘It looks like he’s going to live,’ Barak said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDPI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDPJ">‘That’s a shame. When I saw that axe sticking out of his back, I thought somebody’d solved one of my problems for me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDPK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDPL">‘It was too low,’ Barak said rather mournfully. ‘It broke his spine, but it didn’t hit anything else significant. He won’t be walking any more, but he’s still breathing.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDPM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDPN">‘You can’t depend on a Murgo to do anything right,’ Anheg said in disgust.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDPO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDPP">‘They </span><span class="italic" aid="MSDPQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDPR">did</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDPS"> thin out the Bear-cult pretty thoroughly,’ Barak noted cheerfully. ‘I don’t think there are more than two dozen of them left. They fought pretty well, though.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDPT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDPU">‘That’s what they were here for. How long do you think it will be before daylight?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDPV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQ0">‘Half an hour, maybe.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQ1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQ2">‘Where’s Rhodar?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQ3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQ4">‘He and Fulrach are sacking the warehouses,’ King Cho-Hag replied. ‘The Murgos had some supply dumps here. Fulrach wants to confiscate them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQ5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQ6">‘He would,’ Anheg said. ‘Maybe we’d better send somebody for them. It’s getting on toward the time when we’ll want to think about pulling out of here. As soon as it gets light, all this smoke’s going to announce what we’ve done to anyone within twenty leagues. It’s about time to start the fleet moving, and it’s a long march back to the forts on top of the escarpment.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQ7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQ8">‘How long will it take you to get to the Sea of the East?’ Cho-Hag asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQ9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQA">‘A couple days,’ Anheg told him. ‘You can move a ship pretty fast when you’ve got the current behind you. It will take your army a week at least to get back to the forts, won’t it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQC">‘Probably,’ Cho-Hag said. ‘The infantry can’t move all that fast. There’s Brendig! I’ll send him to fetch Rhodar.’ He shouted down to the Sendar. ‘Colonel Brendig, see if you can find Rhodar. Ask him to join us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQE">‘What’s that?’ Barak asked suddenly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQG">‘What’s what?’ Anheg demanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQI">‘I thought I saw something out there – way to the south – where you can just start to make out that hilltop.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQK">‘I don’t see anything.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQM">‘It was just a flicker – something moving.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQO">‘Probably a Murgo scout creeping in for a look.’ Anheg laughed shortly. ‘I don’t imagine we’ll be able to keep what happened here a secret for very long.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQQ">‘There it is again,’ Barak said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQS">‘I saw it that time, too,’ King Cho-Hag agreed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDQU">There was a long silence as the sky imperceptibly grew lighter. Ce’Nedra held her breath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDQV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDR0">‘Belar!’ Anheg swore in a stunned voice. ‘They stretch for miles!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="MSDR1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="MSDR2">‘Lelldorin!’ Barak shouted down from the wall. ‘Brendig’s gone to get Rhodar. Go find them and tell them to get up here at once. The plain to the south is covered with Murgos.’</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_24" aid="MSDR3"></div>

    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
