<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos607605" aid="NQU21"><span class="calibre5" aid="NQU22"><span class="italic" aid="NQU23"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU24">Chapter Sixteen</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="NQU25"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU26">‘Lady Polgara!’ Ce’Nedra cried, jerking back the flap of the tent. ‘Lady Polgara!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU27"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU28">‘What is it, Ce’Nedra?’ Polgara’s voice came from the darkness inside the tent.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU29"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU2A">‘Barak and Anheg are up on the walls of the city,’ the princess said in a frightened voice. ‘They just saw a Murgo army coming up from the south.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU2B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU2C">Polgara came quickly out into the firelight, holding the sleepy Errand by the hand. ‘Where’s Beldin?’ she demanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU2D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU2E">‘I haven’t seen him since early last night.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU2F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU2G">Polgara raised her face and closed her eyes. A moment or so later there was a rushing sound of wings, and the large hawk settled to the sand not far from their flickering fire.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU2H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU2I">Beldin was swearing sulfurously even as he shimmered and blurred back into his natural shape.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU2J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU2K">‘How did they slip past you, Uncle?’ Polgara asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU2L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU2M">‘There are Grolims with them,’ he growled, still sizzling the air around him with oaths. ‘The Grolims could feel me watching, so the troops moved only at night, and the Grolims shielded them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU2N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU2O">‘Where did they hide in the daytime?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU2P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU2Q">‘In the Thullish villages, apparently. There are dozens of communities out there. It never occurred to me to pay all that much attention to them.’ He began to swear again, berating himself savagely for having missed the movement of the Murgo army.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU2R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU2S">‘There’s no point in swearing about it, Uncle,’ Polgara told him coolly. ‘It’s done, now.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU2T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU2U">‘Unfortunately there’s a bit more, Pol,’ the sorcerer told her. ‘There’s another army at least as big coming in from the north – Malloreans, Nadraks, and Thulls. We’re caught right between them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU2V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU30">‘How long have we got before they reach us?’ Polgara asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU31"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU32">Beldin shrugged. ‘Not long. The Murgos have some rough ground to cross – probably about an hour. The Malloreans will be here in quite a bit less.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU33"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU34">Polgara began to curse fervently under her breath. ‘Go to Rhodar,’ she told the hunchback. ‘Tell him that we have to release Anheg’s fleet immediately – before the Angaraks can bring up catapults and destroy the ships where they’re anchored.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU35"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU36">The deformed man nodded and stooped slightly, curving his arms out like wings even as he began to waver and change.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU37"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU38">‘Olban,’ Polgara called to the young Rivan, ‘go find Sir Mandorallen and Lord Hettar. Send them to me at once. Hurry.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU39"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU3A">Olban gave her one startled look, then ran for his horse.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU3B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU3C">Durnik the smith came sliding down the grassy bank onto their little beach. His face was grave. ‘You and the ladies must leave at once, Mistress Pol,’ he told her. ‘There’s going to be fighting here, and the middle of a battle’s no place for any of you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU3D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU3E">‘I’m not going anywhere, Durnik,’ she replied with a trace of irritation. ‘I started all this, and I’m going to see it through.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU3F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU3G">Ariana had gone back into the tent as soon as the situation became clear to her. She now emerged again, carrying the stout canvas bag in which she kept her medical supplies. ‘Have I thy permission to leave, Lady Polgara?’ she asked with a certain cool professionalism. ‘In battle men are injured, and I must go make preparations for their care. This spot is somewhat too remote and confined to receive the wounded.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU3H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU3I">Polgara gave her a quick look. ‘All right,’ she agreed. ‘Just be careful not to get too close to the fighting.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU3J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU3K">Taiba pulled on her cloak. ‘I’ll go with you,’ she told Ariana. ‘I don’t know that much about it, but you can teach me as we go along.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU3L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU3M">‘Go help them get set up, Durnik,’ Polgara told the smith. ‘Then come back here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU3N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU3O">Durnik nodded gravely and helped the two women up the steep bank.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU3P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU3Q">Mandorallen thundered up on his charger with Hettar at his side.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU3R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU3S">‘You know what’s happened?’ Polgara demanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU3T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU3U">Mandorallen nodded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU3V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU40">‘Is there any possibility of withdrawing before the enemy forces arrive?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU41"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU42">‘Nay, my Lady Polgara,’ the great knight replied. ‘They are too close. Moreover, our purpose has ever been to gain passage for the ships of Cherek into the Sea of the East. We must buy them time to sail beyond the reach of the siege engines of the Angaraks.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU43"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU44">‘I didn’t want this,’ Polgara said angrily and she began to mutter curses again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU45"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU46">Brand, the gray-cloaked Rivan Warder, accompanied by General Varana, rode up to join Mandorallen and Hettar at the top of the steep bank. The four of them dismounted and slid down the bank to the sand. ‘We’ve begun evacuating the city,’ the big Rivan said in his deep voice, ‘and most of the fleet is pulling anchor. We’re holding just enough ships to maintain the bridges across the south channel.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU47"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU48">‘Is there any possibility of putting the entire army on one bank or the other?’ Polgara asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU49"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4A">He shook his head. ‘There isn’t time, Polgara.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU4B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4C">‘We’re going to be divided by the river,’ she pointed out, ‘and neither force is going to be strong enough to meet the Angaraks coming against it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU4D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4E">‘A tactical necessity, my dear Lady Polgara,’ General Varana told her. ‘We have to hold both banks until the fleet is clear.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU4F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4G">‘I think Rhodar misjudged the Angarak intentions,’ Brand said. ‘He was so sure that Taur Urgas and ‘Zakath would both want to avoid taking casualties that he didn’t consider this possibility.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU4H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4I">General Varana clasped his muscular hands behind his back and limped back and forth along the little beach, his face creased with thought. ‘I think I begin to understand the meaning of that Murgo column we destroyed in the uplands,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU4J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4K">‘Your Grace?’ Mandorallen asked, puzzled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU4L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4M">‘It was a test of our commitment,’ Varana explained. ‘The Angaraks needed to know when we were making our major move. One of the basic rules of war is not to become involved in serious conflicts if what you’re doing is merely diversionary. That column was bait. Unfortunately, we took it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU4N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4O">‘You mean we shouldn’t have attacked the column?’ Hettar asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU4P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4Q">Varana made a rueful face. ‘Apparently not. It gave away our intentions – let them know that </span><span class="italic" aid="NQU4R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4S">this</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4T"> expedition was </span><span class="italic" aid="NQU4U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU4V">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU50"> a diversion. I underestimated Taur Urgas. He threw away a thousand men just to find out what we were up to.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU51"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU52">‘What now?’ Hettar asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU53"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU54">‘We get ready to fight,’ Varana said. ‘I wish we had better terrain for it, but I suppose we’ll have to make do with what we have.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU55"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU56">Hettar looked out across the river, his hawk-face hungry. ‘I wonder if I’ve got time to make it over to the south bank,’ he mused.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU57"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU58">‘One side or the other,’ Brand said, looking puzzled. ‘What’s the difference?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU59"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5A">‘The Murgos are over there,’ Hettar replied. ‘I don’t really have anything against Malloreans.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU5B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5C">‘This isn’t a personal fight, Lord Hettar,’ Varana pointed out.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU5D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5E">‘It is with me,’ Hettar said grimly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU5F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5G">‘We must needs see to the safety of Lady Polgara and the princess,’ Mandorallen said. ‘Mayhap an escort should be provided to convey them back to the forts atop the escarpment.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU5H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5I">Brand shook his head. ‘The region is likely to be patrolled heavily,’ he disagreed. ‘It wouldn’t be safe.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU5J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5K">‘He’s right, Mandorallen,’ Polgara told the knight. ‘Besides, you need every man you’ve got right here.’ She looked off toward the northeast. ‘Then, too, there’s that.’ She pointed toward a heavy cloudbank that had begun to stain the sky just above the horizon. The clouds were an inky black, seething and rolling and illuminated from within by fitful flickers of lightning.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU5L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5M">‘A storm?’ General Varana asked, looking a bit surprised.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU5N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5O">‘Not at this time of year – and certainly not from that direction,’ Polgara replied. ‘The Grolims are up to something, and that’s going to be </span><span class="italic" aid="NQU5P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5Q">my</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5R"> fight. Deploy your forces, gentlemen. If there’s going to be a battle, let’s be ready for it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU5S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5T">‘The ships are moving,’ Durnik reported as he and Olban came back to the sheltered little cove, ‘and the troops are leaving the city.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU5U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU5V">King Rhodar rode up. His broad face was streaked with soot and perspiration. ‘Anheg’s leaving,’ he said, swinging down from his saddle with a grunt.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU60"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU61">‘Where’s Fulrach?’ Brand asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU62"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU63">‘He’s taking the bulk of the troops across to the south bank.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU64"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU65">‘Isn’t that going to leave us a little undermanned on this side?’ General Varana inquired politely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU66"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU67">‘That bridge is too narrow,’ Rhodar told him. ‘It would take hours to bring enough men across to make any difference. Brendig’s already got a crew undermining the supports so that we can bring the bridge down before the Angaraks get here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU68"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU69">‘What for?’ Ce’Nedra asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU6A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU6B">‘Thull Mardu’s too good a vantage point, your Highness,’ General Varana explained. ‘We don’t want any Angaraks on the island if we can help it.’ He looked at King Rhodar. ‘Have you given any thought to tactics?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU6C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU6D">‘We want to give Anheg a half a day, if possible,’ Rhodar replied. ‘The ground along the river gets marshy about twenty leagues downstream, and the Angaraks won’t be able to get close enough to pester him, once he gets that far. Let’s form up a conventional infantry line – pikemen, the legions, Sendars, and so on. We’ll put the archers in support and use the Algars to slash at the flanks. I want to hold the Mimbrate knights in reserve until the Malloreans mass up for their first charge.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU6E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU6F">‘That’s not a winning tactic, if your Majesty will forgive my saying so,’ General Varana said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU6G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU6H">‘We aren’t here to win, Varana,’ Rhodar told him. ‘We’re here to delay the Angaraks for about six hours and then withdraw. I’m not going to waste lives trying to win a battle I haven’t any chance of winning.’ He turned to Hettar. ‘I want you to send a force of your clansmen on a sweep downriver. Tell them to uproot any Malloreans they find emplaced along the riverbank. The significance of the fleet still may have escaped ‘Zakath and Taur Urgas. Angaraks aren’t good sailors, so they probably don’t realize what Anheg can do, once he gets into the Seas of the East.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU6I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU6J">‘Excuse me, your Majesty,’ Varana objected, ‘but all of your strategy – even the fleet – is merely a delaying action.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU6K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU6L">‘That’s the whole point, Varana,’ Rhodar told him bluntly. ‘All of this is really rather insignificant. What’s really important is going to happen in Mallorea when Belgarion reaches Cthol Mishrak. We’d better move, gentlemen. The Malloreans will be here before long, and we want to be ready for them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU6M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU6N">The cloudbank Polgara had pointed out was sweeping toward them with an alarming speed, a seething darkness of rolling purple, stalking forward on crooked legs of lightning. A hot wind seemed to flee out ahead of it, flattening the grass and whipping the manes and tails of the horses wildly. As King Rhodar and the others moved out to meet the approaching Mallorean army, Polgara, her face pale and her hair tossing behind her in the wind, climbed the grassy bank with Ce’Nedra and Durnik behind her and stood watching the approach of the cloud. ‘Take the child, Ce’Nedra,’ she said quite calmly. ‘Don’t let go of him, no matter what happens.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU6O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU6P">‘Yes, Lady Polgara,’ Ce’Nedra said, holding out her arms to Errand. The child came to her immediately, his serious little face unafraid. She picked him up and held him close, her cheek against his.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU6Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU6R">‘Errand?’ he said, pointing at the approaching storm.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU6S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU6T">Then, among the ranks of their army, shadowy figures rose up out of the ground. The figures wore black robes and polished steel masks and carried cruel-pointed short spears. Without pausing to even think, a mounted young Mimbrate knight swept his broadsword from its scabbard and swung the whistling blade at one of the steel-masked figures. His sword passed through the figure with no effect. As he struck, however, a sizzling bolt of lightning struck him, seeming to attach itself to the point of his helmet. He stiffened convulsively as the lightning, like a writhing snake of intense light, clung to the tip of his steel helm. Smoke boiled out of the slits of his visor as he roasted inside his armor. His horse lurched forward onto its knees while the ghastly, flickering light engulfed them both. Then the lightning was gone, and horse and man collapsed, stone dead.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU6U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU6V">Polgara hissed and then raised her voice. She did not seem to be speaking that loudly, but the effect of her words reached the farthest edges of the army. ‘Do not touch the shadows,’ she warned. ‘They’re Grolim illusions and can’t hurt you unless you touch them. They’re here to draw the lightning to you, so stay clear of them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU70"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU71">‘But, Mistress Pol,’ Durnik protested, ‘the troops won’t be able to hold ranks if they have to keep dodging the shadows.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU72"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU73">‘I’ll take care of the shadows,’ she replied grimly. She raised both arms above her head, her fists clenched. A look of dreadful concentration filled her face, and then she spoke a single word, opening her hands as she did so. The grass, which had been bending toward them in the hot wind preceding the storm, suddenly flattened in the opposite direction as the force of Polgara’s will rippled outward. As that force passed over each shadowy Grolim illusion, the figures seemed to flinch, then shrivel, and then with silent detonations, each shadow exploded into shards and fragments of darkness.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU74"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU75">Polgara was gasping as the last of the shadows on the farthest edge of the army vanished, and she would have collapsed had Durnik not jumped to her side to support her. ‘Are you all right?’ he asked worriedly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU76"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU77">‘Just give me a moment,’ she said, wilting against him. ‘That took a great deal of effort.’ She smiled at him, a wan little smile, and then her head drooped wearily.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU78"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU79">‘Won’t they come back?’ Ce’Nedra demanded. ‘What I mean is, it didn’t actually hurt the real Grolims, did it? Just their shadows.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU7A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU7B">Polgara laughed weakly. ‘Oh, it hurt them, all right,’ she replied. ‘Those Grolims don’t </span><span class="italic" aid="NQU7C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU7D">have</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU7E"> shadows any more. Not one of them will ever cast a shadow again.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU7F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU7G">‘Not ever?’ the princess gasped.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU7H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU7I">‘Not ever.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU7J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU7K">Then Beldin joined them, swooping in with the wind tearing at his feathers. ‘We’ve got work to do, Polgara,’ he growled even as he shimmered into his natural shape. ‘We’re going to have to break up this storm they’re bringing in from the west. I talked with the twins. They’ll work on the southern side of it, and you and I’ll take this side.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU7L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU7M">She looked at him inquiringly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU7N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU7O">‘Their army’s going to be advancing right behind the storm,’ he explained. ‘There’s no point in trying to hold it back now. It’s got too much momentum. What we want to do is break open the rear edge of it and let it spill back over the Angaraks.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU7P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU7Q">‘How many Grolims are working on the storm, Uncle?’ she asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU7R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU7S">‘Who knows?’ He shrugged. ‘But it’s taking every bit of effort they can muster just to keep it under control. If the four of us hit the back side all at once, the pressures in the storm itself will do the rest.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU7T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU7U">‘Why not just let it pass over?’ Durnik asked. ‘Our troops aren’t children. They won’t fall apart just because of a little squall.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU7V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU80">‘This isn’t just a little squall, blacksmith,’ Beldin said acidly. Something large and white thudded to the ground a few feet away. ‘If you get four or five of those hailstones on top of the head, you won’t care </span><span class="italic" aid="NQU81"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU82">how</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU83"> the battle turns out.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU84"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU85">‘They’re as big as hens’ eggs,’ Durnik said in astonishment.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU86"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU87">‘And they’ll probably get bigger.’ Beldin turned back to Polgara. ‘Give me your hand,’ he told her. ‘I’ll pass the signal to Beltira, and we’ll all strike at the same time. Get ready.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU88"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU89">More of the hailstones thudded into the springy turf, and one particularly large one shattered into a thousand fragments as it crashed down on a large rock with stunning force. From the direction of the army came an intermittent banging as the hailstones bounced off the armor of the Mimbrate knights or clanged down on the hastily raised shields of the infantry.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU8A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU8B">And then, mixed with the hail, the rain squalls struck – seething sheets of water driven before the wind like raging waves. It was impossible to see, and almost impossible to breathe. Olban jumped forward with his shield raised to protect Ce’Nedra and Errand. He winced once as a large hailstone struck his shoulder, but his shield arm did not waver.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU8C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU8D">‘It’s breaking, Pol!’ Beldin shouted. ‘Let’s push it once more. Let them eat their own storm for a while.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU8E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU8F">Polgara’s face twisted into an agony of concentration, and then she half-slumped as she and Beldin unleashed their combined wills at the rolling sky. The sound of it was beyond belief as the vast forces collided. The sky ripped suddenly apart and lightning staggered and lurched through the smoking air. Great, incandescent bolts crashed into each other high above, showering the earth beneath with fireballs. Men fell, charred instantly into black, steaming husks in the driving downpour, but the casualties were not only among the men of the west.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU8G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU8H">The vast storm with its intolerable pressures recoiled as the combined wills of Polgara and Beldin on the north bank and the twins on the south bank ripped open the back edge of it, and the advancing Malloreans received that recoil full in the teeth. A curtain of lightning swept back across their close-packed ranks like an enormous, blinding broom, littering the earth with their smoking dead. As the fabric of Grolim sorcery which had driven the stormfront toward the river ripped apart, the gale winds suddenly reversed and flowed back, shrieking and howling, confounding the advancing Angaraks with rain and hail.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU8I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU8J">From out of the center of the dreadful cloud overhead, swirling fingers of murky black twitched and reached down toward the earth with hideous roaring sounds. With a last, almost convulsive jerk, one of those huge, swirling funnels touched the earth in the midst of the red-clad Malloreans. Debris sprayed up and out from the point of the dreadful vortex as, with ponderous immensity, it cut an erratic course two hundred yards wide directly through the enemy ranks. Men and horses were ripped to pieces by the insane winds within the swirling column of cloud, and bits of armor and shreds of red tunics – and worse – showered down on the stunned and terrified Malloreans on either side of the swath of absolute destruction moving inexorably through their midst.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU8K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU8L">‘Beautiful!’ Beldin exulted, hopping up and down in a grotesque display of glee.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU8M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU8N">There was the sudden sound of a great horn, and the close-packed ranks of Drasnian pikemen and Tolnedran legionnaires facing the faltering ranks of the Malloreans opened. From behind them, his armor streaming water, Mandorallen led the charge of the Mimbrate knights. Full upon the confused and demoralized Malloreans they fell, and the sound of the impact as they struck was a terrible, rending crash, punctuated by screams. Rank upon rank was crushed beneath the charge, and the terrified Malloreans wavered and then broke and fled. Even as they ran, the clans of Algar swept in among them from the flanks, their sabres flashing in the rain.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU8O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU8P">At a second blast of Mandorallen’s horn, the charging Mimbrates reined in, wheeled and galloped back, leaving a vast wreckage behind them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU8Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU8R">The rain slackened fitfully, little more than errantly passing showers now, and patches of blue appeared among the racing clouds overhead. The Grolim storm had broken and dispersed back across the plains of Mishrak ac Thull.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU8S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU8T">Ce’Nedra looked toward the south bank and saw that the storm there had also dispersed and that the forces under the command of King Cho-Hag and King Korodullin were assaulting the front ranks of the demoralized Murgo army. Then the princess looked sharply at the south channel of the river. The last bridges of Cherek ships had broken loose during the violent storm, and there was now only open water on that side of the island. The last troops remaining in the city were streaming across the bridge over the north channel. A tall Sendarian lad was among the last to cross. As soon as he reached the bank, he came immediately upriver. As he drew nearer, Ce’Nedra recognized him. It was Rundorig, Garion’s boyhood friend from Faldor’s farm, and he was openly weeping.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU8U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU8V">‘Goodman Durnik,’ he sobbed as he reached them, ‘Doroon’s dead.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU90"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU91">‘What did you say?’ Lady Polgara demanded, raising her tired face suddenly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU92"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU93">‘Doroon, Mistress Pol,’ Rundorig wept. ‘He drowned. We were crossing over to the south bank when the storm broke the ropes holding the ships. Doroon fell into the river, and he didn’t know how to swim. I tried to save him, but he went under before I could reach him.’ The tall young man buried his face in his hands.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU94"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU95">Polgara’s face went absolutely white, and her eyes filled with sudden tears. ‘Take care of him, Durnik,’ she told the smith, then turned and walked away, her head bowed in her grief.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU96"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU97">‘I tried, Durnik,’ Rundorig blurted, still sobbing. ‘I really tried to reach him – but there were too many people in my way. I couldn’t get to him in time. I saw him go under, and there was nothing I could do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU98"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU99">Durnik’s face was very grave as he put his arm about the weeping boy’s shoulders. The smith’s eyes were also filled, and he said nothing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU9A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU9B">Ce’Nedra, however, could not weep. She had reached out her hand and plucked these unwarlike young men from their homes and dragged them halfway across the world, and now one of Garion’s oldest friends had died in the chill waters of the River Mardu. His death was on her head, but she could not weep. A terrible fury suddenly filled her. She turned to Olban. ‘Kill them!’ she hissed from between clenched teeth.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU9C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU9D">‘My Queen?’ Olban gaped at her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU9E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU9F">‘Go!’ she commanded. ‘Take your sword and go. Kill as many Angaraks as you can – for me, Olban. Kill them for me!’ And then she could weep.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU9G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU9H">Olban looked first at the sobbing little princess and then at the milling ranks of the Malloreans, still reeling from the savagery of the Mimbrate assault. His face grew exultant as he drew his sword. ‘As my Queen commands!’ he shouted and ran to his horse.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU9I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU9J">Even as the decimated front ranks of the Malloreans fled, hurried by the sabre-wielding Algars, greater and greater numbers of their countrymen reached the field, and soon the low hills to the north were covered with them. Their red tunics made it look almost as if the earth itself were bleeding. It was not the Malloreans, however, who mounted the next attack. Instead, thick-bodied Thulls in mud-colored smocks marched reluctantly into position. Directly behind the Thulls, mounted Malloreans urged them on with whips.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU9K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU9L">‘Basic Mallorean strategy,’ Beldin growled. ‘’Zakath wants to let the Thulls do most of the dying. He’ll try to save his own troops for the campaign against Taur Urgas.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU9M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU9N">Ce’Nedra raised her tear-streaked face. ‘What do we do now?’ she asked the misshapen sorcerer.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU9O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU9P">‘We kill Thulls,’ he said bluntly. ‘A charge or two by the Mimbrates ought to break their spirits. Thulls don’t make very good soldiers, and they’ll run away as soon as we give them the chance.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU9Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU9R">Even as the sluggish forces of Mishrak ac Thull flowed like a mudslide downhill toward the solid line of pikemen and legionnaires, the Asturian archers just to the rear of the infantry raised their bows and filled the air with a solid, arching sheet of yard-long arrows. The Thulls quailed as rank after rank melted under the withering storm of arrows. The shouts of the Malloreans at the rear became more desperate, and the crack of their whips filled the air.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU9S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU9T">And then Mandorallen’s horn sounded, the ranks of infantry opened and the armored knights of Mimbre charged again. The Thulls took one look at the steel-clad men and horses crashing toward them and immediately bolted. The Mallorean whip-men were swarmed under and trampled in the panic-stricken flight of the Thull army.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQU9U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQU9V">‘So much for the Thulls,’ Beldin grunted with satisfaction as he watched the rout. He grinned an evil grin. ‘I imagine that ‘Zakath will speak firmly to King Gethell about this.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUA0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUA1">Mandorallen’s knights thundered back to their positions behind the infantry, and the two armies glared at each other across a field littered with Angarak dead.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUA2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUA3">Ce’Nedra began to shiver as a sudden chill swept the battlefield. Although the sun had broken through the ragged clouds as the Grolim storm rapidly dispersed, there was no warmth to it. Even though all trace of wind had died, it grew colder. Then from the ground and from the dark surface of the river, tendrils of fog began to rise.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUA4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUA5">Beldin hissed. ‘Polgara,’ he snapped to the grieving sorceress, ‘I need you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUA6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUA7">‘Leave me alone, Uncle,’ she replied in a voice still choked with sorrow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUA8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUA9">‘You can cry later,’ he told her harshly. ‘The Grolims are drawing the heat out of the air. If we don’t stir up a wind, the fog’s going to get so thick you’ll be able to walk on it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUAA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUAB">She turned, and her face was very cold. ‘You don’t respect anything, do you?’ she said flatly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUAC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUAD">‘Not much,’ he admitted, ‘but that’s beside the point. If the Grolims can build up a good fog bank, we’ll have the whole stinking Mallorean army on top of us before we can even see them coming. Let’s go, Pol. People get killed; it happens. You can get sentimental about it later.’ He held out his gnarled, lumpy hand to her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUAE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUAF">The tendrils of fog had begun to thicken, lying in little pockets now. The littered battlefield in front of the infantry lines seemed to waver, and then disappeared entirely as the fog congealed into a solid wall of white.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUAG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUAH">‘Wind, Pol,’ Beldin said, taking hold of her hand. ‘As much wind as you can raise.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUAI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUAJ">The struggle which ensued then was a silent one. Polgara and Beldin, their hands joined together, gathered in their wills and then reached out with them, probing, searching for some weakness in the mass of dead-calm air that imprisoned the thickening fog along the banks of the river. Fitful little gusts of breeze swirled the eddying fog, then died as quickly as they had arisen.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUAK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUAL">‘Harder, Pol,’ Beldin urged. His ugly face streamed with rivulets of sweat as he struggled with the vast inertness of unmoving air.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUAM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUAN">‘It’s not going to work this way, Uncle,’ she declared, pulling her hand free. Her face showed her own strain. ‘There’s nothing to get hold of. What are the twins doing?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUAO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUAP">‘The Hierarchs of Rak Cthol are riding with Taur Urgas,’ the hunchback replied. ‘The twins have their hands full dealing with them. They won’t be able to help.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUAQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUAR">Polgara straightened then, steeling herself. ‘We’re trying to work too close,’ she said. ‘Every time we start a little local breeze, a dozen Grolims jump in and smother it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUAS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUAT">‘All right,’ Beldin agreed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUAU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUAV">‘We’ll have to reach out farther,’ she continued. ‘Start the air moving somewhere out beyond their range so that by the time it gets here, it has so much momentum that they can’t stop it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUB0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUB1">Beldin’s eyes narrowed. ‘That’s dangerous, Pol,’ he told her. ‘Even if we </span><span class="italic" aid="NQUB2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUB3">can</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUB4"> do it, it’s going to exhaust the both of us. If they throw anything else at us, neither of us will have any strength left to fight them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUB5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUB6">‘It’s a gamble, Uncle,’ she admitted, ‘but the Grolims are stubborn. They’ll try to protect this fog bank even after all chance of maintaining it has gone. They’ll get tired, too. Maybe too tired to try anything else.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUB7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUB8">‘I don’t like maybes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUB9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUBA">‘Have you got a better idea?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUBB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUBC">‘Not right now, no.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUBD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUBE">‘All right, then.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUBF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUBG">They joined hands again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUBH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUBI">It took, it seemed to the princess, an eternity. With her heart in her throat she stared at the two of them as they stood with their hands joined and their eyes closed – reaching out with their minds toward the hot, barren uplands to the west, trying with all their strength to pull that heated air down into the broad valley of the River Mardu. All around her, Ce’Nedra seemed to feel the oppressive chill of Grolim thought lying heavily on the stagnant air, holding it, resisting all effort to dissipate the choking fog.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUBJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUBK">Polgara was breathing in short gasps, her chest heaving and her face twisted with an inhuman striving. Beldin, his knotted shoulders hunched forward, struggled like a man attempting to lift a mountain.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUBL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUBM">And then Ce’Nedra caught the faintest scent of dust and dry, sun-parched grass. It was only momentary, and she thought at first that she had imagined it. Then it came again, stronger this time, and the fog eddied sluggishly. But once more that faint scent died, and with it the breath of air that had carried it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUBN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUBO">Polgara groaned then, an almost strangled sound, and the fog began to swirl. The wet grass at Ce’Nedra’s feet, drenched with droplets of mist, bent slightly, and the dusty smell of the Thullish uplands grew stronger.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUBP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUBQ">It seemed that the blanket of concentration that had held the fog motionless became more desperate as the Grolims fought to stop the quickening breeze pouring down the valley from the acrid stretches to the west. The blanket began to tatter and to fall apart as the weaker of the Grolims, pushed beyond their capacity, collapsed in exhaustion.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUBR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUBS">The breeze grew stronger, became a hot wind that rippled the surface of the river. The grass bent before it, and the fog began to seethe like some vast living thing, writhing at the touch of the arid wind.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUBT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUBU">Ce’Nedra could see the still-burning city of Thull Mardu now, and the infantry lines drawn up on the plain beside the river.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUBV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUC0">The hot, dusty wind blew stronger, and the fog, as insubstantial as the thought that had raised it from the earth, dissolved, and the morning sun broke through to bathe the field in golden light.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUC1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUC2">‘Polgara!’ Durnik cried in sudden alarm.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="NQUC3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="NQUC4">Ce’Nedra whirled in time to see Polgara, her face drained deathly white, slowly toppling to the earth.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_25" aid="NQUC5"></div>
