<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos649729" aid="OPEK1"><span class="calibre5" aid="OPEK2"><span class="italic" aid="OPEK3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEK4">Chapter Seventeen</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="OPEK5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEK6">Lelldorin of Wildantor had been nervously pacing back and forth along the ranks of his bowmen, stopping often to listen for any sound coming out of the fog from the field lying in front of the massed infantry. ‘Can you hear anything?’ he asked urgently of a Tolnedran legionnaire standing nearby.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEK7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEK8">The Tolnedran shook his head.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEK9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKA">That same whisper came out of the fog from a dozen different places.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEKB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKC">‘Can you hear anything?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEKD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKE">‘Can </span><span class="italic" aid="OPEKF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKG">you</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKH"> hear anything?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEKI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKJ">‘What are they doing?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEKK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKL">Somewhere to the front, there was a faint clink.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEKM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKN">‘There!’ everyone cried almost in unison.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEKO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKP">‘Not yet!’ Lelldorin snapped to one of his countrymen who was raising his bow. ‘It could be just a wounded Thull out there. Save your arrows.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEKQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKR">‘Is that a breeze?’ a Drasnian pikeman asked. ‘Please, Belar, let it be a breeze.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEKS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKT">Lelldorin stared into the fog, nervously fingering his bowstring.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEKU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEKV">Then he felt a faint touch of air on his cheek.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEL0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEL1">‘A breeze,’ someone exulted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEL2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEL3">‘A breeze.’ The phrase raced through the massed army.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEL4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEL5">Then the faint breath of air died, and the fog settled again, seeming thicker than ever.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEL6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEL7">Someone groaned bitterly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEL8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEL9">The fog stirred then and began to eddy sluggishly. It </span><span class="italic" aid="OPELA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPELB">was</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPELC"> a breeze!</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPELD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPELE">Lelldorin held his breath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPELF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPELG">The fog began to move, flowing gray over the ground like water.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPELH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPELI">‘There’s something moving out there!’ a Tolnedran barked. ‘Get ready!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPELJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPELK">The flowing fog moved faster, thinning, melting in the hot, dusty breeze blowing down the valley. Lelldorin strained his eyes to the front. There were moving shapes out there, no more than seventy paces from the infantry.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPELL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPELM">Then, as if all its stubborn resistance had broken at once, the fog shimmered and dissolved, and the sun broke through. The entire field before them was filled with Malloreans. Their stealthy forward pace froze momentarily as they flinched in the sudden light of the sun.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPELN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPELO">‘Now!’ Lelldorin shouted, raising his bow. Behind him, his archers with one universal motion followed his action, and the sudden release of a thousand bowstrings all at once was like some vast, thrumming note. A whistling sheet of arrows soared over the heads of the solidly standing infantry, seemed to hang motionless in the air for a moment, then hurtled into the close-packed Mallorean ranks.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPELP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPELQ">The creeping attack of the Malloreans did not waver or falter; it simply dissolved. With a vast, sighing groan, entire regiments fell in their tracks under the Asturian arrow storm.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPELR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPELS">Lelldorin’s hand flickered to the forest of arrows thrust point-first into the turf at his feet. He smoothly nocked another shaft, drew and released. And then again – and again. The sheet of arrows overhead was like some great slithering bridge arching over the infantry and riddling the Malloreans as it fell among them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPELT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPELU">The storm of Asturian arrows crept inexorably across the field, and the Mallorean dead piled up in windrows as if some enormous scythe had passed through their ranks.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPELV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEM0">And then Sir Mandorallen’s brazen horn sounded its mighty challenge, the ranks of archers and infantry opened, and the earth shook beneath the thunder of the charge of the Mimbrate knights.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEM1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEM2">Demoralized by the arrow storm and the sight of that inexorable charge descending upon them, the Malloreans broke and fled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEM3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEM4">Laughing delightedly, Lelldorin’s cousin Torasin lowered his bow to jeer at the backs of the routed Angaraks. ‘We did it, Lelldorin!’ he shouted, still laughing. ‘We broke their backs!’ He was half-turned now, not facing the littered field. His bow was in his hands; his dark hair was thrown back; and his face reflected his exultant delight. Lelldorin would always remember him so.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEM5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEM6">‘Tor! Look out!’ Lelldorin shouted, but it was too late. The Mallorean answer to the Asturian arrow storm was a storm of their own. From a hundred catapults concealed behind the low hills to the north, a great cloud of rocks hurtled into the air and crashed down into the close-packed ranks along the riverbank. A stone perhaps somewhat larger than a man’s head struck Torasin full in the chest, smashing him to the ground.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEM7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEM8">‘Tor!’ Lelldorin’s cry was anguished as he ran to his stricken cousin. Torasin’s eyes were closed, and blood was flowing from his nose. His chest was crushed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEM9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEMA">‘Help me!’ Lelldorin cried to a group of serfs standing nearby. The serfs obediently moved to assist him, but their eyes, speaking louder than any words, said that Torasin was already dead.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="OPEMB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEMC">Barak’s face was bleak as he stood at the tiller of his big ship. His oarsmen stroked to the beat of a muffled drum, and the ship raced downriver.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEMD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEME">King Anheg of Cherek lounged against the rail. He had pulled off his helmet so that the cool river air could blow the stink of smoke out of his hair. His coarse-featured face was as grim as his cousin’s. ‘What do you think their chances are?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEMF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEMG">‘Not very good,’ Barak replied bluntly. ‘We never counted on the Murgos and Malloreans hitting us at Thull Mardu. The army’s split in two by the river, and both halves of it are outnumbered. They’re going to have a bad time of it, I’m afraid.’ He glanced over his shoulder at the half-dozen small, narrow-beamed boats trailing in the wake of his big ship. ‘Close it up!’ he bellowed at the men in the smaller boats.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEMH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEMI">‘Malloreans ahead! On the north bank!’ the lookout at the mast shouted. ‘About a half a mile!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEMJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEMK">‘Wet down the decks,’ Barak ordered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEML"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEMM">The sailors tossed buckets on long ropes over the side, hauled up water, and soaked the wooden decks.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEMN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEMO">‘Signal the ships behind us,’ Anheg told the bearded sailor standing in the very stern of the ship. The sailor nodded, turned and lifted a large flag attached to a long pole. He began to wave it vigorously at the ships strung out behind them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEMP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEMQ">‘Be careful with that fire!’ Barak shouted to the men clustered around a raised platform filled with gravel and covered with glowing coals. ‘If you set us ablaze, you’ll all have to swim to the Sea of the East.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEMR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEMS">Just to the front of the platform stood three heavy-limbed catapults, cocked and ready.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEMT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEMU">King Anheg squinted ahead at the Malloreans gathered around a dozen or so siege engines standing solidly on the north bank. ‘Better send in your arrowboats now,’ he suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEMV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEN0">Barak grunted and waved his arm in a broad chopping motion to the six narrow boats in his wake. In answer, the lean little boats leaped ahead, cutting through the water. Mounted at the prow of each arrow-boat stood a long-armed catapult armed with a loosely packed bundle of arrows. Aided by the current, the narrow little boats sped past, their oars bending.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEN1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEN2">‘Load the engines!’ Barak roared to the men around the gravel-based fire. ‘And don’t slop any of that tar on my decks.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEN3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEN4">With long iron hooks, the sailors lifted three large earthenware pots out of the coals. The pots contained a seething mixture of tar, pitch, and naptha. They were quickly dipped in tar barrels and then hastily wrapped in naptha-soaked rags. Then they were placed in the baskets of the waiting engines.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEN5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEN6">As the arrow-boats, speeding like greyhounds, swept in close to shore where the Malloreans struggled to aim their catapults, the arrow-bundles were suddenly hurled high into the air by the lashing arms of the Cherek engines. The arrows rose swiftly, then slowed at the top of their arching flight, separating and spreading out as they flew. Then, in a deadly rain, they fell upon the red-tunicked Malloreans.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEN7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEN8">Barak’s ship, trailing just behind the arrow-boats, ran in close to the brush-covered riverbank, and the red-bearded man stood with both of his big hands on the tiller, staring intently at his catapult master, a gray-bearded old sailor with arms like oak stumps. The catapult master was squinting at a line of notches chipped into the railing in front of his engines. Over his head he held a long white baton and he indicated direction by pointing it either to the right or the left. Barak moved his tiller delicately in response to the movements of the baton. Then the baton cut sharply straight down, and Barak locked his tiller in an iron grip. The rags wrapped around the pots leaped into flame as they were touched by waiting torches.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEN9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPENA">‘Shoot!’ the catapult master barked. With a thudding crash, the beams lashed forward, hurling the flaming pots and their deadly contents in a high arch toward the struggling Malloreans and their siege engines. The pots burst open upon impact, spraying fire in front of them. The Mallorean catapults were engulfed in flame.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPENB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPENC">‘Good shooting,’ Anheg noted professionally.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEND"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPENE">‘Child’s play,’ Barak shrugged. ‘A shoreline emplacement isn’t much of a challenge, really.’ He glanced back. The arrow-boats of Greldik’s ship were sweeping in to rake the Malloreans with more arrows, and the catapults on his bearded friend’s decks were cocked and loaded. ‘Malloreans don’t appear to be any brighter than Murgos. Didn’t it ever occur to them that we might shoot back?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPENF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPENG">‘It’s an Angarak failing,’ Anheg replied. ‘It shows up in all their writings. Torak never encouraged creative thinking.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPENH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPENI">Barak gave his cousin a speculative look. ‘You know what I think, Anheg? I think that all that fuss you raised back at Riva – about Ce’Nedra leading the army, I mean – I think that it wasn’t entirely sincere. You’re too intelligent to be so stubborn about something that wasn’t that important.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPENJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPENK">Anheg winked broadly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPENL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPENM">‘No wonder they call you Anheg the sly,’ Barak chuckled. ‘What was it all about?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPENN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPENO">‘It pulled Brand’s teeth.’ The King of Cherek grinned. ‘He’s the one who could have stopped Ce’Nedra cold if I’d given him the chance. Rivans are very conservative, Barak. I sided with Brand and did all the talking. Then when I gave in, he didn’t have any ground left to stand on.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPENP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPENQ">‘You were very convincing. I thought for a while that your reason had slipped.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPENR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPENS">‘Thank you,’ the Cherek King replied with a mock bow. ‘When you’ve got a face like mine, it’s easy for people to think the worst about you. I’ve found that useful from time to time. Here come the Algars.’ He pointed at the hills just behind the burning Mallorean siege engines. A great crowd of horsemen came surging over the hilltops to sweep down like a wolf-pack upon the confounded Malloreans.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPENT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPENU">Anheg sighed then. ‘I’d like to know what’s happening to them back there at Thull Mardu,’ he said. ‘I don’t suppose we’ll ever find out, though.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPENV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEO0">‘Not very likely,’ Barak agreed. ‘We’ll all get sunk eventually, once we get out into the Sea of the East.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEO1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEO2">‘We’ll take a lot of Malloreans with us, though, won’t we, Barak?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEO3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEO4">Barak’s reply was an evil grin.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEO5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEO6">‘I don’t really care much for the notion of drowning,’ Anheg said, making a face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEO7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEO8">‘Maybe you’ll get lucky and catch an arrow in the belly.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEO9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEOA">‘Thanks,’ Anheg said sourly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEOB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEOC">An hour or so later, after three more Angarak positions on the riverbanks had been destroyed, the land along the River Mardu turned marshy, flattening out into a sea of reeds and bending cattails. At Anheg’s orders, a raft piled high with firewood was moored to a dead snag and set afire. Once the blaze was going well, buckets of greenish crystals were hurled into the flames. A thick pillar of green smoke began to climb into the blue sky.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEOD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEOE">‘I hope Rhodar can see that.’ The King of Cherek frowned.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEOF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEOG">‘If he can’t, the Algars will,’ Barak replied. ‘They’ll get word back to him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEOH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEOI">‘I just hope he’s got enough time left to make his retreat.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEOJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEOK">‘Me too,’ Barak said. ‘But as you say, we’ll probably never know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="OPEOL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEOM">King Cho-Hag, Chief of the Clan-Chiefs of Algaria, sat his horse beside King Korodullin of Arendia. The fog was nearly gone now, and only a filmy haze remained. Not far away, the twin sorcerers, Beltira and Belkira, exhausted by their efforts, sat side by side on the ground, their heads bowed and their chests heaving. Cho-Hag shuddered inwardly at the thought of what might have happened if the two saintly old men had not been there. The hideous illusions of the Grolims that had risen from the earth just before the storm had struck terror into the hearts of the bravest warriors. Then the storm, its intensity deafening, had smashed down on the army, and after that had come the choking fog. The two sweet-faced sorcerers, however, had met and overcome each Grolim attack with calm determination. Now the Murgos were coming, and it was time for steel instead of sorcery.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEON"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEOO">‘I’d let them get a little closer,’ Cho-Hag advised in his quiet voice as he and Korodullin watched the veritable sea of Murgos advancing against the emplaced ranks of Drasnian pikemen and Tolnedran legionnaires.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEOP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEOQ">‘Art thou sure of thy strategy, Cho-Hag?’ the young Arendish King asked with a worried frown. ‘It hath ever been the custom of the knights of Mimbre to meet an attack head-on. Thy proposal to charge the flanks puzzles me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEOR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEOS">‘It will kill more Murgos, Korodullin,’ Cho-Hag replied, shifting his weak legs in their stirrups. ‘When your knights charge in from either flank, you’ll cut off whole regiments of the enemy. Then we can grind the ones who’ve been cut off up against the infantry.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEOT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEOU">‘It is passing strange to me to work thus with foot troops,’ Korodullin confessed. ‘I have a vast ignorance of unmounted combat.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEOV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEP0">‘You aren’t alone, my friend,’ Cho-Hag told him. ‘It’s as alien to me as it is to you. It would be unfair of us, though, not to let the foot troops have a </span><span class="italic" aid="OPEP1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEP2">few</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEP3"> Murgos, wouldn’t it? They </span><span class="italic" aid="OPEP4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEP5">did</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEP6"> walk a long way, after all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEP7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEP8">The King of Arendia considered that gravely. He was quite obviously incapable of anything remotely resembling humor. ‘I had not considered that,’ he confessed. “Twould be selfish in the extreme of us to deny them </span><span class="italic" aid="OPEP9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPA">some</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPB"> part in the battle, I must agree. How many Murgos dost thou think would be their fair portion?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEPC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPD">‘Oh, I don’t know,’ Cho-Hag replied with a straight face. ‘A few thousand or so, I imagine. We wouldn’t want to appear stingy – but it doesn’t do to be over generous, either.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEPE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPF">Korodullin sighed. ‘It is a difficult line to walk, King Cho-Hag – this fine division between parsimony and foolish prodigality.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEPG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPH">‘One of the prices of kingship, Korodullin.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEPI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPJ">‘Very true, Cho-Hag, very true.’ The young King of Arendia sighed again and bent all his concentration to the problem of how many of the advancing Murgos he could really afford to give away. ‘Thinkest thou that two Murgos apiece might content those who fight afoot?’ he asked rather hesitantly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEPK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPL">‘Sounds fair to me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEPM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPN">Korodullin smiled then with happy relief. ‘Then that is what we shall allot them,’ he declared. ‘I have not divided up Murgos before, but it is not nearly so difficult as I had imagined.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEPO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPP">King Cho-Hag began to laugh.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="OPEPQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPR">Lady Ariana put her arms about Lelldorin’s shaking shoulders and drew him gently away from the pallet upon which his cousin’s body lay.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEPS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPT">‘Can’t you do </span><span class="italic" aid="OPEPU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEPV">something</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQ0">, Ariana?’ he pleaded, tears streaming down his face. ‘Perhaps a bandage of some sort – and a poultice.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQ1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQ2">‘He is beyond my art, my Lord,’ Ariana replied gently, ‘and I share thy sorrow at his death.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQ3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQ4">‘Don’t say that word, Ariana. Torasin </span><span class="italic" aid="OPEQ5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQ6">can’t</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQ7"> be dead.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQ8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQ9">‘I’m sorry, my Lord,’ she said simply. ‘He is gone, and none of my remedies or skill can bring him back.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQB">‘Polgara can do it,’ Lelldorin declared suddenly, an impossible hope leaping into his eyes. ‘Send for Polgara.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQD">‘I have no-one to send, my Lord,’ Ariana told him, looking around the makeshift tent where she and Taiba and a few others were caring for the wounded. ‘The injured men here command all our attention and care.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQF">‘I’ll go then,’ Lelldorin declared, his eyes still streaming tears. He spun and dashed from the tent.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQH">Ariana sighed mournfully and drew a blanket over Torasin’s pale face. Then she turned back to the wounded men who were being carried in a steady stream into her tent.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQJ">‘Don’t bother yourself with him, my Lady,’ a lean-faced Arendish serf told her as she bent over the body of the man’s companion.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQL">Ariana looked at the thin serf inquiringly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQN">‘He’s dead,’ the serf explained. ‘He took a Mallorean arrow right through the chest.’ He looked down at the dead man’s face. ‘Poor Detton,’ he sighed. ‘He died in my arms. Do you know what his last words were?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQP">Ariana shook her head.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQR">‘He said, “At least I had a good breakfast.” And then he died.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQT">‘Why didst thou bring him here, since thou didst know he was already dead?’ Ariana asked him gently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEQU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEQV">The lean, bitter-faced serf shrugged. ‘I didn’t want to leave him just lying in a muddy ditch like a dead dog,’ he replied. ‘In his whole life, nobody ever treated him as if he mattered at all. He was my friend, and I didn’t want to leave him there like a pile of garbage.’ He laughed a short, bitter laugh. ‘I don’t suppose it matters very much to him, but at least there’s a little bit of dignity here.’ He awkwardly patted the dead man’s shoulder. ‘Sorry, Detton,’ he said, ‘but I guess I’d better go back to the fighting.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPER0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPER1">‘What is thy name, friend?’ Ariana asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPER2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPER3">‘I’m called Lammer, my Lady.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPER4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPER5">‘Is the need for thee in the battle urgent?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPER6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPER7">‘I doubt it, my Lady. I’ve been shooting arrows at the Malloreans. I’m not very good at it, but it’s what I’m supposed to do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPER8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPER9">‘My need for thee is greater, then,’ she declared. ‘I have many wounded here and few hands to help with their care. Despite thy surly exterior, I sense a great compassion in thee. Wilt thou help me?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPERA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPERB">He regarded her for a moment. ‘What do you want me to do?’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPERC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPERD">‘Taiba is boiling cloth for bandages over that fire there,’ she replied. ‘See to the fire first, then thou wilt find a cart just outside with blankets in it. Bring in the blankets, good Lammer. After that I will have other tasks for thee.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPERE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPERF">‘All right,’ Lammer replied laconically, moving toward the fire.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="OPERG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPERH">‘What can we do for her?’ the Princess Ce’Nedra demanded of the misshapen Beldin. The princess was staring intently into Polgara’s pale, unconscious face as the sorceress lay exhausted in the arms of Durnik the smith.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPERI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPERJ">‘Let her sleep,’ Beldin grunted. ‘She’ll be all right in a day or so.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPERK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPERL">‘What’s the matter with her?’ Durnik asked in a worried voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPERM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPERN">‘She’s exhausted,’ Beldin snapped. ‘Isn’t that obvious?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPERO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPERP">‘Just from raising a breeze? I’ve seen her do things that looked a lot harder.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPERQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPERR">‘You don’t have the faintest idea of what you’re talking about, blacksmith,’ Beldin growled. The hunch-backed sorcerer was himself pale and shaking. ‘When you start tampering with the weather, you’re putting your hands on the most powerful forces in the world. I’d rather try to stop a tide or uproot a mountain than stir up a breeze in dead air.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPERS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPERT">‘The Grolims brought in that storm,’ Durnik said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPERU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPERV">‘The air was already moving. Dead-calm air is altogether different. Do you have the remotest idea of how much air you’ve got to move to stir even the faintest breath of air? Do you know what kind of pressures are involved – how much all that air </span><span class="italic" aid="OPES0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPES1">weighs</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPES2">?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPES3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPES4">‘Air doesn’t weigh anything,’ Ce’Nedra protested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPES5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPES6">‘Really?’ Beldin replied with heavy sarcasm. ‘I’m so glad you told me. Would the two of you shut up and let me get my breath?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPES7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPES8">‘But how is it that she collapsed and you didn’t?’ Ce’Nedra protested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPES9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPESA">‘I’m stronger than she is,’ Beldin replied, ‘and more vicious. Pol throws her whole heart into things when she gets excited. She always did. She pushed beyond her strength, and it exhausted her.’ The twisted little man straightened, shook himself like a dog coming out of water and looked around, his face bleak. ‘I’ve got work to do,’ he said. ‘I </span><span class="italic" aid="OPESB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPESC">think</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPESD"> we’ve pretty much worn out the Mallorean Grolims, but I’d better keep an eye on them, just to be safe. You two stay here with Pol – and keep an eye on that child.’ He pointed at Errand, who stood on the sandy beach with his small face very serious.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPESE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPESF">Then Beldin crouched, shimmering already into the form of a hawk, and launched himself into the air almost before his feathers were fully formed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPESG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPESH">Ce’Nedra stared after him as he spiraled upward over the battlefield and then turned her attention back to the unconscious Polgara.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="OPESI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPESJ">The charge of Korodullin’s Mimbrate knights came at the last possible moment. Like two great scythes, the armored men on their massive chargers sliced in at a thundering gallop from the flanks with their lances leveled and cut through the horde of Murgos rushing toward the waiting pikemen and legionnaires. The results were devastating. The air was filled with screams and the sounds of steel striking steel with stunning impact. In the wake of the charge lay a path of slaughtered Murgos, a trail of human wreckage a hundred yards wide.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPESK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPESL">King Cho-Hag, sitting on his horse on a hilltop some distance to the west, nodded his approval as he watched the carnage. ‘Good,’ he said finally. He looked around at the eager faces of the Algar clansmen clustered around him. ‘All right, my children,’ he said calmly, ‘let’s go cut up the Murgo reserves.’ And he led them at a gallop as they poured down off the hill, smoothly swung around the outer flanks of the tightly packed assault forces and then slashed into the unprepared Murgo units bringing up the rear.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPESM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPESN">The slash-and-run tactics of the clans of the Algars left heaps of sabred dead in their wake as they darted in and out of the milling confusion of terrified Murgos. King Cho-Hag himself led several charges, and his skill with the sabre, which was legendary in Algaria, filled his followers with an awed pride as they watched his whiplike blows raining down on Murgo heads and shoulders. The whole thrust of Algar strategy was based on speed – a sudden dash on a fast horse and a series of lightninglike sabre slashes, and then out before the enemy could gather his wits. King Cho-Hag’s sabre arm was the fastest in Algaria.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPESO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPESP">‘My King!’ one of his men shouted, pointing toward the center of several close-packed Murgo regiments milling about in a shallow valley a few hundred yards away. ‘There’s the black banner!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPESQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPESR">King Cho-Hag’s eyes suddenly gleamed as a wild hope surged through him. ‘Bring my banner to the front!’ he roared, and the clansman who carried the burgundy-and-white banner of the Chief of the Clan-Chiefs galloped forward with the standard streaming above his head. ‘Let’s go, my children!’ Hag shouted and drove his horse directly at the Murgos in the valley. With sabre raised, the crippled King of the Algars led his men down into the Murgo horde. His warriors slashed to the right and to the left, but Cho-Hag plunged directly at the center, his eyes fixed on the black banner of Taur Urgas, King of the Murgos.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPESS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEST">And then, in the midst of the household guard, Cho-Hag saw the blood-red mail of Taur Urgas himself. Cho-Hag raised his bloody sabre and shouted a ringing challenge. ‘Stand and fight, you Murgo dog!’ he roared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPESU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPESV">Startled by that shout, Taur Urgas wheeled his horse to stare incredulously at the charging King of Algaria. His eyes suddenly bulged with the fervid light of insanity, and his lips, foam-flecked, drew back in a snarl of hatred. ‘Let him come!’ he grated. ‘Clear the way for him!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPET0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPET1">The startled members of his personal guard stared at him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPET2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPET3">‘Make way for the King of Algaria!’ Taur Urgas shrieked. ‘He is mine!’ And the Murgo troops melted out of Cho-Hag’s path.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPET4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPET5">The Algar King reined in his horse. ‘And so it’s finally come, Taur Urgas,’ he said coldly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPET6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPET7">‘It has indeed, Cho-Hag,’ Taur Urgas replied. ‘I’ve waited for this moment for years.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPET8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPET9">‘If I’d known you were waiting, I’d have come sooner.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPETA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPETB">‘Today is your last day, Cho-Hag.’ The Murgo King’s eyes were completely mad now, and foam drooled from the corners of his mouth.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPETC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPETD">‘Do you plan to fight with threats and hollow words, Taur Urgas? Or have you forgotten how to draw your sword?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPETE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPETF">With an insane shriek, Taur Urgas ripped his broadbladed sword from its scabbard and drove his black horse toward the Algar King. ‘Die!’ he howled, slashing at the air even as he charged. ‘Die, Cho-Hag!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPETG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPETH">It was not a duel, for there were proprieties in a duel. The two kings hacked at each other with an elemental brutality, thousands of years of pent-up hatred boiling in their blood. Taur Urgas, totally mad now, sobbed and gibbered as he swung his heavy sword at his enemy. Cho-Hag, cold as ice and with an arm as fast as the flickering tongue of a snake, slid the crushing Murgo blows aside, catching them on his sliding sabre and flicking his blade like a whip, its edge biting again and again into the shoulders and face of the King of the Murgos.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPETI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPETJ">The two armies, stunned by the savagery of the encounter, recoiled and gave the mounted kings room for their deadly struggle.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPETK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPETL">Frothing obscenities, Taur Urgas hacked insanely at the elusive form of his foe, but Cho-Hag, colder yet, feinted and parried and flicked his whistling sabre at the Murgo’s bleeding face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPETM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPETN">Finally, driven past even what few traces of reason were left to him, Taur Urgas hurled his horse directly at Cho-Hag with a wild animal scream. Standing in his stirrups, he grasped his sword hilt in both hands, raising it like an axe to smash his enemy for ever. But Cho-Hag danced his horse to one side and thrust with all his strength, even as Taur Urgas began his massive blow. With a steely rasp, his sabre ran through the Murgo’s blood-red mail and through the tensed body, to emerge dripping from his back.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPETO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPETP">Unaware in his madness that he had just received a mortal wound, Taur Urgas raised his sword again, but the strength drained from his arms and the sword fell from his grasp. With stunned disbelief, he gaped at the sabre emerging from his chest, and a bloody froth burst from his mouth. He lifted his hands like claws as if to tear away the face of his enemy, but Cho-Hag contemptuously slapped his hands away, even as he pulled his slender, curved blade out of the Murgo’s body with a slithering whistle.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPETQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPETR">‘And so it ends, Taur Urgas,’ he declared in an icy voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPETS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPETT">‘No!’ Taur Urgas croaked, trying to pull a heavy dagger from his belt.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPETU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPETV">Cho-Hag watched his feeble efforts coldly. Dark blood suddenly spurted from the open mouth of the Murgo King, and he toppled weakly from his saddle. Struggling, coughing blood, Taur Urgas lurched to his feet, gurgling curses at the man who had just killed him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEU0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEU1">‘Good fight, though,’ Cho-Hag told him with a bleak smile, and then he turned to ride away.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEU2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEU3">Taur Urgas fell, clawing at the turf in impotent rage. ‘Come back and fight,’ he sobbed. ‘Come back.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEU4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEU5">Cho-Hag glanced over his shoulder. ‘Sorry, your Majesty,’ he replied, ‘but I have pressing business elsewhere. I’m sure you understand.’ And with that he began to ride away.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEU6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEU7">‘Come back!’ Taur Urgas wailed, belching blood and curses and digging his fingers into the earth. ‘Come back!’ Then he collapsed facedown in the bloody grass. ‘Come back and fight, Cho-Hag!’ he gasped weakly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEU8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEU9">The last that Cho-Hag saw of him, the dying King of Cthol Murgos was biting at the sod and clawing at the earth with trembling fingers.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEUA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEUB">A vast moan shuddered through the tight-packed regiments of the Murgos, and a sudden cheer rose from the ranks of the Algars as Cho-Hag, victorious, rode back to join the army.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="OPEUC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEUD">‘They’re coming again,’ General Varana announced with cool professionalism as he watched the waves of oncoming Malloreans.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEUE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEUF">‘Where </span><span class="italic" aid="OPEUG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEUH">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEUI"> that signal?’ Rhodar demanded, staring intently downriver. ‘What’s Anheg doing down there?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEUJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEUK">The front ranks of the Mallorean assault struck with a resounding crash. The Drasnian pikemen began to thrust with their long, wide-bladed spears, wreaking havoc among the red-garbed attackers, and the legions raised their shields in the interlocked position that presented a solid wall against which the Malloreans beat futilely. Upon a sharp, barked command, the legionnaires turned their shields slightly and each man thrust his lance out through the opening between his shield and the next. The Tolnedran lances were not as long as the Drasnian pikes but they were long enough. A huge, shuddering cry went through the front ranks of the Malloreans, and they fell in heaps beneath the feet of the men behind.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEUL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEUM">‘Are they going to break through?’ Rhodar puffed. Even though he was not directly involved in the fighting, the Drasnian King began to pant at each Mallorean charge.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEUN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEUO">Varana carefully assessed the strength of the assault. ‘No,’ he concluded, ‘not this time. Have you worked out how you’re going to make your withdrawal? It’s a little difficult to pull back when your troops are engaged.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEUP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEUQ">‘That’s why I’m saving the Mimbrates,’ Rhodar replied. ‘They’re resting their horses now for one last charge. As soon as we get the signal from Anheg, Mandorallen and his men will shove the Malloreans back, and the rest of us will run like rabbits.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEUR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEUS">‘The charge will only hold them back for so long,’ Varana advised, ‘and then they’ll come after you again.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEUT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEUU">‘We’ll form up again upriver a ways,’ Rhodar said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEUV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEV0">‘It’s going to take a long time to get back to the escarpment if you’re going to have to stop and fight every half-mile or so,’ Varana told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEV1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEV2">‘I know that,’ Rhodar snapped peevishly. ‘Have you got any better ideas?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEV3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEV4">‘No,’ Varana replied. ‘I was just pointing it out, that’s all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEV5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEV6">‘Where </span><span class="italic" aid="OPEV7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEV8">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEV9"> that signal?’ Rhodar demanded again.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="OPEVA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEVB">On a quiet hillside some distance from the struggle taking place on the north bank, the simpleminded serf boy from the Arendish forest was playing his flute. His melody was mournful, but even in its sadness, it soared to the sky. The boy did not understand the fighting and he had wandered away unnoticed. Now he sat alone on the grassy hillside in the warm, midmorning sunlight with his entire soul pouring out of his flute.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEVC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEVD">The Mallorean soldier who was creeping up behind him with drawn sword had no ear for music. He did not know – or care – that the song the boy played was the most beautiful song any man had ever heard.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEVE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEVF">The song ended very suddenly, never to begin again.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="OPEVG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEVH">The stream of casualties being carried to Ariana’s makeshift hospital grew heavier, and the overtaxed Mimbrate girl was soon forced into making some cruel decisions. Only those men with some chance of survival could be treated. The mortally hurt were quickly given a drink of a bitter-tasting potion of herbs that would ease their pain and then were left to die. Each such decision wrung Ariana’s heart, and she worked with tears standing in her eyes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEVI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEVJ">And then Brand, the Rivan Warder, entered the tent with a stricken face. The big Rivan’s mail shirt was blood-spattered, and there were savage sword cuts along the edge of his broad, round shield. Behind him, three of his sons bore the limp, bleeding form of their younger brother, Olban.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEVK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEVL">‘Can you see to him?’ Brand asked Ariana hoarsely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEVM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEVN">A single glance, however, told the blond girl that the wound in Olban’s chest was mortal. ‘I can make him comfortable,’ she replied a bit evasively. She quickly knelt beside the bleeding young man, lifted his head, and held a cup to his lips.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEVO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEVP">‘Father,’ Olban said weakly after he had drunk, ‘I have something I have to tell you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEVQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEVR">‘Time enough for that later,’ Brand told him gruffly, ‘after you’re better.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEVS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEVT">‘I’m not going to get better, father,’ Olban said in a voice scarcely more than a whisper.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPEVU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPEVV">‘Nonsense,’ Brand told him, but there was no conviction in his voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF00"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF01">‘There’s not much time, father,’ Olban said, coughing weakly. ‘Please listen.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF02"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF03">‘Very well, Olban,’ the Warder said, leaning forward to catch his son’s words.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF04"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF05">‘At Riva – after Belgarion came – I was humiliated because you had been deposed. I couldn’t bear it, father.’ Olban coughed again, and a bloody froth came to his lips.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF06"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF07">‘You should have known me better than that, Olban,’ Brand said gently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF08"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF09">‘I do – now.’ Olban sighed. ‘But I was young and proud, and Belgarion – a nobody from Sendaria – had pushed you from your rightful place.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF0A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF0B">‘It wasn’t my place to begin with, Olban,’ Brand told him. ‘It was his. Belgarion’s the Rivan King. That has nothing to do with position or place. It’s a duty – and it’s his, not mine.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF0C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF0D">‘I hated him,’ Olban whispered. ‘I began to follow him every place. Wherever he went, I wasn’t far behind him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF0E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF0F">‘What for?’ Brand asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF0G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF0H">‘At first I didn’t know. Then one day he came out of the throne room wearing his robe and crown. He seemed so puffed-up with his own importance – as if he really </span><span class="italic" aid="OPF0I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF0J">was</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF0K"> a king instead of just a common Sendarian scullion. Then I knew what I had to do. I took my dagger and I threw it at his back.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF0L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF0M">Brand’s face suddenly froze.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF0N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF0O">‘For a long time after that, I tried to avoid him,’ Olban continued. ‘I knew that what I had done was wrong – even as the dagger left my fingers. I thought that if I stayed away from him, he’d never find out that I was the one who’d tried to kill him. But he has powers, father. He has ways of knowing things no man could possibly know. He sought me out one day and gave me back the dagger I’d thrown at him and he told me that I should never tell anyone what I’d done. He did that for you, father – to keep my disgrace from you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF0P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF0Q">Grim-faced, Brand rose to his feet. ‘Come,’ he said to his other three sons. ‘We have fighting to do – and no time to waste on traitors.’ Quite deliberately he turned his back on his dying son.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF0R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF0S">‘I tried to repay his mercy, father,’ Olban pleaded. ‘I pledged my life to protecting his queen. Doesn’t that count for anything?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF0T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF0U">Brand’s face was stony, and he kept his back turned in grim silence.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF0V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF10">‘Belgarion forgave me, father. Can’t you find it in your heart to forgive me too?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF11"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF12">‘No,’ Brand said harshly, ‘I cannot.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF13"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF14">‘Please, father,’ Olban begged. ‘Don’t you have one tear for me?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF15"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF16">‘Not one,’ Brand told him, but Ariana saw that his words were a lie. The grim, gray-clad man’s eyes were full, but his face remained granitelike. Without another word, he strode from the tent.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF17"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF18">Wordlessly, each of Olban’s brothers clasped his hand in turn, and then they left to follow their father.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF19"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF1A">Olban wept quietly for a time, but then his growing weakness and the drug Ariana had given him drained away his grief. He lay, half-dozing on his pallet for a time, then struggled to raise himself and beckoned to the Mimbrate girl. She knelt beside him, supporting him with one arm about his shoulders and her head bent to catch his faltering words. ‘Please,’ he whispered. ‘Please tell her Majesty what I said to my father – and tell her how sorry I was.’ And then his head fell forward against Ariana, and he quietly died in her arms.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF1B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF1C">Ariana had no time to mourn, for precisely then three Sendars carried Colonel Brendig into her tent. The colonel’s left arm was mangled beyond all hope of repair.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF1D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF1E">‘We were bringing down the bridge that crosses to the city,’ one of the Sendars reported tersely. ‘There was a support that wouldn’t give way, so the colonel went down himself to chop it away. When it finally broke, the timbers of the bridge fell on him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF1F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF1G">Ariana gravely examined Brendig’s shattered arm. ‘I fear there is no recourse, my Lord,’ she told him. ‘The arm will have to come off, lest it mortify and carry thy life away with it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF1H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF1I">Brendig nodded soberly. ‘That’s about what I’d expected,’ he replied. ‘I suppose we’d better get on with it, then.’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="OPF1J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF1K">‘There!’ King Rhodar shouted, pointing downriver. ‘The smoke – it’s green! That’s the signal. We can start the retreat now.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="OPF1L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="OPF1M">General Varana, however, was staring at the riverbank upstream. ‘It’s too late, I’m afraid, your Majesty,’ he said quietly. ‘A column of Malloreans and Nadraks have just reached the river to the west of us. It very much looks as if we’ve been cut off.’</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_26" aid="OPF1N"></div>
