<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos702154" aid="PNV61"><span class="calibre5" aid="PNV62"><span class="italic" aid="PNV63"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV64">Chapter Eighteen</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="PNV65"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV66">The news of the death of Taur Urgas spread through the Murgo army in a vast groan, and the heart went out of the black-robed troops. Taur Urgas had been feared by his men, but his savage madness had lent them all a peculiar sense that they were invincible. They had felt somehow that nothing could stand in his path, and that they, as the instruments of his brutal will, shared in some measure his apparent invulnerability. But with his death, each Murgo became aware with a sudden cold touch of fear that he also could die, and the assault on the armies of the west along the south bank faltered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV67"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV68">King Cho-Hag watched the crumbling of the Murgo resolve with a certain grim satisfaction, then rode down to the lines of infantry and the milling Mimbrate knights to confer with the other leaders. King Fulrach strode forward from the ranks of his Sendars. The dumpy, brown-bearded monarch looked almost comical in his burnished breastplate, but his sword showed signs of recent use, and his helmet was dented in a couple of places, mute evidence that the King of Sendaria had participated in the fight.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV69"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6A">‘Have you seen Anheg’s signal yet?’ Fulrach demanded as he approached.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV6B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6C">Cho-Hag shook his head. ‘It should come any time now, though,’ he replied. ‘We’d better make some plans. Have you seen Korodullin?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV6D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6E">‘The physicians are working on him,’ Fulrach said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV6F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6G">‘Is he hurt?’ Cho-Hag was startled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV6H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6I">‘I don’t think it’s too serious. He went to help his friend, the Baron of Vo Ebor, and a Murgo hit him in the head with a mace. His helmet absorbed most of the blow. He’s bleeding out of the ears a bit, but the physicians say he’ll recover. The baron’s in worse shape, though.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV6J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6K">‘Who’s in charge of the Mimbrates, then?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV6L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6M">‘Sir Andorig. He’s a good man in a fight, but his understanding is a bit limited.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV6N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6O">Cho-Hag laughed shortly. ‘You’ve just described most of Arendia, my friend. They’re </span><span class="italic" aid="PNV6P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6Q">all</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6R"> good in a fight, and they </span><span class="italic" aid="PNV6S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6T">all</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV6U"> have limited understanding.’ Carefully he dismounted, holding onto his saddle as his weak legs nearly buckled. ‘We can make our decisions without Andorig’s help, I think.’ He looked at the retreating Murgos. ‘As soon as we see Anheg’s signal, I think we’re going to want to get out of here in a hurry. The Murgos are demoralized right now, but they’ll probably stiffen up again as soon as the shock wears off.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV6V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV70">Fulrach nodded. ‘Did you really kill Taur Urgas in a duel?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV71"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV72">Cho-Hag nodded. ‘It wasn’t really all that much of a duel. He was raving when he came at me and didn’t even try to defend himself. When Anheg signals, we’ll have the Mimbrates charge the Murgo front. The Murgos will probably break and run. I’ll follow after them with my clansmen to hurry them along. That should give you and your foot troops time to start upriver. Andorig and I’ll keep the Murgos off your back until you get clear. How does that sound?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV73"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV74">King Fulrach nodded. ‘It sounds workable,’ he agreed. ‘Do you think they’ll try to follow us?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV75"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV76">Cho-Hag grinned. ‘I’ll encourage them not to,’ he replied. ‘Have you got any idea of what’s going on across the river?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV77"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV78">‘It’s hard to say, but things don’t look very good.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV79"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV7A">‘Can you think of any way we can send them help?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV7B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV7C">‘Not on short notice,’ Fulrach answered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV7D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV7E">‘Neither can I,’ Cho-Hag said. He began to pull himself back up into his saddle. ‘I’ll go give Andorig his instructions. Keep your eyes open for Anheg’s signal.’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="PNV7F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV7G">‘Belgarath!’ Ce’Nedra called out silently, her hand tightly clasped about the amulet at her throat. ‘Belgarath, can you hear me?’ She was standing several yards away from where Durnik was trying to make the unconscious Polgara as comfortable as possible. The princess had her eyes tightly closed and she was putting every ounce of concentration into casting her thought to the sky, reaching out with all her heart toward the ancient sorcerer.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV7H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV7I">‘Ce’Nedra?’ The old man’s voice was as clear as if he were standing beside her. ‘What are you doing? Where’s Polgara?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV7J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV7K">‘Oh, Belgarath!’ The princess almost sobbed with relief. ‘Help us. Lady Polgara’s unconscious, and the Malloreans are attacking again. We’re being slaughtered, Belgarath. Help us.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV7L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV7M">‘Slow down,’ he commanded brusquely. ‘What happened to Pol? Where are you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV7N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV7O">‘We’re at Thull Mardu,’ Ce’Nedra replied. ‘We had to take the city so that the Cherek fleet could go on down the river. The Malloreans and the Murgos crept up on us. They’ve been attacking since early this morning.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV7P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV7Q">Belgarath started to swear. ‘What’s wrong with Pol?’ he demanded harshly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV7R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV7S">‘The Grolims brought in an awful storm, and then there was fog. Lady Polgara and Beldin made the wind blow, and then she just collapsed. Beldin said that she exhausted herself and that we have to let her sleep.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV7T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV7U">‘Where’s Beldin?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV7V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV80">‘He said that he had to keep an eye on the Grolims. Can you help us?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV81"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV82">‘Ce’Nedra, I’m a thousand leagues away from you. Garion, Silk, and I are in Mallorea – practically on Torak’s doorstep. If I so much as raise my hand, it will wake him, and Garion’s not ready to meet him yet.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV83"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV84">‘We’re doomed, then,’ Ce’Nedra wailed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV85"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV86">‘Stop that,’ he snapped. ‘This isn’t the time for hysterics. You’re going to have to wake Polgara.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV87"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV88">‘We’ve tried – and Beldin says that we’ve got to let her rest.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV89"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV8A">‘She can rest later,’ Belgarath retorted. ‘Is that bag she always carries somewhere about – the one she keeps all those herbs in?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV8B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV8C">‘I – I think so. Durnik was carrying it a little while ago.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV8D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV8E">‘Durnik’s with you? Good. Now listen, and listen carefully. Get the bag and open it. What you want will be in a silk pouch. Don’t open any jars or bottles. She keeps her poisons in those. In one of the silk bags you’ll find a yellow-colored powder. It has a very acrid odor to it. Put a spoonful or so of that powder into a pot of boiling water. Put the pot beside Pol’s head and cover her face with a cloak so she has to breathe the fumes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV8F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV8G">‘What will that do?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV8H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV8I">‘It will wake her up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV8J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV8K">‘Are you sure?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV8L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV8M">‘Don’t argue with me, Ce’Nedra. She’ll wake up, believe me. Those fumes would wake up a dead stick. As soon as she’s awake, she’ll know what to do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV8N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV8O">Ce’Nedra hesitated. ‘Is Garion there?’ she blurted finally.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV8P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV8Q">‘He’s asleep. We had a rough time last night.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV8R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV8S">‘When he wakes up, tell him that I love him.’ She said it very fast, as if afraid that if she thought about it at all, she wouldn’t be able to say it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV8T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV8U">‘Why confuse him?’ the old man asked her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV8V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV90">‘Belgarath!’ Ce’Nedra’s voice was stricken.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV91"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV92">‘I was teasing. I’ll tell him. Now get to work – and don’t do this any more. I’m trying to sneak up on Torak, and it’s a little hard to sneak when you’re shouting at somebody a thousand leagues away.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV93"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV94">‘We aren’t shouting.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV95"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV96">‘Oh yes we are – it’s a special kind of shouting, but it’s shouting all the same. Now take your hand off that amulet and get to work.’ And then his voice was gone.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV97"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV98">Durnik, of course, would never understand, so Ce’Nedra did what was necessary by herself. She rummaged around until she found a small pot. She filled it with water and set it on the small fire the smith had built the night before. Then she opened Polgara’s herb bag. The blond child, Errand, stood at her side, watching her curiously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV99"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV9A">‘What are you doing, Princess?’ Durnik asked, still hovering anxiously over the sleeping Polgara.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV9B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV9C">‘I’m fixing something to make her rest easier,’ Ce’Nedra lied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV9D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV9E">‘Are you sure you know what you’re doing? Some of those are very dangerous.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV9F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV9G">‘I know which one I’m looking for,’ she replied. ‘Trust me, Durnik.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV9H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV9I">The powder she finally located was so acrid that it made her eyes water. She carefully measured out a bit of it and dumped it into the pot. The steaming fumes were awful, and the princess kept her face averted as she carried the pot to where Polgara lay. She set the pot beside the lady’s pale, sleeping face and then laid a cloak across her. ‘Give me a stick,’ the princess said to the smith.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV9J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV9K">Durnik, his face dubious, handed her a broken-off arrow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV9L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV9M">Ce’Nedra carefully propped up the cloak, making a small tent over the pot and Polgara’s face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV9N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV9O">‘What now?’ Durnik asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV9P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV9Q">‘Now we wait,’ Ce’Nedra told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV9R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV9S">Then, coming from the direction of the battle, a group of Sendarian soldiers, evidently wounded, appeared at the top of the grassy bank surrounding the secluded little beach. Their jerkins all had bloodstains on them, and several of the men wore bandages. Unlike most of the wounded who had already passed that morning, however, these men still carried their weapons.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV9T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNV9U">Under the tented cloak, Polgara began to cough.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNV9V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVA0">‘What have you done?’ Durnik cried, snatching the cloak away.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVA1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVA2">‘It was necessary,’ Ce’Nedra replied. ‘I talked with Belgarath. He told me that I had to wake her up – and how to do it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVA3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVA4">‘You’ll hurt her,’ Durnik accused. With sudden, uncharacteristic anger, he kicked the fuming pot, sending it rolling down the beach toward the water’s edge.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVA5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVA6">Polgara’s eyelids were fluttering as she continued to cough. When she opened her eyes, however, her look was blank, uncomprehending.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVA7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVA8">‘Can you spare us some water?’ one of the wounded Sendars asked as the group of men approached.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVA9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVAA">‘There’s a whole river right there,’ Ce’Nedra replied absently, pointing even as she intently stared into Polgara’s eyes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVAB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVAC">Durnik, however, gave the men a startled look, then suddenly reached for his sword.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVAD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVAE">But the men in Sendarian jerkins had jumped down from the bank and were already upon them. It took three of them to disarm the powerful smith and to hold his arms.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVAF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVAG">‘You’re not Sendars,’ Durnik exclaimed, struggling with his captors.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVAH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVAI">‘How clever of you to notice,’ one of them replied in an accent so guttural that it was almost unintelligible. Another of them drew his sword and stood over the dazed Polgara. ‘Stop fighting, friend,’ he told Durnik with an ugly smirk, ‘or I’ll kill this woman.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVAJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVAK">‘Who are you?’ Ce’Nedra demanded indignantly. ‘What do you think you’re doing?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVAL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVAM">‘Actually, we’re members of the Imperial Elite Guard,’ the man with the sword answered urbanely. ‘And we’re here, your Highness, to extend to you the invitation of his Imperial Majesty ’Zakath, Emperor of Mallorea. His Majesty requests the honor of your presence in his pavilion.’ His face hardened, and he looked at his men. ‘Bring them,’ he ordered. ‘Let’s get out of here before someone comes along and starts asking questions.’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="PNVAN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVAO">‘They’re digging in,’ Hettar reported to King Rhodar, gesturing toward the west and their now-blocked escape route. ‘They’ve already got a trenchline running from the river for about a half a mile.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVAP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVAQ">‘Is there any chance of going around them?’ Rhodar asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVAR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVAS">Hettar shook his head. ‘That whole flank’s seething with Nadraks.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVAT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVAU">‘We’ll have to go through them, then,’ the King of Drasnia decided.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVAV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVB0">‘I can’t very well attack trenches with cavalry,’ Hettar pointed out.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVB1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVB2">‘We’ll storm them with the infantry units,’ Rhodar declared. ‘We’ll have a certain advantage. The Asturian bows have a longer range than the short ones the Malloreans use. We’ll move the archers to the front as we advance. They can rake the trenches and then harass the Mallorean archers behind the lines. The pikemen will go in first.’ The sweating fat man looked at General Varana. ‘Can your legionnaires clear the trenches once we open a hole for you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVB3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVB4">Varana nodded. ‘We train extensively for trench fighting,’ he replied confidently. ‘We’ll clear the trenches.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVB5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVB6">‘We’ll bring the wounded with the main force,’ Rhodar said. ‘Somebody locate Polgara and the princess. It’s time to leave.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVB7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVB8">‘What task hast thou for Lord Hettar and me?’ Mandorallen inquired. The great knight’s armor showed a number of dents, but he spoke as calmly as if he had not spent the entire morning involved in heavy fighting.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVB9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBA">‘I want you and your knights to hold the rear,’ Rhodar told him. ‘Keep that army out there off my back.’ He turned to Hettar. ‘And I want you and your clansmen to go to work on the Nadraks. I don’t want them to come swarming in while we’re working in the trenches.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVBB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBC">‘It’s a desperate move, King Rhodar,’ General Varana said seriously. ‘Attacking even hasty fortifications is always costly, and you’re going to do it with another army coming at you from the rear. If your attack is beaten back, you’ll be caught between two superior forces. They’ll grind you to dogmeat right on the spot.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVBD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBE">‘I know,’ Rhodar admitted glumly, ‘but our only hope of escape is breaking through those lines that have us blocked off. We’ve </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVBF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBG">got</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBH"> to get back upriver. Tell your men that we </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVBI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBJ">have</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBK"> to take those trenches on the first charge. Otherwise, we’re all going to die right here. All right, gentlemen, good luck.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVBL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBM">Once again Mandorallen led his steel-clad knights in their fearsome charge, and once again the attacking Malloreans recoiled, driven back by the dreadful shock as the mounted men of Mimbre struck their front ranks. This time, however, the pikemen and legionnaires, as soon as they were disengaged from the enemy, turned sharply to the left and, at a jingling trot, abandoned their positions to follow the Sendars and Asturians who were already withdrawing from the field toward the west.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVBN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBO">The delaying action of the Mimbrate knights was costly. Riderless horses galloped wildly about the battlefield, quite frequently adding to the havoc by trampling through the Mallorean ranks. Here and there among the red tunics that carpeted the field lay the single gleaming form of a fallen knight. Again and again the Mimbrates hurled themselves against the advancing red tide, slowing the Malloreans, but not quite able to stop them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVBP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBQ">‘It’s going to be tight, your Majesty,’ General Varana advised as he and King Rhodar rode toward the hastily drawn lines blocking their escape. ‘Even if we break through, the bulk of the Mallorean forces are going to be hot on our heels.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVBR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBS">‘You’ve got a great talent for the obvious, General,’ Rhodar replied. ‘As soon as we get through, we’ll put the archers at the rear and let the Malloreans march through a rain of arrows. That will hold them back.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVBT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVBU">‘Until the archers run out of arrows,’ Varana added.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVBV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVC0">‘After we break through, I’ll send the Algars on ahead. Fulrach’s got whole wagonloads of arrows at the rapids.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVC1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVC2">‘Which is two days march ahead.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVC3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVC4">‘Do you always look at the dark side of things?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVC5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVC6">‘Just trying to anticipate, your Majesty.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVC7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVC8">‘Would you mind anticipating someplace else?’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="PNVC9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVCA">The Algars had moved out to the right flank of the retreating army and were gathering in their characteristic small bands, preparing to charge the Nadraks drawn up on the hills above the river. Hettar, his scalp lock streaming, moved forward at a steady lope, his sabre drawn and his eyes like flint. The Nadraks appeared at first to be awaiting his charge, but then, amazingly, they turned away and rode rapidly toward the river.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVCB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVCC">From the midst of that sudden surge, a half-dozen men riding under the Nadrak banner swerved out toward the advancing Algars. One of the riders was waving a short stick with a white rag tied to it. The group reined in sharply about a hundred yards in front of Hettar’s horse.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVCD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVCE">‘I’ve got to talk to Rhodar,’ one of the Nadraks bellowed in a shrill voice. He was a tall, emaciated man with a pock-marked face and a scraggly beard, but on his head he wore a crown.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVCF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVCG">‘Is this some trick?’ Hettar shouted back.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVCH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVCI">‘Of course it is, you jackass,’ the scrawny man replied. ‘But it’s not on you this time. Get me to Rhodar at once.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVCJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVCK">‘Keep an eye on them,’ Hettar told a nearby Clan-Chief, pointing at the Nadrak forces now streaming toward the Mallorean trenches lying in the path of the retreating army. ‘I’ll take this maniac to see King Rhodar.’ He turned and led the group of Nadrak warriors toward the advancing infantry.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVCL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVCM">‘Rhodar!’ the thin man wearing the crown shrieked as they approached the Drasnian King. ‘Don’t you ever answer your mail?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVCN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVCO">‘What are you doing, Drosta?’ King Rhodar shouted back.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVCP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVCQ">‘I’m changing sides, Rhodar,’ King Drosta lek Thun replied with an almost hysterical laugh. ‘I’m joining forces with you. I’ve been in touch with your queen for weeks. Didn’t you get her messages?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVCR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVCS">‘I thought you were playing games.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVCT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVCU">‘Naturally I’m playing games.’ The Nadrak King giggled. ‘I’ve always got something up my sleeve. Right now my army’s opening an escape route for you. You </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVCV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVD0">do</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVD1"> want to escape, don’t you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVD2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVD3">‘Of course I do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVD4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVD5">‘So do I. My troops will butcher the Malloreans in those trenches, and then we can all make a run for it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVD6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVD7">‘I don’t trust you, Drosta,’ Rhodar said bluntly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVD8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVD9">‘Rhodar,’ Drosta said in mock chagrin, ‘how can you say that to an old friend?’ He giggled again, his voice shrill and nervous.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVDA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVDB">‘I want to know why you’re changing sides in the middle of a battle – particularly when your side’s winning.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVDC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVDD">‘Rhodar, my kingdom’s awash with Malloreans. If I don’t help you to defeat them, ‘Zakath will simply absorb Gar og Nadrak. It’s much too long and involved to talk about now. Will you accept my aid?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVDE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVDF">‘I’ll take all the help I can get.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVDG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVDH">‘Good. Maybe later we can get drunk together and talk things over, but for right now, let’s get out of here before ‘Zakath hears about this and comes after me personally.’ The King of Gar og Nadrak laughed again, the same shrill, almost hysterical laugh as before. ‘I did it, Rhodar,’ he exulted. ‘I actually betrayed ’Zakath of Mallorea and got away with it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVDI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVDJ">‘You haven’t gotten away with it yet, Drosta,’ Rhodar told him dryly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVDK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVDL">‘I will if we run fast enough, Rhodar, and right now I </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVDM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVDN">really</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVDO"> feel like running.’</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="PNVDP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVDQ">‘Zakath, dread Emperor of boundless Mallorea, was a man of medium height with glossy black hair and a pale, olive-tinged complexion. His features were regular, even handsome, but his eyes were haunted by a profound melancholy. He appeared to be about thirty-five years old, and he wore a plain linen robe with no ornament or decoration upon it to indicate his exalted rank.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVDR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVDS">His pavilion stood in the center of the camp of the Malloreans, a vast sea of tents standing on the plains of Mishrak ac Thull. The earthen floor of the pavilion was covered with priceless Mallorean carpets, and the polished tables and chairs were inlaid with gold and with mother of pearl. Candles filled the pavilion with glowing light. Somewhere nearby, a small group of musicians played subdued melodies set in a minor key.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVDT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVDU">The Emperor’s only companion was a half-grown cat, a common, mackerel-striped tabby with that gangling, long-legged awkwardness of the adolescent feline. While ‘Zakath watched with a sort of sad-eyed amusement, the young cat stalked a scrap of balled-up parchment, her feet noiseless on the carpet and her face set in a look of intent concentration.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVDV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVE0">As Princess Ce’Nedra and her companions were escorted into the pavilion, ‘Zakath, seated on a low, cushioned divan, held up his hand for silence, his eyes still fixed on the cat. ‘She hunts,’ the Emperor murmured in a dead voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVE1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVE2">The cat crept nearer to her intended prey, crouched and shifted her hind feet nervously, her bottom twitching from side to side and her tail lashing. Then she leaped at the parchment. The ball crackled as she pounced on it, and, startled, she jumped high into the air. She batted the ball experimentally with one paw; suddenly finding a new game, she bounced it across the floor with a series of soft-pawed jabs, scampering after it with awkward enthusiasm.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVE3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVE4">‘Zakath smiled sadly. ‘A young cat,’ he said, ‘with much yet to learn.’ He rose gracefully to his feet and bowed to Ce’Nedra. ‘Your Imperial Highness,’ he greeted her formally. His voice was resonant, but there was that peculiar deadness in it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVE5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVE6">‘Your Imperial Majesty,’ Ce’Nedra replied, inclining her head in response.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVE7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVE8">‘Please, Goodman,’ ‘Zakath said to Durnik, who was supporting the still-dazed Polgara, ‘let the lady rest here.’ He indicated the divan. ‘I’ll send for my physicians, and they will see to her indisposition.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVE9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVEA">‘Your Majesty is too kind.’ Ce’Nedra mouthed the ritual phrase, but her eyes were searching ‘Zakath’s face for some hint of his real intentions. ‘One is surprised to meet such courtesy – under the circumstances.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVEB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVEC">He smiled again, rather whimsically. ‘And, of course, all Malloreans are supposed to be raving fanatics – like Murgos. Courtesy is out of character, right?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVED"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVEE">‘We have very little information about Mallorea and its people,’ the princess responded. ‘I was not certain what to expect.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVEF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVEG">‘That’s surprising,’ the Emperor observed. ‘I have a great deal of information about your father and your Alorn friends.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVEH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVEI">‘Your Majesty has the aid of Grolims in gathering intelligence,’ Ce’Nedra said, ‘while we must rely on ordinary men.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVEJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVEK">‘The Grolims are overrated, Princess. Their first loyalty is to Torak; their second to their own hierarchy. They tell me only what they want to tell me – although periodically I manage to have a bit of additional information extracted from one of them. It helps to keep the rest of them honest.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVEL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVEM">An attendant entered the pavilion, fell to his knees, and pressed his face to the carpet.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVEN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVEO">‘Yes?’ ‘Zakath inquired.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVEP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVEQ">‘Your Imperial Majesty asked that the King of Thulldom be brought here,’ the attendant replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVER"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVES">‘Ah, yes. I’d nearly forgotten. Please excuse me for a moment, Princess Ce’Nedra – a small matter requiring my attention. Please, you and your friends make yourselves comfortable.’ He looked critically at Ce’Nedra’s armor. ‘After we’ve dined, I’ll have the women of my household see to more suitable clothing for you and for Lady Polgara. Does the child require anything?’ He looked curiously at Errand, who was intently watching the cat.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVET"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVEU">‘He’ll be all right, your Majesty,’ Ce’Nedra replied. Her mind was working very rapidly. This urbane, polished gentleman might be easier to deal with than she had anticipated.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVEV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVF0">‘Bring in the King of the Thulls,’ ‘Zakath ordered, his hand wearily shading his eyes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVF1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVF2">‘At once, your Imperial Majesty,’ the attendant said, scrambling to his feet and backing out of the pavilion, bent in a deep bow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVF3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVF4">Gethell, the King of Mishrak ac Thull, was a thick-bodied man with lank, mud-colored hair. His face was a pasty white as he was led in, and he was trembling violently. ‘Y-Your Imperial Majesty,’ he stammered in a croaking voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVF5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVF6">‘You forgot to bow, Gethell,’ ‘Zakath reminded him gently. One of the Mallorean guards doubled his fist and drove it into Gethell’s stomach. The Thull monarch doubled over.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVF7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVF8">‘Much better,’ ‘Zakath said approvingly. ‘I’ve asked you here in regard to some distressing news I received from the battlefield, Gethell. My commanders report that your troops did not behave well during the engagement at Thull Mardu. I am no soldier, but it seems to me that your men might have stood at least </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVF9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFA">one</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFB"> charge by the Mimbrate knights before they ran away. I’m informed however, that they did not. Have you any explanation for that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVFC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFD">Gethell began to babble incoherently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVFE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFF">‘I thought not,’ ‘Zakath told him. ‘It’s been my experience that the failure of people to do what’s expected of them is the result of poor leadership. It appears that you’ve not taken the trouble to encourage your men to be brave. That was a serious oversight on your part, Gethell.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVFG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFH">‘Forgive me, dread ‘Zakath,’ the King of the Thulls wailed, falling to his knees in terror.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVFI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFJ">‘But of course I forgive you, my dear fellow,’ ‘Zakath told him. ‘How absurd of you to think that I wouldn’t. A reprimand of some sort </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVFK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFL">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFM"> in order, though, don’t you think?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVFN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFO">‘I freely accept full responsibility,’ Gethell declared, still on his knees.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVFP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFQ">‘Splendid, Gethell. Absolutely splendid. I’m so glad that this interview is going so well. We’ve managed to avoid all kinds of unpleasantness.’ He turned to the attendant. ‘Would you be so good as to take King Gethell out and have him flogged?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVFR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFS">‘At once, your Imperial Majesty.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVFT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVFU">Gethell’s eyes started from his head as the two soldiers dragged him to his feet.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVFV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVG0">‘Now,’ ‘Zakath mused. ‘What do we do with him after we’ve flogged him?’ He thought a moment. ‘Ah, I know. Is there any stout timber in the vicinity?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVG1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVG2">‘It’s all open grassland, your Imperial Majesty.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVG3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVG4">‘What a pity.’ ‘Zakath sighed. ‘I was going to have you crucified, Gethell, but I suppose I’ll have to forgo that. Perhaps an extra fifty lashes will serve as well.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVG5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVG6">Gethell began to blubber.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVG7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVG8">‘Oh, come now, my dear fellow, that just won’t do. You </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVG9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGA">are</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGB"> a king, after all, and you absolutely </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVGC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGD">must</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGE"> provide a good example for your men. Run along now. I have guests. One hopes that the sight of your public flogging will give your troops greater incentive to do better. They’ll reason that if I’d do that to </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVGF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGG">you</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGH">, then what I’ll do to </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVGI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGJ">them</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGK"> will be infinitely worse. When you recover, encourage them in that belief, because the next time this happens, I’ll have made arrangements to have the necessary timber on hand. Take him away,’ he said to his men without so much as a glance over his shoulder.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVGL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGM">‘Forgive me for the interruption, your Highness,’ he apologized. ‘These little administrative details consume so much of one’s time.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVGN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGO">The King of the Thulls was dragged sobbing from the pavilion.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVGP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGQ">‘I’ve ordered a small supper for you and your friends, Princess Ce’Nedra,’ ‘Zakath continued. ‘All the finest delicacies. Then I’ll make arrangements for the absolute comfort of you and your companions.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVGR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGS">‘I hope that this won’t offend your Imperial Majesty,’ Ce’Nedra began bravely, ‘but one is curious about your plans in regard to our future.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVGT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVGU">‘Please set your mind at rest, your Highness,’ ‘Zakath replied in his dead-sounding voice. ‘Word has reached me that the madman, Taur Urgas, is dead. I will never be able to repay you for that service, and I bear you absolutely no ill will whatsoever.’ He glanced toward one corner of his tent where his cat, purring ecstatically, was lying on her back in Errand’s lap with all four paws in the air. The smiling child was gently stroking her furry belly. ‘How charming,’ ‘Zakath murmured in an oddly melancholy voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVGV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVH0">Then the Emperor of boundless Mallorea rose and approached the divan where Durnik supported Lady Polgara. ‘My Queen,’ he said, bowing to her with profound respect. ‘Your beauty quite transcends all reports.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVH1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVH2">Polgara opened her eyes and gave him a level gaze. A wild hope leaped in Ce’Nedra’s heart. Polgara was conscious.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVH3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVH4">‘You are courteous, my Lord,’ Polgara told him in a weak voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVH5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVH6">‘You </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVH7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVH8">are</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVH9"> my queen, Polgara,’ ‘Zakath told her, ‘and I can now understand my God’s ages-old longing for you.’ He sighed then as his apparently habitual melancholy descended upon him once again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVHA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVHB">‘What are you going to do with us?’ Durnik asked, his arms still holding Polgara protectively.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="PNVHC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVHD">Zakath sighed again. ‘The God of my people is not a good or kindly God,’ he told the smith. ‘If the arranging of things had been left to me, all might have been different. I was not consulted, however. I am Angarak, and I must bow to the will of Torak. The sleep of the Dragon-God grows fitful, and I must obey his commands. Though it wounds me deeply, I must turn you and your companions over to the Grolims. They will deliver you up to Zedar, disciple of Torak in Cthol Mishrak, City of Night, where </span><span class="italic" aid="PNVHE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVHF">he</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="PNVHG"> will decide your fate.’</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_27" aid="PNVHH"></div>

<blockquote class="calibre_21" id="filepos743572" aid="QMFO1"><blockquote class="calibre8" aid="QMFO2"><blockquote class="calibre_22" aid="QMFO3"><span class="calibre1" aid="QMFO4"><span class="italic" aid="QMFO5"><span class="bold" aid="QMFO6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="QMFO7">Part Three</span></span></span></span></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote class="calibre_23" aid="QMFO8"><blockquote class="calibre8" aid="QMFO9"><blockquote class="calibre_22" aid="QMFOA"><span class="calibre1" aid="QMFOB"><span class="bold" aid="QMFOC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="QMFOD">MALLOREA</span></span></span></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><br class="calibre3"/><p class="calibre_" aid="QMFOE"><img class="calibre_27" src="kindle:embed:0005?mime=image/jpeg"/>
