<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
  <link href="kindle:flow:0001?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
<link href="kindle:flow:0002?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
</head>
  <body class="calibre" aid="RL0A0">
</body>
</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos744086" aid="RL0A1"><span class="calibre5" aid="RL0A2"><span class="italic" aid="RL0A3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0A4">Chapter Nineteen</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="RL0A5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0A6">They remained for nearly a week in the Imperial compound as the personal guests of the Emperor ‘Zakath, who for some strange reason seemed to take a melancholy pleasure in their company. Quarters were provided for them within the labyrinth of silken tents and pavilions that sheltered ‘Zakath’s household staff, and their every comfort received the personal attention of the Emperor himself.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0A7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0A8">The strange, sad-eyed man puzzled Princess Ce’Nedra. Although he was the absolute soul of courtesy, the memory of his interview with King Gethell frightened her. His ruthlessness was all the more chilling because he never lost his temper. He never seemed to sleep either, and when, often in the middle of the night, he felt some obscure need for conversation, he would send for Ce’Nedra. He never apologized for having interrupted her rest. It apparently did not even occur to him that his summons might in some way inconvenience her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0A9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0AA">‘Where did King Rhodar receive his military training?’ ‘Zakath asked her during one of these midnight interviews. ‘None of my information about him even hints about any such talent.’ The Emperor was seated deep in the purple cushions of a soft chair with golden candlelight playing over his face and his cat dozing in his lap.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0AB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0AC">‘I really couldn’t say, your Majesty,’ Ce’Nedra replied, toying absently with the sleeve of the pale silk gown that had been provided for her soon after her arrival. ‘I only met Rhodar last winter.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0AD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0AE">‘Very peculiar,’ ‘Zakath mused. ‘We had always assumed that he was just a foolish old man doting on his young wife. We had never even considered him a possible threat. We concentrated our attentions on Brand and Anheg. Brand is too self-effacing to be a good leader, and Anheg seemed too erratic to give us much concern. Then Rhodar appeared out of nowhere to take charge of things. The Alorns are an enigma, aren’t they? How can a sensible Tolnedran girl stand them?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0AF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0AG">She smiled briefly. ‘They have a certain charm, your Majesty,’ she told him rather pertly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0AH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0AI">‘Where is Belgarion?’ The question came without any warning.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0AJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0AK">‘We don’t know, your Majesty,’ Ce’Nedra answered evasively. ‘Lady Polgara was furious when he slipped away.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0AL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0AM">‘In the company of Belgarath and Kheldar,’ the Emperor added. ‘We heard of the search for them. Tell me, Princess, does he by any chance have Cthrag Yaska with him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0AN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0AO">‘Cthrag Yaska?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0AP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0AQ">‘The burning stone – what you in the west call the Orb of Aldur.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0AR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0AS">‘I’m not at liberty to discuss that, your Majesty,’ she told him rather primly, ‘and I’m sure you’re too courteous to try to wring the information out of me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0AT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0AU">‘Princess,’ he said reprovingly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0AV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0B0">‘I’m sorry, your Majesty,’ she apologized and gave him that quick, little girl smile that was always her weapon of last resort.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0B1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0B2">‘Zakath smiled gently. ‘You’re a devious young woman, Ce’Nedra,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0B3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0B4">‘Yes, your Majesty,’ she acknowledged. ‘What prompted you and Taur Urgas to bury your enmity and unite against us?’ Ce’Nedra wanted to demonstrate that she too could ask surprise questions.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0B5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0B6">‘There was no unity in our attack, Princess,’ he replied. ‘I was merely responding to Taur Urgas.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0B7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0B8">‘I don’t understand.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0B9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0BA">‘So long as he remained at Rak Goska, I was perfectly content to stay at Thull Zelik; but as soon as he began to march north, I had to respond. The land of the Thulls is of too much strategic importance to allow it to be occupied by a hostile force.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0BB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0BC">‘And what now, ‘Zakath?’ Ce’Nedra asked him impudently. ‘Taur Urgas is dead. Where will you turn now in search of an enemy?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0BD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0BE">He smiled a wintry smile. ‘How little you understand us, Ce’Nedra. Taur Urgas was only the symbol of Murgo fanaticism, Ctuchik is dead, and Taur Urgas is dead, but Murgodom lives on – even as Mallorea will live on when I am gone. Our enmity goes back for eons. At last, however, a Mallorean Emperor is in a position to crush Cthol Murgos once and for all and make himself undisputed overking of Angarak.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0BF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0BG">‘It’s all for power, then?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0BH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0BI">‘What else is there?’ he asked sadly. ‘When I was very young, I thought that there might be something else – but events proved that I was wrong.’ A brief look of pain crossed his face, and he sighed. ‘In time you will discover that same truth. Your Belgarion will grow colder as the years pass and the chill satisfaction of power comes more and more to possess him. When it is complete, and only his love of power remains, then he and I will move against each other as inevitably as two great tides. I will not attack him until his education is complete. There is no satisfaction in destroying a man who does not fully comprehend reality. When all of his illusions are gone and only his love of power remains, then he will be a fit opponent.’ His face had grown bleak. He looked at her, his eyes as dead and cold as ice. ‘I think I’ve kept you from your rest too long, Princess,’ he said. ‘Go to bed and dream of love and other absurdities. The dreams will die all too soon, so enjoy them while you can.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0BJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0BK">Early the next morning, Ce’Nedra entered the pavilion where Polgara rested, recuperating from the struggle with the Grolims at Thull Mardu. She was alert, but still dreadfully weak.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0BL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0BM">‘He’s every bit as insane as Taur Urgas was,’ Ce’Nedra reported. ‘He’s so obsessed with the idea of becoming overking of Angarak that he isn’t even paying any attention to what we’ve been doing.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0BN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0BO">‘That may change once Anheg starts sinking his troop ships,’ Polgara replied. ‘There’s nothing we can do at the moment, so just keep listening to him and be polite.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0BP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0BQ">‘Do you think we should try to escape?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0BR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0BS">‘No.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0BT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0BU">Ce’Nedra looked at her, a bit startled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0BV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0C0">‘What’s happening is supposed to happen. There’s some reason that the four of us – you, Durnik, Errand, and I – are supposed to go to Mallorea. Let’s not tamper with it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0C1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0C2">‘You knew this was going to happen?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0C3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0C4">Polgara gave her a weary smile. ‘I knew that’s where we were going. I didn’t know how, exactly. ‘Zakath isn’t interfering in any way, so don’t aggravate him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0C5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0C6">Ce’Nedra sighed in resignation. ‘Whatever you say, Lady Polgara,’ she said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0C7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0C8">It was early afternoon of that same day when the first reports of King Anheg’s activities in the Sea of the East reached the Emperor ‘Zakath. Ce’Nedra, who was present when the dispatches were delivered, felt a secret sense of satisfaction as the icy man showed the first hint of irritation she had seen in him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0C9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0CA">‘Are you certain of this?’ he demanded of the trembling messenger, holding up the parchment.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0CB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0CC">‘I only carried the dispatch, dread Lord.’ The messenger quailed, cringing back from his Emperor’s anger.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0CD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0CE">‘Were you at Thull Zelik when the ships arrived?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0CF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0CG">‘There was only one ship, dread Lord.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0CH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0CI">‘One ship out of fifty?’ ‘Zakath’s tone was incredulous. ‘Weren’t there others – perhaps coming along the coast?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0CJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0CK">‘The sailors said there weren’t, your Imperial Majesty.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0CL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0CM">‘What kind of barbarian is this Anheg of Cherek?’ ‘Zakath exclaimed to Ce’Nedra. ‘Each of those ships carried two hundred men.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0CN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0CO">‘King Anheg is an Alorn, your Majesty,’ Ce’Nedra replied coolly. ‘They’re an unpredictable people.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0CP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0CQ">With a great deal of effort, ‘Zakath regained his composure. ‘I see,’ he said after a moment’s reflection. ‘This was your plan from the beginning, wasn’t it, Princess? The entire attack on Thull Mardu was a subterfuge.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0CR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0CS">‘Not entirely, your Majesty. I was assured that the city had to be neutralized to permit the passage of the fleet.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0CT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0CU">‘But why is he drowning </span><span class="italic" aid="RL0CV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0D0">my</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0D1"> soldiers? I bear the Alorns no malice.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0D2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0D3">‘Torak does – or so I’m told – and it is Torak who will command the combined armies of Angarak. We cannot allow your forces to land on this continent, your Majesty. We cannot give Torak that advantage.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0D4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0D5">‘Torak is asleep – and he’s likely to remain so for a number of years yet.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0D6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0D7">‘Our information indicates that it will not be nearly so long. Belgarath himself is convinced that the time is near at hand.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0D8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0D9">His eyes narrowed slightly. ‘I must hand you all over to the Grolims, then,’ he said. ‘I’d hoped to wait until Polgara had regained her strength before subjecting her to the journey; but if what you say is true, there is little time to waste. Advise your friends to make their preparations, Princess. You will depart for Thull Zelik tomorrow morning.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0DA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0DB">‘As your Majesty wishes,’ Ce’Nedra replied, a chill going down her spine as she bowed her head in acquiescence.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0DC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0DD">‘I am a secular man, Princess,’ he said by way of explanation. ‘I bow to the altar of Torak when the occasion demands it, but I make no pretence at excessive piety. I will not involve myself in a religious dispute between Belgarath and Zedar, and I most certainly will not stand between Torak and Aldur when they confront each other. I would strongly advise you to follow the same course.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0DE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0DF">‘That decision is not mine to make, your Majesty. My part in this was decided for me long before I was born.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0DG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0DH">He looked amused. ‘The Prophecy, you mean? We Angaraks have one also, Princess, and I don’t imagine yours is any more reliable than ours. Prophecy is no more than a trick of the priesthood to maintain its grip on the gullible.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0DI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0DJ">‘Then you believe in nothing, my Lord?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0DK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0DL">‘I believe in my own power. Nothing else makes any sense.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0DM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0DN">The Grolims who escorted them in easy stages northward across the summer-browned plains of Mishrak ac Thull toward Thull Zelik were coldly proper. Ce’Nedra could not be sure if their behavior was the result of warnings from the Emperor of Mallorea or their fear of Polgara. The stifling heat was past now, and the air smelled faintly of the dusty end of summer. The Thullish plain was dotted with villages, random collections of thatch-roofed cottages and dirt streets. The villagers watched, sullen and afraid, as the priests of Torak rode through the little towns, their faces cold and aloof.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0DO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0DP">The plain to the west of Thull Zelik was covered with the red tents of the vast staging area that had been erected for the Mallorean army. With the exception of caretaker detachments, however, the huge camp was empty. The troops already in Mishrak ac Thull were with ‘Zakath near Thull Mardu, and the steady stream of new arrivals had been quite suddenly cut off.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0DQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0DR">Thull Zelik itself was like any port town in the world, smelling of salt water, fish, tar, and rotting seaweed. The gray stone buildings were low and squat, almost like the Thulls themselves, and the cobblestoned streets all sloped down to the harbor, which lay in the curve of a broad estuary and faced a somewhat similar harbor on the other side.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0DS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0DT">‘What city is that?’ Ce’Nedra curiously asked one of the Grolims as she looked across the dirty water toward the far shore.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0DU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0DV">‘Yar Marak,’ the black-robed priest answered curtly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0E0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0E1">‘Ah,’ she said, remembering now her tedious geography lessons. The two cities, one Thullish, the other Nadrak, faced each other across the estuary at the mouth of the River Cordu, and the boundary between Mishrak ac Thull and Gar og Nadrak ran down the precise center of the river.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0E2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0E3">‘When the Emperor returns from Thull Mardu, I imagine he’ll take steps to eradicate that place over there,’ one of the other Grolims added. ‘He was not pleased with the behavior of King Drosta on the battlefield, and some chastisement seems in order.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0E4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0E5">They proceeded directly down a cobbled avenue to the harbor, where but a few ships were moored to the wharves.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0E6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0E7">‘My crew absolutely refuses to put to sea,’ the Mallorean captain of the ship upon which they were to embark reported to the Grolims. ‘The Chereks out there are like a pack of wolves, burning and sinking everything afloat.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0E8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0E9">‘The Cherek fleet is farther south,’ the priest in charge of the detachment of Grolims declared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0EA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0EB">‘The Cherek fleet is everywhere, revered priest,’ the captain disagreed. ‘Two days ago they burned four coastal towns two hundred leagues to the south of here, and yesterday they sank a dozen ships a hundred leagues to the north. You wouldn’t believe how fast they can move. They don’t even take the time to loot the towns they burn.’ He shuddered. ‘They’re not men! They’re a natural disaster.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0EC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0ED">‘We will set sail within the hour,’ the Grolim insisted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0EE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0EF">‘Not unless your priests know how to man oars and handle the rigging,’ the captain told him. ‘My men are terrified. They won’t sail.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0EG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0EH">‘We’ll convince them,’ the Grolim said darkly. He gave a few orders to his under-priests. An altar was quickly erected on the high stern deck, and a brazier filled with glowing coals was placed to one side of it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0EI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0EJ">The leader of the Grolims took his place at the altar and began chanting in a deep, hollow voice, his arms raised to the sky. In his right hand he held a gleaming knife. At random, his cohorts selected a sailor and dragged him, screaming and struggling, to the stern deck. As Ce’Nedra watched with horror, he was bent backward across the altar and butchered with an almost casual efficiency. The Grolim who had wielded the knife lifted the dead man’s dripping heart. ‘Behold our offering, Dragon-God of Angarak!’ he cried in a great voice, then turned and deposited the heart in the smoking brazier. The heart steamed and sizzled horribly for a moment, then began to blacken and shrivel as the fire consumed it. From the bow of the ship a gong clanged in iron celebration of the sacrifice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0EK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0EL">The Grolim at the altar, his bloody hands dripping, turned to confront the ashen-faced sailors crowded amidships. ‘Our ceremonies will continue until the ship sails,’ he told them. ‘Who will be the next to give his heart to our beloved God?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0EM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0EN">The ship set sail immediately.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0EO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0EP">Ce’Nedra, sick with revulsion, turned her face away. She looked at Polgara, whose eyes burned with hatred and who seemed in the grip of an overpowering interior struggle. Ce’Nedra knew her, and she knew that it was only by a tremendous effort of her will that Polgara was able to keep herself from unleashing a terrible retribution on the blood-stained Grolim at the altar. Beside her, protected in the clasp of one of her arms, stood Errand. On the child’s face was an expression Ce’Nedra had never seen there before. His look was sad, compassionate, and at the same time filled with a kind of iron-hard resolution, as if, had he but the power, he would destroy every altar to Torak in all the world.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0EQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0ER">‘You will go belowdecks now,’ one of their Grolim captors told them. ‘It will be a matter of some days before we reach the shores of boundless Mallorea.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0ES"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0ET">They sailed north, hugging the Nadrak coastline, fearfully ready to run for any beach that offered itself, should Cherek ships appear on the horizon. At a certain point, the Mallorean captain peered about at the empty sea, swallowed hard, and swung his tiller over for the quick, terrified dash across open water to the east.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0EU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0EV">Once, a day or more out from the Nadrak coast, they saw a dreadful column of thick black smoke rising far to the south, and a day or so farther on they sailed through a sea littered with charred debris where bodies, pale and bloated, bobbed in the dark waves of the eastern sea. The frightened sailors pulled their oars with all their strength, not even needing the encouragement of whips to row faster.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0F0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0F1">Then, one murky morning when the sky behind them threatened rain squalls and the air was oppressively heavy with the advancing storm, a low, dark smudge appeared on the horizon ahead of them, and the sailors doubled their efforts, rushing desperately toward the safety of the Mallorean coast ahead.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0F2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0F3">The beach upon which the small boats from their ship landed them was a sloping shingle of dark, salt-crusted gravel where the waves made a strange, mournful sighing as they receded. Awaiting them some distance up from the water’s edge sat a mounted party of Grolims, their black robes belted at the waist with crimson sashes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0F4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0F5">‘Archpriests,’ Polgara noted coldly. ‘We’re to be escorted with some ceremony, I take it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0F6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0F7">The Grolim who had commanded their escort went quickly up the gravel stand toward the waiting group and prostrated himself before them, speaking with a hushed reverence. One of the Archpriests, an aged man with a deeply lined face and sunken eyes, dismounted rather stiffly and came down to where Ce’Nedra and her friends had just stepped from the small boat.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0F8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0F9">‘My Queen,’ he said to Polgara, bowing respectfully. ‘I am Urtag, Archpriest of the district of Camat. I am here with my brethren to escort you to the City of Night.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0FA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0FB">‘I’m disappointed not to find Zedar waiting,’ the sorceress replied coldly. ‘I trust he’s not indisposed.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0FC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0FD">Urtag gave her a quick look of irritation. ‘Do not rail against your foreordained fate, Queen of Angarak,’ he advised her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0FE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0FF">‘I have two fates awaiting me, Urtag,’ she said. ‘Which one I will follow has not yet been decided.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0FG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0FH">‘I do not have any doubts about the matter,’ he declared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0FI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0FJ">‘That’s probably because you’ve never dared to look at the alternatives,’ she replied. ‘Shall we go, Urtag? A windy beach is hardly the place for philosophical discussion.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0FK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0FL">The Grolim Archpriests had brought horses with them, and the party was soon mounted and riding away from the sea across a line of low, wooded hills in a generally northeasterly direction. The trees bordering the upper edge of the gravel beach had been dark-boughed spruces, but once they topped the first rise, they entered a vast forest of white-barked aspens. To Ce’Nedra’s eyes, the stark, white trunks looked almost corpse-like, and the entire forest had a gloomy, unhealthy quality about it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0FM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0FN">‘Mistress Pol,’ Durnik said in a voice that was scarcely more than a whisper, ‘shouldn’t we be working on some kind of plan?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0FO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0FP">‘For what, Durnik?’ she asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0FQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0FR">‘For our escape, of course.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0FS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0FT">‘But we don’t want to escape, Durnik.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0FU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0FV">‘We don’t?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0G0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0G1">‘The Grolims are taking us to the place we want to go.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0G2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0G3">‘Why do we want to go to this Cthol Mishrak of theirs?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0G4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0G5">‘We have something to do there.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0G6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0G7">‘From everything I’ve heard it’s a bad sort of place,’ he told her. ‘Are you sure you haven’t made some mistake?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0G8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0G9">She reached out and laid her hand on his arm. ‘Dear Durnik,’ she said, ‘you’ll just have to trust me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0GA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0GB">‘Of course, Mistress Pol,’ he replied immediately. ‘But shouldn’t I know what to expect? If I should have to take steps to protect you, I ought to be prepared.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0GC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0GD">‘I’d tell you if I knew, Durnik,’ she said, ‘but I don’t know what we should expect. All I know is that the four of us are supposed to go to Cthol Mishrak. What’s going to happen there needs us in order for it to be complete. Each of us has something to do there.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0GE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0GF">‘Even me?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0GG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0GH">‘Especially you, Durnik. At first I didn’t understand who you really are. That’s why I tried to keep you from coming along. But now I </span><span class="italic" aid="RL0GI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0GJ">do</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0GK"> understand. You have to be there because you’re going to do the one thing that’s going to turn the entire outcome one way or the other.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0GL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0GM">‘What is it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0GN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0GO">‘We don’t know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0GP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0GQ">His eyes grew wide. ‘What if I do it wrong?’ he asked in a worried voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0GR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0GS">‘I don’t think you can,’ she reassured him. ‘From everything I understand, what you’re going to do will flow very naturally out of who and what you are.’ She gave him a brief, wry little smile. ‘You won’t be able to do it wrong, Durnik – any more than you’d be able to lie or cheat or steal. It’s built into you to do it right, so don’t worry about it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0GT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0GU">‘That’s all very well for you to say, Mistress Pol,’ he replied, ‘but if you don’t mind, I </span><span class="italic" aid="RL0GV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0H0">will</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0H1"> worry about it just a bit – privately, of course.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0H2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0H3">She laughed then, a light, fond little laugh. ‘You dear, dear man,’ she said, impulsively taking his hand. ‘Whatever would we do without you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0H4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0H5">Durnik blushed and tried to look away, but her glorious eyes held his, and he blushed even more.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0H6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0H7">After they had passed through the forest of aspen, they entered a strangely desolate landscape. White boulders stuck up out of tangled weeds like tombstones in a long-abandoned graveyard, and dead trees thrust their crooked limbs at the overcast sky like pleading fingers. The horizon ahead was covered with a bank of darker cloud, a cloud so intensely black that it seemed almost purple. Oddly, Ce’Nedra noted, the cloudbank did not seem to be moving at all. There was no sign anywhere of any human habitation, and the route they followed was not even marked by a trail.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0H8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0H9">‘Does no-one live there?’ the princess asked Polgara.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0HA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0HB">‘Cthol Mishrak is deserted except for a few Grolims,’ the sorceress replied. ‘Torak smashed the city and drove its people out the day my father and King Cherek and his sons stole the Orb back from the iron tower.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0HC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0HD">‘When was that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0HE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0HF">‘A very long time ago, Ce’Nedra. As nearly as we’ve been able to determine, it was precisely on the same day that Beldaran and I were born – and the day our mother died. It’s a bit hard to say for sure. We were a bit casual about keeping track of time in those days.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0HG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0HH">‘If your mother had died and Belgarath was here, who took care of you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0HI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0HJ">‘Beldin, of course.’ Polgara smiled. ‘He wasn’t a very good mother, but he did the best he could until Father returned.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0HK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0HL">‘Is that why you’re so fond of him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0HM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0HN">‘One of the reasons, yes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0HO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0HP">The ominous cloudbank still did not move. It stretched across the sky as stationary as a range of mountains; as they rode toward it, it loomed higher and higher.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0HQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0HR">‘That’s a very strange cloud,’ Durnik noted, looking speculatively at the thick curtain of purple ahead. ‘The storm is coming in behind us, but that cloud doesn’t seem to be moving at all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0HS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0HT">‘It doesn’t move, Durnik,’ Polgara told him. ‘It never has moved. When the Angaraks built Cthol Mishrak, Torak put that cloud there to hide the city. It’s been there ever since.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0HU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0HV">‘How long is that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0I0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0I1">‘About five thousand years.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0I2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0I3">‘The sun never shines there?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0I4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0I5">‘Never.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0I6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0I7">The Grolim Archpriests had begun to look about with a certain apprehension, and finally Urtag called a halt. ‘We must make ourselves known,’ he declared. ‘We don’t want the watchers to mistake us for intruders.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0I8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0I9">The other Archpriests nodded nervously, and then all removed polished steel masks from beneath their robes and carefully covered their faces with them. Then each of them untied a thick torch from his saddle and ignited it with a brief, mumbled incantation. The torches burned with a peculiarly green-tinged flame and gave off a reeking, sulfurous smoke.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0IA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0IB">‘I wonder what would happen if I were to blow out your torches,’ Polgara suggested with a hint of a mischievous smile. ‘I could, you know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0IC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0ID">Urtag gave her a worried look. ‘This is no time for foolishness, my Lady,’ he warned her. ‘The watchers are very savage with intruders. Our lives depend on those torches. Please don’t do anything to bring down a disaster on us all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0IE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0IF">She laughed lightly and let it go at that.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0IG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0IH">As they rode in beneath the cloud, it grew steadily darker. It was not precisely the clean darkness of night, but was rather a kind of dirty murkiness, a deep shade hovering in the air. They crested a rise and saw before them a cloud-enshrouded basin, and in its center, half-obscured by the pervasive gloom, stood the ravaged City of Night. The vegetation around them had shrunk to a few sparse weeds and an unhealthy-looking, stunted grass, pale and sick for want of sun. The boulders thrusting up out of the earth were splotched with a sort of leprous lichen that ate into the rock itself, and nodules of a white fungus lumped in grotesque profusion, spreading out across the dank soil as if the ground itself were diseased.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0II"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0IJ">With a slow, careful pace, their sputtering torches held above their heads, the Grolim Archpriests led the way down into the gloomy basin and across the unwholesome plain toward the shattered walls of Cthol Mishrak.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0IK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0IL">As they entered the city, the princess saw furtive hints of movement among the tumbled stones. Shadowy forms scurried from place to place among the ruins, and the sound of their movements was the clicking scrape made by creatures whose feet were clawed. Some of the shapes were upright, others were not. Ce’Nedra grew cold and afraid. The watchers of Cthol Mishrak were neither beast nor human, and they seemed to exude a kind of indiscriminate malice toward all other living things. More than anything, she was afraid that one of them might suddenly turn and confront her with a face that might rip away her sanity by its hideousness.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0IM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0IN">As they passed down a broken street, Urtag began to intone an ancient prayer to Torak, his voice hollow and shaking. The dank air grew colder, and the diseaselike lichen ate at the tumbled stones of the ruined houses. Mold seemed to cling to everything, and the pale fungus grew in grotesque lumps in corners and crannies. The smell of decay was everywhere, a damp, rotten stench, and slimy pools of stagnant water lay among the ruins.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0IO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0IP">In the center of the city stood the rusted stump of a vast iron tower, the broken-off girders which had supported it thicker than a man’s waist. Just to the south of the stump lay a broad, rusted trail of total destruction where the tower had fallen, crushing everything beneath it. Over the eons, the iron had rusted down into a sort of damp red mud that outlined the enormous dimensions of the fallen structure.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0IQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0IR">The stump had eroded down the years, rounding off the broken edges. The rust mingled in places with a kind of thick black ooze that ran down the faces of the iron plates like gobbets of clotted blood.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0IS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0IT">Urtag, trembling visibly now, dismounted before a vast, arched portal and led them through a half-open iron door. The echoing chamber they entered was as large as the Imperial throne room in Tol Honeth. Wordlessly, his torch held high over his head, Urtag led them across the pitted floor to another iron-arched doorway and then down a flight of clanging iron steps that reached into the darkness beneath. At the bottom of the stairs, perhaps fifty feet below the wreckage above, stood another door of black iron, studded with great, round rivet-heads. Hesitantly, Urtag rapped his knuckles on the door, and the sound of his rapping echoed hollowly in the chamber beyond.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0IU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0IV">‘Who comes to disturb the slumber of the Dragon-God of Angarak?’ a muffled voice demanded from behind the door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0J0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0J1">‘I am Urtag, the Archpriest of Camat.’ The Grolim’s voice was frightened. ‘As commanded, I bring the prisoners to the Disciple of Torak.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0J2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0J3">There was a moment of silence, and then the rattling sound of an immense chain, followed by the grating of an enormous bolt. Then slowly, creakingly, the door opened.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0J4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0J5">Ce’Nedra gasped. Standing in the doorway was Belgarath! It was a moment before her startled eyes began to sort out the subtle differences that informed her that the white-haired man before her was not indeed the old sorcerer, but rather someone who looked so much like him that they could easily pass for brothers. Subtle though the differences were, they were nonetheless profound. In the eyes of the man in the doorway there was a haunted look – a look compounded of grief and horror and a dreadful self-loathing, all overlaid with the helpless adoration of a man who has given himself utterly to a dreadful master.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0J6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0J7">‘Welcome to the tomb of the one-eyed God, Polgara,’ he greeted the sorceress.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0J8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0J9">‘It’s been a long time, Belzedar,’ she replied in an oddly neutral voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0JA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0JB">‘I’ve given up the right to that name,’ he told her, and his tone was faintly regretful.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0JC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0JD">‘It was your decision, Zedar.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0JE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0JF">He shrugged. ‘Perhaps,’ he said. ‘Perhaps not. Maybe what I’m doing is also necessary.’ He pushed the door open wider. ‘Come inside, if you will. This crypt is habitable – if only barely.’ He looked directly at Urtag then. ‘You have performed a service, Urtag, Archpriest of Torak, and a service should not be unrewarded. Come.’ And he turned and led them back into the vaulted chamber beyond. The walls were of stone, massive blocks set without mortar, and bolted to the topmost tier were great iron arches supporting the ceiling and the immense ruin above. The great chill of masses of cold stone and iron was held off by large, glowing braziers set in each corner. In the center of the room stood a table and several chairs, and along one wall lay a cluster of loosely rolled pallets and a neat stack of gray woolen blankets. On the table stood a pair of large candles, their flame unwinking and steady in the dead air of the tomb.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0JG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0JH">Zedar paused briefly at the table to pick up one of the candles, then led them across the flagstone floor to an arched alcove set in the far wall. ‘Your reward, Urtag,’ he said to the Grolim. ‘Come and behold the face of your God.’ He lifted the candle.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0JI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0JJ">Lying upon its back on a stone bier within the alcove lay a huge figure, robed and cowled in black. The face was concealed by a polished steel mask. The eyes of the mask were closed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0JK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0JL">Urtag took one terrifed look, then prostrated himself on the floor.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0JM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0JN">There was a deep, rasping sigh, and the recumbent figure in the alcove moved slightly. As Ce’Nedra stared in horrified fascination, the vast, steel-covered face turned restlessly toward them. For a moment the polished left eyelid opened. Behind that eyelid burned the dreadful fire of the eye that was not. The steel face moved as if it were flesh, twisting into an expression of contempt at the priest groveling on the flagstones, and a hollow murmuring came from behind the polished lips.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0JO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0JP">Urtag started violently and raised his suddenly stricken face, listening to the hollow muttering which he alone in the dim crypt could hear clearly. The hollow voice continued, murmuring in Urtag’s ears. The Archpriest’s face drained as he listened, and a look of unspeakable horror slowly twisted his features. The hollow muttering droned on. The words were indistinct, but the inflections were not. Desperately, Ce’Nedra covered her ears.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="RL0JQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="RL0JR">Finally Urtag screamed and scrambled to his feet. His face had gone absolutely white, and his eyes were starting from their sockets. Gibbering insanely, Urtag fled, and the sound of his screams echoed back down the iron stairway as he ran in terror from the ruined tower.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_29" aid="RL0JS"></div>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">

    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>

<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos786606" aid="SJGS1"><span class="calibre5" aid="SJGS2"><span class="italic" aid="SJGS3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGS4">Chapter Twenty</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="SJGS5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGS6">The whispering had begun almost as soon Belgarath, Silk, and Garion reached the coast of Mallorea. It was indistinct at first, little more than a sibilant breath sounding perpetually in Garion’s ears, but in the days that followed as they moved steadily south, occasional words began to emerge. The words were the sort to be reckoned with – home, mother, love, and death – words upon which attention immediately fastened.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGS7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGS8">Unlike the land of the Morindim which they had left behind, northernmost Mallorea was a land of rolling hills covered with a tough-stemmed, dark green grass. Occasional nameless rivers wound among those hills, roiling and turbulent beneath a lead gray sky. They had not seen the sun for what seemed weeks. A sort of dry overcast had moved in off the Sea of the East, and a stiff breeze, chill and smelling of the polar ice, pressed continually at their backs as they moved south.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGS9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGSA">Belgarath now rode with extreme caution. There was no sign of that half-doze that was his custom in more civilized parts of the world, and Garion could feel the subtle push of the old man’s mind as he probed ahead for any hidden dangers. So delicate was the sorcerer’s searching that it seemed only a slowly expiring breath, light, tentative, concealed artfully in the sound of the breeze passing through the tall grass.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGSB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGSC">Silk also rode warily, pausing frequently to listen, and seeming on occasion to sniff at the air. Often he would even go so far as to dismount and put his ear to the turf, to see if he might pick up the muffled tread of unseen horses approaching.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGSD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGSE">‘Nervous work,’ the little man said as he remounted after one such pause.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGSF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGSG">‘Better to be a little overcautious than to blunder into something,’ Belgarath replied. ‘Did you hear anything?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGSH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGSI">‘I think I heard a worm crawling around down there,’ Silk answered brightly. ‘He didn’t say anything, though. You know how worms are.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGSJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGSK">‘Do you mind?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGSL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGSM">‘You did ask, Belgarath.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGSN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGSO">‘Oh, shut up!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGSP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGSQ">‘You heard him ask, didn’t you, Garion?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGSR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGSS">‘That is probably the most offensive habit I’ve ever encountered in anyone,’ Belgarath told the little thief.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGST"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGSU">‘I know,’ Silk answered. ‘That’s why I do it. Infuriating, isn’t it? How far do we have to go before we come to woods again?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGSV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGT0">‘Several more days. We’re still a goodly distance north of the tree line. Winter’s too long and summer too short for trees to grow up here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGT1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGT2">‘Boring sort of place, isn’t it?’ Silk observed, looking around at the endless grass and the rounded hills that all looked the same.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGT3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGT4">‘Under the circumstances, I can stand a little boredom. The alternatives aren’t all that pleasant.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGT5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGT6">‘I can accept that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGT7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGT8">They rode on, their horses wading through the knee-high, gray-green grass.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGT9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTA">The whispering inside Garion’s head began again. ‘Hear me, Child of Light.’ That sentence emerged quite clearly from the rest of the unintelligible sibilance. There was a dreadfully compelling quality in that single statement. Garion concentrated, trying to hear more.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGTB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTC">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJGTD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTE">I wouldn’t do that</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTF">,’ the familiar dry voice told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGTG"><span class="italic" aid="SJGTH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTI">‘What?’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGTJ"><span class="italic" aid="SJGTK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTL">‘Don’t do what he tells you to do.’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGTM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTN">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJGTO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTP">Who is it?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTQ">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGTR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTS">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJGTT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTU">Torak, of course. Who did you think it was?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGTV">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGU0"><span class="italic" aid="SJGU1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGU2">‘He’s awake?’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGU3"><span class="italic" aid="SJGU4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGU5">‘Not yet. Not fully at any rate – but then he’s never been entirely asleep either.’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGU6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGU7">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJGU8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGU9">What’s he trying to do?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUA">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGUB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUC">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJGUD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUE">He’s trying to talk you out of killing him.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUF">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGUG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUH">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJGUI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUJ">He’s not afraid of me, is he?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUK">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGUL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUM">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJGUN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUO">Of course he’s afraid. He doesn’t know what’s going to happen any more than you do, and he’s just as frightened of you as you are of him.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUP">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGUQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUR">That immediately made Garion feel better. </span><span class="italic" aid="SJGUS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGUT">‘What should I do about the way he keeps whispering to me?’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGUU"><span class="italic" aid="SJGUV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGV0">‘There’s not much you can do. Just don’t get into the habit of obeying his orders, that’s all.’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGV1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGV2">They camped that evening as they usually did in a well-sheltered hollow between two hills and, as usual, they built no fire to give away their location.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGV3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGV4">‘I’m getting a bit tired of cold suppers,’ Silk complained, biting down hard on a piece of dried meat. ‘This beef’s like a strip of old leather.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGV5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGV6">‘The exercise is good for your jaws,’ Belgarath told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGV7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGV8">‘You can be a very unpleasant old man when you set your mind to it, do you know that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGV9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGVA">‘The nights are getting longer, aren’t they?’ Garion said to head off any further wrangling.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGVB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGVC">‘The summer’s winding down,’ Belgarath told him. ‘It will be autumn up here in another few weeks, and winter will be right on its heels.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGVD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGVE">‘I wonder where we’ll be when winter comes,’ Garion said rather plaintively.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGVF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGVG">‘I wouldn’t do that,’ Silk advised. ‘Thinking about it isn’t going to help, and it’s only going to make you nervous.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGVH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGVI">‘Nervouser,’ Garion corrected. ‘I’m already nervous.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGVJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGVK">‘Is there such a word as “nervouser?”’ Silk asked Belgarath curiously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGVL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGVM">‘There is now,’ Belgarath replied. ‘Garion just invented it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGVN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGVO">‘I wish I could invent a word,’ Silk said admiringly to Garion, his ferretlike little eyes gleaming mischievously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGVP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGVQ">‘Please don’t poke fun at me, Silk. I’m having enough trouble as it is.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGVR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGVS">‘Let’s get some sleep,’ Belgarath suggested. ‘This conversation isn’t going anywhere, and we’ve got a long way to ride tomorrow.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGVT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJGVU">That night the whispering invaded Garion’s sleep, and it seemed to convey its meaning in images rather than words. There was an offer of friendship – of a hand outstretched in love. The loneliness that had haunted his boyhood from the moment he had discovered that he was an orphan seemed to fade, to pass somehow behind him with that offer, and he found himself rather desperately wanting to run toward that hand reaching toward him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJGVV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH00">Then, very clearly, he saw two figures standing side by side. The figure of the man was very tall and very powerful, and the figure of the woman was so familiar that the very sight of her caught at Garion’s heart. The tall, powerful man seemed to be a stranger, and yet was not. His face went far beyond mere human handsomeness. It was quite the most beautiful face Garion had ever seen. The woman, of course, was not a stranger. The white lock at the brow and the glorious eyes were the most familiar things in Garion’s life. Side by side, the beautiful stranger and Aunt Pol reached out their arms to him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH01"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH02">‘You will be our son,’ the whispering voice told him. ‘Our beloved son. I will be your father, and Polgara your mother. This will be no imaginary thing, Child of Light, for I can make all things happen. Polgara will really be your mother, and all of her love will be yours alone; and I, your father, will love and cherish you both. Will you turn away from us and face again the bitter loneliness of the orphan child? Does that chill emptiness compare with the warmth of loving parents? Come to us, Belgarion, and accept our love.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH03"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH04">Garion jerked himself out of sleep, sitting bolt upright, trembling and sweating. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJH05"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH06">I need help</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH07">,’ he cried out silently, reaching into the vaults of his mind to find that other, nameless presence.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH08"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH09">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJH0A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH0B">What’s your problem now?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH0C">’ the dry voice asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH0D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH0E">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJH0F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH0G">He’s cheating</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH0H">,’ Garion declared, outraged.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH0I"><span class="italic" aid="SJH0J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH0K">‘Cheating? Did somebody come along and make up a set of rules while I wasn’t watching?’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH0L"><span class="italic" aid="SJH0M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH0N">‘You know what I mean. He’s offering to make Aunt Pol my mother if I’ll do what he says.’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH0O"><span class="italic" aid="SJH0P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH0Q">‘He’s lying. He can’t alter the past. Ignore him.’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH0R"><span class="italic" aid="SJH0S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH0T">‘How can I? He keeps reaching into my mind and putting his hand on the most sensitive spots.’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH0U"><span class="italic" aid="SJH0V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH10">‘Think about Ce’Nedra. That’ll confuse him.’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH11"><span class="italic" aid="SJH12"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH13">‘Ce’Nedra?’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH14"><span class="italic" aid="SJH15"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH16">‘Every time he tries to tempt you with Polgara, think about your flighty little princess. Remember exactly how she looked when you peeked at her while she was bathing that time back in the Wood of the Dryads.’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH17"><span class="italic" aid="SJH18"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH19">‘I did not peek!’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH1A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1B">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJH1C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1D">Really? How is it that you remember every single detail so vividly, then?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1E">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH1F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1G">Garion blushed. He had forgotten that his daydreams were not entirely private.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH1H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1I">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJH1J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1K">Just concentrate on Ce’Nedra. It will probably irritate Torak almost as much as it does me.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1L">’ The voice paused. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJH1M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1N">Is that all you can really think about?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1O">’ it asked then.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH1P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1Q">Garion did not try to answer that.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH1R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1S">They pushed on southward under the dirty overcast and two days later they reached the first trees, scattered sparsely at the edge of the grassland where great herds of antlered creatures grazed as placidly and unafraid as cattle. As the three of them rode south, the scattered clumps of trees became thicker, and soon spread into a forest of dark-boughed evergreens.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH1T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH1U">The whispering blandishments of Torak continued, but Garion countered them with thoughts of his red-haired little princess. He could sense the irritation of his enemy each time he intruded these daydreams upon the carefully orchestrated images Torak kept trying to instill in his imagination. Torak wanted him to think of his loneliness and fear and of the possibility of becoming a part of a loving family, but the intrusion of Ce’Nedra into the picture confused and baffled the God. Garion soon perceived that Torak’s understanding of men was severely limited. Concerned more with elementals, with those towering compulsions and ambitions which had inflamed him for the endless eons, Torak could not cope with the scattered complexities and conflicting desires that motivated most men. Garion seized on his advantage to thwart the insidious and compelling whispers with which Torak tried to lure him from his purpose.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH1V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH20">The whole business was somehow peculiarly familiar. This had happened before – not perhaps in exactly the same way, but very similarly. He sorted through his memories, trying to pin down this strange sense of repetition. It was the sight of a twisted tree stump, lightning-blasted and charred, that suddenly brought it all flooding back in on him. The stump, when seen from a certain angle, bore a vague resemblance to a man on horseback, a dark rider who seemed to watch them as they rode by. Because the sky was overcast, the stump cast no shadow, and the image clicked into place. Throughout his childhood, hovering always on the edge of his vision, Garion had seen the strange, menacing shape of a dark-cloaked rider on a black horse, shadowless even in the brightest sunlight. That had been Asharak the Murgo, of course, the Grolim whom Garion had destroyed in his first open act as a sorcerer. But had it? There had existed between Garion and that dark figure which had so haunted his childhood a strange bond. They had been enemies; Garion had always known that; but in their enmity there had always been a curious closeness, something that seemed to pull them together. Garion quite deliberately began to examine a startling possibility. Suppose that the dark rider had </span><span class="italic" aid="SJH21"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH22">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH23"> in fact been Asharak – or if it had been, suppose that Asharak had somehow been suffused by another, more powerful awareness.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH24"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH25">The more he thought about it, the more convinced Garion became that he had stumbled inadvertently across the truth of the matter. Torak had demonstrated that, even though his body slept, his awareness could still move about the world, twisting events to his own purposes. Asharak had been involved, certainly, but the dominating force had always been the consciousness of Torak. The Dark God had stood watch over him since infancy. The fear he had sensed in that dark shape that had hovered always on the edge of his boyhood had not been Asharak’s fear, but Torak’s. Torak had known who he was from the beginning, had known that one day Garion would take up the sword of the Rivan King and come to the meeting that had been ordained since before the world was made.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH26"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH27">Acting upon a sudden impulse, Garion put his left hand inside his tunic and took hold of his amulet. Twisting slightly, he reached up and laid the marked palm of his right hand on the Orb, which stood on the pommel of the great sword strapped across his back.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH28"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH29">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJH2A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2B">I know you now</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2C">,’ he declared silently, hurling the thought at the murky sky. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJH2D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2E">You might as well give up trying to win me over to your side, because I’m not going to change my mind. Aunt Pol is not your wife, and I’m not your son. You’d better stop trying to play games with my thoughts and get ready, because I’m coming to kill you.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2F">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH2G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2H">The Orb beneath his hand flared with a sudden exultation as Garion threw his challenge into the Dark God’s teeth, and the sword at Garion’s back suddenly burst into a blue flame that flickered through the sheath enclosing it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH2I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2J">There was a moment of deadly silence, and then what had been a whisper suddenly became a vast roar. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJH2K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2L">Come, then, Belgarion, Child of Light</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2M">,’ Torak hurled back the challenge. ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="SJH2N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2O">I await thee in the City of Night. Bring all thy will and all thy courage with thee, for I am ready for our meeting.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2P">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH2Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2R">‘What in the name of the seven Gods do you think you’re doing?’ Belgarath almost screamed at Garion, his face mottled with angry astonishment.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH2S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2T">‘Torak’s been whispering at me for almost a week now,’ Garion explained calmly, taking his hand from the Orb. ‘He’s been offering me all kinds of things if I’d give up this whole idea. I got tired of it, so I told him to stop.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH2U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH2V">Belgarath spluttered indignantly, waving his hands at Garion.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH30"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH31">‘He knows I’m coming, Grandfather,’ Garion said, trying to placate the infuriated old man. ‘He’s known who I was since the day I was born. He’s been watching me all this time. We’re not going to be able to take him by surprise, so why try? I wanted to let him know that I was on to him. Maybe it’s time for </span><span class="italic" aid="SJH32"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH33">him</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH34"> to start worrying and being afraid just a little bit, too.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH35"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH36">Silk was staring at Garion. ‘He’s an Alorn, all right,’ he observed finally.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH37"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH38">‘He’s an idiot!’ Belgarath snapped angrily. He turned back to Garion. ‘Did it ever occur to you that there might be something out here to worry about besides Torak?’ he demanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH39"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH3A">Garion blinked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH3B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH3C">‘Cthol Mishrak is </span><span class="italic" aid="SJH3D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH3E">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH3F"> unguarded, you young blockhead. You’ve just succeeded in announcing our presence to every Grolim within a hundred leagues.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH3G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH3H">‘I didn’t think of that,’ Garion mumbled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH3I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH3J">‘I didn’t think you’d thought. Sometimes I don’t think you know </span><span class="italic" aid="SJH3K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH3L">how</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH3M"> to think.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH3N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH3O">Silk looked around apprehensively. ‘Now what do we do?’ he asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="SJH3P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="SJH3Q">‘We’d better get out of here – as fast as our horses can carry us,’ Belgarath said. He glared at Garion. ‘Are you sure you don’t have a trumpet somewhere under your clothes?’ he asked with heavy sarcasm. ‘Maybe you’d like to blow a few fanfares as we go along.’ He shook his head in disgust and then gathered up his reins. ‘Let’s ride,’ he said.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_30" aid="SJH3R"></div>

    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
