<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos809363" aid="TI1E1"><span class="calibre5" aid="TI1E2"><span class="italic" aid="TI1E3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1E4">Chapter Twenty-one</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="TI1E5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1E6">The aspens were stark white and motionless under the dead sky, and they rose, straight and slender, like the bars of an interminable cage. Belgarath led them at a walk, carefully weaving his way through the endless stretches of this vast, silent forest.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1E7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1E8">‘How much farther?’ Silk asked the old man tensely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1E9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1EA">‘Not much more than a day, now,’ Belgarath replied. ‘The clouds ahead are getting thicker.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1EB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1EC">‘You say the cloudbank never moves?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1ED"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1EE">‘Never. It’s been stationary since Torak put it there.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1EF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1EG">‘What if a wind came along? Wouldn’t that move it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1EH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1EI">Belgarath shook his head. ‘The normal rules have been suspended in that region. For all I know, the cloud might not actually be cloud. It might be something else.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1EJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1EK">‘Like what?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1EL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1EM">‘An illusion of some kind, perhaps. The Gods are very good at illusions.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1EN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1EO">‘Are they looking for us? The Grolims, I mean.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1EP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1EQ">Belgarath nodded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1ER"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1ES">‘Are you taking steps to keep them from finding us?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1ET"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1EU">‘Naturally.’ The old man looked at him. ‘Why this sudden urge for conversation? You’ve been talking steadily for the last hour.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1EV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1F0">‘I’m a little edgy,’ Silk admitted. ‘This is unfamiliar territory, and that always makes me nervous. I’m much more comfortable when I’ve got my escape routes worked out in advance.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1F1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1F2">‘Are you always ready to run?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1F3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1F4">‘In my profession you have to be. What was that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1F5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1F6">Garion heard it too. Faintly, somewhere far off behind them, there was a deep-toned baying – one animal at first, but soon joined by several others. ‘Wolves?’ he suggested.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1F7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1F8">Belgarath’s face had grown bleak. ‘No,’ he replied, ‘not wolves.’ He shook his reins, and his nervous horse began to trot, the sound of its hoofs muffled by the rotting loam lying thick beneath the aspens.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1F9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1FA">‘What is it then, Grandfather?’ Garion asked, also pushing his horse into a trot.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1FB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1FC">‘Torak’s Hounds,’ Belgarath replied tersely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1FD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1FE">‘Dogs?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1FF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1FG">‘Not really. They’re Grolims – rather specialized ones. When the Angaraks built the city, Torak decided that he needed something to guard the surrounding countryside. Certain Grolims volunteered to take on nonhuman shapes. The change was permanent.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1FH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1FI">‘I’ve dealt with watchdogs before,’ Silk said confidently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1FJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1FK">‘Not like these. Let’s see if we can outrun them.’ Belgarath didn’t sound very hopeful.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1FL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1FM">They pushed their horses into a gallop, weaving in and out among the tree trunks. The limbs slapped against their faces as they rode, and Garion raised his arm to ward them off as the three of them plunged on.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1FN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1FO">They crested a low ridge and galloped down the far side. The baying behind them seemed to be closer now.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1FP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1FQ">Then Silk’s horse stumbled, and the little man was almost thrown from his saddle. ‘This isn’t working, Belgarath,’ he said as the old man and Garion reined in. ‘This ground’s too treacherous for us to keep this pace.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1FR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1FS">Belgarath held up his hand and listened for a moment. The deep-toned baying was definitely closer. ‘They’re outrunning us anyway,’ the old man agreed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1FT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1FU">‘You’d better think of something,’ Silk said, looking back nervously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1FV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1G0">‘I’m working on it.’ Belgarath raised his face to sniff at the air. ‘Let’s keep going. I just got a whiff of stagnant water. The area’s dotted with swampy places. We might be able to hide our scent if we can get into a big enough patch of water.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1G1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1G2">They moved on down the slope toward the bottom of the valley. The odor of standing water grew steadily stronger as they rode.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1G3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1G4">‘Just ahead.’ Garion pointed toward a patch of brown water intermittently visible among the white tree trunks.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1G5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1G6">The swamp was quite extensive, a broad patch of reeking, oily water trapped in the bottom of a thickly grown basin. Dead trees thrust up out of the water, their leafless branches seeming almost like clawed hands reaching up in mute supplication to the indifferent sky.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1G7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1G8">Silk wrinkled his nose. ‘It stinks bad enough to hide our scent from almost anything,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1G9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1GA">‘We’ll see,’ Belgarath replied. ‘This would probably throw off an ordinary dog, but don’t forget that the Hounds are really Grolims. They have the ability to reason, so they won’t be relying on scent alone.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1GB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1GC">They pushed their reluctant horses into the murky water and began to splash along, changing direction frequently, weaving in and out among the dead tree trunks. Their horses’ hoofs stirred up rotting vegetation from the bottom, filling the air with an even more powerful stench.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1GD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1GE">The sound of the baying Hounds drew closer, filled now with an excitement and a terrible hunger.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1GF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1GG">‘I think they’ve hit the edge of the swamp,’ Silk said, cocking his head to listen.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1GH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1GI">There was a momentary bafflement in the baying behind them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1GJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1GK">‘Grandfather!’ Garion cried, reining in sharply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1GL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1GM">Directly before them, knee-deep in the brown water stood a slavering black dog-shape. It was enormous – fully as large as a horse, and its eyes actually burned with a malevolent green fire. Its front shoulders and chest were massive, and the fangs protruding from its mouth were at least a foot long, curving down cruelly and dripping foam.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1GN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1GO">‘We have you now,’ it growled, seeming almost to chew on the words as it twisted its muzzle into speech. The voice issuing from its mouth was a rasping, tearing sound.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1GP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1GQ">Silk’s hand instantly flashed toward one of his hidden daggers.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1GR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1GS">‘Never mind,’ Belgarath told him. ‘It’s only a projection – a shadow.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1GT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1GU">‘It can do that?’ Silk’s tone was startled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1GV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1H0">‘I told you that they’re Grolims.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1H1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1H2">‘We hunger,’ the fiery-eyed Hound rumbled. ‘I will return soon with my pack-mates, and we will feed on man-meat.’ Then the shape flickered and vanished.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1H3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1H4">‘They know where we are now.’ Silk’s voice was alarmed. ‘You’d better do something, Belgarath. Can’t you use sorcery?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1H5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1H6">‘That would just pinpoint our location. There are other things out there as well as the Hounds.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1H7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1H8">‘I’d say we’ll have to chance it. Let’s worry about one thing at a time. Did you see those teeth?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1H9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1HA">‘They’re coming,’ Garion said tensely. From far back in the swamp, he could clearly hear the sound of splashing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1HB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1HC">‘Do something, Belgarath!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1HD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1HE">The sky overhead had grown darker, and the air seemed suddenly oppressively heavy. From far off there was an angry mutter of thunder. A vast sigh seemed to pass through the forest.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1HF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1HG">‘Keep going,’ Belgarath said, and they splashed off through the slimy brown water toward the far side of the swamp. The aspen trees on the solid ground ahead of them quite suddenly turned the silvery undersides of their leaves upward, and it was almost as if a great, pale wave had shuddered through the forest.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1HH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1HI">The Hounds were very close now, and their baying was triumphant as they plunged through the oily, reeking swamp.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1HJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1HK">And then there was a brilliant blue-white flash, and a shattering clap of thunder. The sky ripped open above them. With a sound nearly as loud as the thunder, they were engulfed in a sudden deluge. The wind howled, ripping away the aspen leaves in great sheets and whirling them through the air. The rain drove horizontally before the sudden gale, churning the swamp to froth and obliterating everything more than a few feet away.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1HL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1HM">‘Did you do this?’ Silk shouted at Belgarath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1HN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1HO">But Belgarath’s stunned face clearly said that the storm was as much a surprise to him as to Silk. They both turned to look at Garion. ‘Did you do it?’ Belgarath demanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1HP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1HQ">‘He didn’t. I did.’ The voice which came from Garion’s mouth was not his. ‘I’ve labored too long at this to be thwarted by a pack of dogs.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1HR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1HS">‘I didn’t hear a thing,’ Belgarath marveled, wiping at his streaming face. ‘Not even a whisper.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1HT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1HU">‘You were listening at the wrong time,’ the voice of Garion’s inner companion replied. ‘I set it in motion early last spring. It’s just now getting here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1HV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1I0">‘You knew we’d need it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1I1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1I2">‘Obviously. Turn east. The Hounds won’t be able to track you in all this. Swing around and come at the city from the east side. There are fewer watchers on that flank.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1I3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1I4">The downpour continued, punctuated by ripping claps of thunder and flashes of lightning.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1I5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1I6">‘How long will the rain last?’ Belgarath shouted over the noise.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1I7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1I8">‘Long enough. It’s been building in the Sea of the East for a week. It hit the coast this morning. Turn east.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1I9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IA">‘Can we talk as we ride?’ Belgarath asked. ‘I have a great many questions.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1IB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IC">‘This is hardly the time for discussion, Belgarath. You have to hurry. The others arrived at Cthol Mishrak this morning, just ahead of the storm. Everything’s ready there, so move.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1ID"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IE">‘It’s going to be </span><span class="italic" aid="TI1IF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IG">tonight</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IH">?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1II"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IJ">‘It will, if you get there in time. Torak’s almost awake now. I think you’d better be there when he opens his eyes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1IK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IL">Belgarath wiped his streaming face again, and his eyes had a worried look. ‘Let’s go,’ he said sharply and he led them splashing off through the driving rain to solid ground.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1IM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IN">The rain continued for several hours, driven before a screaming wind. Sodden, miserable, and half-blinded by flying leaves and twigs, the three of them cantered toward the east. The baying of the Hounds trapped in the swamp faded behind them, taking on a baffled, frustrated note as the thunderous deluge obliterated all scents from the swamp and the forest.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1IO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IP">When night fell, they had reached a low range of hills far to the east, and the rain had subsided into a steady, unpleasant drizzle, punctuated by periodic squalls of chilly, gusting wind and erratic downpours that swept in randomly off the Sea of the East.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1IQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IR">‘Are you sure you know the way?’ Silk asked Belgarath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1IS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IT">‘I can find it,’ Belgarath said grimly. ‘Cthol Mishrak’s got a peculiar smell to it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1IU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1IV">The rain slackened into a few scattered droplets pattering on the leaves overhead and died out entirely by the time they reached the edge of the wood. The smell of which Belgarath had spoken was not a sharp reek, but rather was a muted, dank compound of odors. Damp rust seemed to be a major part of it, although the reek of stagnant water was also present, and the musty scent of fungus. The overall effect was one of decay. When they reached the last of the trees, Belgarath reined in. ‘Well, there it is,’ he said in a quiet voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1J0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1J1">The basin before them was faintly illuminated by a kind of pale, sickly radiance that seemed to emanate from the ground itself, and in the center of that large depression reared the jagged, broken remains of the city.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1J2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1J3">‘What’s that strange light?’ Garion whispered tensely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1J4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1J5">Belgarath grunted. ‘Phosphorescence. It comes from the fungus that grows everywhere out there. The sun never shines on Cthol Mishrak, so it’s a natural breeding ground for unwholesome things that grow in the dark. We’ll leave the horses here.’ He dismounted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1J6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1J7">‘Is that a very good idea?’ Silk asked him as he too swung down from his saddle. ‘We might want to leave in a hurry.’ The little man was still wet and shivering.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1J8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1J9">‘No,’ Belgarath said calmly. ‘If things go well, nothing in the city’s going to be interested in giving us any trouble. If things don’t go well, it’s not going to matter anyway.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1JA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1JB">‘I don’t like unalterable commitments,’ Silk muttered sourly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1JC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1JD">‘You picked the wrong journey, then,’ Belgarath replied. ‘What we’re about to do is just about as unalterable as things ever get. Once we start, there won’t be any possible way to turn back.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1JE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1JF">‘I still don’t have to like it, do I? What now?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1JG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1JH">‘Garion and I are going to change into something a bit less conspicuous. You’re an expert at moving about in the dark without being seen or heard, but we aren’t that skilled at it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1JI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1JJ">‘You’re going to use sorcery – </span><span class="italic" aid="TI1JK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1JL">this</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1JM"> close to Torak?’ Silk asked him incredulously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1JN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1JO">‘We’re going to be very quiet about it,’ Belgarath assured him. ‘A shape-change is directed almost entirely inward, so there isn’t that much noise involved anyway.’ He turned to Garion. ‘We’re going to do it slowly,’ he said. ‘That spreads out what little sound there is and makes it even fainter. Do you understand?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1JP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1JQ">‘I think so, Grandfather.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1JR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1JS">‘I’ll go first. Watch me.’ The old man glanced at their horses. ‘Let’s move away a bit. Horses are afraid of wolves. We don’t want them to get hysterical and start crashing around.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1JT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1JU">They crept along the edge of the trees until they were some distance from the horses.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1JV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1K0">‘This ought to be far enough,’ Belgarath said. ‘Now watch.’ He concentrated for a moment, and then his form began to shimmer and blur. The change-over was very gradual, and for several moments his face and the wolf’s face seemed to coexist in the same place. The sound it made was only the faintest of whispers. Then it was done, and the great silver wolf sat on his haunches.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1K1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1K2">‘Now you do it,’ he told Garion with the slight change of expression that is so much a part of the speech of wolves.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1K3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1K4">Garion concentrated very hard, holding the shape firmly in his mind. He did it so slowly that it seemed that he could actually feel the fur growing on his body.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1K5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1K6">Silk had been rubbing dirt on his face and hands to reduce the visibility of his skin. He looked at the two wolves, his eyes questioning.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1K7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1K8">Belgarath nodded once and led the way out onto the bare earth of the basin that sloped down toward the rotting ruins of Cthol Mishrak.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1K9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KA">There were other shapes moving in the faint light, prowling, snuffling. Some of the shapes had a dog smell to them; others smelled faintly reptilian. Grolims, robed and cowled, stood watch on various hummocks and rocks, searching the darkness with their eyes and their minds for intruders.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1KB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KC">The earth beneath Garion’s paws felt dead. There was no growth, no life on this wasted heath. With Silk crouched low between them, the two wolves crept, belly low, toward the ruin, taking full advantage of rocky outcrops and eroded gullies. Their pace seemed excruciatingly slow to Garion, but Belgarath paid little attention to the passage of time. Occasionally, when they passed near one of the watching Grolims, they moved but one paw at a time. The minutes dragged by as they crept closer and closer to the broken City of Night.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1KD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KE">Near the shattered wall, two of the hooded priests of Torak stood in quiet conversation. Their muted voices fell clearly upon Garion’s intensely sharpened ears.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1KF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KG">‘The Hounds seem nervous tonight,’ one of them said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1KH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KI">‘The storm,’ the other replied. ‘Bad weather always makes them edgy.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1KJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KK">‘I wonder what it’s like to be a Hound,’ the first Grolim mused.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1KL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KM">‘If you like, perhaps they’ll let you join them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1KN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KO">‘I don’t think I’m </span><span class="italic" aid="TI1KP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KQ">that</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KR"> curious.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1KS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KT">Silk and the two wolves, moving as silently as smoke, passed no more than ten yards from the two idly chatting guards, and crept over the fallen stones into the dead City of Night. Once among the ruins, they were able to move faster. The shadows concealed their movements, and they flitted among the blasted stones in Belgarath’s wake, moving steadily toward the center of the city where the stump of the iron tower now reared stark and black toward the murky sky.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1KU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1KV">The reek of rust, stagnation, and decay was much stronger, coming to Garion’s wolf-sharp nose in almost overpowering waves. It was a gagging smell, and he clamped his muzzle shut and tried not to think about it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1L0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1L1">‘Who’s there?’ a voice came sharply from just ahead of them. A Grolim with a drawn sword stepped out into the rubble-strewn street, peering intently into the deep shadows where the three crouched, frozen into immobility. Garion sensed rather than heard or saw Silk’s slow, deliberate reach toward the dagger sheathed at the back of his neck. Then the little man’s arm swung sharply down, and his knife made a fluttering whistle as it sped with deadly accuracy, turning end for end as it flew.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1L2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1L3">The Grolim grunted, doubling over sharply, then he sighed and toppled forward, his sword clanging as it fell.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1L4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1L5">‘Let’s move!’ Silk ran past the huddled form of the dead Grolim sprawled on the stones.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1L6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1L7">Garion smelled fresh blood as he loped past, and the smell brought a sudden, hot taste to his mouth.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1L8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1L9">They reached the massive tangle of twisted girders and crumpled plates that had been the iron tower and crept silently through the open doorway into the total blackness of the chamber within. The smell of rust was everywhere now; coupled with it was a smell of ancient, brooding evil. Garion stopped, sniffing nervously at the tainted air, feeling his hackles rising on his ruffed neck. With an effort, he suppressed the low growl that rose involuntarily in his throat.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1LA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1LB">He felt Belgarath’s shoulder brush him and he followed the old wolf, guided now by scent alone in the utter blackness. At the far end of the huge, empty, iron room there was another doorway.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1LC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1LD">Belgarath stopped, and Garion felt again that faint brushing whisper as the old man slowly shifted back into the shape of a man. Garion clenched in his own will and let himself gradually flow back into his own form.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1LE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1LF">Silk was breathing a string of colorful curses, fervent but almost inaudible.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1LG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1LH">‘What’s the matter?’ Belgarath whispered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1LI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1LJ">‘I forgot to stop for my knife,’ Silk replied, grating his teeth together. ‘It’s one of my favorites.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1LK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1LL">‘What now, Grandfather?’ Garion asked, his whisper hoarse.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1LM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1LN">‘Just beyond this door, there’s a flight of stairs leading down.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1LO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1LP">‘What’s at the bottom?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1LQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1LR">‘A cellar. It’s a sort of tomb where Zedar’s got Torak’s body. Shall we go down?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="TI1LS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="TI1LT">Garion sighed, then squared his shoulders. ‘I guess that’s what we came for,’ he replied.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_31" aid="TI1LU"></div>

<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos836511" aid="UGI01"><span class="calibre5" aid="UGI02"><span class="italic" aid="UGI03"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI04">Chapter Twenty-Two</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="UGI05"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI06">‘You don’t actually believe I’ll accept that, do you, Zedar?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI07"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI08">Garion froze in the act of putting his hand on the iron door at the foot of the stairs.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI09"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0A">‘You can’t evade your responsibility with the pretence of necessity,’ the voice beyond the door continued.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI0B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0C">‘Aren’t we all driven by necessity, Polgara?’ a stranger’s voice replied with a kind of weary sadness. ‘I won’t say that I was blameless, but wasn’t my apostacy predestined? The universe has been divided against itself since the beginning of time, and now the two Prophecies rush toward each other for their final meeting when all will be resolved. Who can say that what I have done was not essential to that meeting?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI0D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0E">‘That’s an evasion, Zedar,’ Aunt Pol told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI0F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0G">‘What’s </span><span class="italic" aid="UGI0H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0I">she</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0J"> doing here?’ Garion whispered to Belgarath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI0K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0L">‘She’s supposed to be here,’ Belgarath whispered back with an odd note of satisfaction. ‘Listen.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI0M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0N">‘I don’t think we’ll gain anything by wrangling with each other, Polgara,’ Zedar the Apostate was saying. ‘We each believe that what we did was right. Neither of us could ever persuade the other to change sides at this point. Why don’t we just let it go at that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI0O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0P">‘Very well, Zedar,’ Aunt Pol replied coolly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI0Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0R">‘What now?’ Silk breathed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI0S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0T">‘There should be others in there, too,’ Belgarath answered softly. ‘Let’s make sure before we go bursting in.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI0U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI0V">The iron door in front of them did not fit tightly, and faint light seeped through the cracks around the frame. Garion could make out Belgarath’s intent face in that dim light.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI10"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI11">‘How’s your father?’ Zedar asked in a neutral tone.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI12"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI13">‘About the same as always. He’s very angry with you, you know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI14"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI15">‘That was to be expected, I suppose.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI16"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI17">‘He’s finished eating, Lady Polgara,’ Garion heard Ce’Nedra say. He looked sharply at Belgarath, but the old man put one finger to his lips.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI18"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI19">‘Spread one of those pallets out for him, dear,’ Aunt Pol instructed, ‘and cover him with some blankets. It’s very late, and he’s sleepy.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI1A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI1B">‘I’ll do that,’ Durnik offered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI1C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI1D">‘Good,’ Belgarath breathed. ‘They’re all here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI1E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI1F">‘How did they get here?’ Silk whispered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI1G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI1H">‘I haven’t the faintest idea, and I’m not going to worry about it. The important thing is that they’re here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI1I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI1J">‘I’m glad you were able to rescue him from Ctuchik,’ Zedar said. ‘I grew rather fond of him during the years we spent together.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI1K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI1L">‘Where did you find him?’ Aunt Pol asked. ‘We’ve never been able to pin down what country he’s from.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI1M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI1N">‘I forget precisely,’ Zedar answered, and his voice was faintly troubled. ‘Perhaps it was Camaar or Tol Honeth – or maybe some city on the other side of Mallorea. The details keep slipping away from me – almost as if I weren’t supposed to examine them too closely.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI1O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI1P">‘Try to remember,’ she said. ‘It might be important.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI1Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI1R">Zedar sighed. ‘If it amuses you,’ he said. He paused as if thinking. ‘I’d grown restless for some reason,’ he began. ‘It was – oh, fifty or sixty years ago. My studies no longer interested me, and the bickering of the various Grolim factions began to irritate me. I took to wandering about – not really paying much attention to where I was. I must have crossed and crisscrossed the Kingdoms of the West and the Angarak Kingdoms a half-dozen times in those years.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI1S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI1T">‘Anyway, I was passing through some city somewhere when the idea struck me all at once. We all know that the Orb will destroy anyone who touches it with the slightest trace of evil in his heart, but what would it do to someone who touched it in total innocence? I was stunned by the simplicity of the idea. The street I was on was full of people, and I needed quiet to consider this remarkable idea, so I turned a corner into some forgotten alley, and there the child was – almost as if he’d been waiting for me. He seemed to be about two years old at the time – old enough to walk and not much more. I held out my hand to him and said, “I have a little errand for you, my boy.” He came to me and repeated the word, “Errand.” It’s the only word I’ve ever heard him say.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI1U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI1V">‘What did the Orb do when he first touched it?’ Aunt Pol asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI20"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI21">‘It flickered. In some peculiar way it seemed to recognize him, and something seemed to pass between them when he laid his hand on it.’ He sighed. ‘No, Polgara, I don’t know who the child is – or even what he is. For all I know, he may even be an illusion. The idea to use him in the first place came to me so suddenly that I sometimes wonder if perhaps it was placed in my mind. It’s entirely possible, I suppose, that I didn’t find </span><span class="italic" aid="UGI22"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI23">him</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI24">, but that he found </span><span class="italic" aid="UGI25"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI26">me</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI27">.’ He fell silent again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI28"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI29">There was a long pause on the other side of the iron door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI2A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI2B">‘Why, Zedar?’ Aunt Pol asked him very quietly. ‘Why did you betray our Master?’ Her voice was strangely compassionate.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI2C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI2D">‘To save the Orb,’ he replied sadly. ‘At least, at first that was the idea. From the moment I first saw it, it owned me. After Torak took it from our Master, Belgarath and the others began making their plans to regain it by force, but I knew that if Aldur himself did not join his hand with theirs to strike directly at Torak, they would fail – and Aldur would not do that. I reasoned that if force must fail, then guile might succeed. I thought that by pretending allegiance to Torak, I might gain his confidence and steal it back from him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI2E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI2F">‘What happened, Zedar?’ Her question was very direct.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI2G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI2H">There was another long, painful pause.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI2I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI2J">‘Oh, Polgara!’ Zedar’s voice came in a strangled sob. ‘You cannot know! I was so sure of myself – so certain that I could keep a part of my mind free from Torak’s domination – but I was wrong – wrong! His mind and will overwhelm me. He took me in his hand and he crushed out all of my resistance. The touch of his hand, Polgara!’ There was horror in Zedar’s voice. ‘It reaches down into the very depths of your soul. I know Torak for what he is – loathsome, twisted, evil beyond your understanding of the word – but when he calls me, I must go; and what he bids me do, I must do – even though my soul shrieks within me against it. Even now, as he sleeps, his fist is around my heart.’ There was another hoarse sob.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI2K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI2L">‘Didn’t you know that it’s impossible to resist a God?’ Aunt Pol asked in that same compassionate voice. ‘Was it pride, Zedar? Were you so sure of your power that you thought you could trick him – that you could conceal your intention from him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI2M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI2N">Zedar sighed. ‘Perhaps,’ he admitted. ‘Aldur was a gentle Master. He never brought his mind down on me, so I was not prepared for what Torak did to me. Torak is not gentle. What he wants, he takes – and if he must rip out your soul in the taking, it does not matter to him in the slightest. You’ll discover his power, Polgara. Soon he’ll awaken and he’ll destroy Belgarion. Not even the Rivan King is a match for that awful mind. And then Torak will take you as his bride – as he has always said he would. Don’t resist him, Polgara. Save yourself that agony. In the end, you’ll go to him anyway. You’ll go willingly – even eagerly.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI2O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI2P">There was a sudden scraping sound in the room beyond the iron door, and a quick rush of feet.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI2Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI2R">‘Durnik!’ Aunt Pol cried sharply. ‘No!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI2S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI2T">‘What’s happening?’ Garion demanded of Belgarath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI2U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI2V">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="UGI30"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI31">That’s</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI32"> what it means!’ Belgarath gasped. ‘Get that door open!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI33"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI34">‘Get back, you fool!’ Zedar was shouting.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI35"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI36">There was a sudden crash, the sound of bodies locked in struggle smashing into furniture.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI37"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI38">‘I warn you,’ Zedar cried again. ‘Get back!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI39"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI3A">There was the sharp sound of a blow, of a fist striking solid bone.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI3B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI3C">‘Zedar!’ Belgarath roared, yanking at the iron door.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI3D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI3E">Then within the room there was a thunderous detonation.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI3F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI3G">‘Durnik!’ Aunt Pol shrieked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI3H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI3I">In a sudden burst of fury, Belgarath raised his clenched hand, joined his flaming will with his arm and drove his fist at the locked door. The massive force of his blow ripped the iron door from its hinges as if it had been no more than paper.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI3J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI3K">The room beyond had a vaulted, curved ceiling supported by great iron girders, black with age. Garion seemed to see everything in the room at once with a curious kind of detachment, as if all emotion had been drained from him. He saw Ce’Nedra and Errand clinging to each other in fright beside one wall. Aunt Pol was standing as if locked in place, her eyes wide as she stared in stunned disbelief at the still form of Durnik the smith, who lay crumpled on the floor, and whose face had that deadly pale cast to it that could only mean one thing. A terrible flood of realization suddenly swept her face – a realization of an irrevocable loss. ‘No!’ she cried out. ‘My Durnik – No!’ She rushed to the fallen man, fell on her knees beside him and gathered his still form into her arms with a heartbroken wail of grief and despair.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI3L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI3M">And then Garion saw Zedar the Apostate for the first time. The sorcerer was also staring at Durnik’s body. There was a desperate regret on his face – a knowledge that he had finally committed the one act that for ever put him past all hope of redemption. ‘You fool,’ he muttered. ‘Why? Why did you make me kill you? That’s the one thing above all others I didn’t want to do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI3N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI3O">Then Belgarath, as inexorable as death itself, lunged through the shattered remains of the door and rushed upon the man he had once called brother.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI3P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI3Q">Zedar flinched back from the old sorcerer’s awful rage. ‘I didn’t mean to do it, Belgarath,’ he quavered, his hands raised to ward off Belgarath’s rush. ‘The fool tried to attack me. He was—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI3R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI3S">‘You—’ Belgarath grated at him from between teeth clenched with hate. ‘You – you—’ But he was past speech. No word could contain his rage. He raised both arms and struck at Zedar’s face with his fists. Zedar reeled back, but Belgarath was upon him, grappling, pounding at him with his hands.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI3T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI3U">Garion could feel flickers of will from one or the other of them; but caught up in emotions so powerful that they erased thought, neither was coherent enough to focus the force within him. And so, like two tavern brawlers, they rolled on the floor, kicking, gouging, pounding at each other, Belgarath consumed with fury and Zedar with fear and chagrin.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI3V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI40">Desperately, the Apostate jerked a dagger from the sheath at his waist, and Belgarath seized his wrist in both hands and pounded it on the floor until the knife went skittering away. Then each struggled to reach the dagger, clawing and jerking at each other, their faces frozen into intense grimaces as each strove to reach the dagger first.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI41"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI42">At some point during the frenzied seconds when they had burst into the room, Garion had, unthinking, drawn the great sword from its sheath across his back, but the Orb and the blade were cold and unresponsive in his hand as he stood watching the deadly struggle between the two sorcerers.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI43"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI44">Belgarath’s hands were locked about Zedar’s throat, and Zedar, strangling, clawed desperately at the old man’s arms. Belgarath’s face was contorted into an animal snarl, his lips drawn back from clenched teeth as he throttled his ancient enemy. As if finally driven past all hope of sanity, he struggled to his feet, dragging Zedar up with him. Holding the Apostate by the throat with one hand, he began to rain blows on him with the other. Then, between one blow and the next, he swung his arm down and pointed at the stones beneath their feet. With a dreadful grinding, a great crack appeared, zigzagging across the floor. The rocks shrieked in protest as the crack widened. Still struggling, the two men toppled and fell into the yawning fissure. The earth seemed to shudder. With a terrible sound, the crack ground shut.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI45"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI46">Incredulously, his mouth suddenly agape, Garion stared in stunned disbelief at the scarcely discernible crack through which the two men had fallen.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI47"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI48">Ce’Nedra screamed, her hands going to her face in horror.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI49"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4A">‘Do something!’ Silk shouted at Garion, but Garion could only stare at him in blank incomprehension.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI4B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4C">‘Polgara!’ Silk said desperately, turning to Aunt Pol. Still incapacitated by her sudden, overwhelming grief, she could not respond, but knelt with Durnik’s lifeless body in her arms, weeping uncontrollably as she rocked back and forth, holding him tightly against her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI4D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4E">From infinitely far beneath there was a sullen detonation, and then another. Even in the bowels of the earth, the deadly struggle continued.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI4F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4G">As if compelled, Garion’s eyes sought out the embrasure in the far wall; there in the dim light he could make out the recumbent form of Kal Torak. Strangely emotionless, Garion stared at the form of his enemy, meticulously noting every detail. He saw the black robe and the polished mask. And he saw Cthrek Goru, Torak’s great black sword.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI4H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4I">Although he did not – could not – move or even feel, a struggle, nonetheless, raged inside him – a struggle perhaps even more dreadful than that which had just plunged Belgarath and Zedar into the depths of the earth. The two forces which had first diverged and then turned and rushed at each other down the endless corridors of time had finally met within him. The </span><span class="calibre2" aid="UGI4J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4K">EVENT</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4L"> which was the ultimate conclusion of the two Prophecies, had begun, and its first skirmishes were taking place within Garion’s mind. Minute and very subtle adjustments were shifting some of his most deeply ingrained attitudes and perceptions.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI4M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4N">Torak moved, stirring restlessly, as those same two forces met within </span><span class="italic" aid="UGI4O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4P">him</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4Q">.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI4R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4S">Dreadful flashes of the sleeping God’s mind assailed Garion, and he saw clearly the terrible subterfuge that lay behind Torak’s offer of friendship and love. Had his fear of their duel drawn him into yielding, fully half of creation would have shimmered and vanished. More than that, what Torak had offered was not love but an enslavement so vile that it was beyond imagining.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI4T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI4U">But he had not yielded. He had somehow evaded the overwhelming force of Torak’s mind and had placed himself utterly in the hands of the Prophecy that had drawn him here. With an absolute denial of self, he had become the instrument of the Prophecy. He was no longer afraid. Sword in hand, the Child of Light awaited the moment when the Prophecy would release him to join in deadly struggle with the Dark God.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI4V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI50">Then, even as Silk desperately tried to arouse either Garion or Polgara to action, the stones of the floor buckled upward, and Belgarath rose from the earth.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="UGI51"><span class="calibre_1" aid="UGI52">Garion, still abstracted and bemused, saw that all traces of the sometimes foolish old man he had known before were gone. The thieving old storyteller had vanished. Even the irritable old man who had led the quest for the Orb no longer existed. In their place stood the form of Belgarath the sorcerer, the Eternal Man, shimmering in the aura of his full power.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_32" aid="UGI53"></div>
