<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos857368" aid="VF2I1"><span class="calibre5" aid="VF2I2"><span class="italic" aid="VF2I3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2I4">Chapter Twenty-Three</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="VF2I5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2I6">‘Where is Zedar?’ Aunt Pol asked, raising her tearstreaked face from Durnik’s lifeless body to stare with a dreadful intensity at her father.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2I7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2I8">‘I left him down there,’ Belgarath replied bleakly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2I9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2IA">‘Dead?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2IB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2IC">‘No.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2ID"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2IE">‘Bring him back.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2IF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2IG">‘Why?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2IH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2II">‘To face me.’ Her eyes burned.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2IJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2IK">The old man shook his head. ‘No, Pol,’ he said to her. ‘You’ve never killed anyone. Let’s leave it that way.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2IL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2IM">She gently lowered Durnik’s body to the floor and rose to her feet, her pale face twisted with grief and an awful need. ‘Then </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2IN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2IO">I</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2IP"> will go to him,’ she declared, raising both arms as if to strike at the earth beneath her feet.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2IQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2IR">‘No,’ Belgarath told her, extending his own hand, ‘you will </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2IS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2IT">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2IU">.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2IV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2J0">They stood facing each other, locked in a dreadful, silent struggle. Aunt Pol’s look at first was one of annoyance at her father’s interference. She raised one arm again to bring the force of her will crashing down at the earth, but once again Belgarath put forth his hand.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2J1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2J2">‘Let me go, father.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2J3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2J4">‘No.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2J5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2J6">She redoubled her efforts, twisting as if trying to free herself from his unseen restraint. ‘Let me go, old man,’ she cried.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2J7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2J8">‘No. Don’t do this, Pol. I don’t want to hurt you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2J9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2JA">She tried again, more desperately this time, but once again Belgarath smothered her will with his. His face hardened, and he set his jaw.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2JB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2JC">In a last effort, she flung the whole force of her mind against the barrier he had erected. Like some great rock, however, the old man remained firm. Finally her shoulders slumped, and she turned, knelt beside Durnik’s body, and began to weep again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2JD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2JE">‘I’m sorry, Pol,’ he said gently. ‘I never wanted to have to do that. Are you all right?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2JF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2JG">‘How can you ask that?’ she demanded brokenly, wringing her hands over Durnik’s silent body.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2JH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2JI">‘That’s not what I meant.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2JJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2JK">She turned her back on him and buried her face in her hands.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2JL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2JM">‘I don’t think you could have reached him anyway, Pol,’ the old man told her. ‘You know as well as I that what one of us does, another cannot undo.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2JN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2JO">Silk, his ferretlike face shocked, spoke in a hushed voice. ‘What did you do to him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2JP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2JQ">‘I took him down until we came to solid rock. And then I sealed him up in it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2JR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2JS">‘Can’t he just come up out of the earth the way you did?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2JT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2JU">‘No. That’s impossible for him now. Sorcery is thought, and no man can exactly duplicate the thought of another. Zedar’s imprisoned inside the rock for ever – or until I choose to free him.’ The old man looked mournfully at Durnik’s body. ‘And I don’t think I’ll chose to do that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2JV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2K0">‘He’ll die, won’t he?’ Silk asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2K1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2K2">Belgarath shook his head. ‘No. That was part of what I did to him. He’ll lie inside the rock until the end of days.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2K3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2K4">‘That’s monstrous, Belgarath,’ Silk said in a sick voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2K5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2K6">‘So was that,’ Belgarath replied grimly, pointing at Durnik.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2K7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2K8">Garion could hear what they were saying and could see them all quite clearly, but it seemed somehow that they were actually someplace else. The others in the underground crypt seemed to be on the periphery of his attention. For him there was only one other in the vaulted chamber, and that other was Kal Torak, his enemy.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2K9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KA">The restless stirring of the drowsing God became more evident. Garion’s peculiarly multiple awareness – in part his own, in part derived from the Orb, and as ever overlaid by the consciousness which he had always called the dry voice in his mind – perceived in that stirring the pain that lay beneath the maimed God’s movements. Torak was actually writhing as he half-slept. An injured man would heal in time, and his pain would gradually diminish and ultimately disappear, because injury was a part of the human condition. A man was born to be hurt from time to time, and the mechanism for recovery was born with him. A God, on the other hand, was invulnerable, and he had no need for the ability to heal. Thus it was with Torak. The fire which the Orb had loosed upon him when he had used it to crack the world still seared his flesh, and his pain had not diminished in the slightest down through all the endless centuries since his maiming. Behind that steel mask, the flesh of the Dragon-God’s face still smoked, and his burned eye still boiled endlessly in its socket. Garion shuddered, almost pitying that perpetual agony.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2KB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KC">The child, Errand, pulled himself free from Ce’Nedra’s trembling arms and crossed the flagstone floor of the tomb, his small face intent. He stopped, bent and put his hand on Durnik’s shoulder. Gently he shook the dead man as if trying to wake him. His little face became puzzled when the smith did not respond. He shook again, a bit harder, his eyes uncomprehending.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2KD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KE">‘Errand,’ Ce’Nedra called to him, her voice breaking, ‘come back. There’s nothing we can do.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2KF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KG">Errand looked at her, then back at Durnik. Then he gently patted the smith’s shoulder with a peculiar little gesture, sighed, and went back to the princess. She caught him suddenly in her arms and began to weep, burying her face against his small body. Once again with that same curious little gesture, he patted her flaming hair.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2KH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KI">Then from the alcove in the far wall there came a long, rasping sigh, a shuddering expiration of breath. Garion looked sharply toward the alcove, his hand tightening on the hilt of his cold sword. Torak had turned his head, and his eyes were open. The hideous fire burned in the eye that was not as the God came awake.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2KJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KK">Belgarath drew in his breath in a sharp hiss as Torak raised the charred stump of his left hand as if to brush away the last of his sleep, even as his right hand groped for the massive hilt of Cthrek Goru, his black sword. ‘Garion!’ Belgarath said sharply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2KL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KM">But Garion, still locked in stasis by the forces focusing upon him, could only stare at the awakening God. A part of him struggled to shake free, and his hand trembled as he fought to lift his sword.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2KN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KO">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="VF2KP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KQ">Not yet</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KR">,’ the voice whispered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2KS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KT">‘Garion!’ Belgarath actually shouted this time. Then, in a move seemingly born of desperation, the old sorcerer lunged past the bemused young man to fling himself upon the still recumbent form of the Dark God.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2KU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2KV">Torak’s hand released the hilt of his sword and almost contemptuously grasped the front of Belgarath’s tunic, lifting the struggling old man from him as one might lift a child. The steel mask twisted into an ugly sneer as the God held the helpless sorcerer out from him. Then, like a great wind, the force of Torak’s mind struck, hurling Belgarath across the room, ripping away the front of his tunic. Something glittered across Torak’s knuckles, and Garion realized that it was the silver chain of Belgarath’s amulet – the polished medallion of the standing wolf. In a very peculiar way the medallion had always been the center of Belgarath’s power, and now it lay in the grip of his ancient enemy.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2L0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2L1">With a dreadfully slow deliberation, the Dark God rose from his bier, towering over all of them, Cthrek Goru in his hand.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2L2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2L3">‘Garion!’ Ce’Nedra screamed. ‘Do something!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2L4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2L5">With deadly pace Torak strode toward the dazed Belgarath, raising his sword. But Aunt Pol sprang to her feet and threw herself between them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2L6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2L7">Slowly Torak lowered his sword, and then he smiled a loathsome smile. ‘My bride,’ he rasped in a horrid voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2L8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2L9">‘Never, Torak,’ she declared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2LA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2LB">He ignored her defiance. ‘Thou hast come to me at last, Polgara,’ he gloated.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2LC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2LD">‘I have come to watch you die.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2LE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2LF">‘Die, Polgara? Me? No, my bride, that is not why thou hast come. My will has drawn thee to me as was foretold. And now thou art mine. Come to me, my beloved.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2LG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2LH">‘Never!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2LI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2LJ">‘Never, Polgara?’ There was a dreadful insinuation in the God’s rasping voice. ‘Thou wilt submit to me, my bride. I will bend thee to my will. Thy struggles shall but make my victory over thee the sweeter. In the end, I will have thee. Come here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2LK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2LL">So overwhelming was the force of his mind that she swayed almost as a tree sways in the grip of a great wind. ‘No,’ she gasped, closing her eyes and turning her face away sharply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2LM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2LN">‘Look at me, Polgara,’ he commanded, his voice almost purring. ‘I am thy fate. All that thou didst think to love before me shall fall away, and thou shalt love only me. Look at me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2LO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2LP">Helplessly she turned her head and opened her eyes to stare at him. The hatred and defiance seemed to melt out of her, and a terrible fear came into her face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2LQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2LR">‘Thy will crumbles, my beloved,’ he told her. ‘Now come to me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2LS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2LT">She </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2LU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2LV">must</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2M0"> resist! All the confusion was gone now, and Garion understood at last. </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2M1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2M2">This</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2M3"> was the real battle. If Aunt Pol succumbed, they were all lost. It had all been for this.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2M4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2M5">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="VF2M6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2M7">Help her</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2M8">,’ the voice within him said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2M9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MA">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="VF2MB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MC">Aunt Pol!</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MD">’ Garion threw the thought at her, ‘</span><span class="italic" aid="VF2ME"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MF">Remember Durnik!</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MG">’ He knew without knowing how he knew that this was the one thing that could sustain her in her deadly struggle. He ranged through his memory, throwing images of Durnik at her – of the smith’s strong hands at work at his forge – of his serious eyes – of the quiet sound of his voice – and most of all of the good man’s unspoken love for her, the love that had been the center of Durnik’s entire life.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2MH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MI">She had begun involuntarily to move, no more than a slight shifting of her weight in preparation for that first fatal step in response to Torak’s overpowering command. Once she had made that step, she would be lost. But Garion’s memories of Durnik struck her like a blow. Her shoulders, which had already begun to droop in defeat, suddenly straightened, and her eyes flashed with renewed defiance. ‘Never!’ she told the expectantly waiting God. ‘I </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2MJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MK">will</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2ML"> not!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2MM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MN">Torak’s face slowly stiffened. His eyes blazed as he brought the full, crushing force of his will to bear upon her, but she stood firmly against all that he could do, clinging to the memory of Durnik as if to something so solid that not even the will of the Dark God could tear her from it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2MO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MP">A look of baffled frustration contorted Torak’s face as he perceived that she would never yield – that her love would be for ever denied to him. She had won, and her victory was like a knife twisting slowly inside him. Thwarted, enraged, maddened by her now-unalterable will to resist, Torak raised his face and suddenly howled – a shocking, animallike sound of overwhelming frustration.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2MQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MR">‘Then perish both!’ he raged. ‘Die with thy father!’ And with that, he once more raised his deadly sword.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2MS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MT">Unflinching, Aunt Pol faced the raging God.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2MU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2MV">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="VF2N0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2N1">Now, Belgarion!</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2N2">’ The voice cracked in Garion’s mind.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2N3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2N4">The Orb, which had remained cold and dead throughout all the dreadful confrontation between Aunt Pol and the maimed God, suddenly flared into life, and the sword of the Rivan King exploded into fire, filling the crypt with an intense blue light. Garion leaped forward, extending his sword to catch the deadly blow which was already descending upon Aunt Pol’s unprotected face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2N5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2N6">The steel sound of blade against blade was like the striking of a great bell, and it rang within the crypt, shimmering and echoing from the walls. Torak’s sword, deflected by the flaming blade, plowed a shower of sparks from the flagstone floor. The God’s single eye widened as he recognized all in one glance the Rivan King, the flaming sword and the blazing Orb of Aldur. Garion saw in the look that Torak had already forgotten Aunt Pol and that now the maimed God’s full attention was focused on </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2N7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2N8">him</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2N9">.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2NA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2NB">‘And so thou hast come at last, Belgarion,’ the God greeted him gravely. ‘I have awaited thy coming since the beginning of days. Thy fate awaits thee here. Hail, Belgarion, and farewell.’ His arm lashed back, and he swung a vast blow, but Garion, without even thinking, raised his own sword and once again the crypt rang with the bell note of blade against blade.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2NC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2ND">‘Thou art but a boy, Belgarion,’ Torak said. ‘Wilt thou pit thyself against the might and invincible will of a God? Submit to me, and I will spare thy life.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2NE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2NF">The will of the God of Angarak was now directed at </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2NG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2NH">him</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2NI">, and in that instant, Garion fully understood how hard Aunt Pol’s struggle had been. He felt the terrible compulsion to obey draining the strength from him. But suddenly a vast chorus of voices rang down through all the centuries to him, crying out the single word, ‘No!’ All the lives of all who preceeded him had been directed at this one moment, and those lives infused him now. Though he alone held Iron-grip’s sword, Belgarion of Riva was </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2NJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2NK">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2NL"> alone, and Torak’s will could not sway him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2NM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2NN">In a move of absolute defiance, Garion again raised his flaming sword.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2NO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2NP">‘So be it, then,’ Torak roared. ‘To the death, Belgarion!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2NQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2NR">At first it seemed but some trick of the flickering light that filled the tomb, but almost as soon as that thought occurred, Garion saw that Torak </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2NS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2NT">was</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2NU"> growing larger, swelling upward, towering, expanding. With an awful wrenching sound, he shouldered aside the rusted iron roof of the tomb, bursting upward.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2NV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2O0">Once again without thinking, without even stopping to consider </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2O1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2O2">how</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2O3"> to do it, Garion also began to expand, and he too exploded through the confining ceiling, shuddering away the rusty debris as he rose.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2O4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2O5">In open air among the decaying ruins of the City of Night the two titanic adversaries faced each other beneath the perpetual cloud that blotted out the sky.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2O6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2O7">‘The conditions are met,’ the dry voice spoke through Garion’s lips.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2O8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2O9">‘So it would seem,’ another, equally unemotional voice came from Torak’s steel-encased mouth.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2OA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2OB">‘Do you wish to involve others?’ Garion’s voice asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2OC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2OD">‘It hardly seems necessary. These two have sufficient capacity for what must be brought to bear upon them.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2OE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2OF">‘Then let it be decided here.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2OG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2OH">‘Agreed.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2OI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2OJ">And with that Garion felt a sudden release as all constraint was removed from him. Torak, also released, raised Cthrek Goru, his lips drawn back in a snarl of hate.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2OK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2OL">Their struggle was immense. Rocks shattered beneath the colossal force of deflected blows. The sword of the Rivan King danced in blue flames, and Cthrek Goru, Torak’s blade of shadows, swept a visible darkness with it at every blow. Beyond thought, beyond any emotion but blind hatred, the two swung and parried and lurched through the broken ruins, crushing all beneath them. The elements themselves erupted as the fight continued. The wind shrieked through the rotting city, tearing at the trembling stones. Lightning seethed about them, glaring and flickering. The earth rumbled and shook beneath their massive feet. The featureless cloud that had concealed the City of Night beneath its dark mantle for five millenia began to boil and race above them. Great patches of stars appeared and disappeared in the roiling middle of the surging cloud. The Grolims, both human and nonhuman, aghast at the towering struggle that had suddenly erupted in their very midst, fled shrieking in terror.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2OM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2ON">Garion’s blows were directed at Torak’s blind side, and the Dark God flinched from the fire of the Orb each time the flaming sword struck, but the shadow of Cthrek Goru put a deathly chill into Garion’s blood each time it passed over him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2OO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2OP">They were more evenly matched than Garion had imagined possible. Torak’s advantage of size had been erased when they had both swelled into immensity, and Garion’s inexperience was offset by Torak’s maiming.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2OQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2OR">It was the uneven ground that betrayed Garion. Retreating before a sudden flurry of massive blows, he felt one heel catch on a heap of tumbled rock, and the rotten stones crumbled and rolled beneath his feet. Despite his scrambling attempt to keep his balance, he fell.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2OS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2OT">Torak’s single eye blazed in triumph as he raised the dark sword. But, seizing his sword hilt in both hands, Garion raised his burning blade to meet that vast blow. When the swords struck, edge to edge, a huge shower of sparks cascaded down over Garion.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2OU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2OV">Again Torak raised Cthrek Goru, but a strange hunger flickered across his steel-encased face. ‘Yield!’ he roared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2P0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2P1">Garion stared up at the huge form towering over him, his mind racing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2P2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2P3">‘I have no wish to kill thee, boy,’ Torak said, almost pleading. ‘Yield and I will spare thy life.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2P4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2P5">And then Garion understood. His enemy was not trying to kill him, but was striving instead to force him to submit. Torak’s driving need was for domination! </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2P6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2P7">This</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2P8"> was where the real struggle between them lay!</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2P9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PA">‘Throw down thy sword, Child of Light, and bow before me,’ the God commanded, and the force of his mind was like a crushing weight.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2PB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PC">‘I </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2PD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PE">will</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PF"> not,’ Garion gasped, wrenching away from that awful compulsion. ‘You may kill me, but I will </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2PG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PH">not</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PI"> yield.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2PJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PK">Torak’s face twisted as if his perpetual agony had been doubled by Garion’s refusal. ‘Thou </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2PL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PM">must</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PN">,’ he almost sobbed. ‘Thou art helpless before me. Submit to me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2PO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PP">‘No!’ Garion shouted, and, taking advantage of Torak’s chagrin at that violent rejection, he rolled out from under the shadow of Cthrek Goru and sprang to his feet. Everything was clear now, and he knew at last how he could win.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2PQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PR">‘Hear me, maimed and despised God,’ he grated from between clenched teeth. ‘You are nothing. Your people fear you, but they do not love you. You tried to deceive me into loving you; you tried to force Aunt Pol to love you; but I refuse you even as she did. You’re a God, but you are nothing. In all the universe there is not one person – not one thing – that loves you. You are alone and empty, and even if you kill me, I will still win. Unloved and despised, you will howl out your miserable life to the end of days.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2PS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PT">Garion’s words struck the maimed God like blows, and the Orb, as if echoing those words, blazed anew, lashing at the Dragon-God with its consuming hatred. </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2PU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2PV">This</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2Q0"> was the </span><span class="calibre2" aid="VF2Q1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2Q2">EVENT</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2Q3"> for which the universe had waited since the beginning of time. </span><span class="italic" aid="VF2Q4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2Q5">This</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2Q6"> was why Garion had come to this decaying ruin – not to fight Torak, but to reject him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2Q7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2Q8">With an animal howl of anguish and rage, the Child of Dark raised Cthrek Goru above his head and ran at the Rivan King. Garion made no attempt to ward off the blow, but gripped the hilt of his flaming sword in both hands and, extending his blade before him, he lunged at his charging enemy.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2Q9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2QA">It was so easy. The sword of the Rivan King slid into Torak’s chest like a stick into water, and as it ran into the God’s suddenly stiffening body, the power of the Orb surged up the flaring blade.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2QB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2QC">Torak’s vast hand opened convulsively, and Cthrek Goru tumbled harmlessly from his grip. He opened his mouth to cry out, and blue flame gushed like blood from his mouth. He clawed at his face, ripping away the polished steel mask to reveal the hideously maimed features that had lain beneath. Tears started from his eyes, both the eye that was and the eye that was not, but the tears were also fire, for the sword of the Rivan King buried in his chest filled him with its flame.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2QD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2QE">He lurched backward. With a steely slither, the sword slid out of his body. But the fire the blade had ignited within him did not go out. He clutched at the gaping wound, and blue flame spurted out between his fingers, spattering in little burning pools among the rotting stones about him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2QF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2QG">His maimed face, still streaked with fiery tears, contorted in agony. He lifted that burning face to the heaving sky and raised his vast arms. In mortal anguish, the stricken God cried to heaven, ‘Mother!’ and the sound of his voice echoed from the farthest star.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2QH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2QI">He stood so for a frozen moment, his arms upraised in supplication, and then he tottered and fell dead at Garion’s feet.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2QJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2QK">For an instant there was absolute silence. Then a howling cry started at Torak’s dead lips, fading into unimaginable distance as the dark Prophecy fled, taking the inky shadow of Cthrek Goru with it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2QL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2QM">Again there was silence. The racing clouds overhead stopped in their mad plunge, and the stars that had appeared among the tatters of that cloud went out. The entire universe shuddered – and stopped. There was a moment of absolute darkness as all light everywhere went out and all motion ceased. In that dreadful instant all that existed – all that had been, all that was, all that was yet to be – was wrenched suddenly into the course of one Prophecy. Where there had always been two, there was now but one.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2QN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2QO">And then, faint at first, the wind began to blow, purging away the rotten stink of the City of Night, and the stars came on again like suddenly reilluminated jewels on the velvety throat of night. As the light returned, Garion stood wearily over the body of the God he had just killed. His sword still flickered blue in his hand, and the Orb exulted in the vaults of his mind. Vaguely he was aware that in that shuddering moment when all light had died, both he and Torak had returned to their normal size, but he was too tired to wonder about it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2QP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2QQ">From the shattered tomb not far away, Belgarath emerged, shaken and drawn. The broken chain of his medallion dangled from his tightly clenched hand, and he stopped to stare for a moment at Garion and the fallen God.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2QR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2QS">The wind moaned in the shattered ruins, and somewhere, far off in the night, the Hounds of Torak howled a mournful dirge for their fallen master.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2QT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2QU">Belgarath straightened his shoulders; then, in a gesture peculiarly like that which Torak had made in the moment of his death, he raised his arms to the sky.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="VF2QV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="VF2R0">‘Master!’ he cried out in a huge voice. ‘It is finished!’</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_33" aid="VF2R1"></div>

<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos888744" aid="10DJ41"><span class="calibre5" aid="10DJ42"><span class="italic" aid="10DJ43"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ44">Chapter Twenty-Four</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="10DJ45"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ46">It was over, but there was a bitterness in the taste of Garion’s victory. A man did not lightly kill a God, no matter how twisted or evil the God might be. And so Belgarion of Riva stood sadly over the body of his fallen enemy as the wind, smelling faintly of the approaching dawn, washed over the decaying ruins of the City of Night.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ47"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ48">‘Regrets, Garion?’ Belgarath asked quietly, putting his hand on his grandson’s shoulder.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ49"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ4A">Garion sighed. ‘No, Grandfather,’ he said. ‘I suppose not – not really. It had to be done, didn’t it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ4B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ4C">Belgarath nodded gravely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ4D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ4E">‘It’s just that he was so alone at the end. I took everything away from him before I killed him. I’m not very proud of that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ4F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ4G">‘As you say, it had to be done. It was the only way you could beat him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ4H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ4I">‘I just wish I could have left him something, that’s all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ4J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ4K">From the ruins of the shattered iron tower, a sad little procession emerged. Aunt Pol, Silk, and Ce’Nedra were bringing out the body of Durnik the smith, and walking gravely beside them came Errand.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ4L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ4M">A pang of almost unbearable grief ran through Garion. Durnik, his oldest friend, was pale and dead, and in that vast internal upheaval that had preceded the duel with Torak, Garion had not even been able to mourn.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ4N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ4O">‘It was necessary, you understand,’ Belgarath said sadly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ4P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ4Q">‘Why? Why did Durnik have to die, Grandfather?’ Garion’s voice was anguished, and tears stood openly in his eyes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ4R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ4S">‘Because his death gave your Aunt the will to resist Torak. That’s always been the one flaw in the Prophecy – the possibility that Pol might yield. All Torak needed was one person to love him. It would have made him invincible.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ4T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ4U">‘What would have happened if she had gone to him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ4V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ50">‘You’d have lost the fight. That’s why Durnik had to die.’ The old man sighed regretfully. ‘I wish it could have been otherwise, but it was inevitable.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ51"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ52">The three who had borne Durnik from the broken tomb gently laid his still form on the ground, and Ce’Nedra sadly joined Belgarath and Garion. Wordlessly, the tiny girl slipped her hand into Garion’s, and the three of them stood, silently watching as Aunt Pol, past tears now, gently straightened Durnik’s arms at his sides and then covered him with her cloak. She sat then upon the earth, took his head into her lap and almost absently stroked his hair, her head bowed over his in her grief.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ53"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ54">‘I can’t bear it,’ Ce’Nedra suddenly sobbed, and she buried her face in Garion’s shoulder and began to weep.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ55"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ56">And then there was light where there had been only darkness before. As Garion stared, a single beam of brilliant blue light descended from the broken and tattered cloud rolling overhead. The entire ruin seemed bathed in its intense radiance as the light touched the earth. Like a great, glowing column, the beam of light reached down to the earth from the night sky, was joined by other beams, red and yellow and green and shades Garion could not even name. Like the colors at the foot of a sudden rainbow, the great columns of light stood side by side on the other side of Torak’s fallen body. Then, indistinctly, Garion perceived that a glowing, incandescent figure stood within the center of each column of light. The Gods had returned to mourn the passing of their brother. Garion recognized Aldur, and he could easily identify each of the others. Mara still wept, and dead-eyed Issa seemed to undulate, serpentlike, as he stood within his glowing column of pale green light. Nedra’s face was shrewd, and Chaldan’s proud. Belar, the blond-haired, boyish God of the Alorns, had a roguish, impudent look about him, though his face, like those of his brothers, was sad at the death of Torak. The Gods had returned to earth in glowing light and with sound as well. The reeking air of Cthol Mishrak was suddenly alive with that sound as each colored beam of light gave off a different note, the notes joining in a harmony so profound that it seemed the answer to every question that had ever been asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ57"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ58">And finally, joining the other columns of light, a single, blindingly white beam slowly descended, and within the center of that radiance stood the white-robed form of UL, that strange God whom Garion had seen once in Prolgu.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ59"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ5A">The figure of Aldur, still embraced in its glowing blue nimbus, approached the ancient God of Ulgo. ‘Father,’ Aldur said sadly, ‘our brother, thy son Torak, is slain.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ5B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ5C">Shimmering and incandescent, the form of UL, father of the other Gods, moved across the rubble-strewn ground to stand over the silent body of Torak. ‘I tried to turn thee from this path, my son,’ he said softly, and a single tear coursed its way down his eternal cheek. Then he turned back to Aldur. ‘Take up the form of thy brother, my son, and place it upon some more suitable resting place. It grieves me to see him lie so low upon the earth.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ5D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ5E">Aldur, joined by his brethren, took up the body of Torak and placed it upon a large block of stone lying amid the ancient ruins, and then, standing in a quiet gleaming circle about the bier, they mourned the passing of the God of Angarak.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ5F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ5G">Unafraid as always, seemingly not even aware that the glowing figures which had descended from the sky were not human, Errand walked quite confidently to the shining form of UL. He reached out his small hand and tugged insistently at the God’s robe. ‘Father,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ5H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ5I">UL looked down at the small face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ5J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ5K">‘Father,’ Errand repeated, perhaps echoing Aldur, who had in his use of that name, revealed at last the true identity of the God of Ulgo. ‘Father,’ the little boy said again. Then he turned and pointed at the silent form of Durnik. ‘Errand!’ It was in some strange way more a command than a request.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ5L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ5M">The face of UL became troubled. ‘It is not possible, child,’ he replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ5N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ5O">‘Father,’ the little boy insisted, ‘Errand.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ5P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ5Q">UL looked inquiringly at Garion, his eyes profoundly unsettled. ‘The child’s request is serious,’ he said gravely, speaking not to Garion but to that other awareness, ‘and it places an obligation upon me – but it crosses the uncrossable boundary.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ5R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ5S">‘The boundary must remain intact,’ the dry voice replied through Garion’s lips. ‘Thy sons are passionate, Holy UL, and having once crossed this line, they may be tempted to do so again, and perhaps in one such crossing they may change that which must not be changed. Let us not provide the instrumentality whereby Destiny must once more follow two divergent paths.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ5T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ5U">UL sighed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ5V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ60">‘Wilt thou and thy sons, however, lend of your power to </span><span class="italic" aid="10DJ61"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ62">my</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ63"> instrument so that </span><span class="italic" aid="10DJ64"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ65">he</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ66"> may cross the boundary?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ67"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ68">UL looked startled at that.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ69"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ6A">‘Thus will the boundary be protected, and thy obligation shall be met. It can happen in no other way.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ6B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ6C">‘Let it be as thou wilt,’ UL agreed. He turned then and a peculiar look passed between the father of the Gods and his eldest son, Aldur.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ6D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ6E">Aldur, still bathed in blue light, turned from his sad contemplation of his dead brother toward Aunt Pol, who was still bowed over Durnik’s body.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ6F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ6G">‘Be comforted, my daughter,’ he told her. ‘His sacrifice was for thee and for all mankind.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ6H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ6I">‘That is slight comfort, Master,’ she replied, her eyes full of tears. ‘This was the best of men.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ6J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ6K">‘All men die, my daughter, the best as well as the worst. In thy life thou hast seen this many times.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ6L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ6M">‘Yes, Master, but this is different.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ6N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ6O">‘In what way, beloved Polgara?’ Aldur seemed to be pressing her for some reason.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ6P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ6Q">Aunt Pol bit her lip. ‘Because I loved him, Master,’ she replied finally.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ6R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ6S">The faintest touch of a smile appeared on Aldur’s lips. ‘Is that so difficult to say, my daughter?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ6T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ6U">She could not answer, but bowed again over Durnik’s lifeless form.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ6V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ70">‘Wouldst thou have us restore this man to thee, my daughter?’ Aldur asked then.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ71"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ72">Her face came up sharply. ‘That isn’t possible, Master,’ she said. ‘Please don’t toy with my grief like this.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ73"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ74">‘Let us, however, consider that it </span><span class="italic" aid="10DJ75"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ76">may</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ77"> be possible,’ he told her. ‘Wouldst thou have us restore him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ78"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ79">‘With all my heart, Master.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ7A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7B">‘To what end? What task hast thou for this man that demands his restoration?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ7C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7D">She bit her lip again. ‘To be my husband, Master,’ she blurted finally with a trace of defiance in her voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ7E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7F">‘And was that also so very difficult to say? Art thou sure, however, that this love of thine derives not from thy grief, and that once this good man is restored, thy mind might not turn away from him? He </span><span class="italic" aid="10DJ7G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7H">is</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7I">, thou must admit, most ordinary.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ7J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7K">‘Durnik has never been ordinary,’ she flared with sudden heat. ‘He is the best and bravest man in the world.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ7L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7M">‘I meant him no disrespect, Polgara, but no power doth infuse him. The force of the Will and the Word is not in him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ7N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7O">‘Is that so important, Master?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ7P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7Q">‘Marriage must be a joining of equals, my daughter. How could this good, brave man be husband to thee, so long as </span><span class="italic" aid="10DJ7R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7S">thy</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7T"> power remains?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ7U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ7V">She looked at him helplessly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ80"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ81">‘Couldst thou, Polgara, limit thyself? Wouldst thou become his equal? With power no more than his?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ82"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ83">She stared at him, hesitated, then blurted the one word, ‘Yes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ84"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ85">Garion was shocked – not so much by Aunt Pol’s acceptance but rather by Aldur’s request. Aunt Pol’s power was central to her very being. To remove it from her would leave her with nothing. What would she be without it? How could she even live without it? It was a cruel price to demand, and Garion had believed that Aldur was a kindly God.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ86"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ87">‘I will accept thy sacrifice, Polgara,’ Aldur was saying. ‘I will speak with my father and my brothers. For good and proper reasons, we have denied ourselves this power, and we must all agree to it before any of us might attempt this violation of the natural order of things.’ And he returned to the sorrowful gathering about Torak’s bier.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ88"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ89">‘How could he do that?’ Garion, his arm still about Ce’Nedra, demanded of his grandfather.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ8A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8B">‘Do what?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ8C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8D">‘Ask her to give up her power like that? It will destroy her.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ8E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8F">‘She’s much stronger than you think, Garion,’ Belgarath assured him, ‘and Aldur’s reasoning is sound. No marriage could survive that kind of inequality.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ8G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8H">Among the glowing Gods, however, one angry voice was raised. ‘No!’ It was Mara, the weeping God of the Marags, who were no more. ‘Why should one man be restored when all my slaughtered children still lie cold and dead? Did Aldur hear </span><span class="italic" aid="10DJ8I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8J">my</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8K"> pleas? Did he come to </span><span class="italic" aid="10DJ8L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8M">my</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8N"> aid when my children died? I will not consent.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ8O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8P">‘I hadn’t counted on that,’ Belgarath muttered. ‘I’d better take steps before this goes any further.’ He crossed the littered ground and bowed respectfully. ‘Forgive my intrusion,’ he said, ‘but would my Master’s brother accept a woman of the Marags as a gift in exchange for his aid in restoring Durnik?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ8Q"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8R">Mara’s tears, which had been perpetual, suddenly stopped, and his face became incredulous. ‘A Marag woman?’ he demanded sharply. ‘None such exist. I would have known in my heart if one of my children had survived in Maragor.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ8S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8T">‘Of a certainty, Lord Mara,’ Belgarath agreed quickly. ‘But what of those few who were carried </span><span class="italic" aid="10DJ8U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ8V">out</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ90"> of Maragor to dwell in perpetual slavery?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ91"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ92">‘Knowest thou of such a one, Belgarath?’ Mara asked with a desperate eagerness.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ93"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ94">The old man nodded. ‘We discovered her in the slave pens beneath Rak Cthol, Lord Mara. Her name is Taiba. She is but one, but a race may be restored by such a one as she – particularly if she be watched over by a loving God.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ95"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ96">‘Where is Taiba, my daughter?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ97"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ98">‘In the care of Relg, the Ulgo,’ Belgarath replied. ‘They seem quite attached to each other,’ he added blandly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ99"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ9A">Mara looked at him thoughtfully. ‘A race may not be restored by one,’ he said, ‘even in the care of the most loving God. It requires two.’ He turned to UL. ‘Wilt thou give me this Ulgo, Father?’ he asked. ‘He shall become the sire of my people.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ9B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ9C">UL gave Belgarath a rather penetrating look. ‘Thou knowest that Relg hath another duty to perform,’ he said pointedly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ9D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ9E">Belgarath’s expression was almost impish. ‘I am certain that the Gorim and I can work out the details, Most Holy,’ he declared with utmost self-confidence.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ9F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ9G">‘Aren’t you forgetting something, Belgarath?’ Silk asked diffidently, as if not wanting to intrude. ‘Relg has this little problem, remember?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ9H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ9I">Belgarath gave the little man a hard look.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ9J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ9K">‘I just thought I ought to mention it,’ Silk said innocently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ9L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ9M">Mara looked sharply at them. ‘What is this?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ9N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ9O">‘A minor difficulty, Lord Mara,’ Belgarath said quickly. ‘One I’m certain Taiba can overcome. I have the utmost confidence in her in that particular area.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ9P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ9Q">‘I will have the truth of this,’ Mara said firmly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ9R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ9S">Belgarath sighed and gave Silk another grim look. ‘Relg is a zealot, Lord Mara,’ he explained. ‘For religious reasons, he avoids certain – ah – forms of human contact.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ9T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJ9U">‘Fatherhood is his destiny,’ UL said. ‘From him will issue a special child. I will explain this to him. He is an obedient man, and he will put aside his aversions for my sake.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJ9V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJA0">‘Then thou wilt give him to me, Father?’ Mara asked eagerly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJA1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJA2">‘He is thine – with but one restriction – of which we will speak later.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJA3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJA4">‘Let us see to this brave Sendar, then,’ Mara said, and all traces of his weeping were now gone.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJA5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJA6">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="10DJA7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJA8">Belgarion</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJA9">,’ the voice in Garion’s mind said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJAA"><span class="italic" aid="10DJAB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJAC">‘What?’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJAD"><span class="italic" aid="10DJAE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJAF">‘The restoration of your friend is in your hands now.’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJAG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJAH">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="10DJAI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJAJ">Me? Why me?</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJAK">’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJAL"><span class="italic" aid="10DJAM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJAN">‘Must you always say that? Do you want Durnik’s life restored?’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJAO"><span class="italic" aid="10DJAP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJAQ">‘Of course, but I can’t do it. I wouldn’t even know where to begin.’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJAR"><span class="italic" aid="10DJAS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJAT">‘You did it before. Remember the colt in the cave of the Gods?’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJAU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJAV">Garion had almost forgotten that.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJB0"><span class="italic" aid="10DJB1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJB2">‘You are my instrument, Belgarion. I can keep you from making mistakes – most of the time anyway. Just relax; I’ll show you what to do.’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJB3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJB4">Garion was already moving without conscious volition. He let his arm fall from about Ce’Nedra’s shoulders, and, his sword still in his hand, he walked slowly toward Aunt Pol and Durnik’s body. He looked once into her eyes as she sat with the dead man’s head in her lap, and then he knelt beside the body.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJB5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJB6">‘For me, Garion,’ she murmured to him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJB7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJB8">‘If I can, Aunt Pol,’ he said. Then, without knowing why, he laid the sword of the Rivan King upon the ground and took hold of the Orb at its pommel. With a faint click, the Orb came free in his hand. Errand, smiling now, approached from the other side and also knelt, taking up Durnik’s lifeless hand in his. Holding the Orb in both hands, Garion reached out and put it against the dead man’s chest. He was faintly conscious of the fact that the Gods had gathered about in a circle and that they had reached out their arms, palm to palm, forming an unbroken ring. Within that circle, a great light began to pulsate, and the Orb, as if in answer, glowed between his hands.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJB9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBA">The blank wall he had seen once before was there again, still black, impenetrable, and silent. As he had before in the cave of the Gods, Garion pushed tentatively against the substance of death itself, striving to reach through and pull his friend back into the world of the living.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJBB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBC">It was different this time. The colt he had brought to life in the cave had never lived except within its mother’s body. Its death had been as tenuous as its life, and it lay but a short distance beyond the barrier. Durnik, however, had been a man full grown, and his death, like his life, was far more profound. With all his strength, Garion pushed. He could feel the enormous force of the combined wills of the Gods joining with his in the silent struggle, but the barrier would not yield.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJBD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBE">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="10DJBF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBG">Use the Orb!</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBH">’ the voice commanded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJBI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBJ">This time Garion focused all the power, his own and that of the Gods, upon the round stone between his hands. It flickered, then glowed, then flickered again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJBK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBL">‘</span><span class="italic" aid="10DJBM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBN">Help me!</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBO">’ Garion commanded it.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJBP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBQ">As if suddenly understanding, the Orb flared into a coruscating eruption of colored light. The barrier was weakening.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJBR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBS">With an encouraging little smile, Errand reached out and laid one hand upon the blazing Orb.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJBT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJBU">The barrier broke. Durnik’s chest heaved, and he coughed once.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJBV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJC0">With profoundly respectful expressions upon their eternal faces, the Gods stepped back. Aunt Pol cried out in sudden relief and clasped her arms about Durnik, cradling him against her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJC1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJC2">‘Errand,’ the child said to Garion with a peculiar note of satisfaction. Garion stumbled to his feet, exhausted by the struggle and nearly staggering as he moved away.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJC3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJC4">‘Are you all right?’ Ce’Nedra demanded of him, even as she ducked her head beneath his arm and firmly pulled it about her tiny shoulders.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJC5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJC6">He nodded, though his knees almost buckled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJC7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJC8">‘Lean on me,’ she told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJC9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJCA">He was about to protest, but she put her hand firmly to his lips. ‘Don’t argue, Garion,’ she told him. ‘You know that I love you and that you’re going to be leaning on me for the rest of your life anyway, so you might as well get used to the idea.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJCB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJCC">‘I think my life’s going to be different now, Master,’ Belgarath was saying to Aldur. ‘Pol’s always been there, ready to come when I called her – not always willingly, perhaps – but she always came. Now she’ll have other concerns.’ He sighed. ‘I suppose our children all grow up and get married sometime.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJCD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJCE">‘This particular pose doth not become thee, my son,’ Aldur told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJCF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJCG">Belgarath grinned. ‘I’ve never been able to slip anything past you, Master,’ he said. Then his face grew serious again. ‘Polgara’s been almost like a son to me,’ he told Aldur, ‘but perhaps it’s time that I let her be a woman. I’ve denied her that for too long.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJCH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJCI">‘As it seems best to thee, my son,’ Aldur said. ‘And now, I pray thee, go apart a little way and permit us our family grief.’ He looked at Torak’s body lying on the bier and then at Garion. ‘I have but one more task for thee, Belgarion,’ he said. ‘Take the Orb and place it upon my brother’s breast.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJCJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJCK">‘Yes, Master,’ Garion replied immediately. He removed his arm from about Ce’Nedra’s shoulders and walked to the bier, trying not to look at the dead God’s seared and twisted face. He reached out and laid the round blue stone upon the motionless chest of Kal Torak. Then he stepped back. Once again his little princess wormed her way beneath his arm and clasped him about the waist. It was not unpleasant, but he had the brief, irrational thought that things would be awkward if she were going to insist on this close embrace for the rest of their lives.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJCL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJCM">Once again the Gods formed their circle, and once again the Orb began to glow. Gradually, the seared face started to change, its maiming slowly disappearing. The light surrounding the Gods and the bier grew stronger, and the glow of the Orb became incandescent. The last Garion saw of the face of Torak, it was calm, composed and unmarked. It was a beautiful face, but it was nonetheless still a dead face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJCN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJCO">And then the light grew so intense that Garion could no longer look at it. When it subsided, and when Garion looked back at the bier, the Gods and the body of Torak were gone. Only the Orb remained, glowing slightly as it lay on the rough stone.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJCP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJCQ">Errand, once again with that confident look, went to the bier. Standing on his tiptoes, he reached across the block to retrieve the glowing stone. Then he carried it to Garion. ‘Errand, Belgarion,’ he said firmly, handing the Orb back, and in their touch as the Orb exchanged hands, Garion felt something profoundly different.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJCR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJCS">Drawn together by what had happened, the little group silently gathered about Aunt Pol and Durnik. To the east, the sky had begun to lighten, and the rosy blush of dawn touched the few last remaining tatters of the cloud that had covered Cthol Mishrak. The events of the dreadful night had been titanic, but now the night was nearly over, and they stood together, not speaking as they watched the dawn.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="10DJCT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="10DJCU">The storm that had raged through the long night had passed. For years beyond counting, the universe had been divided against itself, but now it was one again. If there were such things as beginnings, this was a beginning. And so it was, through broken cloud, that the sun rose on the morning of the first day.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_34" aid="10DJCV"></div>

<blockquote class="calibre_21" id="filepos919203" aid="11C3M1"><blockquote class="calibre8" aid="11C3M2"><blockquote class="calibre_22" aid="11C3M3"><span class="calibre1" aid="11C3M4"><span class="italic" aid="11C3M5"><span class="bold" aid="11C3M6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="11C3M7">Epilogue</span></span></span></span></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote class="calibre_23" aid="11C3M8"><blockquote class="calibre8" aid="11C3M9"><blockquote class="calibre_22" aid="11C3MA"><span class="calibre1" aid="11C3MB"><span class="bold" aid="11C3MC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="11C3MD">THE ISLE OF THE WINDS</span></span></span></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><br class="calibre3"/><p class="calibre_" aid="11C3ME"><img class="calibre_28" src="kindle:embed:0006?mime=image/jpeg"/>
</p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_35" aid="11C3MF"></div>
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <head>
    <title>Enchanters' End Game</title>
    <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
  <link href="kindle:flow:0001?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
<link href="kindle:flow:0002?mime=text/css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>

  <body class="calibre" aid="12AK80">
</body>
</html>
<blockquote class="calibre_18" id="filepos919728" aid="12AK81"><span class="calibre5" aid="12AK82"><span class="italic" aid="12AK83"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK84">Chapter Twenty-Five</span></span></span></blockquote><p class="calibre_25" aid="12AK85"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK86">Belgarion of Riva slept very fitfully the night before his wedding. Had he and Ce’Nedra been married in some simple, private little ceremony shortly after his meeting with Torak, things might have gone more smoothly. At that time both he and his flightly little princess had been too tired and too overwhelmed by the events which had taken place to be anything but absolutely honest with each other. During those few short days he had found her to be almost a different person. She had watched his every move with a kind of patient adoration, and she was forever touching him – his hair, his face, his arms – her fingers gentle and curious. The peculiar way she had of coming up to him, no matter who was present or what was going on, and worming her way into the circle of his arm had been, on the whole, rather nice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK87"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK88">Those days had not, however, lasted. Once she had reassured herself that he was all right and that he was really there and not some figment of her imagination which might be snatched away at any moment, Ce’Nedra had gradually changed. He felt somehow like a possession; following her initial delight in ownership, his princess had rather deliberately embarked upon some grand plan of alteration.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK89"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8A">And now the day upon which her possession of him was to be formalized was only hours away. His sleep came in fits and starts with dreams mingling peculiarly with memories as he dipped in and out of sleep like a sea bird skimming across the waves.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK8B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8C">He was at Faldor’s farm again. Even in his sleep he could hear the ringing of Durnik’s hammer and smell the odors coming from Aunt Pol’s kitchen. Rundorig was there – and Zubrette – and Doroon – and there was Brill, creeping around a corner. He half-woke and turned restlessly in the royal bed. That wasn’t possible. Doroon was dead, drowned in the River Mardu, and Brill had vanished for ever over the parapet of mile-high Rak Cthol.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK8D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8E">And then he was in the palace at Sthiss Tor, and Salmissra, her blatant nudity glowing through her filmy gown, was touching his face with her cold fingers.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK8F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8G">But Salmissra was no longer a woman. He had watched her himself as she had changed into a serpent.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK8H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8I">Grul the Eldrak hammered at the frozen ground with his iron-shod club, bellowing, ‘Come ‘Grat, fight!’ and Ce’Nedra was screaming.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK8J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8K">In the chaotic world of dreams half-mixed with memories he saw Ctuchik, his face contorted with horror, exploding once more into nothingness in the hanging turret at Rak Cthol.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK8L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8M">And then he stood once again in the decaying ruin of Cthol Mishrak, his sword ablaze, and watched as Torak raised his arms to the rolling cloud, weeping tears of fire, and once again he heard the stricken God’s final cry, ‘Mother!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK8N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8O">He stirred, half-rousing and shuddering as he always did when that dream recurred, but dipped almost immediately into sleep again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK8P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8Q">He was standing on the deck of Barak’s ship just off the Mallorean coast, listening as King Anheg explained why Barak was chained to the mast.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK8R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8S">‘We had to do it, Belgarath,’ the coarse-faced monarch said mournfully. ‘Right during the middle of that storm, he turned into a </span><span class="italic" aid="12AK8T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8U">bear</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK8V">! He drove the crew to row toward Mallorea all night long, and then, just before daybreak, he turned back into a man again.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK90"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK91">‘Unchain him, Anheg,’ Belgarath said disgustedly. ‘He’s not going to turn into a bear again – not as long as Garion’s safe and well.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK92"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK93">Garion rolled over and sat up. </span><span class="italic" aid="12AK94"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK95">That</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK96"> had been a startling revelation. There had been a purpose behind Barak’s periodic alterations.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK97"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK98">‘You’re Garion’s defender,’ Belgarath had explained to the big man. ‘That’s why you were born. Any time Garion was in mortal danger, you changed into a bear in order to protect him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK99"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9A">‘You mean to say that I’m a sorcerer?’ Barak had demanded incredulously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK9B"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9C">‘Hardly. The shape-change isn’t all that difficult, and you didn’t do it consciously. The Prophecy did the work, not you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK9D"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9E">Barak had spent the rest of the voyage back to Mishrak ac Thull trying to come up with a tastefully understated way to add that concept to his coat of arms.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK9F"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9G">Garion climbed out of his high, canopied bed and went to the window. The stars in the spring sky looked down at the sleeping city of Riva and at the dark waters of the Sea of the Winds beyond the harbor. There was no sign that dawn was anywhere near yet. Garion sighed, poured himself a drink of water from the pitcher on the table, and went back to bed and his troubled sleep.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK9H"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9I">He was at Thull Zelik, and Hettar and Mandorallen were reporting on the activities of ‘Zakath, the Mallorean Emperor. ‘He’s laying siege to Rak Goska right now,’ hawk-faced Hettar was saying. There had been a peculiar softening in Hettar’s face since Garion had last seen him, as if something very significant had happened. The tall Algar turned to Garion. ‘Eventually you’re going to have to do something about ‘Zakath,’ he said. ‘I don’t think you want him roaming around at will in this part of the world.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK9J"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9K">‘Why me?’ Garion asked without thinking.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK9L"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9M">‘You’re Overlord of the West, remember?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK9N"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9O">Once again Garion awoke. Sooner or later he </span><span class="italic" aid="12AK9P"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9Q">would</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9R"> have to deal with ‘Zakath; there was no question about that. Maybe after the wedding, he’d have time to consider the matter. That thought, however, stopped him. Strangely, he had no conception of anything that might happen after the wedding. It stood before him like some huge door that led into a place he had never been. ‘Zakath would have to wait. Garion had to get through the wedding first.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK9S"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9T">Half asleep, somewhere between dreaming and remembering, Garion relived a significant little exchange between himself and her Imperial Highness.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AK9U"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AK9V">‘It’s stupid, Ce’Nedra,’ he was protesting. ‘I’m not going to fight anybody, so why should I ride in waving my sword?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKA0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKA1">‘They deserve to see you, Garion,’ she explained as if talking to a child. ‘They left their homes and rode into battle at your summons.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKA2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKA3">‘I didn’t summon anybody.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKA4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKA5">‘I did it in your behalf. They’re a very good army, really, and I raised them all by myself. Aren’t you proud of me?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKA6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKA7">‘I didn’t ask you to do that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKA8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKA9">‘You were too proud to ask. That’s one of your failings, Garion. You must never be too proud to ask the people who love you for help. Every man in the army loves you. They followed me because of you. Is it too much trouble for the great Overlord of the West to reward his faithful soldiers with just a little bit of a display of appreciation? Or have you become too grand and lofty for simple gratitude?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKAA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAB">‘You’re twisting things, Ce’Nedra. You do that a lot, you know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKAC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAD">But Ce’Nedra had already moved on as if the entire matter were settled. ‘And of course you </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKAE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAF">will</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAG"> wear your crown – and some nice armor. I think a mail shirt would be appropriate.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKAH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAI">‘I’m not going to make a clown of myself just to satisfy your urges toward cheap theatricality.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKAJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAK">Her eyes filled. Her lower lip trembled. ‘You don’t love me any more,’ she accused him in a quavering little voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKAL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAM">Garion groaned even in his sleep. It </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKAN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAO">always</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAP"> came down to that. She won every single argument with that artful bit of deception. He </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKAQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAR">knew</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAS"> it was not genuine. He </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKAT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAU">knew</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKAV"> that she only did it to get her own way, but he was absolutely defenseless against it. It might have nothing whatsoever to do with the matter under discussion, but she always managed to twist things around until she could unleash that devastating accusation, and all hope of his winning even the smallest point was immediately lost. Where had she learned to be so heartlessly dishonest?</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKB0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKB1">And so it was that Garion, dressed in mail, wearing his crown and self-consciously holding his flaming sword aloft, had ridden into the forts atop the eastern escarpment to the thunderous cheers of Ce’Nedra’s army.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKB2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKB3">So much had happened since Garion and Silk and Belgarath had crept from the citadel at Riva the previous spring. The young king lay musing in his high, canopied bed, having almost given up on sleep. Ce’Nedra </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKB4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKB5">had</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKB6"> in fact raised an army. As he had heard more of the details, he had been more and more astonished – not only by her audacity but also by the enormous amount of energy and sheer will she had expended in the process. She had been guided and assisted, certainly, but the initial concept had been hers. His admiration for her was tinged slightly with apprehension. He was going to marry a very strong-minded young woman – and one who was not overly troubled by scruples.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKB7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKB8">He rolled over and punched at his pillow, hoping somehow by that familiar act to bring on more normal sleep, but once again he slipped into restless dreaming. Relg and Taiba were walking toward him, and they were holding hands!</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKB9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKBA">And then he was at the Stronghold, sitting at Adara’s bedside. His beautiful cousin was even paler than he remembered, and she had a persistent, racking cough. Even as the two of them talked, Aunt Pol was taking steps to remedy the last complications of the wound which had so nearly claimed the girl’s life.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKBB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKBC">‘I was mortified, of course,’ Adara was saying. ‘I’d taken so much care to conceal it from him, and now I’d gone and blurted it out to him, and I wasn’t even dying.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKBD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKBE">‘Hettar?’ Garion said again. He’d already said it three times.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKBF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKBG">‘If you don’t stop that, Garion, I’m going to be cross with you,’ Adara said quite firmly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKBH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKBI">‘I’m sorry,’ he apologized quickly. ‘It’s just that I’ve never considered him in that light. He’s a good friend, but I never thought of him as particularly loveable. He’s so – I don’t know – implacable, I suppose.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKBJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKBK">‘I have certain reasons to believe that may change,’ Adara said with a faint blush.
