Then she began to cough again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKBL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKBM">‘Drink this, dear,’ Aunt Pol ordered, coming to the bedside with a fuming cup.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKBN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKBO">‘It’s going to taste awful,’ Garion warned his cousin.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKBP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKBQ">‘That will do, Garion,’ Aunt Pol told him. ‘I can manage this without the helpful comments.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKBR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKBS">And then he was in the caves beneath Prolgu, standing beside Relg as the Gorim performed the simple ceremony uniting the zealot and the Marag woman who had so totally changed Relg’s life. Garion sensed another presence in the underground chamber, and he wondered if anyone had yet told Relg about the bargain that had been struck in Cthol Mishrak. He’d thought about saying something himself, but had decided against it. All things considered, it might be best to let Relg adjust to one thing at a time. Marriage to Taiba was probably going to be enough of a shock to the fanatic’s system for now. Garion could feel Mara’s gloating exultation as the ceremony concluded. The weeping God no longer wept.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKBT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKBU">It was useless, Garion decided. He was not going to be able to sleep – at least not the kind of sleep that would do him any good. He threw off the covers and pulled on his robe. The fire in his fireplace had been banked for the night, and he stirred it up again. Then he sat in the chair in front of it, staring pensively into the dancing flames.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKBV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKC0">Even if his wedding to Ce’Nedra had taken place immediately upon their arrival back at Riva, things might still have turned out all right, but the arrangements for a royal wedding of this magnitude were far too complex to be made overnight, and many of those who were to be honored guests were still recuperating from wounds received during the battle of Thull Mardu.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKC1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKC2">The interim had given Ce’Nedra time to embark upon a full-blown plan of modification. She had, it appeared, a certain concept of him – some ideal which only she could perceive – and she was absolutely determined to cram him into that mold despite all his objections and protests. Nothing could make her relent in her singleminded drive to make him over. It was so unfair. He was quite content to accept her exactly as she was. She had her flaws – many of them – but he was willing to take the good with the bad. Why couldn’t she extend him the same courtesy? But each time he tried to put his foot down and absolutely refuse one of her whims, her eyes would fill with tears, her lip would tremble, and the fatal, ‘You don’t love me any more,’ would drop quaveringly upon him. Belgarion of Riva had considered flight several times during that long winter.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKC3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKC4">Now it was spring again, and the storms which isolated the Isle of the Winds during the winter months were past. The day which Garion felt would never come had suddenly rushed upon him. Today was the day in which he would take the Imperial Princess Ce’Nedra to wife, and it was too late to run.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKC5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKC6">He knew that if he brooded about it much longer, he’d push himself over the edge into total panic, and so he stood up and quickly dressed himself in plain tunic and hose, ignoring the more ostentatious garments which his valet – at Ce’Nedra’s explicit instructions – had laid out for him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKC7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKC8">It was about an hour before daylight as the young king of Riva opened the door to the royal apartment and slipped into the silent corridor outside.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKC9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCA">He wandered for a time through the dim, empty halls of the Citadel, and then, inevitably, his undirected steps led him to Aunt Pol’s door. She was already awake and seated by her fire with a cup of fragrant tea in her hands. She wore a deep blue dressing gown, and her dark hair flowed down across her shoulders in a lustrous wave.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKCB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCC">‘You’re up early,’ she noted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKCD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCE">‘I couldn’t sleep.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKCF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCG">‘You should have. You have a very full day ahead of you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKCH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCI">‘I know. That’s why I couldn’t sleep.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKCJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCK">‘Tea?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKCL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCM">‘No, thanks.’ He sat in the carved chair on the other side of the fireplace. ‘Everything’s changing, Aunt Pol,’ he said after a moment of thoughtful silence. ‘After today, nothing will ever be the same again, will it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKCN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCO">‘Probably not,’ she said, ‘but that doesn’t necessarily mean that it will be a change for the worse.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKCP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCQ">‘How do </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKCR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCS">you</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCT"> feel about the idea of getting married?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKCU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKCV">‘A bit nervous,’ she admitted calmly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKD0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKD1">‘You?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKD2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKD3">‘I’ve never been married before either, Garion.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKD4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKD5">Something had been bothering him about that. ‘Was it really such a good idea, Aunt Pol?’ he asked her. ‘I mean, arranging to have you and Durnik get married on the same day as Ce’Nedra and I? What I’m trying to say is that you’re the most important woman in the world. Shouldn’t your wedding be a special occasion?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKD6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKD7">‘That was what we were trying to avoid, Garion,’ she replied. ‘Durnik and I decided that we wanted our wedding to be private, and we hope that it will be lost in all the confusion and ceremony that’s going to surround yours.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKD8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKD9">‘How is he? I haven’t seen him for several days now.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKDA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKDB">‘He’s still a bit strange. I don’t think he’ll ever be the same man we all knew.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKDC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKDD">‘He’s all right, isn’t he?’ Garion’s question was concerned.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKDE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKDF">‘He’s fine, Garion. He’s just a bit different, that’s all. Something happened to him that’s never happened to any other man, and it changed him. He’s as practical as ever, but now he looks at the other side of things as well. I think I rather like that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKDG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKDH">‘Do you </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKDI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKDJ">really</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKDK"> have to leave Riva?’ he asked suddenly. ‘You and Durnik could stay here in the Citadel.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKDL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKDM">‘We want our own place, Garion,’ she told him. ‘We need to be alone with each other. Besides, if I were here, every time you and Ce’Nedra had a squabble, I’d have one or both of you hammering on my door. I’ve done my best to raise you two. Now you’re going to have to work things out on your own.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKDN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKDO">‘Where will you go?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKDP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKDQ">‘To the Vale. My mother’s cottage is still standing there. It’s a very solid house. All it needs is new thatching on the roof and new doors and windows. Durnik will know how to take care of that, and it will be a good place for Errand to grow up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKDR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKDS">‘Errand? You’re taking him with you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKDT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKDU">‘Someone has to care for him, and I’ve grown used to having a small boy around. Besides, father and I’ve decided that we’d like for him to be some distance from the Orb. He’s still the only one beside you who can touch it. Someone at some time might seize upon that and try to use him in the same way Zedar did.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKDV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKE0">‘What’d be the point? I mean, Torak’s gone now. What good would the Orb do anybody else?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKE1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKE2">She looked at him very gravely, and the white lock of her brow seemed to glow in the soft light. ‘I don’t believe that was the only reason for the Orb’s existence, Garion,’ she told him seriously. ‘Something hasn’t been completed yet.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKE3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKE4">‘What? What else is there left to do?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKE5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKE6">‘We don’t know. The Mrin Codex does not end with the meeting between the Child of Light and the Child of Dark. You’re the Guardian of the Orb now, and it’s still as important as ever, so don’t just put it on the back shelf of a closet somewhere and forget about it. Be watchful, and don’t let ordinary affairs dull your mind. Keeping the Orb is still your first duty – and I’m not going to be here to remind you about it every day.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKE7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKE8">He didn’t want to think about that. ‘What will you do if somebody comes to the Vale and tries to take Errand away? You won’t be able to protect him, now that—’ He faltered to a stop. He had not spoken to her about that.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKE9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKEA">‘Go ahead and say it, Garion,’ she said directly. ‘Let’s look it right in the face. You were going to say now that I no longer have any power.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKEB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKEC">‘What’s it like, Aunt Pol? Is it like losing something – a sort of emptiness, maybe?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKED"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKEE">‘I feel the same as always, dear. Of course I haven’t tried to </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKEF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKEG">do</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKEH"> anything since I agreed to give it up. It might be painful if I tried to make something happen and failed. I don’t think I’d care for the experience, so I simply haven’t tried.’ She shrugged. ‘That part of my life is over, so I’ll just have to put it behind me. Errand will be safe, though. Beldin’s in the Vale – and the twins. That’s enough power in one place to keep away anything that might want to harm him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKEI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKEJ">‘Why’s Durnik spending so much time with Grandfather?’ Garion asked suddenly. ‘Ever since we got back to Riva, they’ve been together just about every minute they were awake.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKEK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKEL">She gave him a knowing smile. ‘I imagine they’re preparing some surprise for me,’ she replied. ‘Some suitable wedding present. They both tend to be a trifle transparent.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKEM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKEN">‘What is it?’ Garion asked curiously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKEO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKEP">‘I haven’t the slightest idea – and I wouldn’t dream of trying to find out. Whatever it is, they’ve both worked too hard at it for me to spoil it for them by snooping around.’ She glanced at the window where the first light of dawn was appearing. ‘Perhaps you’d better run along now, dear,’ she suggested. ‘I have to start getting ready. This is a very special day for me, too, and I really want to look my best.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKEQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKER">‘You could never look anything less than beautiful, Aunt Pol,’ he told her sincerely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKES"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKET">‘Why thank you, Garion.’ She smiled at him, looking somehow almost girlish. ‘But I’d rather not take the chance.’ She gave him an appraising glance and touched his cheek. ‘Why don’t you visit the baths, dear,’ she suggested, ‘and wash your hair and get somebody to shave you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKEU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKEV">‘I can do that myself, Aunt Pol.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKF0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKF1">‘That’s not a good idea, Garion. You’re a little nervous today, and you don’t want to put a razor to your face when your hands are trembling.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKF2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKF3">He laughed a bit ruefully, kissed her, and started toward the door. Then he stopped and turned back toward her. ‘I love you, Aunt Pol,’ he said simply.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKF4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKF5">‘Yes, dear, I know. I love you, too.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKF6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKF7">After he had visited the baths, Garion went looking for Lelldorin. Among the matters that had finally been settled was the marital status of the young Asturian and his semiofficial bride. Ariana had finally despaired of Lelldorin’s ever making the first move on his own and had solved the entire problem by simply moving in with him. She had been quite firm about it. Garion gathered that Lelldorin’s resistance had faded rather quickly. His expression of late had been somewhat more foolish than usual, and Ariana’s had been, although radiant, just a trifle smug. In a peculiar way, they closely resembled Relg and Taiba in that respect. Since his wedding, Relg’s expression had been one of almost perpetual astonishment, while Taiba’s had that same smugness that marked Ariana’s. Garion wondered if he might not awaken tomorrow morning to see that same self-satisfied little smirk on Ce’Nedra’s lips.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKF8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKF9">There was a purpose to Garion’s search for his Asturian friend. As a result of one of Ce’Nedra’s whims, their wedding was going to be followed by a grand ball, and Lelldorin had been teaching Garion how to dance.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKFA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKFB">The idea of the ball had been greeted with enthusiasm by all the ladies; the men, however, had not been universal in their approval. Barak had been particularly vehement in his objections. ‘You want </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKFC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKFD">me</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKFE"> to get in the middle of the floor and dance?’ he had demanded of the princess in an outraged tone of voice. ‘What’s wrong with all of us just getting drunk? That’s the normal way to celebrate a wedding.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKFF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKFG">‘You’ll be just fine,’ Ce’Nedra had told him, patting his cheek in that infuriating way of hers. ‘And you will do it, won’t you, Barak – for me?’ And she had insincerely fluttered her eyelashes at him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKFH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKFI">Barak had stamped away, muttering curses under his breath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKFJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKFK">Garion found Lelldorin and Ariana doting on each other across the breakfast table in their rooms.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKFL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKFM">‘Wilt thou take breakfast with us, your Majesty?’ Ariana inquired politely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKFN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKFO">‘Thanks all the same, my Lady,’ Garion declined, ‘but I don’t seem to have much appetite today.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKFP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKFQ">‘Nerves,’ Lelldorin observed sagely.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKFR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKFS">‘I think I’ve got most of it,’ Garion rushed to the core of his problem, ‘but that crossover baffles me. My feet keep getting all tangled up.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKFT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKFU">Lelldorin immediately fetched a lute, and with Ariana’s help, walked Garion through the complex procedure.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKFV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKG0">‘Thou art becoming most skilled, your Majesty,’ Ariana complimented him at the end of the lesson.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKG1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKG2">‘All I want to do is get through it without tripping and falling on my face in public.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKG3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKG4">‘The princess would surely support thee, shouldst thou stumble.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKG5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKG6">‘I’m not sure about that. She might enjoy watching me make a fool of myself.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKG7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKG8">‘How little thou knowest of women.’ Ariana gave Lelldorin an adoring look – a look he fatuously returned.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKG9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKGA">‘Will you two stop that?’ Garion demanded irritably. ‘Can’t you wait until you’re alone to carry on that way?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKGB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKGC">‘My heart is too full of love for me to hide it, Garion,’ Lelldorin said extravagantly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKGD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKGE">‘So I’ve noticed,’ Garion said dryly. ‘I’ve got to go see Silk, so I’ll leave you two to your amusements.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKGF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKGG">Ariana blushed, then smiled. ‘Might we take that as a royal command, your Majesty?’ she asked archly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKGH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKGI">Garion fled.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKGJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKGK">Silk had arrived from the east late the previous evening, and Garion was anxious for news. He found the little Drasnian lingering over a breakfast of partridge and hot, spiced wine.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKGL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKGM">‘Isn’t that a little heavy for breakfast?’ Garion asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKGN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKGO">‘I’ve never been that partial to gruel first thing in the morning,’ Silk replied. ‘Gruel’s the sort of thing a man has to work himself up to.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKGP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKGQ">Garion went directly to the point. ‘What’s happening in Cthol Murgos?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKGR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKGS">‘’Zakath is still laying siege to Rak Goska,’ Silk reported. ‘He’s transporting in more troops, though. It’s pretty obvious that he’s going to strike into southern Cthol Murgos as soon as the ground’s firm enough to move an army.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKGT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKGU">‘Are the Thulls with him?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKGV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKH0">‘Only a few. Most of them are concentrating on finding the few Grolims left in their kingdom. I always thought Thulls were a stupid people, but you’d be amazed at how creative they can be when it comes to finding new and interesting ways for Grolims to die.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKH1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKH2">‘We’re going to have to keep an eye on ‘Zakath,’ Garion said. ‘I wouldn’t want him to come creeping up on me from the south.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKH3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKH4">‘I think you can count on him not to creep,’ Silk said. ‘He sent you a message of congratulations, incidentally.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKH5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKH6">‘He did </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKH7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKH8">what</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKH9">?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKHA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKHB">‘He’s a civilized man, Garion – </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKHC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKHD">and</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKHE"> a politician. He was badly shaken by the fact that you killed Torak. I think he’s actually afraid of you, so he wants to stay on your good side – at least until he finishes up in southern Cthol Murgos.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKHF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKHG">‘Who’s in command of the Murgos, now that Taur Urgas is dead?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKHH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKHI">‘Urgit, his third son by his second wife. There was the usual squabble over the succession by the various sons of Taur Urgas’s assorted wives. The fatalities were numerous, I understand.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKHJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKHK">‘What kind of man is Urgit?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKHL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKHM">‘He’s a schemer. I don’t think he’s any match for ’Zakath, but he’ll keep the Malloreans busy for ten or twenty years. By then, ‘Zakath may be too old and tired of war to give you any problems.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKHN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKHO">‘Let’s hope so.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKHP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKHQ">‘Oh, I almost forgot. Hettar married your cousin last week.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKHR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKHS">‘Adara? I thought she was ill.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKHT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKHU">‘Not that much, apparently. They’re coming to your wedding – along with Cho-Hag and Silar.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKHV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKI0">‘Is </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKI1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKI2">everybody</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKI3"> getting married?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKI4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKI5">Silk laughed. ‘Not </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKI6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKI7">me</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKI8">, my young friend. In spite of this universal plunge toward matrimony, </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKI9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKIA">I</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKIB"> still haven’t lost my senses. If worse comes to worst, I still know how to run. The Algars should arrive sometime this morning. They met Korodullin’s entourage, and they’re all coming together. Their ship was right behind mine when we left Camaar.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKIC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKID">‘Was Mandorallen with them?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKIE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKIF">Silk nodded. ‘Along with the Baroness of Vo Ebor. The Baron’s still much too ill to travel. I think he’s hoping that he’ll die, to leave the way clear for his wife and Mandorallen.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKIG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKIH">Garion sighed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKII"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKIJ">‘Don’t let it make you unhappy, Garion,’ Silk advised. ‘Arends actually enjoy that kind of misery. Mandorallen’s perfectly content to suffer nobly.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKIK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKIL">‘That’s a rotten thing to say,’ Garion accused the little man.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKIM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKIN">Silk shrugged. ‘I’m a rotten sort of person,’ he admitted.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKIO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKIP">‘Where are you going after—’ Garion left it hanging.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKIQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKIR">‘After I see you safely married?’ Silk suggested pleasantly. ‘As soon as I recover from all the drinking I’ll do tonight, I’ll be off for Gar og Nadrak. There’s a great deal of opportunity in the new situation there. I’ve been in contact with Yarblek. He and I are going to form a partnership.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKIS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKIT">‘With Yarblek?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKIU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKIV">‘He’s not so bad – if you keep an eye on him – and he’s very shrewd. We’ll probably do rather well together.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJ0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJ1">‘I can imagine.’ Garion laughed. ‘One of you is bad enough all by himself, but with the two of you acting together, no honest merchant’s going to escape with his skin.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJ2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJ3">Silk grinned wickedly. ‘That was sort of what we had in mind.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJ4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJ5">‘I imagine that you’ll get very rich.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJ6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJ7">‘I suppose I could learn to live with that.’ Silk’s eyes took on a distant look. ‘That’s not really what it’s all about, though,’ he noted. ‘It’s a game. The money’s just a way of keeping score. It’s the game that’s important.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJ8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJ9">‘It seems to me that you told me that once before.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJB">‘Nothing’s changed since then, Garion,’ Silk told him with a laugh.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJD">Aunt Pol’s wedding to Durnik took place later that morning in a small, private chapel in the west wing of the Citadel. There were but few guests. Belgarath and the twins, Beltira and Belkira, were there of course, and Silk and Barak. Aunt Pol, beautiful in a deep blue velvet gown, was attended by Queen Layla, and Garion stood with Durnik. The ceremony was performed by the hunchbacked Beldin, dressed for once in decent clothing and with a strangely gentle expression on his ugly face.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJF">Garion’s emotions were very complex during the ceremony. He realized with a sharp little pang that Aunt Pol would no longer be exclusively his. An elemental, childish part of him resented that. He was, however, pleased that it was Durnik whom she was marrying. If anyone deserved her, it was Durnik. The good, plain man’s eyes were filled with absolute love, and he obviously could not take them from her face. Aunt Pol herself was gravely radiant as she stood at Durnik’s side.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJH">As Garion stepped back while the two exchanged vows, he heard a faint rustle. Just inside the door of the chapel, in a hooded cloak that covered her from head to foot and wearing a heavy veil that covered her face, stood Princess Ce’Nedra. She had made a large issue of the fact that by an ancient Tolnedran custom, Garion was not supposed to see her before their wedding on this day, and the cloak and veil provided her with the illusion of invisibility. He could imagine her wrestling with the problem until she had come up with this solution. Nothing could have kept her from Polgara’s wedding, but all the niceties and formalities had to be observed. Garion smiled slightly as he turned back to the ceremony.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJJ">It was the expression on Beldin’s face that made him turn again to look sharply toward the back of the chapel – an expression of surprise that turned to calm recognition. At first Garion saw nothing, but then a faint movement up among the rafters caught his eye. The pale, ghostly shape of a snowy owl perched on one of the dark beams, watching as Aunt Pol and Durnik were married.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJL">When the ceremony was concluded and after Durnik had respectfully and rather nervously kissed his bride, the white owl spread her pinions to circle the chapel in ghostly silence. She hovered briefly as if in silent benediction over the happy couple; then with two soft beats of her wings, she moved through the breathless air to Belgarath. The old sorcerer resolutely averted his eyes.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJN">‘You may as well look at her, father,’ Aunt Pol told him. ‘She won’t leave until you recognize her.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJP">Belgarath sighed then, and looked directly at the oddly luminous bird hovering in the air before him. ‘I still miss you,’ he said very simply. ‘Even after all this time.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJR">The owl regarded him with her golden, unblinking eyes for a moment, then flickered and vanished.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJT">‘What an absolutely astonishing thing,’ Queen Layla gasped.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKJU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKJV">‘We’re astonishing people, Layla,’ Aunt Pol replied, ‘and we have a number of peculiar friends – and relatives.’ She smiled then, her arm closely linked in Durnik’s. ‘Besides,’ she added with a twinkle in her eye, ‘you wouldn’t really expect a girl to get married without her mother in attendance, would you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKK0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKK1">Following the wedding, they all walked through the corridors of the Citadel back to the central fortress and stopped outside the door of Aunt Pol’s private apartment. Garion was about to follow Silk and Barak as, after a few brief congratulations, they moved on down the hallway, but Belgarath put his hand on his grandson’s arm. ‘Stay a moment,’ the old man said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKK2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKK3">‘I don’t think we should intrude, Grandfather,’ Garion said nervously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKK4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKK5">‘We’ll only stay for a few minutes,’ Belgarath assured him. The old man’s lips were actually quivering with a suppressed mirth. ‘There’s something I want you to see.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKK6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKK7">One of Aunt Pol’s eyebrows raised questioningly as her father and Garion followed into the apartment. ‘Are we responding to some ancient and obscure custom, father?’ she asked.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKK8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKK9">‘No, Pol,’ he replied innocently. ‘Garion and I only want to toast your happiness, that’s all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKKA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKKB">‘What exactly are you up to, Old Wolf?’ she asked him, but her eyes had an amused look in them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKKC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKKD">‘Do I have to be up to something?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKKE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKKF">‘You usually are, father.’ She did, however, fetch four crystal goblets and a decanter of fine old Tolnedran wine.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKKG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKKH">‘The four of us started all this together quite a long time ago,’ Belgarath recalled. ‘Perhaps, before we all separate, we should take a moment to remember that we’ve come a long way since then, and some rather strange things have happened to us. We’ve all changed in one way or another, I think.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKKI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKKJ">‘You haven’t changed all that much, father,’ Aunt Pol said meaningfully. ‘Would you get to the point?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKKK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKKL">Belgarath’s eyes were twinkling openly now with some huge, suppressed mirth. ‘Durnik has something for you,’ he said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKKM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKKN">Durnik swallowed hard. ‘Now?’ he asked Belgarath apprehensively.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKKO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKKP">Belgarath nodded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKKQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKKR">‘I know how much you love beautiful things – like that bird over there,’ Durnik said to Aunt Pol, looking at the crystal wren Garion had given her the previous year. ‘I wanted to give you something like that, too – only I can’t work in glass or in gemstones. I’m a metalsmith, so I have to work in steel.’ He had been unwrapping something covered in plain cloth. What he produced finally was an intricately wrought steel rose, just beginning to open. The details were exquisite, and the flower glowed with a burnished life of its own.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKKS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKKT">‘Why, Durnik,’ Aunt Pol said, genuinely pleased. ‘How very lovely.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKKU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKKV">Durnik, however, did not give her the rose yet. ‘It has no color, though,’ he noted a bit critically, ‘and no fragrance.’ He glanced nervously at Belgarath.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKL0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKL1">‘Do it,’ the old man told him. ‘The way I showed you.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKL2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKL3">Durnik turned back to Aunt Pol, still holding the burnished rose in his hand. ‘I really have nothing to give you, my Pol,’ he told her humbly, ‘except an honest heart – and this.’ He held out the rose in his hand, and his face took on an expression of intense concentration.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKL4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKL5">Garion heard it very clearly. It was a familiar, rushing surge of whispered sound, filled with a peculiarly bell-like shimmer. The polished rose in Durnik’s outstretched hand seemed to pulsate slightly, and then gradually it began to change. The outsides of the petals were as white as new snow, but the insides, where the flower was just opening, were a deep, blushing red. When Durnik finished, he held a living flower out to Aunt Pol, its petals beaded with dew.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKL6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKL7">Aunt Pol gasped as she stared incredulously at the rose. It was unlike any flower that had ever existed. With a trembling hand she took it from him, her eyes filled with sudden tears. ‘How is it possible?’ she asked in an awed voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKL8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKL9">‘Durnik’s a very special man now,’ Belgarath told her. ‘So far as I know, he’s the only man who ever died and then lived again. That could not help changing him – at least a little. But then, I suspect that there’s always been a poet lurking under the surface of our good, practical friend. Maybe the only real difference is that now he has a way of letting that poet out.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKLA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKLB">Durnik, looking just a bit embarrassed, touched the rose with a tentative finger. ‘It does have one advantage, my Pol,’ he noted. ‘The steel is still in it, so it will never fade or wilt. It will stay just as it is now. Even in the middle of winter, you’ll have at least one flower.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKLC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKLD">‘Oh, Durnik!’ she cried, embracing him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKLE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKLF">Durnik looked a bit abashed as he awkwardly returned her embrace. ‘If you really like it, I could make you some others,’ he told her. ‘A whole garden of them, I suppose. It’s not really all that hard, once you get the hang of it.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKLG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKLH">Aunt Pol’s eyes, however, had suddenly widened. With one arm still about Durnik, she turned slightly to look at the crystal wren perched upon its glass twig. ‘Fly,’ she said, and the glowing bird spread its wings and flew to her outstretched hand. Curiously it inspected the rose, dipped its beak into a dew drop, and then it lifted its head and began to sing a trilling little song. Gently Aunt Pol raised her hand aloft, and the crystal bird soared back to its glass twig. The echo of its song still hung in the silent air.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKLI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKLJ">‘I expect it’s time for Garion and me to be going,’ Belgarath said, his face rather sentimental and misty.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKLK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKLL">Aunt Pol, however, had quite obviously realized something. Her eyes narrowed slightly, then went very wide. ‘Just a moment, Old Wolf,’ she said to Belgarath with a faint hint of steel in her voice. ‘You knew about this from the very beginning, didn’t you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKLM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKLN">‘About what, Pol?’ he asked innocently.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKLO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKLP">‘That Durnik – that I—’ For the first time in his life Garion saw her at a loss for words. ‘You knew!’ she flared.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKLQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKLR">‘Naturally. As soon as Durnik woke up, I could feel something different in him. I’m surprised you didn’t feel it yourself. I had to work with him a bit to bring it out, though.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKLS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKLT">‘Why didn’t you tell me?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKLU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKLV">‘You didn’t ask, Pol.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKM0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKM1">‘You – I—’ With an enormous effort she gained control of herself. ‘All of these months you let me go on thinking that my power was gone, and it was there all the time! It was still there, and you put me through all of that?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKM2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKM3">‘Oh, really, Pol. If you’d just stopped to think, you’d have realized that you can’t give it up like that. Once it’s there, it’s there.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKM4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKM5">‘But our Master said—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKM6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKM7">Belgarath raised one hand. ‘If you’ll just stop and remember, Pol, all he really asked was if you’d be willing to limit your independence in marriage and go through life with no more power than Durnik has. Since there’s no way he could remove </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKM8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKM9">your</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKMA"> power, he obviously had something else in mind.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKMB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKMC">‘You let me believe—’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKMD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKME">‘I have no control over what you believe, Pol,’ he replied in his most reasonable tone of voice.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKMF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKMG">‘You tricked me!’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKMH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKMI">‘No, Pol,’ he corrected, ‘you tricked yourself.’ Then he smiled fondly at her. ‘Now, before you go off into a tirade, think about it for a moment. All things considered, it didn’t really hurt you, did it? And isn’t it really nicer to find out about it this way?’ His smile became a grin. ‘You can even consider it my wedding present to you, if you’d like,’ he added.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKMJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKMK">She stared at him for a moment, obviously wanting to be cross about the whole thing, but the look he returned her was impish. The confrontation between them had been obscure, but he had quite obviously won this time. Finally, no longer able to maintain even the fiction of anger, she laughed helplessly and put her hand affectionately on his arm. ‘You’re a dreadful old man, father,’ she told him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKML"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKMM">‘I know,’ he admitted. ‘Coming, Garion?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKMN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKMO">Once they were in the hall outside, Belgarath began to chuckle.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKMP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKMQ">‘What’s so funny?’ Garion asked him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKMR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKMS">‘I’ve been waiting for that moment for months,’ his grandfather said, still chortling. ‘Did you see her face when she finally realized what had happened? She’s been moping around with that look of noble self-sacrifice for all this time, and then she suddenly finds out that it was absolutely unnecessary.’ His face took on a wicked little smirk. ‘Your Aunt’s always been just a little too sure of herself, you know. Maybe it was good for her to go for a little while thinking that she was just an ordinary person. It might give her some perspective.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKMT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKMU">‘She was right.’ Garion laughed. ‘You </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKMV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKN0">are</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKN1"> a dreadful old man.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKN2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKN3">Belgarath grinned. ‘One does one’s best.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKN4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKN5">They went along the hallway to the royal apartment where the clothes Garion was to wear for his wedding were already laid out.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKN6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKN7">‘Grandfather,’ Garion said, sitting down to pull off his boots, ‘there’s something I’ve been meaning to ask you. Just before Torak died, he called out to his mother.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKN8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKN9">Belgarath, tankard in hand, nodded.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKNA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKNB">‘Who is his mother?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKNC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKND">‘The universe,’ the old man replied.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKNE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKNF">‘I don’t understand.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKNG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKNH">Belgarath scratched thoughtfully at his short, white beard. ‘As I understand it, each of the Gods began as an idea in the mind of UL, the father of the Gods, but it was the universe that brought them forth. It’s very complicated. I don’t understand it entirely myself. Anyway, as he was dying, Torak cried out to the one thing that he felt still loved him. He was wrong, of course. UL and the other Gods </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKNI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKNJ">did</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKNK"> still love him, even though they knew that he had become twisted and totally evil. And the universe grieved for him.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKNL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKNM">‘The universe?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKNN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKNO">‘Didn’t you feel it? That instant when everything stopped and all the lights went out?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKNP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKNQ">‘I thought that was just me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKNR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKNS">‘No, Garion. For that single instant all the light in the universe went out, and everything stopped moving – everything – everywhere. A part of that was the grief of the universe for her dead son.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKNT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKNU">Garion thought about that. ‘He had to die, though, didn’t he?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKNV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKO0">Belgarath nodded. ‘It was the only way that things could get back on the right course. Torak had to die so that things could go toward what they’re supposed to. Otherwise, everything would have ultimately wound up in chaos.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKO1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKO2">A sudden strange thought struck Garion. ‘Grandfather,’ he said, ‘who is Errand?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKO3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKO4">‘I don’t know,’ Belgarath replied. ‘Perhaps he’s just a strange little boy. Perhaps he’s something else. You’d probably better start changing clothes.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKO5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKO6">‘I was trying not to think about that.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKO7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKO8">‘Oh, come now. This is the happiest day of your life.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKO9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOA">‘Really?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKOB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOC">‘It might help if you keep saying that to yourself.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKOD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOE">By general consent, the Gorim of Ulgo had been selected to perform the ceremony uniting Garion and Ce’Nedra in marriage. The frail, saintly old man had made the journey from Prolgu in short, easy stages, carried by litter through the caves to Sendaria, then conveyed in King Fulrach’s royal carriage to the city of Sendar and thence by ship to Riva. The revelation of the fact that the God of the Ulgos was the father of the other Gods had struck theological circles like a thunderclap. Entire libraries of turgid philosophical speculation had instantly become obsolete, and priests everywhere now stumbled about in a state of shock. Grodeg, the High Priest of Belar, fainted dead away at the news. The towering ecclesiastic, already crippled for life by the wounds he had received during the battle of Thull Mardu, did not take this final blow well. When he recovered from his swoon, his attendants found that his mind had reverted to childhood, and he spent his days now surrounded by toys and brightly colored bits of string.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKOF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOG">The royal wedding, of course, took place in the Hall of the Rivan King, and everyone was there. King Rhodar was in crimson, King Anheg in blue. King Fulrach wore brown, and King Cho-Hag the customary Algar black. Brand, the Rivan Warder, his face made even more somber by the death of his youngest son, was dressed in Rivan gray. There were other royal visitors as well. Ran Borune XXIII in his gold-colored mantle was strangely jovial as he bantered with the shaven-headed Sadi. Oddly enough, the two of them got on well together. The possibilities of the new situation in the west appealed to them both, and they were obviously moving toward an accommodation of some sort. King Korodullin wore royal purple and stood about with the other kings – although he spoke but little. The blow to his head during the battle of Thull Mardu had affected his hearing, and the young king of Arendia was obviously uncomfortable in company.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKOH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOI">In the very center of the gathered monarchs stood King Drosta lek Thun of Gar og Nadrak, wearing a curiously unattractive yellow doublet. The nervous, emaciated king of the Nadraks spoke in short little bursts, and when he laughed, there was a shrill quality in his voice. King Drosta made many arrangements that afternoon – some of which he even intended to honor.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKOJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOK">Belgarion of Riva, of course, did not participate in those discussions – which was probably just as well. The Rivan King’s mind was a trifle distracted at that moment. Dressed all in blue, he paced nervously in a nearby antechamber where he and Lelldorin awaited the fanfare which was to summon them into the great hall. ‘I wish this was all over,’ he said for the sixth time.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKOL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOM">‘Just be patient, Garion,’ Lelldorin advised him again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKON"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOO">‘What are they </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKOP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOQ">doing</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOR"> out there?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKOS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOT">‘Probably waiting for word that her Highness is ready. At this particular time, she’s far more important than you are. That’s the way weddings are, you know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKOU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKOV">‘You’re the lucky one. You and Ariana just ran off and got married without all this fuss.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKP0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKP1">Lelldorin laughed ruefully. ‘I didn’t really escape it. Garion,’ he said, ‘just postponed it for a while. All the preparations here have inflamed my Ariana. As soon as we return to Arendia, she wants us to have a proper wedding.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKP2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKP3">‘What is it about weddings that does such strange things to the female mind?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKP4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKP5">‘Who can say?’ Lelldorin shrugged. ‘A woman’s mind is a mystery – as you’ll soon discover.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKP6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKP7">Garion gave him a sour look and adjusted his crown once again. ‘I wish it were all over,’ he said again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKP8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKP9">In time the fanfare echoed through the Hall of the Rivan King, the door opened, and, trembling visibly, Garion adjusted his crown one last time and marched out to meet his fate. Although he knew most of the people in the hall, the faces around him were all a blur as he and Lelldorin walked past the peat fires glowing in the pits in the floor toward the throne where his great sword once more hung in its proper place with the Orb of Aldur glowing on its pommel.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKPA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKPB">The hall was hung with buntings and banners, and there was a vast profusion of spring flowers. The wedding guests, in silks, satins, and brightly colored brocades, seemed themselves almost like some flower garden as they twisted and strained to watch the entrance of the royal bridegroom.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKPC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKPD">Awaiting him before the throne stood the white-robed old Gorim of Ulgo, a smile on his gentle face. ‘Greetings, Belgarion,’ the Gorim murmured as Garion mounted the steps.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKPE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKPF">‘Holy Gorim,’ Garion replied with a nervous bow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKPG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKPH">‘Be tranquil, my son,’ the Gorim advised, noting Garion’s shaking hands.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKPI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKPJ">‘I’m trying, Holy One.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKPK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKPL">The brazen horns sounded yet another fanfare, and the door at the back of the hall swung wide. The Imperial Princess Ce’Nedra, dressed in her creamy, pearl-studded wedding gown, stood in the doorway with her cousin Xera at her side. She was stunning. Her flaming hair streamed down across one shoulder of her gown, and she wore the varicolored golden circlet of which she had always been so fond. Her face was demure, and a delicate little blush colored her cheeks. She kept her eyes downcast, although once she flickered a quick glance at Garion, and he saw the little twinkle that lurked behind her thick lashes. He knew then with absolute certainty that all that demure modesty was a pose. She stood long enough to allow all to look their fill at her perfection before, accompanied by the sound of gently cascading harps, she came down the aisle to meet her quivering bridegroom. In a ceremony Garion thought just a trifle overdone, Barak’s two little daughters preceded the bride, strewing her path with flowers.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKPM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKPN">When she reached the dais, Ce’Nedra rather impulsively kissed the kindly old Gorim’s cheek and then took her place at Garion’s side. There was a fragrance about her that was strangely flowerlike – a fragrance that for some reason made Garion’s knees tremble.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKPO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKPP">The Gorim looked out at the assemblage and began to speak. ‘We are gathered today,’ he began, ‘to witness the last unraveling of the Prophecy which has guided all our lives through the deadliest of peril and brought us safely to this happy moment. As foretold, the Rivan King has returned. He has met our ancient foe and he has prevailed. His reward stands radiant at his side.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKPQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKPR">Reward? Garion had not considered it in precisely that light before. He thought about it a bit as the Gorim continued, but it didn’t really help all that much. He felt a sharp little nudge in his ribs.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKPS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKPT">‘Pay attention,’ Ce’Nedra whispered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKPU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKPV">It got down to the questions and answers shortly after that. Garion’s voice cracked slightly, but that was only to be expected. Ce’Nedra’s voice, however, was clear and firm. Couldn’t she at least </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKQ0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQ1">pretend</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQ2"> to be nervous – just a little?</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQ3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQ4">The rings which they exchanged were carried on a small velvet cushion by Errand. The child took his duties quite seriously, but even on </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKQ5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQ6">his</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQ7"> small face there was that slightly amused look. Garion resented that. Was </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKQ8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQ9">everyone</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQA"> secretly laughing at him?</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQC">The ceremony concluded with the Gorim’s benediction, which Garion did not hear. The Orb of Aldur, glowing with an insufferable smugness, filled his ears with its song of jubilation during the Gorim’s blessing, adding its own peculiar congratulations.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQE">Ce’Nedra had turned to him. ‘Well?’ she whispered.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQG">‘Well what?’ he whispered back.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQI">‘Aren’t you going to kiss me?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQK">‘Here? In front of everybody?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQM">‘It’s customary.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQO">‘It’s a stupid custom.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQQ">‘Just do it, Garion,’ she said with a warm little smile of encouragement. ‘We can discuss it later.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQS">Garion tried for a certain dignity in the kiss – a kind of chaste formality in keeping with the general tone of the occasion. Ce’Nedra, however, would have none of that. She threw herself into the business with an enthusiasm which Garion found slightly alarming. Her arms locked about his neck and her lips were glued to his. He irrationally wondered just how far she intended to go with this. His knees were already beginning to buckle.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKQU">The cheer which resounded through the hall saved him. The trouble with kissing in public was that one was never sure just how long one should keep it up. If it were too short, people might suspect a lack of regard; if it were too long, they might begin to snicker. Grinning rather foolishly, Belgarion of Riva turned to face the wedding guests.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKQV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKR0">The wedding ball and the supper which was part of it immediately followed the ceremony. Chatting gaily, the wedding guests trooped through a long corridor to a brightly decorated hall which had been converted into a grand ballroom ablaze with candles. The orchestra was composed of Rivan musicians under the direction of a fussy Arendish concertmaster, who strove mightily to keep the independent Rivans from improvising on those melodies which pleased them.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKR1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKR2">This was the part Garion had dreaded the most. The first dance was to be a solo affair featuring the royal couple. He was expected to march Ce’Nedra to the center of the floor and perform in public. With a sudden horror, he realized – even as he and his radiant bride went to the center of the room – that he had forgotten everything Lelldorin had taught him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKR3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKR4">The dance which was popular at that particular season in the courts of the south was graceful and quite intricate. The partners were to face in the same direction, the man behind and slightly to one side of the woman. Their arms were supposed to be extended and their hands joined. Garion managed that part without too much trouble. It was all those quick, tiny little steps in time to the music that had him worried.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKR5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKR6">In spite of everything, though, he did quite well. The fragrance of Ce’Nedra’s hair, however, continued to work on him, and he noted that his hands trembled visibly as the two of them danced. At the end of the first melody, the wedding guests applauded enthusiastically; as the orchestra took up the second tune, they all joined in, and the floor was filled with whirling colors as the dance became general.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKR7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKR8">‘I guess we didn’t do too badly,’ Garion murmured.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKR9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKRA">‘We were just fine,’ Ce’Nedra assured him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKRB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKRC">They continued to dance.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKRD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKRE">‘Garion,’ she said after a few moments.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKRF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKRG">‘Yes?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKRH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKRI">‘Do you really love me?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKRJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKRK">‘Of course I do. What a silly thing to ask.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKRL"><span class="italic" aid="12AKRM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKRN">‘Silly?’</span></span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKRO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKRP">‘Wrong word,’ he amended quickly. ‘Sorry.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKRQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKRR">‘Garion,’ she said after a few more measures.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKRS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKRT">‘Yes?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKRU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKRV">‘I love you too, you know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKS0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKS1">‘Of course I know.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKS2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKS3">‘Of course? Aren’t you taking a bit much for granted?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKS4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKS5">‘Why are we arguing?’ he asked rather plaintively.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKS6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKS7">‘We aren’t arguing, Garion,’ she told him loftily. ‘We’re discussing.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKS8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKS9">‘Oh,’ he said. ‘That’s all right then.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKSA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKSB">As was expected, the royal couple danced with everyone. Ce’Nedra was passed from king to king like some royal prize, and Garion escorted queens and ladies alike to the center of the floor for the obligatory few measures. Tiny blond Queen Porenn of Drasnia gave him excellent advice, as did the stately Queen Islena of Cherek. Plump little Queen Layla was motherly – even a bit giddy. Queen Silar gravely congratulated him, and Mayaserana of Arendia suggested that he’d dance better if he weren’t quite so stiff. Barak’s wife, Merel, dressed in rich green brocade, gave him the best advice of all. ‘You’ll fight with each other, of course,’ she told him as they danced, ‘but never go to sleep angry. That was always </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKSC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKSD">my</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKSE"> mistake.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKSF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKSG">And finally Garion danced with his cousin Adara.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKSH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKSI">‘Are you happy?’ he asked her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKSJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKSK">‘More than you could ever imagine,’ she replied with a gentle smile.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKSL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKSM">‘Then everything worked out for the best, didn’t it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKSN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKSO">‘Yes, Garion. It’s as if it had all been fated to happen. Everything feels so right, somehow.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKSP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKSQ">‘It’s possible that it </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKSR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKSS">was</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKST"> fated,’ Garion mused. ‘I sometimes think we have very little control over our own lives – I know I don’t.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKSU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKSV">She smiled. ‘Very deep thoughts for a bridegroom on his wedding day.’ Then her face grew gravely serious. ‘Don’t let Ce’Nedra drive you to distraction,’ she advised. ‘And don’t always give in to her.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKT0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKT1">‘You’ve heard about what’s been happening?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKT2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKT3">She nodded. ‘Don’t take it too seriously, Garion. She’s been testing you, that’s all.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKT4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKT5">‘Are you trying to say that I </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKT6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKT7">still</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKT8"> have to prove something?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKT9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKTA">‘With Ce’Nedra – probably every day. I know your little princess, Garion. All she really wants is for you to prove that you love her – and don’t be afraid to say it to her. I think you’ll be surprised at how agreeable she’ll be if you just take the trouble to tell her that you love her – frequently.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKTB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKTC">‘She knows that already.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKTD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKTE">‘But you have to tell her.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKTF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKTG">‘How often do you think I ought to say it?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKTH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKTI">‘Oh, probably every hour or so.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKTJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKTK">He was almost certain that she was joking.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKTL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKTM">‘I’ve noticed that Sendars are a reserved sort of people,’ she told him. ‘That isn’t going to work with Ce’Nedra. You’re going to have to put your upbringing aside and come right out and say it. It will be worth the trouble, believe me.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKTN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKTO">‘I’ll try,’ he promised her.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKTP"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKTQ">She laughed and lightly kissed his cheek. ‘Poor Garion,’ she said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKTR"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKTS">‘Why poor Garion?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKTT"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKTU">‘You still have so much to learn.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKTV"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKU0">The dance continued.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKU1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKU2">Exhausted finally and famished by their efforts, Garion and his bride made their way to the groaning table and sat down to take their wedding supper. The supper was quite special. Two days before the wedding, Aunt Pol had calmly marched into the royal kitchen and had taken charge. As a result, everything was perfect. The smells from the heavily laden table were overwhelming. King Rhodar absolutely could not pass by without just one more nibble.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKU3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKU4">The music and the dance continued, and Garion watched, relieved that he had escaped the floor. His eyes sought out old friends in the crowd. Barak, huge but strangely gentle, danced with Merel, his wife. They looked very good together. Lelldorin danced with Ariana, and their eyes were lost in each others’ faces. Relg and Taiba did not dance, but sat together in a secluded corner. They were, Garion noted, holding hands. Relg’s expression was still slightly startled, but he did not look unhappy.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKU5"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKU6">Near the center of the floor, Hettar and Adara danced with the innate grace of those who spend their lives on horseback. Hettar’s hawklike face was different somehow, and Adara was flushed with happiness. Garion decided that it might be a good time to try Adara’s advice. He leaned toward Ce’Nedra’s pink little ear and cleared his throat. ‘I love you,’ he whispered. It was difficult the first time, so he tried it again – just to get the feel of it. ‘I love you,’ he whispered again. It was easier the second time.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKU7"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKU8">The effect on his princess was electrifying. She blushed a sudden rosy red, and her eyes went very wide and somehow defenseless. Her entire heart seemed to be in those eyes. She appeared unable to speak, but reached out instead gently to touch his face. As he returned her gaze, he was quite amazed at the change that the simple phrase had made in her. Adara, it appeared, had been right. He stored that bit of information away rather carefully, feeling more confident than he had in months.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKU9"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUA">The hall was filled with colors as the guests danced in celebration of the royal wedding. There were, however, a few faces that did not reflect the general happiness. Near the center of the floor, Mandorallen danced with the Lady Nerina, Baroness of Vo Ebor, and their faces mirrored that tragedy which was still central to their lives. Not far from them, Silk danced with Queen Porenn. The little man’s face bore once again that same bitter, self-mocking expression Garion had first seen in King Anheg’s palace in Val Alorn.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKUB"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUC">Garion sighed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKUD"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUE">‘Melancholy already, my husband?’ Ce’Nedra asked him with a little twinkle. Once again, even as they sat, she ducked her head beneath his arm and drew it about her in that peculiar way of hers. She smelled very good, and he noted that she was very soft and warm.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKUF"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUG">‘I was just remembering a few things,’ he replied to her question.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKUH"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUI">‘Good. Try to get that all out of the way now. I wouldn’t want it interfering later.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKUJ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUK">Garion’s face turned bright red, and Ce’Nedra laughed a wicked little laugh. ‘I think that perhaps later is not much further off,’ she said then. ‘You must dance with Lady Polgara, and I will dance with your grandfather. And then I think it will be time for us to retire. It’s been a very full day.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKUL"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUM">‘I </span><span class="italic" aid="12AKUN"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUO">am</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUP"> a bit tired,’ Garion agreed.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKUQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUR">‘Your day isn’t over yet, Belgarion of Riva,’ she told him pointedly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKUS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUT">Feeling a bit peculiar about it, Garion approached Aunt Pol where she and Durnik sat watching the dance. ‘Will you dance with me, Aunt Polgara?’ he asked with a formal little bow.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKUU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKUV">She looked at him a bit quizzically. ‘So you’ve finally admitted it,’ she said.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKV0"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKV1">‘Admitted what?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKV2"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKV3">‘Who I really am.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKV4"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKV5">‘I’ve known.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKV6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKV7">‘But you’ve never called me by my full name before, Garion,’ she pointed out, rising and gently smoothing back his hair. ‘I think it might be a rather significant step.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKV8"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKV9">They danced together in the glowing candlelight to the music of lutes and pipes. Polgara’s steps were more measured and slow than the dance Lelldorin had so painstakingly taught to Garion. She had reached back, Garion realized, into the dim past, and she led him through the stately measures of a dance she had learned centuries before, during her sojourn with the Wacite Arends. Together they moved through the slow, graceful, and somehow melancholy measures of a dance which had vanished forever some twenty-five centuries before, to live on only in Polgara’s memory.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKVA"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKVB">Ce’Nedra was blushing furiously when Belgarath returned her to Garion for their last dance. The old man grinned impishly, bowed to his daughter and took her hands to lead her as well. The four of them danced not far from each other, and Garion clearly heard his Aunt’s question. ‘Have we done well, father?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKVC"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKVD">Belgarath’s smile was quite genuine. ‘Why yes, Polgara,’ he replied. ‘As a matter of fact, I think we’ve done very well indeed.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKVE"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKVF">‘Then it was all worth it, wasn’t it, father?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKVG"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKVH">‘Yes, Pol, it really was.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKVI"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKVJ">They danced on.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKVK"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKVL">‘What did he say to you?’ Garion whispered to Ce’Nedra.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKVM"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKVN">She blushed. ‘Never mind. Maybe I’ll tell you – later.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKVO"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKVP">There was that word again.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKVQ"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKVR">The dance ended, and an expectant hush fell over the crowd. Ce’Nedra went to her father, kissed him lightly, and then returned. ‘Well?’ she said to Garion.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKVS"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKVT">‘Well what?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AKVU"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AKVV">She laughed. ‘Oh, you’re impossible.’ Then she took his hand and very firmly led him from the hall.</span></p><p class="calibre_8" aid="12AL00"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL01">It was quite late – perhaps two hours past midnight. Belgarath the Sorcerer was in a whimsical mood as he wandered about the deserted halls of the Rivan Citadel with a tankard in his hand. Belgarath had done a bit of celebrating, and he was feeling decidedly mellow – though not nearly as much as many of the other wedding guests, who had already mellowed themselves into insensibility.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL02"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL03">The old man stopped once to examine a guard who was snoring in a doorway, sprawled in a puddle of spilled ale. Then, humming rather tunelessly and adding a couple of skipping little dance steps as he proceeded down the hall, the white-bearded old sorcerer made his way in the general direction of the ballroom, where he was certain there was a bit of ale left.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL04"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL05">As he passed the Hall of the Rivan King, he noted that the door was ajar and that there was a light inside. Curious, he stuck his head through the doorway to see if anyone might be about. The Hall was deserted, and the light infusing it came from the Orb of Aldur, resting on the pommel of the sword of the Rivan King.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL06"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL07">‘Oh,’ Belgarath said to the stone, ‘it’s you.’ Then the old man walked a trifle unsteadily down the aisle to the foot of the dais. ‘Well, old friend,’ he said, squinting up at the Orb, ‘I see they’ve all gone off and left you alone too.’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL08"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL09">The Orb flickered its recognition of him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL0A"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL0B">Belgarath sat down heavily on the edge of the dais and took a drink of ale. ‘We’ve come a long way together, haven’t we?’ he said to the Orb in a conversational tone.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL0C"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL0D">The Orb ignored him.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL0E"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL0F">‘I wish you weren’t so serious about things all the time. You’re a very stodgy companion.’ The old man took another drink.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL0G"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL0H">They were silent for a while, and Belgarath pulled off one of his boots, sighed and wriggled his toes contentedly.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL0I"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL0J">‘You really don’t understand any of this, do you, my friend?’ he asked the Orb finally. ‘In spite of everything, you still have the soul of a stone. You understand hate and loyalty and unswerving commitment, but you can’t comprehend the more human feelings – compassion, friendship, love – love most of all, I think. It’s sort of a shame that you don’t understand, really, because those were the things that finally decided all this. They’ve been mixed up in it from the very beginning – but then you wouldn’t know about that, would you?’</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL0K"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL0L">The Orb continued to ignore him, its attention obviously elsewhere.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL0M"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL0N">‘What </span><span class="italic" aid="12AL0O"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL0P">are</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL0Q"> you concentrating on so hard?’ the old man asked curiously.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL0R"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL0S">The Orb, which had glowed with a bright blue radiance, flickered again, and its blue became suddenly infused with a pale pink which steadily grew more and more pronounced until the stone was actually blushing.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL0T"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL0U">Belgarath cast one twinkling glance in the general direction of the royal apartment. ‘Oh,’ he said, understanding. Then he began to chuckle.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL0V"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL10">The Orb blushed even brighter.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL11"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL12">Belgarath laughed, pulled his boot back on and rose unsteadily to his feet. ‘Perhaps you understand more than I thought you did,’ he said to the stone. He drained the last few drops from his tankard. ‘I’d really like to stay and discuss it,’ he said, ‘but I’ve run out of ale. I’m sure you’ll excuse me.’ Then he went back up the broad aisle.</span></p><p class="calibre_20" aid="12AL13"><span class="calibre_1" aid="12AL14">When he reached the doorway, he stopped and cast one amused glance back at the still furiously blushing Orb. Then he chuckled again and went out, quietly closing the door behind him.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_36" aid="12AL15"></div>

<p class="calibre_" aid="1394Q1"><span class="calibre_1" aid="1394Q2">Thus concludes </span><span class="italic" aid="1394Q3"><span class="calibre_1" aid="1394Q4">The Belgariad</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="1394Q5">, which began with </span><span class="italic" aid="1394Q6"><span class="calibre_1" aid="1394Q7">Pawn of Prophecy.</span></span><span class="calibre_1" aid="1394Q8"> And while History, unlike mortal pen, does not cease, the records beyond this point remain as yet unrevealed.</span></p><div class="mbp_pagebreak" id="calibre_pb_37" aid="1394Q9"></div>
